There are tons of "Prince Hotels" all over Tokyo with prices ranging from $200 - $500 per night depending on location and how modern they are.The Prince Park Tower is located on in Shiba Park - a large green space that also is home to the Zojo Temple and several other shrines. The upper floors offer some amazing views of Tokyo - including Tokyo Tower which is a block away. Overall its a solid 4 star hotel that primary appears to cater to the business crowd. The location is convenient to subways, a JR Train station, 20 minute walk to Roppongi and a 10 minute cab ride to the Fish Market or Ginza.Check-in: Relatively efficient - I had a King Panoramic View room - the "panoramic" views vary dramatically depending on the side of the hotel you face. Ask at check in or before for a room facing the Par, Tokyo Tower or Temple.Lobby: Not much of a lobby - just about 20 chairs scattered about the central core where the elevators reside and bridges over the water pool. There is a reasonable convenience store in the lobby with fresh pastries, snacks, gifts etc.Room: Overall, the room was comfortable - probably a shade under 400 sq. ft and wedge shaped - windows on two edges. The furniture looked dated as did the coffered semi-circular ceiling, however, the real King sized bed and sheets were very comfortable. It had updated lighting, electronic curtains and thermostat. The view from the 23rd floor was pretty good - I had the temples, park and some bridge in the distance. The Thermostat was set at 25 celsius, however, seemed cooler. Moving the settings up or down a few degrees didn't seem to have much of an impact. The room had a stocked mini-bar, safe, teapot with assort options, ironing board, desk, sitting area. English TV channels: CNN, BBC, and 2 others - limited options.Bathroom: Although somewhat dated (lots of black), it was spacious. Separate tub and shower (glass cube) with really excellent water pressure and super hot if desire. The standard "Star Trek" Japanese Toilet - with seat warmer and many "cleaning" options - don't press the wrong button - or be prepared for lift off. You have to keep the blinds drawn or you will be exposed while using the bathroom - or at least I couldn't find a opaque button like in their newer hotels.Restaurants: Tons of options on the upper floors or lower levels - all very good - excellent service - but HIGH prices - you can walk a few blocks and save 50%.Concierge: Under staffed - appeared to only have 1 on service at any time. Helpful with transportation options - but not so great with unique tourist requests. Seems to be more of a business focus at this branch.Check Out: Quick and efficient.Taxis: A cue waiting 24/7 at the front door. Uber "Black" is available in Tokyo, however, it is priced the same as Taxis - EXPENSIVE. No UberX or alternative cheap option. Cabs are about $7 to start the ride and go up quickly ($225+ from the Airport to Tokyo). Take the subway or JR railroad - the map looks confusing - but once you get the hang of it, no problem. It's Fast, Cheap and efficient. The Taxi ride to Ueno can range from $35 - $70 depending on time of day, however, JR Train was about $1.70 each way!!!

After 22h of journey, I've been waiting for 2h in order to get the room I booked. They finally found one but hyper noisy room. It is too late to complain.Doesn't worth the price.I have to stay 8 nights in that hotel and that will be long. I miss the Grand Hyatt, the Okura and so on...

Arrived from Haneda airport late and took monorail to Hamamatsucho then walked 15minutes towards Shiba Park. However the entrance of the hotel from the park was closed (Friday evening after 10pm) and had to enter hotel from the other end. Check in was reasonably fast however shared bath (level -1) was closed and I could not wake up early enough the next day before my connecting flight to experience it. Room was clean and view on park nice.

As my title states, this probably will be mostly used as a conference hotel. For leisure travelers there is not much in the area except some parks and temples. It's a nice quiet neighborhood with quaint bakeries around but not as busy as the major areas like shinjuku, Shibuya or ginza. There's a metro station for the Oedo line 200 meters away but the fact that there's only 1 metro line through this place should tell you something about the location Rooms in the main wing are old. Hallways are kinda creepy as they are dark and lights come on as you pass through. Room size is larger than average for Tokyo but some rooms have weird bathroom setups where the toilet is a small room on one side of the hallway and the rest of the bathroom (shower tub and sink) on the other The hotel lobby lounge has nice seats facing a wall of water and its very serene The gym is free to use but there is a charge for all other wet facilities like shower sauna and lockers

Good location views from this hotel. The only issue that we had was that it smelled of cigarettes as apparently, other occupants didn't follow the non-smoking rules. However, after complaining we were upgraded to a smoke-free suite on the 30th floor!

I stayed here for a quick overnight only. The Prince Park Tower is a good hotel, located conveniently next to Tokyo Tower, with subway stations close by assuring easy access to basically all of Tokyo.Public spaces are modern, and staff was very friendly and helpful.My room (corner) was large, with a great view. It's style was rather classic, but tasteful. The bathroom (with separate toilet) was huge as well, boasting the view from the sink and the tub.

Hotel room is big but it is so dated. Price is also very very expensive and not as convenient as some local hotels which are located near the subway stations. Japanese breakfast is good, the international breakfast is normal but has some homemade stuff which is good. Room is so hot when the sun shine in that even the aircon blast at low temperature is uselss.

Arrived at the Hotel in the evening and was met by the stunning view of the Tokyo Tower from the bar at the top of the hotel, really a must see. The Room was well set out and spacious, my room faced south west looking down onto the main ring road, this seemed to be used as a late night race track and there were some really noisy cars and bikes, which didn't help with the jet lag. That being said the bed was comfy and plenty of pillows. Bathroom was great and the power shower is one of the most powerful i have ever experienced, this side of a fire hose! Staff everywhere were courteous and really helpful. I had a a room that gave me access to the premium lounge, which has just as good views of the Tokyo Tower and the food and drink are free! They do have a swimming pool but it is about 5 Minutes walk through the conference centre but it is part of a well apointed helath spa and well worth a visit.

I have been several times during last ten years. Prices are rising but rooms are getting older with no renovation. Courtesy of staff is still at high level, but I am not sure if i will be back. Location is quiet but no ideal for a business trip

Our stay in the Prince Park Tower Tokyo was top notch with a superb view to Tokyo Tower, the largest and most comfortable king-sized bed in the known universe, great room service (we got dessert, totally worth it), a brilliant sashimi restaurant in the basement, exquisite cocktail bar on the top floor (what a brilliant night-time view), a bowling alley (fabulous!) and truly awesome, all-round service. The hotel is to be particularly commended for getting us bookings at two very exclusive restaurants: Sushi Tokami in the Ginza (truly amazing with a one-Michelin star chef) and Orexis at Minato (a sublime French restaurant, also with a one-Michelin star chef). Centrally located, beautifully appointed, exquisite surrounding gardens, luxurious.Would LOVE to stay here again.

I stay in 30th Premium club lounge floor for 3 nights. I was so happy with room, F&B and service. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️No need to explain how clean the room was. I came back late from work feel hungry, They offered complementary light meal ( Hot udon soup, spaghetti, fried chicken etc) and drink (inc alcoholBeverage like a bottle of beer) 1set/per night. Also complementary continental breakfast deliver to my room every morning. The table set, Noritake bone china and silver table ware. 2 regular drinking water and 2 small bottles drinking water.

Located in a beautiful park where you can make a morning jog or evening stroll. Breakfast is possible to choose from three versions: Japanese, American-Japanese, Chinese - American. Pleasantly surprised by the presence at breakfast beneficial for health food supplements like spirulina, goji berries and more.

Great room with a view over Tokyo which is nice, especially at night. Very friendly staff and service was good. Good location as it is near two metros and walkable distance from Roppongi. Highly recommend dinner at the restaurant on the top floor - fantastic view and excellent 5 course meal for a very reasonable price for hotel guests.

Park Tower never disappoints. Have stayed on the Club side and in the regular rooms. Very large rooms for Tokyo even on the standard side. Being situated within the Shiba Park makes it quiet with green garden views on all sides.Staff are very polite, in-line with Japanese standards of service. The area is a bit isolated, not within walking distance of the main attractions but I find that to be a plus.Have had family members stay here and stayed many times myself.If you appreciate quiet beauty and good service, then there are not many hotels in Tokyo that offer the same standard as the Prince Park Tower.Definite recommend

Tokyo is very expensive, so we thought we would save some money and only go for a 4 star hotel. This hotel is centrally located, has an amazing staff, has incredible landmarks within walking distance and provides an awesome buffet with the room. We were traveling around the world with 4 kids and we were all wowed by everything this hotel has to offer. The only thing that I was disappointed by was the fact that the taxis charge $200 to get here from the airport, but I cant think of what the prince park could ever do about this.

Was here for one night which is simply too short to give a decent services review. But the location is definitely great with Tower nearby, park and eateries.The hotel also has a small bowling parlour with 3~4 lanes. Didnt managed to try but everything seems well-maintained (hey, this is Japan)The hotel also has multiple halls and conference rooms which are great for business meetings and conferences.

A good hotel - conveniently located close to the office (8-10 minutes by cab). Was give a room with a clear open view of the park nearby, as well as the Tokyo Tower.Friendly staff - though the luggage staff seemed a bit lost (rang my doorbell to ask the room number of my colleague to drop her bags off).Room was very pristine and quite spacious. The toilet with a lid that would open and close automatically via sensor was convenient.Being my first trip to Japan and my fault for not checking in advance - had not brought my travel power adapter; called the front desk to borrow one. Was put on hold for quite some time only to be told there was none that they could lend me. Found it a bit inconvenient and difficult to understand how a five-star hotel was not equipped with such basic traveler 'tools'.Overall, an okay place to stay for a night.

This is a very lovely hotel with a great atmosphere. I totally enjoyed my visit. Amenities are great you have everything that you need in the room. Also if you have your cleaned every second day (not everyday) you get a ticket for 1000 JPY which is around 10 dollars, you can use this free ticket in the hotel shop. The hotel shop is lovely, there is everthing including souveniers and food/drinks and shampoo/cream etc and the prices are not extreme, quite standard prices. Hotel is at a very central location. You can see Tokyo Tower from the hotel, so cool at night with all the lights. Breakfast is so nice with a great variety of hot and cold food. I especially enjoyed the omlettes. All the staff are so kimd and helpful. Perfect value for the price paid. I will totally return to this hotel!

Chose this hotel based on reviews and Visa discount. The view from the room was great as it overlooked Tokyo Tower. The bed and pillows were very comfortable and the bathroom amenities were very comfortable although I think they could have chosen a better brand for their toiletries. The location is close to 2 train stations which are about a 5 minute walk away. They also provide shuttle service to a JR line station. Concierge service was variable. Some of them were excellent where they will help you book restaurants. Some of them were a bit difficult to communicate with. However, the general impression I got from the hotel is that it's targeted towards business travellers. I was also not impressed with the Sky Lounge as it had a cover charge to sit with a full Tokyo Tower view. It was also a smoking area and the drinks were expensive and the cocktail that I had ordered was not tasty at all to the point where I did not finish it. In summary, I would probably stay here again but only for business and will not step foot into the lounge.

I have stayed at this hotel on each occasion when visiting Tokyo over the past 8 years. It has always exceeded my expectations on how helpful the staff are in meeting my needs. They help with directions, assist with specific areas to shop and where nest to get the transport I need. The rooms are always excellent and very comfortable. Pleasure to stay at this hotel.

Very clean, huge bed, spacious room and bathroom. Near to lots of Metro Stations. Convenience store on the ground floor is attached to a bakery, handy for a quick bite at reasonable prices. Located inside a park with a Buddhist temple and the Tokyo tower. Our room that faced the park has a few of the bridge to Odaiba. During some nights we were awoken by the sounds of sports cars speeding on the highway, even if we were on 20+ flr. Maybe get a higher floor if facing the garden or better yet get a room with a view of Tokyo tower, but these go fast if there is a conference in the hotel. Hotel toiletries are very good, made in Japan and mild enough for sensitive skin.

I have to admit I was a little concerned about the location of this hotel, I wanted to experience that Tokyo life the city is famous for, and in the end everyone in our party simply loved every aspect of it.It's true you're away from some of the popular spots but that isn't a problem, public transportation in Tokyo is very efficient and affordable and this property is within walking distance of two metro stations. Best part is that after a whole day exploring Tokyo we felt very well getting back to this hotel to rest.The rooms were big compared to other properties in Japan and for the most, hotels in Tokyo are planned to accommodate two people in a room. My daughter stayed in the room with us and it was great to check-in and get to the room to find they had set up a roll away bed in the room. We had a nice view of the Tokyo Tower and really enjoyed this hotel.We were also pleasantly surprised by the efficiency, professionalism and courtesy of every single employee we came across during our stay. Concierge was really helpful and provided lots of useful information, maps and even assisted in planning some excursions. Overall, it was a very nice place to stay and wouldn't hesitate to stay here again when we return to Tokyo.

First Impression - Very convenient to get to from the metro. One block walk from Akabanebashi station on the Akasuka line. Inside the Shiba Park in a tranquil setting. Hotel has a grand entrance and immediately makes you feel like your in a luxurious hotel.Final Impression - We spent a week here as our final stop in Japan. It was our favorite hotel. With two kids, definitely go for the Panoramic Junior Suite which has a ton of space with two beds and a sofa bed. The panoramic views are just amazing and the suites are luxurious with a large bathroom. It became a great way to see Tokyo given its rather central location next to the Tokyo Tower, west of the Ginza/Tokyo station areas, and east of the Shinjuku/Shibuya neighorhoods. Its two metro stops away from Rappongi, and a few more away from Shinjuku and Shibuya. Would definitely recommend not staying any further east in Tokyo as being close to Shinjuku and Shibuya provides the most options for shopping and restaurants. A great service the hotel offers is also a free shuttle bus every hour to the Hamamatsucho metro station, which is connected to the Daimon station on the JR line, providing for access to the JR Yamanote line and day trips from there to places like Yokohama and Kamakura. Hotel has a store/shop inside and there is a Lawson's about 10 minutes away on foot. Lastly, the service at this hotel was amazing - staff were always polite and made you feel welcome. Overall, we felt extremely pampered by this amazingly located and furnished hotel and would definitely stay here again.

The hotel is very beautiful, luxurious, and elegant. Also, the staff is amazing. I lost my wallet in the lobby and the staff was nice enough to send it back to me in California. The location is also great!

Went here on new year's eve, even though we didnt get the tokyo tower view, we got to hear the wonderful fireworks from our room. You can also go to the top floor lounge to enjoy the fireworks or view on any other days. Room was big and clean. Awesome stay.

This hotel is very good, clean and all the staff is very kind and helping. Our room was a corner room, so we had a wide view. The location is also very good. It is next to the Tokyo Tower in a park where there is a quite old and known local shrine Zōjō-ji as well. Only the food in the hotel was a bit expensive, but that can be expected if the hotel itself is already very on the more expensive side. The local public transport is also very good near the hotel. They also have a bus driving between Hamamatsucho and the hotel during the day.

Have stayed in Tokyo twice and the Prince Park Tower is my favorite. The view to the Tokyo Tower from my room and the restaurant was amazing and the convienience to have the park so close is perfect for morning runs. Service was good, value/quality is pretty good and rooms are big and comfortable.

The location is convenient if you are visiting Tokyo tower. Oh and they have a bar on 33rd from where you can see Tokyo tower literally in front of you. They have many couches for 2 people and selection of drinks also great. Restaurants on b1 floor very good. Recommend Japanese brekkie at a restaurant called Shibazakura!

My husband surprised me with a night out at the Prince Park Tower. The hotel staff were very professional and check in was very quick which I appreciated. Our room was on the 25th floor and had amazing views of Tokyo and the Rainbow Bridge. Unfortunately we couldn't see Tokyo Tower but when we went outside it was very close and looked nice all lit up. Our room was very comfortable but a little outdated especially for the price of the room, I expected it to be more up to date.The breakfast buffet on the 33rd floor was incredible! There was something for everyone and the views were amazing.

I have stayed here 3 times now and the service never fails to impress me. Rooms are of a very good standard with superb views on higher floors. Nothing is too much trouble. Very easy to find due to proximity of the Tokyo tower so if you go out for a walk you cant get lost !

Would absolutely recommend this hotel for a luxurious treat. We stayed to celebrate an occasion and the hotel staff took pains to make us feel special, including with a card and gift inside the room. The concierge service was very helpful in helping us make a dinner reservation at the nearby Michelin starred Tofuya Ukai (a short and pleasant stroll from the hotel). Unbeknownst to us, they had also notified the restaurant of our occasion and we were presented with a small gift at dinner. After dinner, we headed up to the hotel bar for drinks. One of my only complaints is the "table charge" at the bar. Completely understand the need for bars to have a cover charge, but suggest that it would be appropriate for this to be waived for staying guests, as it is at the Park Hyatt. After drinks, we returned to our room and ordered in room massages. Despite the late hour, two massage therapists were at our room within minutes. The next morning, room service breakfast was promptly delivered at the requested time, along with copies of English language newspapers. We had a lovely morning relaxing over breakfast in bed in our robes, before a very generous checkout time of 12pm. We stored our luggage while we did some sightseeing, and returned in the evening when we took the (half hourly) free hotel bus to the monorail station, minutes away. Throughout our stay, we enjoyed friendly service, small conveniences and a feeling of luxury. To address some of the criticisms I've seen on trip advisor - I agree that it would be good to allow guests to check in early if the room is ready. But I don't think this is a deal breaker and would not assume I could check in before an advertised check in time. The hotel was very happy to store our luggage before check in - although this process could have been more welcoming. It did feel like we weren't treated as guests until 3pm. There would be little cost to the hotel in applying a friendlier or more apologetic tone to guests who arrive early - and it would clearly make people feel better about it. In terms of location, yes the hotel is a bit further away from the hotspots of Shinjuku or Shibuya. However, the subway stations are conveniently located. We used our stay to step back from the Tokyo bustle and unwind, and to see a few things that were more convenient from the Minato district (for example, the hedgehog cafe in Roppongi). There are a lot of extra charges for facilities in the hotel - the pool, massages, bowling etc. But the hotel is also very competitively priced for the 5-star market. We got a very good deal from booking.com. I see the extra charges as meaning that we didn't pay for things we didn't use. If you do want to use the pool, or beauty and spa services, the extra charge for this is still going to place you way below the room rate for many other 5-star hotels in Tokyo. All in all, a good deal and a very satisfactory stay.

Our experience in the hotel is not good. We are very unhappy with the attention received. We are flying back to Spain at midnight and we asked if it would be possible to take a shower in the fitness area before leaving to the airport. First response was no and after complaint, the answer was yes but paying 2060 yens by person. That is incredible in a hotel of this category and after pay around 35000 yens for only one night. Hopefully the direction of the hotel will change their mind in the future and will be more guest oriented:(

The hotel is in a great location for sightseeing and catching the train. The soaking bathtub was great after lots of walking and the bed was super comfortable. The room was a modern, and as is custom in western-style, quite large. We asked for a high floor and the view was fantastic--a little scary standing on the balcony, but worth it!

This is one of the best hotels I've ever stayed. I stayed there before and really liked it, so I booked 10 days on recent trip. I would say I have nothing but the highest compliments. I read a few comments about the staffs not speaking English, but I think that's mostly untrue. I interacted with many hotel staffs and with the exception of the room lady, everyone else spoke English very well. The price on the weekend was unusual high (600 plus USD), but 350 USD is decent given this area is at the heart of Tokyo having access to the subway and highway as well; yet, the hotel is inside a park, very quiet beautiful park. The hotel has 1 buffet style breakfast restaurant on the 33rd floor which I think one should try out at least once, or more if you have a free voucher. I saw many people had voucher so it is probably given with the hotel package; otherwise, it is 37 USD. Another restaurant on the same floor with better view of the Tokyo tower will charge 44USD/breakfast. One should also try the Japanese traditional breakfast down in the basement too. On the first 2 nights I was given a room facing the temple. I didnt like it so I requested the room facing the Tokyo Tower at night. It was so beautiful at night. I didnt have to close the curtain at night because the lights went out gradually. Also, dont forget to try out the tearoom. They offer English style tearoom with Asian Pacific deco/setting that I think quite interesting and different from the usual loud English tearoom. The staffs are very accommodating so dont be afraid to ask for extra good stuff such as pillows, soaps, tea, etc

Stayed at the hotel for two nights. Whilst the room was clean, tidy and well presented, and the staff professional, there were a number of issues with our stay. The first, which set the overall tone to our stay, concerned checking in. Due to our morning arrival in Tokyo, we arrived at the hotel before the advertised check-in time. In my experience as a frequent traveller, when this happens hotels usually try to assist by checking you in early if they have a room available. And if there isn't a room available, it's not an issue and I am always happy to wait until my room becomes available. On this occasion, the reception staff made it quite clear that our room was available and ready for check-in but because we had arrived early, if we wanted to check-in we would have to pay an extra charge. Otherwise we could wait until the advertised check-in time. With many hotel experiences over many years in a range of different countries, this was the first time I had encountered this approach to an early arrival. It was particularly galling given we were scheduled to depart two days later very early in the morning and therefore not staying in the hotel until the advertised check-out time. So, in effect, we were not exceeding the period of our stay in the hotel anyway. We chose not to pay the extra fee to check in early and waited until the advertised time. But the hotel's attitude towards early arrivals undermined its claim to be a five star establishment. Aside from this, we found the hotel services very overpriced - mush more than you would usually expect in a hotel, especially in a major city like Tokyo. A basic iced coffee in the lobby cafe costs over A$20 (ie. a not very tall glass of ice with coffee syrup and cream on the side). Use of the hotel pool required payment of an additional charge of over A$50 per person. For such an overpriced hotel, you would expect everything in the room to work and for the advertised services such as turndown to take place. The TV remote control did not work and had to be replaced during our stay and the turndown service never took place. Small things but they add to a picture of a hotel that purports to be something it isn't. Overall it was not a satisfying visit and I would not be choosing to stay there again. There are many better hotels in that class to choose in Tokyo.

Stayed here during a recent trip as they had a special promotion. The hotel itself is looking dated compared to some of the newer hotels coming up all the time in dynamic Tokyo. Its main disadvantage is the location as it is in the middle of a park and quite far away from all the main areas of Tokyo for sightseeing, shopping and dining. Service is friendly and helpful the staff speak good English.

Staff are super friendly at the Prince Park hotel. We arrived early after an over night flight and were able to check in at midday. We could have paid extra to have the room in the morning but chose to to wait it out instead (given we had a young child with us on it would have been even nice to have the room earlier!)Once in the room - just lovely. Great views to the Sky tower and across the shrine below. You could see all the way to the sky tree.Room was large and the bed was huge. Great full size bathroom as well. We had upgraded so did expect to have access to the pool/gym. But no - had to pay extra. We had some issues with the tv remote but was fixed quickly, likewise when requesting extra towels, they arrived immediately.Most staff spoke some English, so we were able to get directions to the subway - access to at least 2 lines are very close by and a 10 min walk to the JR line.Area was safe and was connected to most of the city tourist hotspots. Avoid the Lobby lounge though - very over-priced!

Yes location might be a bit off but the rooms are large (like really large), impeccable service as expected in such a place in Japan, excellent breakfast buffet with a stunning view over the city from the 33rd floor and a few nice restaurants nearby if you chose not to eat in the hotel.

There are a lot of amenities at this hotel. Fitness center, bowling alley, pool, etc. they list it all on their website. What they don't tell you is that they charge you extra for EVERYTHING! We stayed here for the listed amenities but to use the pool- 2000 yen. The fitness center- 2000 yen. When you're paying to stay at this fancy hotel I don't think that you should be charged for these things.The views are nice but you're not allowed to take pictures from the roof. You pay a table charge for sitting and drinking your 1300 yen beer. The bowling alley closes at 8pm on Saturdays- 10pm on week nights. I also don't think this area is the most happening for things to do. There's a lot of tourists and expensive places and less local culture. I will say that the hotel staff are lovely.
user_name:
eastvillagek
Jebel Ali, United Arab Emirates

review_body: I really loved the hotel! The way there was s little confusing, but the room was amazing! The best amenities - a tube with bubble option, a big shower, separate Toto toilet. The view was stunning! Too bad it was just for one night as we had to travel to Kyoto...we got a great deal for a twin room. The location is near the Tokyo Tower and a convini is near also. My sister and I loved the evening stroll under the illuminated Tower.I really recommend this hotel, I loved it!

Fantastic hotel, delicious breakfast and amazing view on the Tokyo tower in the dining hall! Perfect place for city sight seeing or for business. Compared to other hotels in Tokyo the rooms are spacious and with all the comforts.

The Prince Park did not disappoint in any measureable category. When booked strategically, this hotel delivers serious 'bang for your buck' when factoring value associated with room quality, location, service, and amenities. As with almost all encounters with city-wide Tokyo hospitality, the staff was genuinely warm and inviting, eager to please and assist at every opportunity. The room was comfortable, clean, and well-appointed. Beds very comfortable, temperature mild with efficient working AC, and awesome bathroom with separate tub and enclosed shower. Impressive lounge amongst the top floors with jaw-dropping views of greater Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower. Several subway/metro stations located within reasonable walking distance rounds up all the reason to seriously consider Prince Park as your Tokyo vacation headquarters.

The Prince Park Tower was not my first choice when we were unexpectedly delayed in Tokyo. Travelling with very small children at the height of the summer season, I was concerned about my jet lagged kiddos disturbing other guests. We booked an upper level suite and found that not only was it a bit more spacious than expected (albeit smaller than Western travellers will be accustomed to), but the anticipated noise wasn't an issue. Sound, from inside or outside our room didn't present a problem at any time, day or night. The hotel staff conversed easily in both Japanese and English, the rooms were well appointed and immaculate, and anything we needed was instantly taken care of. We found the hotel staff happy to accommodate our needs. Tower and park views were lovely, spa services and cuisine quite satisfactory, plentiful shopping and activities like bowling readily available, and a park setting with numerous local places of interest right at the door.

Stayed at the hotel for a week while on business.Front desk are very polite yet they barely speak English which makes any request which is out of the ordinary a challenge.Rooms are big yet outdated and worn. The room did have all facilities needed including ironing board, fridge, coffee corner, AC, large desk with LAN+WIFI. Room also had washroom and toilet in separate spaces which is convenient.Washroom had both a very large walk in shower and bath tub with bubble system.Laundry and ironing service have quick turnovers yet are quite expensive.A number of different breakfasts are served in different formats every day only from 7am.Lobby has coupons to get breakfast for 3000 YEN - don't forget to ask for them!Lots (!!!!) of excellent restaurants are available in different styles - they are very good yet prepare to pay 100$ and up for an average dinner. Reservations were needed.You can opt out of room cleaning and receive a 1000 YEN voucher to use in the hotel/restaurants/store.Shuttle bus from Haneda/Narita are available and stop right outside the hotel (from Narita it's a 90 min drive via shuttle bus).Some subway stations pretty close by, 15 minutes of walk to get uptown to some more lively areas.The hotel for some reason decided to get a hold on my credit card for the price of my stay + 10% just a day before I was set to checkout and later did not manage to cancel the hold causing me a lot of trouble and calls to CC company and wasting over an hour at the front desk. They have a real problem with English there while others in restaurants had no problem.Nice stay all in all.

Situated in Shiba Park with Tokyo Tower nearby. Building externally is not attractive but internally really nice. For less than £200 a night got a great room with heated loo seat with integrated bidet. Bath is super cool with bubbles. Bed was super king and pillows eminently sensible. Restaurant and coffee shops really nice but tad pricey. Nice experience

First time staying at this hotel in Tokyo with my family for vacation. The hotel is located in a park which is quiet and pleasant, the view is excellent, you can see the Tokyo Tower for certain rooms. No complaints about the location and facilities. However, when our group checked in, the hotel staff asked us to stand aside and wait by our luggage at the luggage area for finishing check in, not even a chair is provided in the area. We have a group of 13 persons with kids and old people, I was very upset by this very poor hospitality and services by the hotel staff. There were emptied chairs at the hotel lobby that were not occupied by anyone but the staff did not let our family to sit there. I complained to the duty manager who was very polite and apologized. At the price this hotel is charging, the service factor is below standard.

Rooms are spacious and comfortable, all services just perfect. Cleanliness and client oriented service are really the trademark of this hotel. Amenities in the room more than enough. Location is great in a park, walking distance to an underground station. The only drawback I noticed is check-in time set at 15.00 which I find unacceptable. If you want to do it earlier you would pay extra, around 25% of the room rate. Also hotel facilities like pool or gym are to be paid separately, are not included in the room price.

Spacious room compared to other hotels in Tokyo. Sky lounge has a great view of Tokyo tower! For breakfast, you can have set breakfast or buffet on 33/F, or even Japanese traditional breakfast on Basement. Location wise, this hotel is not the best choice, as it requires 15-min walk to the nearest station, Daimon station, or shibakoen station, the hotel offers free shuttle (every 30 mins) to Hamamachutsucho station though, which helps a bit as taxi in Japan is expensive.

The first thing that strikes you is that although it has 33 floors there are many building in sight from your room that are higher.It is is in a good position in Tokyo although if you are driving the road system may confuse you when looking fir how to get to the hotel.The best restarants( and there are a lot)are placed at the top and the broader range are on the lower ground floor. All seem to be fine. For the view go to the 33rd and take the restaurant with the view. They will charge you if you want a front row table but behind the bar is free and pretty much as good. The Chinese restaurant needs to be booked. If you can afford the best Japanese meat is available - the burger version is cheaper. It tastes like very special fillet steak.

The hotel is not fashion except the nice bar on the roof top which is very difficult to get an access because its always full even if you are guest. Such a nice view there. But we have to say the staff is very welcoming and very pro concierges. Rooms and bathrooms are spacious but old fashioned. Some rooms have a small but nice terrasse. Ubication is very convenient...close to the tokyo tower and have a lot of transport conexions. Quiet and convenient.

With a central location, spacious rooms with great views, and very friendly and professional staff, this is a great place to stay. It is good for business travellers, but also has great facilities for families and couples too. The bar on the top floor is an ace place to relax, and there are an array of restaurants and even a bowling alley. Slight downsides are the daily charge to use the gym (ridiculous, skip this, and go for a walk in one of the many nearby parks!!) and the 'western' breakfasts (but on the bright side there is a wonderful Pain Quotodien just 5 mins walk away).

The Hotel is good but the decor of my room was dated (but not tatty). I had a junior suite and room wise I can't complain, aside from the dated decor. The bathroom was great, (shower pressure was fabulous), the Japanese bath superb, the bed comfortable, TV channels were good and the room had all the little bits, like slippers, and bathroom bits. There is also an onsite shop which was a great convenience. Not much to do in the area but that is hardly their fault. I booked through my company site and ordered early check-in which I didn't get, and I had a pre 6 pm on the day cancellation which I was told wasn't an option, (I explored checking in elsewhere when I couldn't check-in) Which was very disappointing. Airport transfers aren't very regular, but Haneda was only a £45 cab ride (at 6am).

Even if you don't stay here or even if you don't drink, you have to visit the bar on the 33rd floor and take in the view at night. The rooms are high end with marble counter bathrooms and glass showers and spa tubs. The beds are comfortable and closets big. The breakfast buffet was great with fresh made eggs and omelettes.

Gorgeous grounds, modern interior and all of the amenities. Very quick walk to a couple of different subway lines that will get you off and running in Tokyo (side note - you must learn to use the subway if you plan on doing any reasonably cost-effective exploring). Cheap it isn't (like Tokyo) but if you can score a 'club' room, you'll have access to a free breakfast on the 32nd floor alongside a spectacular view of Tokyo Tower and beyond as well as nightly free drinks and snacks. The restaurants are wildly overpriced, but high-quality. The on-site sundry shop is well-stocked and has pastries to boot. For business, the conference facilities are as nice as you'll find. Service is what you'd expect at a property of this caliber in Japan, with eager-to-serve staffers everywhere. Only real ding is that the specific location isn't super-interesting to explore on foot - there is a great exercise/jogging path, but the neighborhood itself is fairly generic by Tokyo standards.

This was a Hotwire 4 star, "Hot Rate" hotel, in the Minato area of Tokyo. It was about a 20 minute/$70 taxi ride from Haneda airport, and sits in a large park, right next to the Tokyo Tower and Akabanebashi subway station. The hotel states that it has complimentary SHUTTLE SERVICE, but note that it is not from the airport to the hotel. The Shuttle Service transports people back and forth between the hotel and the Hamamatsucho Subway Station. Hamamatsucho Station is where the monorail from Haneda airport ends. The service is excellent, the location is great (most main attractions are a short subway ride away), and the hotel has one of the best rooftop bar views in the city, but the rooms are dated and worn. If you book this hotel at a great rate, and don't mind the dated rooms, it's a great place to stay. If you'd rather be smack in the middle of lots of Tokyo action, this hotel is not for you.

My family stayed here for 4 nights recently. We arrived in Tokyo off a 14 hr flight from New York a musty smelling room and a wet spot on the carpet, which seemed to be coming from under the refrigerator. We were traveling with a very tired two year old who desperately needed sleep so we decided to report the issue after we'd slept a few hours. We did so in the morning upon leaving for our day with the promise that they would address the issue. We came back to find nothing had been done; they said they checked the fridge and that we must have somehow caused the wet spot from careless showering. They didn't even pick up the wet towel that we had laid down to soak up the leak. To make a long story short, we had to ask for two days and several visits to the front desk to finally switch rooms. The room they switched us to did not have a view of the tower like our original room and it was clearly a smoking room! All of our clothes and our son's crib smelled of smoke after staying one night. We received no recompense of any kind for the hassle and inconvenience of switching rooms, not to mention staying in a room with a wet floor for 3 nights. Needless to say, we were very disappointed and will not be staying here ever again. On the plus side, there is a Le Pain Quotidien located near by that served a delicious breakfast!

Came to Japan for the weekend. This great hotel is perfectly located 5 min walk from Akabenebashi train station (E train). The hotel was situated in a park like area and not very crowded. The rooms were big for Japanese standards. There's many restaurants in the basement. Staff speaks English and are friendly and welcoming. FYI:- airport limousine picks up from hotel and costs 3100 yen one way to airport- use of spa/gym is an additional fee but workout shoes and clothes can be rented- no tattoos in the spa- breakfast is additional cost- if you defer room cleaning, you get 1000yen per day that can be used as a voucher at spa or restaurants - no food/ breakfast available before 7am (prepare if you're catching early airport shuttle)

Well located inside the Shiba Park, the hotel is embraced by a surprisingly vast green area in the busy developed area of Minato district near the heart of Tokyo. Also because it’s adjacent to Zojoji Temple which creates a unique romantic panoramic view at the long window of some suite rooms in the hotel. The outstanding symbolic triangular high-riser of the hotel, though a little outdated in style, is almost as distinguishable as the Tokyo Tower which stands just some 200 metres from it. Yet, tourists to the Tower never get into the quiet zone of the hotel, providing a nice residential comfort for the guests especially during a morning or evening stroll at the tranquil park with these historical sites as backdrop.After a long queue for check-in, my twin room was upgraded to a Junior Suite because of the high occupancy I think. When I entered my unexpected large suite space I was attracted immediately by the uninterrupted Temple view just down my room, a rhythmic composition of traditional temple roofs and the greenery. The room deco is tentatively nostalgic in the mood with pale green wall paper and pine wood colour furniture. At the same time there are good coffee machine, large TV and sophisticated ventilation with the same effect of an open window.The security is rather strict, those who enter the guest room area must have a key card for access. Perhaps because of this and the limited number of rooms on each floor, the corridor out the room is always very quiet. Wifi is one of the fastest among several hotels I stayed at the same period. Choices of breakfast are abundant, namely Japanese, buffet and American. Although I accidently booked this hotel because of high occupancy in Japan at the time, I was surprised to find the high standard provided, gaining more confidence of the established brand of Prince in Japan. And I would say it would become one of my first choices for my next Japanese visit for certain.

Amazing hotel with lots of fresh flower arrangements. Room was good. Great restaurant within the facility. All prices were at the high end. Little walk from the station though. Love the place. Highly recommend it!

This was my second stay at the Prince Park Tower and I enjoyed it every bit as much as my first.The staff are all amazingly helpful, courteous and efficient. Check-in was a breeze despite the fact that I arrived early. My previous stay I had a corner room with a view of the Rainbow Bridge this time I got the Panorama view with Tokyo Tower and Zojo-ji. I have always loved Tokyo Tower so this was a treat. Walking into my room at night and seeing that view wowed me each evening of my 3 night stay.There are several stations nearby including Shibakoen (Mita Line) and Akabanebashi (Oedo Line) both within 5 minutes walking time. Daimon station is a short distance as well and has Asakusa Line and Mita Line. The hotel offers limousine bus service too and from both Haneda and Narita Airports that are fairly frequent. The park is lovely, the hotel rooms are large and comfortable and the views are spectacular. When and if I get to visit Tokyo again I will stay here again for certain.

The hotel is very well located with a clear and nice view of Tokyo Tower. I was here to attend the conference and found that the staff is specially very helpful and they always went out of there way to assist there guests.The spa, room service and the concierge are the best.Try to stay on the higher floors and enjoy the view.Will certainly come again.

We decided to stay in the Prince Tower Tokyo since we stayed at the Prince hotel in Kyoto and the service was very good. We even send our luggages ahead of time so we wouldn't have to transport them on the train. When we arrived in Tokyo, we just had to go to Bic Camera building not far from the Tokyo Station to get a 3 day tourist pass on the Tokyo metro (available for tourists only with passport) and we took the metro to our hotel. Our luggage were already waiting for us in our room. The room we had was very big and very comfortable. The toilet was just out of this world. The Japanese engineering for cleaning their bottom is just something you can never find outside Japan. I wonder what they think of people's cleanliness when they travel outside their country. The service at the hotel was quite good. It was crowded so we had to line up for some time to check-in. We requested a room facing the Tokyo Tower but unfortunately it was unavailable. But the view over the city was still impressive.We also went up to the 33rd floor to the sky bar where you have a wonderful view over the Tokyo Tower and the whole city.There is a shop on ground level that sells pastries and all kind of stuff and food, like a mini market. So since we opted out of the breakfast (too expensive) we would buy some pastries and had it with the tea (green tea only) which they provide in the room for breakfast. We would also sometimes go to one of the 24/7 mini market shop nearby to buy food to eat back in the comfort of our room making it affordable and fun. I noticed many travellers (Japanese) did the same thing.It really is a lovely hotel. We invited some of our local friends to have a drink and enjoy the view at the sky bar to celebrate my husband's birthday.Not far from our hotel is Diamon station where one can walk to and find all sorts of bars, and restaurants.

Situated in a Nice park NeXT to the Tokyo Tower, 10 min walk to JR Railroad and Close to Three different Subway-stations. Clean rooms and as always in Japan VERY friendly staff. Huge room With narrow balcony - above a green park With lots of trees and Close to a shinto temple. The hotel is ideal for wedding ( not my purpose!) With its own both outdoor and indoor chapels. All amenities and services. Stay for more than 7 days and get a low price.

We recently had 2xdeluxe twin rooms for 5x nights there at the Prince Park Tower for spring break. One of our room has a balcony view opens to the Tokyo Tower. Although it's a bit off from the central shopping district, but there's a bus running from the hotel to the World Trade Center building station that basically can connect to most JR & subway lines. Or option a short 10 min across the back hill through the beautiful scenic park to the Daimon Station. This hotel is situated at a more residential Minato-Ku district.Overall the hotel & rooms are a bit outdated. But double thumbs up on the bath facilities - to keep the toilet w/heated seat/bidet at a separate room from the shower room. The toilet is basically a self cleaned vented room - no weird smell at all - so nice! The bathrooms have very hot & strong shower, with separate tub (which I used everyday after the long walking)Inside the hotel there're quite a few good (but very small) restaurants with different varieties of cuisines, ranging from Chinese, Japanese yakitori, tempura, and steak house. Upstairs at the 33rd floor we enjoyed the decent breakfast buffet with panoramic view of the landmark Tokyo Tower. But if you fancy some local eatery or café before 7am or after 10pm (like we did for the first few nights of jetlag), then basically you're out of luck....the only choice was to stock up whatever is there at the in-hotel convenience store by the entrance/lobby. Just a reminder there're actually 2 different Price Park Hotel each on opposite side of the park, so onetime a taxi driver took us to the wrong hotel because I forgot to emphasize the "Park TOWER hotel" ! It would be a long walk around the park to get back to either side, or wait 20 min for the hotel shuttle that runs between the 2 Prince hotels. We had a pleasant stay, and probably will stay here again next time, or any other hotels/resorts under the Prince hotel group.

Stayed here for 4 nights, check-in and out was very smooth, friendly staff and weird enough female bellboys, who also were super friendly! the hotel rooms are not huge, but are equipped with everything you might need, clean and tidy. Breakfast is quite hectic, you may choose from asian or continental breakfast. I tried both, but I must say, even tho the asian has more to offer, larger range of beverages and meals in the buffet, the crowd, the noise and the waiters running up-down did not meet my liking at all. The continental one is basically a set menu, with 3-4 options of set meals and drinks, but it is large enough to fill you for the morning. Service here is much more guest oriented, calm and easy. For the spa even in-house guests have to pay, so be aware of that. Rooftop bar is fun, with great views but staff has a hard time to understand your order, unless you speak Japanese. The whole bar allows smoking!! Location is good, very close to mayor sights in downtown Tokyo. Thank you for a great stay!

If you want to treat yourself to a bit of luxury then this hotel ticks that box. I stayed here for 5 nights while exploring/passing through Tokyo and found that it was in a great location. The rooms boast two extremely comfy kings beds which are just what you need after a big day out and about. There is even a free shuttle bus to and from the train station.

I spent a weekend here exploring the area. I was able to check-in early. The hotel is a large property and located next to a beautiful park. This hotel was perfect for exploring Omotesando which is where I ended up spending a lot of my time. I didn't use the spa/gym ($40 fee) nor did I eat at any of the restaurants.My room was on the 22nd floor and faced busy roads (highway?). Late at night I could hear a group of motorcycles. Some rooms face the tower. Some of the furniture and amenities were damaged or very worn. I had moved from a more modern and newer property so that could be why I noticed the aging aspects a bit more.

It was my first time in Tokyo and overall is a good choice for the price you pay. The rooms are dated, but big and clean. We got a room the first night in the 18th floor facing the speedway and I colud not sleep. The next day we ask for a change, and we got a better room without the view of the tower, but with less noise. The downside is the breakfast that is not included (as in any hotel in Japan, except ryokans, which by the way, they don't serve the best food) and you have to walk 800mts for a Le Pain Quotidien. One day we did have the excellent breakfast served in the hotel but be prepared to pay a very expensive breakfast. The nearest train station is 3 minutes away walking, they have a store inside the hotel with excellent bread.

Just as a good hotel should be. Super service and accommodation all round. The Japanese garden was a surprising feature. The staff were great! Typical Japanese attention to detail. I look forward to another visit.

My husband and I had a fabulous stay at the Prince Park Tower Tokyo. We had a room with Tokyo Tower View and it was absolutely spectacular. Excellent location of the hotel in the center of city, only a short walk away to 2 subway stations,which we ended up using a lot during out stay in Tokyo. Wonderful staff! The mattress was a bit firm, but I am not used sleeping on to futons either. Would love to go back!

A realy 4,5* hotel. Ideal for business travellers and tourist alike. Wonderful view of the city, good connections by public transport, yet in a green park, next to a Shrine that is worth to be visit. Tokyo Tower is a few steps away and a good landmark. Two Metro stations to Reponghi, (Midtown and Hill must be visited). Hotel is rather "big", but staff is very efficient and friendly. Helpfull as well. Wonderful breakfast and good restaurants in the hotel are also available. Rooms are spacious and the bathrooms offer everything you like and more then you need.

This place is in a great location. You can get to three stations within a ten minute walk. The staff is very friendly, the rooms are clean and huge. They have a few restaurants and even have American food for my picky toddler. One side of the building overlooks Tokyo tower and the other side looks over a shrine both of which are beautiful.

We loved our stay here. We were upgraded to rooms on a higher floor. Views were fantastic. There was plenty of storage in the room so we were able to unpack and spread out. The wi-fi signal was strong. I was able to use Netflix with no buffering at all. Plenty of conveniently located plugs for charging your phone or laptop. The rooms were clean and housekeeping was very thorough. We also tried all of the 7 or so restaurants that operate out of this property. Though pricey most were really good. Service was excellent and the food was tasty. It was very pricey though. There was a Western style restaurant, sushi, Japanese, Chinese, steak, breakfast buffet, and a Yakitori restaurant. We tried all of them except the sushi restaurant.The hotel is centrally located. We were able to walk out for coffee and snacks. There was a free shuttle that took you to a nearby subway station where we were able to use our JR Pass to travel and visit other parts of Tokyo. We also used the shuttle to drop us at the station when we traveled for a few days to Kyoto. The grounds of the hotel are beautiful. We spent time walking through the garden and were able to catch a few early bird cherry blossoms. We also had an excellent view of Tokyo tower, It was a easy walk from the hotel. The hotel was one of the stop for Grey Line tours also. The concierge was helpful in booking the tours for us. There's a spa, nail salon and many other services on the bottom floor of the hotel.We would definitely stay here again.

Spent weekend here on a business trip. Efficient and helpful staff. Comfortable room. Two niggles - on both days had to wait about 20 minutes to enter breakfast buffet room; and was charged for entering the hotel's own (modest) gym.

Value for money. Easy access. Very clean hotel. Friendly staff. We will re-visit again. Room is more space than average Tokyo size room. We able to fit 2 children with us. Very good.One concern. Haneda Air port limousine is not stop at this hotel.

This is a hotel with quite nice accomodations, and good sized rooms for Tokyo. The location is very central in Tokyo, and there are many great restaraunts on site. The staff is very friendly, and the rates are very good.

The hotel is built like a tower with 4 sides. The panoramic view of the sun rise is breathtaking. I stayed here for almost a month and the breakfast served on the topmost floor is elaborate with freshly squeezed orange juice and magnificent view of Tokyo Bay from the heights.Japanese impeccable service topped with bath tubs that can create waves gives an impression of Japanese automation.
user_location: Newcastle upon Tyne, England, United Kingdom
user_name:
Anjana P
Newcastle upon Tyne, England, United Kingdom

review_body: We loved this hotel for our family visit to TokyoGreat view of Tokyo tower and gardenWe were there during cherry blossom season so view was greatRooms were niceCould walk to Ginza, fish market and other sightsOnly downside is not a lot of restaurants in the area but great to get away from bustle of Tokyo

A very nice  corporate hotel. There is a good view of the japanese tower and is located inside a park. Walking around, it's possible to see a shrine within walking distance. They have shops in the basement. Very pretty during the cherry blossom season. It's quite a tall hotel so it has nice views - unfortunately sky was a bit grey that day.

I had previously stayed in Roppongi on two prior visits to Tokyo in a big name chain hotel, I was slightly apprehensive about not staying with a chain hotel incase they didnt speak English or the rooms werent well appointed, but those concerns were groundless. This is my preferred hotel in Tokyo now. The price is fantastic and offers excellent value for money, they had more amenities than I'd have thought including handy toothbrushes, hairbrushes and all other kinds of things, the housekeeping standard is excellent and the staff are the depiction of professionalism, all the staff I spoke with seemed to speak English and understand all of my needs and requests. The rooms themselves are quite large for Tokyo standards and the bathroom was well appointed. The TV and internet systems were easy to use. The location is really nice with great views of the city, from my window I could see the Tokyo Skytree and being next to the Tokyo tower made it an easy reference point for walking back to. There was a choice of 3 subway stations roundabout to jump into for getting around. There are plenty of restaurants open quite late a 5 minute walk from the hotel.I was pleasantly surprised and delighted by this hotel and it turns out its part of a large Japanese chain with several hotels around Japan. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

This hotel is simply beautiful. My family and I stayed in the suites and everything is very clean and nicely set up. We payed for the premium floor after the first night. There was a huge difference! While the normal rooms are still very nice, the premium suited are so much better! The lower floors don't provide the nicer toiletries. My daughter loves using the bath salts that they provide nightly. The restaurants are delicious. The hair salon in the hotel is also fantastic.

The hotel close to the tower,after dinner walk to there from hotel need 10 minutes around, very convenient. There are temple in the mid way, that is another lucky thing for the traveling. Hotel have delicious breakfast, fruit pie is my favor, there are also have Chinese breakfast and western style, we love it.

The hotel is located really next to Tokyo Tower only 5 minutes by walk. And only 3 minutes walk from Akabanebashi and Shibakoen MRT. There is no restaurants and shopping malls in this area. Mostly it is suitable for who want to take a break from busy world. There is a temple and park surrounding. And only 2 next stations to Roppongi, lots of restaurants,cafes,pubs and malls. I had stayed 2 night at Panaramic Twin room . The staffs sent email to me after we'd booked the room and request that we want the room where could see the Tokyo tower from our room. They said it would be additional charged about 4000yen per night to book the Panoramic room with Tokyo Tower view at 33fl. And it's worthy. We do love that view. It's really really wonderful. Whatever we had problem, we sent email to ask them directly. And their staffs are very willing help politely. The room is big and comfortable. There is a jacuzzi bahttub and Salt bath spa us . Full amenties. Unfortunately, there is no complimentaly water bottle in room. For the breakfast, it has high standard quality. Love their ham-cheese omelete, japanese ramen, fresh orange juice and Strawberry Danish. Good view and Good taste for dinning on 37fl. The hotel also has Airport limusine bus to Narita and Haneda Airport. For narita is about 3200 yen per person. It's very convenience, no need to carry our lugguage at all. Every staffs can speak english well and polite. If i go back to Tokyo, i will choose this hotel again difintely.

I think the hotel room is great during my stay. My room is facing Tokyo tower & it's gorgeous. Besides, it is very spacious and hard to find in Japan. However, the toilet is not attached to washroom so that not very convenient. The bath tub with massage mode, wonderful especially after crazy shopping.However, I was very disappointed about the integrity of their staff. I need to use my credit card information for reference / deposit when checked in. The staff tear off my credit card slip when we checked out as we paid cash for the accommodation. My credit card information was being used for online purchases from overseas on the following day illegally. This credit card was only used for this hotel deposit within the past month so I'm pretty sure it's someone in this hotel stole my card information for this illegal action. I tried to search any email from their website to contact them & complained about this issue, however, they only got telephone number & so I decided to write my review here to alert all those who are planning to stay in this hotel. I hope this hotel can investigate the case & reply me when read about this review.

I have stayed here both individually for business and with family. The hotel is modern, clean, excellent location and facilities. The staff are magnificent and happy to help with any issue. The rooms are clean, quiet and some provide great views of Tokyo Tower. During a family stay there was an issue with our allocated room, so we were accommodated in a two bedroom Japanese style room on the 2nd floor. This was a combination of beds in one room and futons on tatami in another. There was a spa and doors opened onto a roof balcony. Definitely a recommended hotel for either business or leisure.

Great view on the Tokyo Tower from the room, breath taking during the night. The breakfast is just the best I had in my life, they've got everything, from to most exotic fruits to the best truffle omelet !

I stay here each time I come to Tokyo. It's perfectly located for my office. The rooms are what you'd expect of a good corporate hotel. A little plain but totally comfortable and clean. If you can, request a room with a view of the tower, it's stunning at night. I've stayed in low and high floor rooms and don't believe the high floor rooms are worth the additional premium. So save your money and go for the low floors. The bar on the 33/F is awesome, you must visit for a cocktail and view overlooking the city. I'll be back!

I stayed here on business last week and it was perfect. I booked into a Panoramic Suite and the room was huge for a Japanese hotel. The property is conveniently located to Hamamatsucho station and is within walking distance of Tokyo Tower. My clients and I were very happy with the property except for the gym. I did not like the service there at all. I let the hotel manager know and they were very apologetic despite it not being their fault. Overall, I think this hotel is amazing.

Pretty central to everywhere you want to go in Japan. Walking distance to Roppongi and a quick taxi to Shibuya, Shinjuku, or Ginza. Not a very "young" hotel - more sophisticated for business or visiting families.

Usually come for business but brought family pre skiing. Connecting rooms good size. Not cheap but it's Tokyo near Chinese New Year ... Staff are so friendly and always happy to help. And Tokyo tower just a 5 mins walk. Spa is over 20s only so don't plan on family swimming ...

We did a honeymoon in Japan for 5 nights and spent the last night here. I requested a suite with a view of the Tokyo Tower. It was an expensive room, but the view and the room were fantastic. We loved the bed and the pillows had the best sleep in Japan here. I wish I could take the bed and pillows home with me. We slept with the curtains open overlooking the night lights of Tokyo and the Tower. The bathroom was large and spacious with a large shower and separate bath to fit two.

Service, amazing. My patio door on the 25th floor broke and they upgraded me to a jr suite complete with free alcoholic beverages in the mini fridge and remote controlled shades. Lush, comfortable bedding. Everything felt brand new and hardly touched. Futuristic toilet room seperate from the free standing jaccuzi/shower room. Wedding consultation, olympic pool, full spa on site. Great location mid city, a total heavenly oasis in the heart of Tokyo. Free beautiful postcards in the desk.

We had been to other part of the Japan during the trip, so we just can spend one night in Tokyo. This hotel is absolutely a right choice for us. I made my reservation through a local travel agent. So, in order to secure a room with Tokyo Tower view in Christmas eve (also my husband's birthday), I made my request via e-mail a month before. I was told that an extra 4000 yen can help me get my room gauranteed. I was happy that I did so as it is peak season and rooms can be tight . My room number is 1501 (deluxe twin). The view is stunning. It is just right on 15 th floor, the Tokyo Tower is close enough and not too tall. My room has the view of the Tokyo Skytree too though it is a bit too far away. You may see it on a clear day. I would really like to thanks Mayu Chin from the back office of Prince Hotels who has helped me to make my request directly to the Prince Park Tower Tokyo.When you get off at the Akabanebashi Station, you can spot the hotel easily as you can see there is just one road cross from the Tokyo Tower. The hotel is very beautiful during Christmas time with a lot of lighting and decoration. Check-in is efficient and the staff are helpful and with good command of English. It was a bonus to me that the hotel did not charge me extra for my 2 kids ( aged 4 and 7). The room is spacious, elegant and clean. The balcony is lovely and big. It overlooks the Tokyo Tower and the park. The cakes from the hotel cake shop are lovely and affordable. The souvenir shop sells different kinds of souvenir. I bought myself a Tokyo Tower sakura honey which is lovely for less than 1000 yen. Take the hotel airport express bus if you have big laguage or with kids. 3100 yen for adult and 1550 yen for kid. It is hassle free and you don't need to carry your laguage around. It takes 100 mins to the airport as it needs to pick up passengers from other hotels too.

Loved the room. Nice and quiet with a view of the Tokyo Tower which was truly amazing- especially at night. The surroundings of the hotel are beautiful. So much to see and explore by foot (temples and gardens). The service provided was excellent. Highly recommend this hotel.
user_name:
GlobeTrottersJAR
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The hotel is modern, well located and some rooms offer the view for the Tokyo Tower with is a must, particularly if you are in a high floor. You can see most of Tokyo from there. Many choices of restaurants in the hotel as well as different places for breakfast. The buffet one in the top floor is very nice with many options. The only part that I did not like is having to pay for the access to the gym besides the fact I was staying in the premium apartments.

The Prince Park is a pleasant hotel set in a round tower close to the Tokyo tower. This was my first Tokyo visit and I had worked out how to get to the hotel from Narita airport - monorail and a 15 minute walk - which turned out well. The location isn't in the heart of Tokyo, but the subway is a short walk away and it is easy to navigate around the city. The staff are very friendly. Rooms are a little dated, but clean and have all the facilities required. WiFi is good. My room was high up, but didn't have a view of the Tokyo tower. There was some booming traffic noise from what appeared to be cruising motorbikes, particularly on the Saturday night. There is a lovely bar and restaurant on the top floor, which has fantastic views of the city. Not a bad stay overall.

We stayed at the Premium Club floor. The rooms were well appointed, had a breathtaking view, the amenities were very nice, and had a well-stocked room fridge. The staff spoke good English and were very kind. They accommodated our requests, patiently and politely answered all of our questions, and helped us with our daily itinerary. Private transportation on the days we needed it was easily arranged. They have a shuttle service to the train station which was convenient on the days we chose to take the train but it was an easy and nice walk, less than a kilometer, when we missed the shuttle bus! Conveniently located walkable-y near the Tokyo Tower, Zojoji Temple, the serene Hama Rikyu garden, and many more!

Really loved the room here. We were on the 30th floor and had a lovely view of the Tokyo Bay Bridge and skyline. The room was large and all the amenities were excellent.Some negatives include: The location is not ideal as it is far from any subway station. They have a shuttle bus, but I'm not sure where it drops/picks up. We ended up using taxi, which can get expensive.Check in was also a really long line, that moved slowly. All of that being said, the room was great: big, quiet and excellent view.

My husband booked this hotel for our stay in Tokyo. The hotel is beautiful, the rooms are spacious, the views are beautiful, and the grounds are emaculate. All the staff were very friendly and accommodating. Although the hotel is walking distance to Tokyo Tower (a must-see attraction, especially at night), it is further away from city center. The hotel is in the middle of a business district which means there aren't as many things to do at night. The subway system is easy to navigate (with the help from Google Maps) and it took us about 25 minutes to get to the Ginza district and other attractions. If your stay in Tokyo is limited, I would recommend a hotel closer to Ginza or Imperial Gardens. Otherwise, Prince Hotel is a perfect Tokyo getaway destination.

We arrived at this hotel in the night and we were guided by the imposing Tokyo Tower. The hotel is situated literally next to it and the sight of the Tower from our room was fantastic as we had a corner room.The bath room was awesome: with a spacious shower cubicle and the bath tub had jets to relax one's weary body after a tiring day.Waking up to a bright and sunny day with the view of the Tokyo Tower, shining in the morning light, was a sight to remember.We had breakfast on the 33rd floor where we were afforded a wonderful view of Tokyo, with the Tokyo Tree in the distance.The only view missing was a glimpse of Mount Fuji!The breakfast buffet was vast; with western and Japanese fare to satisfy most.Definitely a hotel to return to.

This was my first trip to Japan and, while I had studied some Japanese in college, I was more than a little rusty. It didn't matter because just about everyone at this hotel spoke English, at least enough to help with any question that I had. They were also very kind and humored me when I tried to speak in broken Japanese. The hotel room I received was GIGANTIC by Japanese standards, and larger than most rooms I've had in cities like San Francisco. The bathroom was a work of art, and the automatic, high-tech toilet had so many buttons and options that I was amazed.I had no problems with the wireless Internet access in my room. We ate breakfast in the hotel restaurant -- do that at least once to experience the view from just about the top of the hotel. If you can get a table on the Tokyo Tower side, that's a pretty nice way to start the day. I believe the other option, by the omelette station, gives you a view of Rainbow Bridge. Speaking of the restaurant, the buffet has an amazing array of American, European, and Japanese offerings. I highly recommend the pastries and the guys making omelettes did them perfectly.We were at this hotel for a convention, and the convention venue was beautiful and conveniently accessible from the main body of the hotel. There are all kinds of shops and even a wedding chapel onsite. The convenience store in the lobby was very well stocked and open both early and late. There are a few train and subway stations nearby; we took the subway from Daimon a couple of times -- that is about a mile away -- and it was pretty convenient. If you would rather take cabs, there seemed to be a continuous stream of those available out front. If you don't want to eat at the hotel, there are plenty of small food shops within easy walking distance. The Zozoji temple is right next to the hotel and is worth a visit, especially if it is your first time to Tokyo. This temple is MUCH less crowded than anything else we visited in the city.

I would rename this place "The Prince Asphalt Tower," since all we can see from our window is a highway and the asphalt in front of the hotel. I can hear highway noise in our room. Very disappointing for the price we are paying. Room is ok but not large. I was looking forward to using the pool and gym until I learned that the hotel charges a not insignificant fee (4120 yen, about $33.62 at today's exchange rate.) I've never stayed in a hotel that charged extra for use of their fitness facilities, much less such a big fee. Would not stay here again - a rip-off, even for Tokyo.

Good quality hotel with nice rooms. We had an excellent view of Tokyo tower. The staff speak excellent English We stayed in the executive wing of hotel with extra security to enter. Has a wonderful gift shop with lots of Japanese merchandise for gifts to take home

I stayed in this hotel for about a week and very much enjoyed it. The staff were super helpful and as expected very polite. My room view was great and case see Tokyo Tower. The hotel restaurant was great and while the service and environment were amazing the price wasn't that dear! They look after all type of food allergies and options very carefully. Relatively close to the Haneda airport.

It Was ok hotel but if you have one more person to stay they will charge you more 5000(something like that the price). But the hotel is near by Tokyo tower and metro actually is very convenient only the staff is not so friendly. But the bath room is very nice big bathtub. The photo is from our room 504 of the view. We are not recommend another one not use room card take the elevator up to entry your room that side of the room.

Booked this hotel after researching just about every affordable hotel/district in Tokyo. We stayed in a corner, tower facing room and it was cracking. Large and spacious, big bed, big bathroom with separate toilet (which was the most high-tech one of the 2 weeks). it was nice to have the spacey, smoke free room to relax in.Hotel location was great for us. Originally I thought Shinjuku would be the place to stay, but in hindsight I'm glad we didn't as that place is a sensory overload!The hotel is situated at the base of a small park, so you get some breathing space! if you don't mind walking, its about 20/25 mins to Ginza or 10 mins to closest station (free shuttle is provided if required). Once at a station, easy enough to travel around the city.Didn't use any of the hotel restaurants and bars, nor the spa (additional charges). picked up some croissants each morning from the in-house bakery and they were sufficient fro a quick bite before heading out. you can also buy beers/food/snacks etc to save using the higher priced room mini bar.Concierge's all speak very good English and are very helpful.

I liked everything about this hotel. From reception onwards, the hotel staff could not have been more pleasant, efficient and accommodating. The restaurants were first-class. The fitness suite, pool and sauna/spa were ideal. And the view from my room (27th floor) was stunning. I haven't often visited Tokyo but if and when I do so again I won't think twice before booking a room here.

Hotel is located very near to Tokyo tower. Rooms very good, especially as I was given an upgrade to s suite. Good choice of restaurants within the hotel and the sashimi in the sushi restaurant was particularly good. Cocktail bar at the top of the restaurant has great views over the city.

I stayed in the premium jr suite. The large windows gave an amazing view of the city. The premium lounge was worth the extra money alone. Excellent food, drinks, views, and service. The room was comfortable, the shower was amazing - high pressure rain shower. The hotel is a little worn but the service makes up for it tenfold. You can call the front desk and someone will be at your door immediately. 7 minute walk to either subway station, 10 minute walk to the Tokyo Tower.

Stayed in this hotel for 4 nights in late August. Room on the higher floor with the view of the Tokyo Tower was the best. Room amenities are the best ever I have seen in my travel around the world. Friendly staff and great food. Banquet facilities are outstanding. Hotel has a great location and many places to visit. Closer to the shopping. Had a outstanding stay.

Stayed at the hotel for a 3 night stay on a business trip to Tokyo in November 2015.Hotel is only about 10 years old, but seemed very dated to me - like a 1980s vintage room. That said - room was very large, and everything worked OK. Like any hotel in Japan - everything was super clean and in good condition.Staff were typically polite - but I was surprised when they refused to help me with dinner reservations for the night after I left the hotel (we moved to a different neighborhood) because it was after checking out - helping non-Japanese guests with reservations is pretty much standard service in Tokyo hotels!Location is OK - central, but not really in any kind of distinctive neighborhood.
