Starting with the journey into Tokyo from Narita, we took the bus to the Tokyo City Air Terminal, and then we took the subway to the Shibakoen stop from the Suitengumae stop (transfer at Jimbocho). And from there, it was only a 5 minute walk to the hotel. Not even reaching the entrance to the hotel, a hotel attendant greeted us up the driveway and took our bags. Amazing service! Check-in was simple and fast, and another attendant showed us to our room. All of the attendant's knowledge of the English language was adequate for communication. The Superior Double room had an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower, and Mt Fuji in the distance! The living area and bathroom space was more than enough, given Tokyo's scarcity of real estate. About a 10 minute walk from the hotel back entrance, around the Zojoji temple, is the downtown Daimon area where you can find a bunch of restaurants. Our first meal was Ramen Thank, which was delicious! Highly recommended and English friendly too! The best thing about PPT was it's convenience to the subway stations. Most of the time, we used the Akabanebashi station, and from there it was easy to transfer to any of the other lines. Take a look at their pastry shop in the morning. They have fresh baked breads which are so good, especially the Maple Bread. I would definitely return here in the future!

This is my first time to Japan so i want to have a great memory. I'm so happy I chose this hotel over others. It is right in the middle of a beautiful park. All major tour trip buses and air port buses will stop by this place as well. I had a tokyo tower view room, it was absolutely amazing. Bathroom fully equipment with everything you can think of or need. I took a hot bath in my jacuzzi tub, went out to dinner with my friend, had drinks up in their roof top lounge, and still managed to got a in room massage at 1AM.Down in basement, they serve Japanese style breakfast. They all greet you with warm smiles, after you order, your food will come along with your bill on the side and you can pay whenever you're ready up front. I checked out the hotel, leaving behind my phone and over a G cash in the room drawer. Guess who found it after a whole day~ They are awesome ppl here. I would definitely come back and recommended this place to anyone.

Stayed here with 2 friends. The room was great, comfortable. The check-in experience was nice.Staff were nice and wanting to help, but sometimes their English was not good enough and we found better help on Google...All in all, I would definitely recommend this place!

Excellent hotel - great staff, well appointed, good rooms. View from breakfast over the city and Mt. Fuji in the sun was only topped by the night cap view from the bar on 33 that usually rounded of a busy day of working.Just the ticket.

The hotel is very close to Tokyo Tower which is beautiful at night as well as a surprise view of Mt Fuji in the morning when opening the drapes! Spa was very relaxing. I definitely recommend The Prince Park Tower.

This hotel is amazing and is well worthy of its high ranking on Tripadvisor! I booked the room through Expedia with a significant discount. Had a great stay during one night and I wish I had the time to stay more. To put it simply, I felt better that I feel at my own home. Large room, very clean, a variety of soaps and towels, very comfy bed with a variety of pillows, large shower room with a shower and a bath tub, toilet in another corner of the room, a large walk-in closet, WIFI with no problem, TV with various channels Japanese and international alike, and quality coffee maker with tea bags. Very intimate and unique place to stay. I enjoyed every moment there.The hotel is in a fantastic location. About 7 minutes walk from the Shibakoen Station on the Subway's Mita Line. About 10 minutes by taxi from Roppongi, one of the most busiest centers, for youngsters especially, in Tokyo, and about 10 minutes walk from Tokyo Tower. It is also close to one of the largest parks in Tokyo.The check in was very impressive and smooth. Not by standing at a reception desk, the way we do in most the world's hotels, but by sitting comfortably down in front of an hotel officer. I asked for a quite room far from the elevator but found out all the rooms are far from the elevator and all are quite. I didn't specify in advance that I would like to have a room facing the Tokyo Tower, but nevertheless this was solved very fast and I got the room 503 facing the Tower. What a beautiful site especially when the Tower was lighten up during December's nights! In fact, the staff as a whole were professional and charming and gave very good service. Concierge was very helpful advising on the use of the free shuttle of the hotel which travels up to Hamamatsu-cho Station, excellent location to start your travel in Tokyo. What a service!Well recommended.

The lobby was gorgeous (non-smoking) staff greeted us out front and loaded our luggage onto a trolley, the front was lit up beautifully in Christmas decorations, as was the lobby. Check in was quick and easy. We travelled with four children (under 11) & 3 adults. The room was beautiful, the bathroom was gorgeous marble, beautiful spa bath, nice powerful shower head, which is what we look for after a 12 hr day of sightseeing. The room was a great size, I was expecting small, but these rooms were spacious and comfy. We had two triple rooms. We didn't try the restaurants or gym. The lobby had a shop which sold beautiful fresh bread/pastries every day. The location was perfect, only a 5 min walk to the JR train station. We will absolutely be staying here again, quality at a great price.

I booked my room through Hotwire and received a pretty fantastic deal. I ended up in a corner room on the 15th floor with the Tokyo Tower in full view. The room is exceptionally large for a Japanese hotel, and incredibly well appointed, with a glass shower stall and separate jacuzzi bath, as well as a different room containing just the toilet (which is even more high-tech than the other Japanese toilets I have encountered thus far). Check-in was easy and simple. I was able to store my bag with the front desk easily, even though I arrived well before my check-in time, and I completed the paperwork prior to being given my room key. The hotel provided me with an adaptor for my computer and the service has been exemplary, if even a little overwhelming. A word of warning (and this should not be a surprise), but the cafe in the lobby is _expensive as hell_, and I'm assuming the restaurants in the hotel fall into the same $$$$ price range. Find yourself a Lawson's if you want to drink some beer in your room at night or have a snack.The hotel is situated just a block or two from the Tokyo Tower, which is neat to look at but seems like kind of a fool's tourist trap. Much more interesting is the nearby Shiba park, which has plenty of hooks and crannies to explore and is full of small statues, shrines, and places to discover, including an active Shinto place of worship. The hotel is not particularly close to any interesting stores or restaurants, but there are two subway stops less than five minutes away, and it was exceptionally easy to get to Shinjuku Station for dinner.I'd highly recommend this hotel if you're able to get a good deal. Great service, beautiful, huge, well-appointed room, convenient to the subway (although not much else). I kind of wish I was staying here for longer than I am.
user_name:
FrontierPsychologist
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Checking-in to the Prince Park Tower is a little like fighting through a zombie war. I arrived early and the fact that no rooms were available was fine. But the staff were very intent on reciting the rules, storing my bag and getting me out of the lobby, with no suggestions about where to recover for the intervening 5 hours. Travellers don't arrive early at hotels in order to create inconvenience for the staff; we are hostage to airline schedules. I was checking in for business, for a week, but asking to use the (small) business centre was clearly an out-of-left-field request. It would have been great to know that the tea lounge is exceptionally comfortable; that the gift shop/boulangerie sells fresh baked croissants; that the basement houses a superbly equipped gym and a full size thermal spring spa (for about USD 25); or that there is a terrific massage service downstairs, alongside the nail bar and the esthetic salon. Once past reception the rooms are large -- if unrenovated -- the service is terrific and the French restaurant on the 33rd floor has one of the best-priced dinner menus in town. I agree that the hotel has a lovely 1960s elegance vibe. Watch out for the breakfast buffet on weekends -- the influx of wedding parties, tour groups and Japanese holiday makers means that the lines are long; it is a destination brunch spot. Location is fine if you are happy to use the subway. There are no shops or restaurants close by but the hotel has a surprisingly well-stocked mini-supermarket, so self-catering and supplies are at hand. My suggestion is that management sends the entire front desk staff over to the Excel Tokyu Hotel in Akasaka-mitsuke to get some training on smiling, personable, 'how can we make you comfortable?' service training. (I returned a week later for a two day stay - same unsmiling check-in; same terrific service elsewhere).

The hotel is great. The rooms are spacious, the king size bed we had was comfortable, the bathroom equipped with a shower and bath tub. We had a room with a balcony which gives an amazing view over the autumn colored trees and the Zojoji Temple. The hotel is located in a bit of a dull area. No shops or supermarkets in the neighborhood but the hotel itself has a small supermarket which is good enough for emergency shoppings. Nearby the hotel you can find 2 subway stations on a 10 minutes walk; Shibakoen and Akabanebashi and from there you can go everywhere in Tokyo as long as you're familiar with the subway station. There is a shuttle bus provided by the hotel which brings you to the train station Hamamatsucho. So enough alternatives to avoid the unbelievable expensive taxis and still go to places.

One of the most professionally run hotels I've stayed in. Staff was unbelievable; even more so considering the language barrier. They make it seamless. Clean, big rooms. Elegant. Very good location if you understand the subways, which are actually easy. Or take a cab. Great park and shrine and the Tokyo Tower right next door. The Sky Lounge gives you a fantastic view of the Tower and city, although pricey.

A beautiful and convenient hotel in Tokyo with 5 star service at affordable rates. At check-in, you're directed to a desk for a personalized welcome followed by an escort to your room along with your luggage. Rooms look a bit dated and worn but this is made up for by the spaciousness of each rooms. Bathrooms are marble with a separate shower and jetted tub. The staff are very friendly and efficient when catering to your requests. Concierge is very knowledgable and understanding of western travelers' needs. The property is located a short walk from the Akebanebashi station.

This hotel must have been the place to be in the 1960's and 1970's. It has a late sixties, early seventies vibe to it. Luxurious but with a kind of vintage elegance to it... dark wood, lots of white marble. A couple of things are great about the hotel... the setting in Shiba Park, the views of the Tokyo Tower and Tokyo Bay and the breakfast buffet and bar on the 33rd floor. It is a short walk to the Akebanebashi subway station so it was easy to get anywhere in Tokyo via the subway station. All in all, one of the better choices for a hotel in Tokyo
brilliant view for Tokyo tower (remember to choose tower view room), great bath room and clean room. A little bit old fashion but not effect the great experience

Due to a conference I had the luxury to spend one night in this great hotel, it was fantastic. The rooms were large, even the non-executive ones. The breakfast buffet at the 33rd floor is superb, both the food as well as the view on Tokyo Tower. At night this same floor has a great bar with the same stunning view. It will cost a few bucks more, but it is actually worth it!

Was there for a business. Stayed in Junior Suite. Large room with two large beds, living room with very comfortable Sofa, refrigerator, with very good quality in-room self coffee maker, large size computer desk with plenty of power outlets. Room was large for holding business meetings of group of 4 comfortably. Staff is very respectful, attentive. Great number of outlets. Toilette separate from the bathroom. The bathroom includes a modern Jacuzzi and shower. Bathroom has high quality amenities for bath/shower, toothbrush, mouthwash, even toothbrush and razor. Cleaning service, towels were great. Temperature controls worked. Wish US hotels learn from industrial design features the hotel has as simple as power strips with multiple outlets with great separation elegantly and strategically placed next to bed and bed lights and located on the computer desk. Great gardens with walking/running paths surrounds the hotel. Zojoji Temple is right around the corner as historical site. Always taxi is available (730 Yen and up). In 10 days for my business spent equivalent of $400 for taxies which is not much considering multiple trips I had to take within Tokyo. There are close-by metro stations.Running in the early morning surrounded by Gardens were very nice. Due to time change, there were nights waking up very early and running in 4 am around the hotel, never felt unsafe at all. Overall Tokyo is a clean and my impression the place was very safe. The hotel has a decent gym and indoor swimming pool which was included in the room in my case. The Gym requires a long walk from the base of the hotel. The Basement has all sort of restaurants including Sushi, grill, steak house, tempura. Once I had Sushi dinner special for the hotel guests. Breakfast buffet I had in 33rd floor most mornings was great. For most rooms it may be included but not in my case which cost (I think) around $30, which is a great price for the great quality of food. Including hot and cold quality entries, some Japanese entries and soup.There is also small store in the hotel to buy pre-made sandwiches, drinks, beverages. Also has a great daily fresh bakery including croissants, some deserts, etc. Very good quality and not too sweet.I really like the hotel, modern, comfortable, very clean and very respectable and helpful hotel staff. If you are looking for a hotel in the middle of action, close to near by small restaurants etc. This is not the one. It is close to Tokyo Tower if you like to visit to see the Tokyo from birds eye view. The sound insulation is good but in night there was some street/traffic noise even though I was at 28th floor. So if you are sensitive to noise or looking for perfectly quite hotel, this may not be the one. Although I doubt there would any hotel in Tokyo without some street noise.I highly recommend the hotel for business and family.

Really, really liked this hotel. Arrived about 3 hours earlier than check in and was in my room an hour later, no fuss. Opted for a premium double room following the tips on here and it was money well spent. Beautiful corner room on 29th floor, comfy large bed, wonderful view (asked for Tokyo tower view on check in and it almost feels in touching distance), free wifi, lovely bathroom with every amenity you could wish for and lovely staff. Access to premium lounge with even better views and a fabulous breakfast on the 33rd floor included in the price. Though there didn't appear to be much happening in the immediate area, there are two underground stations in easy walking distance. Quite a fashionable hotel with lots of glamorous Japanese women wandering around. Took the Limousine Bus from Narita for 3,100 yen each to reach the hotel which was easy and efficient.

The concierge service was very helpful. The breakfast buffet on the 33rd floor was beautifully displayed - lots of choice and "cooked to otder" items. The staff were very service-minded. Our room was clean and comfortable with a very high-tech toilet in a separate room from the bath tub and shower. The amenities were fine quality and generously restocked at every servicing of the room. One evening we enjoyed the piano bar and the yakitori restaurant located below the lobby. Also below the lobby they have a bowling alley, spa, banquet facilities and wedding organizers with gift registry, flowers and wedding fashions.

We decided to give this hotel a try even though we have stayed in a couple of good hotels previously during our yearly trip to Tokyo, Japan. Room is great, we booked a premier room which has a separate toilet cubicle from the main bathroom. This is very rare in Japan's hotel as far as we know. Totally loved it ! Hotel deco is very modern, clean and bathroom toiletries just blown us away, thoughtful is the word to describe. A separate kitchenette sink beside the fridge and mini bar area in the living section is a real plus point. Thumbs up for the great room! Breakfast is on the the top of the hotel building, with queues every morning, however, the staff made the transition very smooth and very quickly we were seated every morning for the 5days we were there. The spread was great, lots of variety. Now, I can't helped but to highlight and compare the hotel spread which we had at Tokyo Disneyland Hotel.....very poor variety given the very expensive breakfast price tag there at Disneyland, we couldnt even find a piece of plain toast to begin with, no egg cooking service, everything on the breakfast buffet were SWEET Stuff !! Seriously? If you want a heart attack to begin your holiday with, go for it ! Back to Prince Park Tower, the breakfast spread was just a heaven to begin with, we totally enjoyed it. Great spread, lots of variety, western and both Japanese. All sorts of milk, and even health juice which is freshly blended. I can't asked for more than that kind of healthy spread. The thought of the breakfast spread at Prince just brought a smile to my face again.The location is fantastic, you get the Tokyo Tower View, both night and day, it has the best angle you could capture of the Tokyo Tower. Nearby the hotel has lots of great restaurants to begin with, great variety and supermarket and convenient stores all within less than 10mins walk- if you walk with little children of course :((To go to the main shopping district, there are a few stations to choose from, very smooth and hassle free, one of the most convenient hotels we have stayed in Tokyo Japan.Inside the hotel, there is a mini mart / souvenir store which provides some great conveniences for those who just need a couple of things.We totally loved the hotel, food, location, I give this hotel a 5 star rating!!

Location was close to my office, near greenery and easy to access. The rooms were nice, decent sized and clean.View from the room was awesome, with a clear view of Tokyo a Tower. The bar at the top was nice enough, a great view and atmosphere for my co-workers to join and most of all convenient!

We spent 5 days in this hotel and I must say that the view of the Tokyo Tower (from our room 1420) was great. The bathroom had a fantastic view of the city as well. The toilet is in a separate room from the shower and bath/jacuzzi tub. The bed was huge for 2 people. There is also free wifi in the room. I loved the cleanliness of the room/bathroom, the courteous, very pleasant and helpful conceirge staff who gave us directions on which trains to take where we needed to go. Though the hotel was a good 15 minute walk from the nearest train station (Hamamatsucho), they have provided a shuttle that will actually take the guests there every 30 minutes and back to the hotel as well. Hamamatsucho station is one of the stops too for the Tokyo monorail that leads to the Haneda airport. You have 3 choices for your breakfast venue (we were only able to try one w/c was at the 33rd flr). Buffet breakfast was a good spread of breads, fruits, etc. If you wish to eat Japanese food, the hotel has an array of restaurants (sushi, steak, etc) at the basement level. There is a shop at the lobby that sells so many items (food, toiletries, souvenirs, etc) and they also have a money changing machine near this shop where you can have your foreign currency changed. Speak of convenience! Overall, we loved this hotel and consider this as one of the highlights of our stay in Tokyo.

Only stayed here one night unfortunately. Ideally located close to Shibakoen and Daimon metro station this hotel entirely met my expectations. Had a great view of the Tokyo skyline at night with the Tokyo tower, amazing! Very modern and luxurious hotel, fancy elevators, room was just great and bed was so so comfy I didn't want to get up. Wonderful stay.

Stayed four nights in October 2014 and have nothing bad to say about it, it was absolutely fantastic! Great central location, next to the Tokyo tower and the beautiful and serene Shiba park, a few minutes away from two subway stations but also within walking distance of another three stations. Bus/coach service from Narita airport available for a reasonable price (it is called Airport Limousine). Free shuttle bus to nearby Hamamatsucho station on the JR line which departs twice an hour. Amazing service, staff are super friendly and so helpful and courteous with a great level of English. The room was big and spotless and with nice views. Large marbled bathroom with both shower cabinet and whirlpool tub and an extensive array of free branded toiletries, including razor & shaving cream, hairbrush, toothbrush, bath salts, etc. Free wi-fi in the room but the use of pool and gym is not free. If you choose not to have your room serviced/cleaned to help the environment, you get a 1000 Yen (approx. 10$) voucher per night (maximum two nights in a row) which you can use towards the restaurants/pool/gym/shops (you need to fill in a form with housekeeping in advance). Area/hotel /room and air-con were not noisy so had a great night’s sleep every night! Will definitely be back!

Wow, what a great hotel and what a good price!Fantastic view from 19th floor towards Tokyo Tower.Room facilities the best ever. Jacuzzi bath, really high quality toiletries, great hotel facilities.The Sky lounge is superb, as are the health spa and the breakfast is out of this world. Best hotel I have ever stayed in.

Spent 4 very pleasant nights in this hotel. Staff where very helpful and had a good grasp of English. Which was good for me. Very close to a number of train stations. Had a room with a view of Tokyo tower, which was an amazing site, both night and day. Very clean and well maintained hotel. Having to pay to use gym and pool, i thought was a bit too much. So i did not use. Very good value for money, i did not have breakfast in the hotel, so can comment on standard. I would recommend the hotel and could not really fault on anything

I have spent 3 nights in The Prince Park Tower Tokyo Hotel which deserves 5 stars and I was pleased during my stay. Our room was spacious and had a great view since we were staying at the top floors. Check-in was easy and fast. We received enough information from the employees about city and the hotel. Bathroom of the hotel was fascinating. Marbles are very clean and chic. In the bathroom there are both separate shower and bathtub. Bed is very comfortable, safe works properly and air condition is silent. In the room, wireless reception and speed are very good. Internet is free of charge.About the location, I think it is in a central place. However if you are planning to spend most of your time in Shibuya and Shinjuku, location of the hotel might be far. Hotel is very close to Roppongi which is also another favorite district. Hotel is equally close to Shibakoen and Akabanebashi metro stations. So you can connect to 2 different lines easily. It takes 3 minutes to reach each stations. Environment of the hotel is also very nice. It is located near the park. It wasn't noisy either. Depending on your budget, I would suggest staying in this hotel without any doubt.

I stayed in prince park tower hotel during a business trip last week. It was an awesome experience. I was booked into a Suite in 31st floor. Great view from the room. We and excellent facilities like good wifi, nice TV and blue ray player. The bath and toilet are separate. The bath had a tub and a shower cabinet. Excellent supply of toiletries. The mini bar is well stocked and replenished on regular basis. Good restaurants for having breakfast. Overall it is an excellent place to stay and I will recommend and go back again,

My first time in Tokyo and I chose well with the Prince Park Tower. Excellent value for the money. Great location. Close to metro, in a beautiful park, easy walking to sights. Room was large, beautiful view of the park and really, that toilet. Those of you who have been there know what I mean. The bathroom amenities were wonderful. Hairbrushes, toothbrushes, razors and shaving cream, lotion, potions and gels. You could go there with only your clothes and have everything you need.The hotel is spotlessly clean, the staff is friendly and very helpful, especially when there is difficulty with the language. Every day they marked off on our map what to do and where to go.We had traditional Japanese breakfast in their beautiful restaurant and it was quite an experience. I won't say that I loved it but the presentation, service and quality was well worth every penny. I wouldn't hesitate to stay there and as well, would recommend to my clients.

We both loved this hotel! Rooms are quite big and have an amazing view on Tokyo city. The bar on the 33rd floor is worth a visit. One negative point is that the spa/pool is not included. You pay an additional fee between 25 and 55 USD to use it. Otherwise the staff is very friendly and helpful. There are several nice restaurants in the basement of the hotel.

Stayed three nights last weekend with family. First visit to tokyo. Great location, central but quiet areaEasy access to metro and monorailPublic facilities and areas fresh and modern feel with standard amazing Japanese customer service (example, I went for a morning run in the rain, when I got back to the hotel,one of the staff came out with a towel for me without any prompt). The room we had on the 7th floor was perfectly good, great bath and the incredible Japanese toilet experience, but it was very dated. Not sure if other rooms have been upgraded, but this one obviously belongs to a prior period!That's the only complaint and it's a pretty minor one. Would stay again, no question.

My wife and I stayed at the Prince Park Tower for four nights at the start of a recent visit to Japan (Tokyo and Kyoto). Arrived at Narita at night and got the Airport Limousine Bus to the front door. Room was very spacious, with huge comfortable bed. We requested a room looking out on to the Tokyo Tower (24th floor) - great outlook with a nice balcony which was good for fresh air and view. This hotel is well situated in relation to Hamamatsucho Station which is the starting point for many of the Sunrise tours and is on the JR Yamanote line - and the hotel runs a shuttle bus to the station every half hour which is handy. We enjoyed our breakfasts in the restaurant on the 33rd floor - found quality and selection of food to our liking. Thoroughly enjoyed our stay.

I really enjoyed staying at this hotel. Upgraded to a spacious corner room with beautiful view of Rainbow bridge. Very fast WiFi service in the room, and very nice and convenient location, and excellent service. Breakfast on 33rd floor has great selections, not to mention the view:-)Also. within walking distance of Hamamatsucho station for Monorail access to Haneda. From Narita, it is a bit tougher since Narita express doesn't stop at above station, and you need jump on Yamatone at Tokyo station.I will stay there anytime I am in Tokyo!

Cant share all the good votes on TA. Stayed here because my business partners office is close nearby. To start with the best: the location close to a little park and a lively neighbourhood where to shop and to visit restaurants was good. Arrived here about midnight and had to help myself with the lugguage. After check in with poor english speaking receptionist I had to go to my room myself without explaination of the room facilities. Although the place from outside looks good the rooms are tired and fit into a 3 star place. Toilet is seperated from the bathroom and is tiny. A 5 year old would fit in.I found no adapter to recharge my smartphone and had to phone several times to get one. Next morning I found the breakfast room. The place was half emtpty but I had to queue for 15 min. For european taste little choice and a complete lack of quality regarding bread and coffee. TV stations only one english speaking film channel. To get acess to hotel free wifi you have to follow some complicated steps to generate a code instead of putting in your name and room number like in any other place of the world.I adressed this issues in an email I sent to the management. The reply was that the best speaking consiererge made some luke warm excuses (poor girl, she was the most capable one in that place). I didnt found that a decent reply to my expierence with the hotel.There are a lot of other places around - A good view can not compensate the lack of standard.I will never return.

It was close to the subway which makes it nice to get around Tokyo, The staff is very helpful giving directions and helping us to find things. Easy two minute walk over to the Tokyo Tower which was really interesting.Rooms were very clean and lots of extras that you don't find in other nice hotels, great tub with jets and bath salts to sooth the aching feet after a day of touring.Items in the hotel were really expensive, they dont' have in room coffee but you could get tea,

Airport limo directly pick up at this hotel... It is convenient as you have kid and luggage along with you...Location is good, near to the station. The view of Tokyo Tower from this hotel is excellent...

We splashed out a little for this room as it was our last few nights in Tokyo. Excellent service on arrival, we were shown to our room and given a tour of how to use things. Room 2920 has a view of the Tokyo tower and Mt Fuji (slightly obscured by a building). The jacuzzi also has views. Lots of lush goodies are provided such as bath salts, Shiseido beauty products and a small make up bag. The bathroom is lovely. We ate breakfast in the western restaurant on the 33rd floor each morning - not substantial (we had the continental) and I would have loved some cereal but it was good nonetheless. However... we booked this hotel specifically as it had a pool and spa. When we went to check it out it was miles away (walking underground for quite a while), then there was a sign saying people with tattoos will not be admitted. I have a tattoo of cultural significance and felt pretty raw about this! I understand that this is commonplace in traditional Onsens but feel that this sort of restriction is out of place in a hotel of this size, that caters to international guests. So we did not use the facilities that we had booked specifically to use. Unfortunately for this reason - despite it being a lovely hotel - I need to give it 3 stars as I am still stinging from that experience.

First note: this is a review for the blue tower hotel and not the sister hotel next door. This hotel is great for the views of Shiba Koen. The service is great (up to Japanese standards) and the hotel is good value for central Tokyo. The decor is a little dated compared to other options but very nice and clean. Walking in the neighborhood of the hotel is great. The location next to Oedo line's Akabanebashi station is convenient. This also provides easy subway access to Hamamatsucho, Yoyogi, Shinjuku, Tsukiji, Roppongi, and Shiodome. The combini in the lobby provides affordable options for drinks, munchies, and basic souvenirs. The restaurant options are also good. They are a bit expensive and less expensive options are abundant although you will have to walk 10+ minutes. I've stayed in a number of hotels in Tokyo and enjoy this place. This isn't my first or last stay. I prefer staying in the Shiodome area and really like the park hotel due to the views. When The Park Hotel is overpriced I always stay here.

Pretty reasonable hotel. Location is central and convenient. The decor however feels a little business-y and drab. Could do with a bit of modernisation.The bar on the 33rd floor has decent views. Although 3,400Yen for 2 beers was reasonably steep!

The minute you walk into this hotel, you'd recognize that it's one of the typical Japanese hotels--a little dated and the typical Japanese service, sufficiently polite but a bit lacking in terms of personal warmth.The location is arguably unbeatable. You're literally in the park (Shibakoen), within walking distance to the Tokyo Tower. I quite like the Daimon area: on the one hand there is the tourist landmark Tokyo Tower and Zojo-ji, on the other hand there is quite a collection of restaurants. Quiet yet conveniently close to actions.The hotel itself got the 1980s/1990s feel, and it might seem that its prime time was in the past. However, the staff is professional and the rooms are clean. Admittedly, the room decor is a bit beat-up, but the management seems to be doing their best to maintain.I booked this place literally on the day of check-in so there wasn't much of a choice in terms of room type, but I got the room at such a great price that it's almost a steal. You probably shouldn't expect to have the Tokyo stay of your life or a romantic stay at this hotel, but it certainly offers value for money at one of the best locations in the city.I would consider this place again either for business or personal stay.

This hotel is well located in a park in the city. There are a number of restaurants on site with excellent food. The rooms are spacious and comfortable with a great shower plus a jacuzzi bath. The sky bar has fantastic night time views of the communications tower and the Tokyo skyline. I didn't make it to the gym but was told there was an additional charge. I don't knowing this is common in japan but wouldn't have been happy with this.

The surrounding park, view of the Tokyo tower and the interiors were pleasant. It is good value for money, although please note the leisure facilities/ swimming pool is not included in the room price. It is separately priced at around 2400-6000yen depending on usage hours, no. of facilities used. In addition, it is not a family friendly establishment. The snobbish spa is managed separately from the hotel and did not allow entry apparently for under 20-years old. We were prepared to pay extra to swim in the pool, but when we brought ourselves in swim-gear down to the basement with our one year old well-behaved baby, we were told by the spa receptionist that unfortunately they do not allow children to use their facilities. While my husband and I were discussing who should stay to swim first, and who should take care of the baby first, the male receptionist rudely interrupted us and said literally "baby out". Our infant did not make any noise and had been sitting calmly in our lap while we were working out the logistics. We thought that poor English was not an excuse for the lack of manners. The receptionist behaved like he was a bouncer for a nightclub or as if we smelled. Maybe if you are American or European, the service is better. (We are Taiwanese). It was our first night ever in Tokyo, and for a country famed for its etiquette, we were shocked by the rebuff. On the upside, there is a good convenience store just inside the hotel which is open until 1am.

Stayed here for a week and loved this hotel! This is mostly a business hotel but although we were usually just in t-shirts and shorts the staff treated us the same as the business travelers. Very clean and comfortable rooms. Free shuttle to the metro. Hotel is located in a park so surrounding area is beautiful. Hotel restaurants & room service quite expensive but a short walk out the east exit of hotel takes you to Daimon district with small restaurants and lots of coffee places. Would stay here again when in Tokyo every time. Staff is very friendly and helpful. Was here with my son in a room with twin beds that were much larger than expected. Very comfortable too.

fantastic & very friendly hotel! just spent two days &would highly recommend. close to eveything. all the staff were welcoming! Breakfast was very healthy. pool excellent. Park like setting right in the heart of tokyo.

I stayed here for 5 days and my experience was wonderful amazement. This was my first trip to Japan and I was amazed by the hospitality and the servicemindedness (if that's a word) of the staff. I stayed in one of the premium rooms located on the 29th floor with a view of Roppongi. The intersection below was quite busy but with the balcony door closed it was not really noticeable. The room was spacious, the wifi was free and stable, the bathroom had both a shower and Jacuzzi. The breakfast on the 33rd floor was perhaps even better than the room. The staff (all of them!) greets you (much like every other place in tokyo but still) and the buffé was well stocked at all hours, I ate both early and late breakfasts during my stay. Obviously the view speaks for itself (see photo). I only tried the restaurant Shiba Zakura and it was very good, although somewhat on the expensive side for my wallet, but again, the staff was very helpful and watching the chefs prepare the courses was a nice experience.Access to and from the hotel is perhaps it's only drawback, from Narita airport it takes bout 2h with the limousine buss (fare is 3100 yen) and it leaves right outside on the hotel grounds and makes stops at both terminal 1 & 2 at Narita. There is also a Hanada line. I found it more convenient compared to the railway with a train switch needed at Tokyo Station. As you probably have read elsewere, don't even think of taking a taxi, the buss will take the same time but for a fraction of the cost.If you can bother walking for ~10 min you can get to some of the more connected subway lines at Daimon (Asakusa/Oedo line) or Toranomon (Ginza line) otherwise there is the Akabanebashi station just outside but the Oedo line isn't the 'best' line when it comes to access to the main attractions. Get a data sim card and just use google maps to navigate the stations and lines, it works perfect both with the Tokyo metro and the JR lines.

Stayed 10 days and loved it! The bed was huge so 2 adults and 5 year old can sleep comfortably. We were on 30smth floor, had a great view, even a small balcony. The service was good. Concierge was helpful. Has a little store in the lobby which was convenient for a snack or quick breakfast. Park in front. Metro close by. The restaurants in the hotel are however overpriced.

The Prince Park Tower tokyo located right in the heart of Tokyo, easy access to the sub-way to inner Tokyo. The hotel is unbelieveably closed to the Tokyo Tower. The view from certain wing of the hotel overlooked a public park. The staff are very helpful and traditionally Japanese style of service.
user_name:
Prasart P
Khon Kaen Province, Thailand

review_body: We stayed here for one night on a holiday in Japan, and we found it a real treat! The room we had was a corner room, with views across Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower, which was excellent. We didn't eat in the hotel, but we did go up to the bar for cocktails, which we sipped as the sun went down and the neon turned on. The facilities are well maintained, and everything was fresh and felt new. The bathroom had a jacuzzi bath, and you could look out over Tokyo whilst having a soak! There are leisure facilities (pool and gym) but as you had to pay for these separately we didn't bother using them, which was a bit disappointing. The surrounding area is fun, and we wandered into a few bars nearby. I'd stay here again (if I ever get to go back to Tokyo!!)

I stayed at this hotel for 2 nights. This hotel has 2 zone - premium zone and normal zone (and the premium zone has the elevator for their rooms that has to use the keycard for using the elevator).My room is big (for the Japanese Standard). There are the sofa, table, and other things. The toilet is separated for two rooms. The first one is the lavatory (automatic light and open the lavatory cover when you open the door) and the second is for the sink, shower box and bathtub. There are a few breakfast restaurant (the first morning, they offer 2 restaurants but the second morning, there are 3 restaurants for breakfast). On the 33rd floor, there are 2 restaurant, Panorama33 for buffet breakfast and the other is the American Breakfast Set. On the B1 floor, there is the breakfast restaurant for Japanese Set and there are the Japanese Style room for having the breakfast too.Some rooms can see the Tokyo Tower, but if you have breakfast on the 33rd floor (Panorama33), it's the panorama view and some tables also can see the Tokyo Tower.This hotel is near the two metro stations, walk around 6 minutes from the hotel. And they serve you the free shuttle bus to the JR station too.For the social media lover, they serve you the free wi-fi in room and in the public area.Near the hotel, there is the park and the temple that you can walk around in the morning.

Prince Park Tower has a great location. Very close to the metro stations and Tokyo Tower. On a very clear day, you can even see Mount Fuji from a distance.The rooms are small, but nothing unexpected as accodation in Japan in generally smaller than normal. The rooms are very well equiped. The Japanese really do think of everyhing, and are very meticulous to detail.The breakfast here is fantastic, with a wide variety of choices. Communication was a little difficult as some of the staff didn't understand basic English, but somehow we managed to get by. They were always polite and smiling, and it is hard to get annoyed at someone who bows to you constantly.

I stayed at the Prince Park Tower in Tokyo last week for business. I stayed for a week and found the property to be very livable.I took the deal which allowed access to the Executive lounge on the 33rd floor and this I found well worthwhile. The lounge is open for breakfast in a buffet style, tea / coffee refreshments during the day and then in the evening snacks and alcoholic refreshments all in a self serve format.The atmosphere is relaxing as well as being able to enjoy the views of Tokyo, including Tokyo Tower which feel like it is right outside the window. The room was well appointed with a toilet that had more electronic features than a Lexus. The bathroom was a good saize with both a shower cubicle as well as a bath with hand held shower nozzle.One trick worth remembering is that you can nominate to not have your your room cleaned and bed turned down for two out of three nights. They still take out the trash every day. You get rewarded with a JPY1,000 voucher per day which can be used in the hotel shops.The hotel is located in Shiba park, so there are no shops or restaurants on the immediate block. The nearest metra station is Shibakoen which is around 400 metres away.

The hotel is exceptionally good for business, although it wouldn't be my first choice for pleasure.The meeting rooms are very well organised and the variety of restaurants in the hotel is wide ranging. The views from the bar on the upper floor are also worth seeing.I didn't like the added costs on top of a very expensive hotel however. I didn't touch the gym due to the price and once in the bar, I was told that I would have to pay $100 if our group wanted to sit near to the window.

在東京市區要得到有浴缸且乾濕分離的旅館並不容易，此飯店設施並不算新但整理得好並且房型的視野都不錯。(確定16~20號房型都看得到鐵塔)＊餐飲：33樓平日中午人很少且有商業午餐。早餐時段人有點多，早餐卷可抵用午餐2500元左右。＊客房餐飲：便當豐盛，但要等待一點時間。＊住超過兩晚可選擇No-cleaning room package，仍會有人幫忙收垃圾，一個晚上贈用1000日圓折價券，可用於飯店內消費使用，個人很喜歡。＊游泳池與健身房使用一次要2000日圓，但使用後會再送一張使用卷，不知是否為常例。如是，就不顯貴了。＊交通：離赤羽橋站與芝公園站都很近，但要找餐廳和便利商店都有點距離，不過樓下有便利商店販賣紀念品和飲料麵包等生活用品尚可彌補此一缺憾。＊服務人員態度都很好，但英語溝通稍微複雜事務仍顯有些困難。

Clean hotel, helpful staff. Expensive add-on to use pool and gym, particularly since room rates are premium already. Just had a problem in checking in early. Extremely tired and asked to check in at 11.30 but would only allow it if we paid an additional $100. Left a sour taste to the experience.

This hotel Was Excellent and I would have no hesitation in booking it again if I were to go back to Tokyo . the hotel staff were very helpful and the little sho inside the hotel was great for convenience foods it ah a cocktail lounge at the top of the building where we had a few cocktails as nightcaps whilst we enjoyed the excellent night views over the city A bit late in posting this review we were there in January 2011

It was a wonderful stay at this hotel back in 2009. We felt the luxury everywhere. Electric curtains..., superb beds and a magnificent view from the bathtub. Close to the main metro lines makes it central as well. If you do not chose to have breakfast in the hotel it has got its own small shops where you van buy an roll and a cuppa to go.

Second time staying here for the amenities and convenience. Ten minute walk to the main train/subway station, 5 min cab ride to Tsujiki fish market (discipline needed for early am start), 15 min stroll to Tokyo tower etc. Food choices reasonable; nice brekky looking out to tower. Hotel shuttle functional but always some risk of missing it on return because of traffic near subway station. Request a corner room or one with tower views if you are into that sort of thing. On a clear day, Fuji San should be visible.

I've been a guest at this fantastic hotel for both private and business trips.Always greeted by friendly and attentive staff marking the start of a very special stay. Large well equipped rooms ..the half of which have a view on the Tokyo Tower which is literary 'in the garden' of the hotel.Magnificent breakfast buffet on the 33rd floor with a panoramic view of Tokyo and the Bay Area.The hotel is located a short walk from the Shibakoen Metro station and it's just a few stops to reach Ginza. Roppongi or any of the other districts of this fascinating city.The restaurants in the hotel are excellent but pricey...however it's only a five minute walk to Daimon where you can find a comprehensive selection of Japanese (and some western) restaurants.Always a luxury experience at a very reasonable price by Tokyo standards.

Very good location, near Tokyo Tower, great staff, very helpfull. Very good selection of good restaurants and bars. Very nice hotel to visit the town, shopping and business trip. Very nice park and beautiful temple near the hotel.

Great location inside a park that houses the Zojoji temple ( a jewel of the Edo or Shogun era).The staff and service were very friendly to us. The attendant showed us the room facilities with great detail. Dry cleaning, in room services all 24 hours. Three restaurants for breakfast with great and expeditious service. The quality of the room, bedding and food were excellent.

Stayed here are the beginning and the end of a great trip to Japan. V decent price for what you get. Massive hotel and geared towards business travelers but not in the hotel much so did not really matter. The room was large and the staff attentive. We asked to move room due to the smell of cigarettes and that was accommodated with no fuss. At the end of our trip (our 2nd stay) they upgraded us to a room on a higher floor with a fantastic view over Tokyo.Location is good. Transport is superb in Tokyo so never far from anywhere and we enjoyed the quiet local area for walks and local eateries. This hotel is massive though and is run like it. Didn't bother us but may not be for everyone.You have to pay for the pool/hot spa but it was not hugely expensive and meant it was very quiet. Also nice bar on a high floor for cocktails and drinks. I'm a non smoker but actually enjoyed being in a smoking bar again - v nostalgic!Would stay there again.

We stayed in both this and the Conrad Tokyo during our visit which is ranked #1 here on Trip Advisor, but I would actually put the Prince Park Tower above it in my estimation based on our stays at the two - for location, room quality and service.Our room was very large and spacious with a sitting area that was large in itself and balcony that had a gorgeous view of Tokyo, including the Tokyo Tower, which was right next door. The toilet was really hi tech - it opened when you entered the room! We got a real kick out of that. And flushed with a button on the same panel as the bidet options. And the bathroom was gorgeous. Marble, huge tub, powerful shower - maybe my favorite of the bathrooms we had on our Japan trip. Toilet was definitely the most hi tech of the toilets we encountered in all our hotels.It was very convenient to the train, with Akebanebashi subway stop very close and a free shuttle to the JR station and Daimon subway that was a little further away. (beware, the shuttle leaves exactly on time, to the second!) Even those were still very accessible without the shuttle by a 10-15 minute walk through a nice and interesting area with restaurants, grocery stores, coffee shops, amenities, and an interesting sense of Tokyo life in the area. There was a tranquil park around the hotel and a temple right next to it that were nice to view every day as we passed. There was also a bus stop nearby which I took one day to Shibuya. Very convenient to get anywhere you needed to go.Breakfast was absolutely delicious with a stunning view through floor to ceiling windows of the Tokyo Tower and surrounding skyline. But it wasn't included with our booking and was expensive so I only had it once during our 7 night stay. My favorite breakfast of the trip, including that at the Conrad and the Ritz Carlton Osaka. Definitely worth it at least once during your stay for the experience of the food and view. We didn't use the pool/spa facilities as they weren't included. Wifi was free and great. We had minimal contact with the staff but they were extremely polite and helpful whenever we did, and pleasant when we were passing.It had the vibe of being a "business hotel", at one point there was a big conference taking place downstairs for a phone company. It also seemed to be a wedding venue, or offer those services. Very bright and airy in the main areas and rooms. Muted cosy lighting in the hallway leading to the room, which gave it a warm, classy, burrow-y effect. Very serene. The hallway had windows looking out to the inside of the hotel so you could see all the floors going down in pods - very striking view. Beautiful fountain near the elevators, and glass walls on some of the elevators which was cool. There were lots of shops in the basement area, kind of a small mall area. We didn't really use them as they were quite high end but fun to walk through. We did make use of the hotel grocery store and bakery which had some delicious things. There was also a nail salon that my friend considered using. Ultimately went with a cheaper one in Shibuya but it was convenient if you wanted to get your nails done at the hotel. They also offer in room massages until 2am - not cheap but not bad and very convenient.All the hotel restaurants were gorgeous with great ambience and delicious food. The Japanese restaurant was incredibly ambient with serene little booths with traditional tables and mats and a little footpath over a stream leading to the booths as you walk through the restaurant. Had some lovely tempura there. Staff were great. My favorite meal of our entire Tokyo trip was at the Yakitori place, where we had mouthwatering grilled vegetables and Camembert. I got leeks, peppers, and asparagus a la carte as I'm vegetarian but there are set meals with multiple courses if you can eat anything. The ice cream for dessert was delicious too. Staff were extremely friendly and polite and seated us even when we arrived a few minutes before last orders one night. It was so good we went twice during our stay. Fun seating arrangement too, they cook the food in the middle right in front of you. All in all, would definitely return if I was looking to stay in this area of Tokyo again. It's quite near Roppongi Hills, not too far from Tsukiji. About half hour on the train from Shibuya and Shinjuku, a cab coming back from those areas late at night ended up costing about 2000 yen or less. Balcony and spacious room size were a highlight for me, as was the excellent choice of delicious food conveniently downstairs.Thank you for a nice stay!

We arrived from Australia in the morning so be aware that when checking in, you know that 2pm means 2pm...once we were in the room I thought the furniture was a little dated but for the price, it is really nice, clean and very comfortable.The bathroom was great, good spa bath and accessories. The pool and gym facility is pricey but the gym is extremely clean and well equipped. We were given a free voucher for the second day so that made the price of approx AUD $20 per person/per day and per area (gym, pool, sauna) more palatable. The breakfast on the 33rd floor made for great city viewing and a really lovely experience and great service.

We enjoyed this hotel but it has no free pool and gym. You must pay around 30€ per person per day for this, and this equipment is slightly far for comfort (around 300 meters). The concierge make too many mistakes and have a fairly poor mastering of English. Breakfast is good in the top floor restaurant with a great view. Good rooms

I stayed here for business and the hotel was great with good service. Good size rooms and bathroom. The business lounge was good to work in between meetings and the bar has some great views of Tokyo Tower

My husband had been to Tokyo dozens of times before I managed to go with him. He said all the rooms are tiny. That was till I found The Prince Park Tower! The rooms were large, comfortable, and even had a verandah. Ok this didn't mean we could sit outside, but we were able to open up the door fully, which gave us a great breeze and a way of taking some fantastic night shots of Tokyo. The location was also amazing with three train stations, all within a 500 metre walk of our hotel. My husband and his company now use this hotel (which is less than a kilometre from their office) for all business trips to Tokyo. Great Find!

I stayed at Prince Park Tower a couple of years ago for a business trip. The location - very close to Tokyo tower, in the Shiba Koen neighborhood - is quite convenient if you are looking to spend time outside the business district; for a pure business trip I would recommend something located in Marunouchi. As for service/amenities, no complaints, very solid all around. Rooms were quite large for a Tokyo hotel, and service was excellent as you would expect.
user_name:
Jeremy R
New York City, New York

review_body: Good hotel beside tokyo tower so nice view at my balcony.for staff very very helpful for me,but im first time at japan.hotel nearby to train station.so im want back to japan and stay at the prince tokyo again.thank u very much

Besides the view of Tokyo Tower from the hotel, the rooms are nice and clean. I love the bathroom that has windows facing out to the skies and a bathtub, and the range of toiletries provided is high quality (Ella Barche,,, my hair never felt so soft and smooth.. retailed at hotel shop if I saw it correctly,at Yen 2,700 for 500ml) The hotel staff (Concierge in particular) is highly helpful and important for your stay because a lot of the bookings/websites are still in Japanese. Ms Miyakawa (hope I spelt it right) was fabulously helpful and for a local, her English is considered highly fluent. They can also help you store the luggage for the day.For breakfast, my favourite is FoieGras Omelette.. lovely, with nice crunchy fresh salads and breads/soups. Even Dine in room service is good, the seafood pasta, clam chowder are good too.For sleep, they have alternate pillows (eg. down pillow, foam and other hard support pillows)On transport, the subway Akabanebashi is nearby (5 mins walk), which is the E21 on the Oedo line. This line can take you directly to Shinjuku E27, Roponggi E23, Ueno E09, directly

Stayed in this hotel for a week. Service is excellent in all aspects; there is nothing you can fault. Adjacent park creates a very nice setting around the hotel. Rooms are of a very good size and bathroom is huge, with a bathtub and big size shower cabinet. Minor inconvenience is that you have a kettle in the room but an assortment of teas and infusions; no coffee. One English channel and news channel; everything else in Japanese. Very good wifi everywhere in the hotel.Breakfast room on the 33rd floor with excellent views of Tokyo and Tokyo Tower. Breakfast is very decent and service impeccable.Asian restaurants in the basement of very high quality.Hotel can arrange bus service to both airports around Tokyo at very good prices and free shuttle service to shopping areas. Taxis readily available within the hotel.Overall a great stay and would definitely reommend it

Fantastic hotel with large, Western style rooms with great views. Marble bathrooms, comfortable bedding, really an enjoyable place to visit. The service is fantastic and the restaurant options in the hotel are really good (and diverse). I've tried the Chinese restaurant, and the Yakitore restaurant, all were great. They have a great bar that looks out over a waterfall, a perfect place to unwind after a long day. Breakfast on the 33rd floor can bet pretty insane at 7 when it opens, I found it best to wait an hour or so to let the crowd die down, or do room service. All in all, I highly recommend this hotel to anyone.

Stayed here for 1 night. A good western sized room with great service. Hotel is a 15 minute walk to Hamamatsucho JR station. They also run an hourly bus shuttle to station. Breakfast buffet in 33rd floor with great view. I found it a reasonable value and good location.

Located near the Tokyo Tower in Tokyo, I found this hotel perfectly located as a starting point to almost anywhere in Tokyo. It was close to the metro and it seemed most of the businesses I had to meet with were within eye-shot of the Tokyo Tower, so they were note far away at all. The hotel itself was super well maintained, quiet, elegant, clean, updated, and elegant. The restaurants were excellent, especially the breakfasts, and there were other great places to grab a coffee or a snack with excellent views of the Tokyo Tower. The staff were very helpful on anything you needed. My room was fabulous. I was upgraded to a room with a Master bed, and it was one of the nicest rooms I have ever had in Tokyo. It had a full separate living room with bar and expansive views, it had a dining room area which also included great views, and exercise bike with towels and water, 1.5 baths with shower and jacuzzi tub, and a separate bedroom with a balcony overlooking the park below. Everywhere in the hotel was peaceful and quiet. Overall great place to be before and after a busy work day in Tokyo.

I stayed at the hotel for a weekend with friends. The value for the price and quality of the hotel was unbeatable for Tokyo, as it's the most expensive city in the world. I really enjoyed that it was right across the street from the Tokyo Tower and that it was close by to Rappongi. There was also the Yamanote train line in case we needed to venture out further. Very clean hotel - recommended!

This might be one of the nicest hotels I've ever stayed at (of course, I usually stay in pretty cheap hotels). The bed was huge. Wider than it was long, and the room was very nice with a nice view of the tokyo tower, especially at night. The staff was also very friendly.

A very comfortable and modern hotel in a great location, right across the Tokyo Tower. Wonderful view of the Rainbow bridge from one side and Tokyo Tower to the other. The staff is excellent and very up to the task, with a very competent concierge. The restaurants in the hotel are upscale in prices but not worth it. You have to pay daily for gym use unless you are in one of the premium floors. I understand that though as they have over 600 rooms and it would be impossible to satisfy all the guests. Location-wise, the hotel is about 200 meters from Akabanebashi station, but also the hotel has a shuttle that takes you to Hamamatsuchuo station, the underground setup is so good that it doesn't really matter where you go from. Roppongi is just around the corner and the possibilities of good food are infinite...

Having travelled dozens of times to Tokyo on business, and stayed at various - expensive - hotels, this time was pleasure and I was looking for a nice hotel without paying 1000$ a night or something. Looking at the TA reviews I choose this. It's 25 mins walk from ginza, so close enough. The hotel is of a retro architecture which is actually quite sweet. Price-wise it was great value. The room had a fab view over the Tokyo tower, was sufficiently big and the bathroom had both a shower and a bathtub. Breakfast was great value for the good selection it offered. The gym was about 20$ but it had a decent selection of cardio and weight machines. The same for the pool - also 20$. Definitely staying again next time. We arrived at 8am, check in was 2pm, they let us get into our room for an extra 100$ which was fair.

Stayed here a 2nd time this past March ('14). Found it the same as the first: perfectly delightful, esp. for a big businessmen's hotel. The staff is typical Japanese: courteous beyond reproach, helpful and in English too, accommodating to your every need. The rooms are spacious and include all the usual deluxe accoutrements: valet stand, kimonos, deluxe toiletries, ultra-deluxe hands-off toilet, shower, separate tub, etc. All clean as a whistle. I found day cleaning and dry cleaning to be cheaper than most hotels and perfectly efficient. They attempt to help the environment by offering a $10/day rebate if you don't need new sheets every day. This rebate can be used in their restaurants (4 I believe) or even their sundry shop for incidentals...really a smart and helpful idea. The hotel is convenient to 2 subway lines, sits in the shadow of the Tokyo tower amid a park setting, most unusual for a Tokyo hotel. All in all, a great, reasonable ($200+) place from which to visit Tokyo anytime of year.

Stayed here in Feb and found it fine. Swimming pool is NOT for kids so a massive disappointment - adults only. Rooms are comfy and spacious. Breakfast is fantastic and hotel has a shop to buy last minute necessities. A short stroll to Akanebashi station, it's not the most prime location but is right next to Tokyo tower (the bar is fab and the best for this view) however ask for rooms facing the tower otherwise the view is the hotel reception taxi rank.

Very nice modern hotel with spacious rooms, balconies on some and very large bathrooms (separate bath and shower). Beds were very comfortable and service quite good. Location is about 1km from nearest jr line though a local line is a bit closer, there is a regular hotel shuttle bus that's free and runs until about 9pm. I've stayed in a few different parts of Tokyo before but will definitely stay her again if prices remain consistent.

We visited Tokyo on holiday a few weeks ago and a friend who had stayed here on business recommended this hotel to us. Since Tokyo is so huge there isn't really a central location to stay in but this hotel is close to 3 underground stations and we found it very easy to navigate to everywhere that we wanted to go to . There aren't many restaurants close by and the hotel restaurants are quite dear (specifically beer and wine) but I was very happy with this hotel and I thought that the rate that I got ( through tripadvisor) meant that I paid about two thirds, possible half, of the price of an equilivent London hotel.
user_name:
Sheena M
Lytham St Anne's, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed at this hotel for two nights as park of a Japan Deluxe Tour package. Our family was traveling with several others, in late March. We arrived after 8pm to discover a COOL room, which is fantastic, since most hotels in Japan do not turn on the A/c at that time of year, much less do it before you get to your room. We were so pleased with our room, which had a spectacular view of the Tokyo tower, and we also found that we had a view of the shrine behind the hotel as well. The beds were very comfortable, the bathroom was excellent and clean, and the room was nice and quiet. There was even a nice futon/sofa we were able to fold out for our son. In the morning, we had an excellent breakfast at the hotel restaurant on the upper floor, overlooking the cityscape below. The food was delicious and plentiful, and top notch service. As part of the tour package, we were only in our room from 8pm to 8am, so we didn't get to explore the rest of the hotel's facilities. We had a nice stay, and would recommend this hotel again. A side note, as an English speaking traveler with only 3 months of Japanese lessons, I found that the amount of Japanese that I had was enough to get us through. All of the staff was polite and helpful.

Great location, great service, great stay - I was updated and stayed in a suite, huge rooms, great view, two small balconies - room design a little dated. Great bar at the top floor at Tokyo upper Hotel prices - will certainly return.

The Prince Park Towers has provided us with everything that was expected from the local hospitality and service. Everything they provide is of a high standard, yet it is more a hotel for business men than for families. No provision is made for kids items on the food menus, plus all facilities including the swimming pool are for adults only. Prior information on these items would have influenced my choice to stay here in the first place.

Stayed here few days for business. Over all ok... just a little bit cold in terms of ambient. Staff very kind and professional. Room not very big (but we are in Japan) but comfortable and clean. Not very international channel on the tv though... I was forced to watch a Sumo championship that was for sure interesting but I would probably preferred something different.

We recently stayed at this lovely hotel for a few days on a trip to see the Cherry Blossom in Japan. We had a corner room on the 28th floor, an amazing view of Tokyo, the bed was huge, you could draw back the curtains at night and go to sleep with all Tokyo sparkling below you. Magic!!!.The service was excellent and the food was first class, the Japanese restaurant on the lower floor was particularly good! There are gardens surrounding the building which include a temple, was surprised to realize that most of this was a roof terrace as there are garages and restaurants below ground level! We spent a day in the Emperors Garden which is all the more surprising for having a backdrop of skyscrapers behind all the views of beautifully maintained traditional Japanese Gardens with spectacularly pruned ancient trees, there is a large pool that contained many huge Koi Carp, these are special in having bushy eyebrows and spectacular flowing tails!! We also took a trip on a boat along the river which is always a different way to see such a city, there are pockets of "old Japan" between the modern skyscrapers, many restaurants around so that one can dine very reasonably or splash out occasionally, the city is spotlessly clean, indeed the whole country seems to be the same, I came back with over 500 photographs and cannot find one with any rubbish at all, except cherry blossom, camellia and peony petals that had fallen to the ground in the gardens!!

I stayed at this hotel for the second time and loved it. Tokyo Tower and Zojo-ji temple and plenty of public transportation are just around the corner. If you come via Narita airport the Limousine Bus brings you from door to door.The staff is very attentive and helpful. Breakfast is great and on a good day you see Mount Fuji from the specialty breakfast room.I head a very spacious corner room overlooking Zojo-ji and the surrounding gardens.I stayed for a 2 week business trip and really enjoyed it.

Got a fantastic rate for this hotel on the internet ($170 vs usual rack rate of double that).Well located to attractions such as the Tokyo Tower & Zojo-ji temple within a short walk. The subway station is also only a 10 minute walk - so it's easy to access the rest of Tokyo as well. Our room was very big, modern and clean with great nighttime views of Tokyo Tower. Staff were always very helpful and overall our stay was very easy. I would have given this hotel a 5 star rating except for the unexpected shock of an extra $25 to use the gym (which I didn't).

I stayed in this hotel overnight and wish that I had longer. The hotel is perfectly situated in Minato. The staff are very professional and helpful. The view from my room was a stunning cityscape. The amenities are exactly what you would expect from a hotel of this class. I highly recommend it.

Revisit to Tokyo after living there 15+ years ago. 2 rooms for family with two teens. We all loved the hotel ... Rooms were great in nice park setting and location was perfect for either walking to familiar surrounding areas or various subway lines. Staff and service was as expected attentive and always helpful. In-hotel Yakitori restaurant was very good and we appreciated the hotel guest rate. Hotel is priced right + highly recommend.

I stayed this hotel last year, and I loved it! The view of my room was fantastic. I had tea time at night, and breakfast in the morning with beautiful Tokyo tower view;) I didn't have to go to any other observatories! Also the bed was super super big. Probably 4~5 women can sleep on it at once. Bathroom was clean and convenient, too. It is easy to go because they have free shuttle bus toward subway station. The reception is really comfortable. There are sofa for each guest, so you can sit on it while your check-in is being processed. You need room key when you open the automatic door in front of room elevator. I feel safety when I saw it. Finally, the staffs were all nice to me. They were polite and kind:) Thank you for all.When I travel again to Tokyo, I can strongly mention that I will choose this hotel again!

The hotel is located in the park surrounded by beautiful blossom trees.The hotel rooms are so much larger than usual hotel rooms and are very comfortable. I can't imagine that there are any rooms with a bad view. Higher rooms have a view of Tokyo Tower on one side or the temple and Tokyo Skytree in the distance. I presume that lower floors see the treesbin the park. On one occasion we were upgraded to a junior sweet which had a California king bed. The other room had a king bed which was more comfortable than the California. It may be that the mattress was newer. The decor in the rooms is dated but given the amenity it didn't bother me. The restaurants we tried were good and there is a good selction. The only issue is that while the hotel is walking distance from Rapongi (to the hotel that is; too steep to walk the other way) it is not that close to other major centres in Tokyo. The service is excellent. The staff are attentive and professional. The view is spectacular from the top floor bar but if you are a non smoker beware. The smoke is oppressive. Would love to stay there again price permitting.

Although I did not stay at the hotel, whilst visiting a friend that lived there we were regulars at the a number of the restaurants within the hotel and the bar on the top floor. The service and food was absolutely perfect, could not fault it! It is something though, that could only be experience properly if you have quite quite deep pockets as its expensive. (£9 for 1/2 pint in the top floor bar) That being said, as the old saying goes, you get what you pay for. This could not be more true, although towards the higher end, the experience is definitely worth it.

Nice view ,clean and luxury. Staffs are polite and very helpful. The hotel just right next to the tokyo tower. Nothing in this hotel disappointed me only It needs to walk a bit for the metro ;) they also have taxi in front of the hotel
user_name:
zan585
Chiang Mai, Chiang Mai, Thailand

review_body: Great hotel, very nice stuff, clean and very spacious rooms. Stayed in a "park type" of room which is the lowest level (they go 3 levels up to "Royal Type") and it was great. They are equipped with a hot tub with bubble function which is very relaxing after long sightseeing walks and a walk in shower. Very nice toiletries even with bath salt to relax your body and feet ;) My room had an astonishing view on the Tokyo tower and temple complex behind the hotel park. Breakfast on the top level of the hotel was included and it is really great in all aspects - great food, nice stuff and a great view on the busy city from above. I would recommend this hotel to everybody. The basement level has big conference and wedding rooms and a nice sushi restaurant. You can even bowl in the hotel bowling club. I liked the stay very much.

We have stayed at Prince Park Tower three times now and have had good experiences all three times. The staff is very nice and helpful and the rooms are comfortable. Each time I had business nearby, thus this choice of location in Tokyo. Metro access is okay but requires connections more than we experienced from other hotels elsewhere in Tokyo. Tokyo Tower and the adjacent temple and park areas are worthy destinations in themselves and ironically were destinations for us the year before we first stayed at Prince Park Tower. The hotel store has a good selection of quick breakfast items (bakery things, yogurt, etc) and there is a nice market a short walk to the northwest on Sakurada Dori. On this year's visit we had dinner at the restaurant atop the hotel one night, and the view and food were fabulous (although expensive). Of note, there was no bar soap in our room, which I prefer, and the toilet (with a mini sink) is completely detached from the bathroom (both connect only to the bedroom), which is unusual but okay. Last year when we visited someone said to check out the amazing car collection in the garage, and we did, and we suggest you do too.

I really like this hotel - the rooms are very spacious and nicely furnished. The bathrooms are large and inviting. I've been in 3 different rooms and each time the views were very nice - maybe not always the "picture postcard" views of Tokyo Tower or Mount Fuji, but still good. As usual the staff are exceptionally wonderful and always attentive. They really make this a high-end hotel with their work.The breakfast can be a challenge to attend on weekends when the hotel is super busy - lines can stretch for the buffet on the 33rd floor. Also, don't think that getting up to make the opening door will help you avoid the crowds... you aren't the only one thinking that. If anything aim for the middle or near the end to make sure you can get in. The Japanese breakfast was an awesome experience, but be sure you know what Japanese breakfast is before you go... it isn't a menu-based situation. (Fish, rice, miso, etc.)I'm a bit frustrated by the neighborhood this hotel sits in - there simply aren't any convenience stores or restaurants in the area. Given that I actually have a budget, I couldn't bring myself to eat dinners in the hotel so I had to travel some distance or make sure I ate before I came to the room. It *is* close to a station with Oedo line, so it's not all lost.

The Prince Park Tower is ideally situated in the center of Tokyo. It is located in a Park in a more residential type neighborhood so it is quiet and relaxing, yet it is close to all the tourist areas (Imperial Palace, Erbisu, Rippongo, etc.). It is also close to public transportation.I highly recommend this hotel. It is clean and comfortable, has great views, the service is superb, the fitness center top notch. This hotel has the best lap pool I have ever seen in a hotel.Also has a very nice restaurant/bar up top with exquisite views.

Enormous room with a view of Mt Fuji, excellent food and service, very busy hotel but staff were excellent nothing too much trouble.Arranged for tours and external restaurants even booked these for me.Next time I am in Japan this is the hotel I will use.

Spent a week in this nice big hotel. Big very beautiful room on 15th floor, comfy beds. Balcony (not big, but still). Lot of restorants, services and shops in hotel, pool. Tokyo Tower nearby.For daily travelling we used mostly Hamamatsucho station on Yamanote line, 10 min walk or use hotel bus. Also several Toei metro stops are close.Did not order breakfast, but bought sandwiches, fresh croissants, yogurts and coffee in hotel shop/bakery and enjoyed meal in Shiba park.Appreciated a lot that they gave 1000 yen coupons on days we marked as non-cleaning days. So nice. Good Wifi in room.

A very pleasant stay at this hotel, which is located a few minutes walk away from several metro stations, making it very easy to get around the city. The reception and bell desk staff are extremely efficient, helpful and polite and this made my stay a very pleasant one. The room that I stayed in (on the 20th floor) had a great view of the Tokyo Tower and was very spacious and clean. It's also very handy that there's a convenience shop near the hotel lobby that is open until 1am. A very comfortable stay and I look forward to staying at this hotel again the next time that I'm in Tokyo.

I loved the stay at the Prince Park Tower hotel - the restaurants at the top of the bldg having stunning views, having a breakfast there is an expierence. The pool and spa are not free and actually very expensive and you should consider this before booking the hotel. Rooms are spacious and nice and the jacuzzi in bathroom is amazing. The service is very high standard. I would surely come back if I ever come back to Japan. Another plus is that the Narita airport bus stops at this hotel. There is a direct metro line to Ginza and a direct one to Roppingi and Shinjuku which is a big plus. One day I even walked from the Roppongi hills back to the hotel. Closeby is an area called Mita with lots of little shops and nice restaurant.

We stayed for our honey moon, they put a biscuit box in our room, it was a nice gesture. The hotel is well situated, it was easy to travel into Tokyo. On our check-in, we had a room with smoke smells, they change us for another room and it was ok then. We enjoyed the swimming pool! maybe the rate for it was a little expensive bu it's Tokyo! isn't it?..

Very smart hotel, clean, glass elevator and you can't beat the automatically opening toilet!Great views to the Tokyo radio tower both day and night. Very good breakfast selection.Top floor bar offers a comfortable environment with good views across the city but be aware, it is expensive.I would stay here again and it is somewhere that suits both the businessman or the family.

I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo.It is located a few minutes walk away from a few different metro stations, so has options for travel. It is also located in a really nice quiet part of town, with Parks and temples near by for you to take a look at.This hotel comes with arguably the best view in Tokyo.
