It was the sole reason i stayed here and it did not let me down in the slightest.The room was a decent size, comparable to a King Executive in the Hilton. However, the bathroom is a real 5* bathroom, modern, equipped and lavish, unlike the Hilton, which was small and dated. The bed was really comfortable also.

From the reception to the room, everything perfect!Japanese cordiality is difficult to surmount. We really enjoyed being treated as royalty.One convenience store in the hotel premises adds comfort.We intend to go back

We found our stay at the Prince Park tower pleasant considering the reasonable rates we obtained. It is situated in a nice uptown neighbourhood and next to a large park while just a couple blocks away and prominently in view is the Tokyo Tower. The hotel is also an easy 10 mins walk from the underground.The rooms were reasonably large and had plenty of room to put the suitcases down and still be able to move around without bumping into furniture. While the room was clean and tidy the decor was uninspiring and plain. The beds were a bit on the hard side which seems to be a standard feature anyway in most hotels in the land of the rising sun. One problem we did have was with the A/C. On some days the room temperature was stuck at 23 and as hard as we tried we could not get it cooler. On other days the room temperature did go below 23 but never as low as we had set the thermostat. It did cause us to have some sleepless nights.One awkward feature of the triple room we stayed in was the toilet being separate from the bathroom meaning that you either had to always keep 2 sets of handwash kits or you had to constantly switch rooms in order to stay hygienic. The toilet was also similar in size to what you would find on a Boeing 777 meaning you had to fold your newspaper several times to read a small column without it always wrapping up the side of the walls. The best way to get to the hotel from Tokyo station is by taxi which will cost almost JPY 2,000. If you only have small hand luggage then it can be easily reached from either the Shibakoen or the Akabanabashi station. Both stations have signs pointing you to the correct exit.

My husband and I spent two nights in Tokyo this past fall at the Prince Park Tower. The property is very large and very convenient. We were able to easily access the metro and had no difficulty finding a place to eat close by. We were given an upgrade upon check-in as my husband mentioned we were on our honeymoon. The room was very big and well maintained with a fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower however our king bed was actually two twin beds separately made and pushed together. This would probably be my only complaint regarding our experience there.There is a gift shop in the hotel that is full of delicious freshly baked goods as well as other grocery items. This was a lifesaver for breakfast and made our stay even more comfortable.I would recommend this hotel.

The hotel is right next to Tokyo tower & a huge park right around it. It was our first time in Tokyo & we were expecting concrete building right next to each other and small rooms. To our surprise there was so much greenery and open area around it & the room size was bigger than the average 5 star. The bed was one of the biggest I have seen. There is a grocery cum bakery on the lobby level which is very convenient. Only disadvantage is that there are no restaurants or stores very close by.

Very modern and conveniently located Hotel in Tokyo. We had a junior suite in the 20th floor with the most amazing views. The rooms were large with all amenities including the infamous Japanese robot toilettes and expresso machines and whirlpool tub. Slightly miffed at having to pay extra ($10) to use gym and pool, any hotel which is 5* should allow guests to use facilities without additional payment! Hotel restaurants were also over-prized and not highly rated.

We "hotwired" here for our first night in Tokyo. Room was quite large. Good views. Excellent amenities. Whirlpool tub and separate shower. Also completely separate room for toilet with sink. Excellent selection of free teas/coffees including lattes. Area is just fair. nothing nearby for breakfast. Our next few nights in Tokyo were at the Conrad using points. Quite frankly, the room here was as good, but not so the location, at 1/4 the retail price.

+ve*the view is the main thing and this is why we chose this hotel as our room looked right out onto the Tokyo Tower - night or day it looks pretty cool.*we had very early starts so opted for breakfast in the room. The pricing was slightly strange whereby if you went for a full continental it would be very expensive, whereas if you selected a few things here and there it was reasonable. It was also the only service we took advantage of and found it very efficient.*the concierge was very helpful with maps and directions.-ve*the room was extremely tired and dated. The carpet has definitely seen better days and had signs of previous spillages. It was generally clean and tidy but this was the main reason for marking it down from 5*.*the location is not amazing and it's quite a far walk to get to a tube station - there is one just past the park but to get to the good attractions, you will want to get to Daimon station, which is about a 10 min walk. If travelling on train from the airport, the station you get off at is just past Daimon so perhaps 15 minutes walking. We did that will big cases and it felt like a long way.Knowing what I know now, would I have booked this hotel? No. I'd have booked somewhere in trendy Ginza and have booked sooner as this was one of very few options in the city.

I flew to Tokyo on business in April, and stayed at The Prince Park Tower. My accommodations were very comfortable. The staff was amazing. The western morning buffet was delicious. I was able to convert my US dollars downstairs, the deli was delicious, the on site resteraunts were impressive. My bed was very comfortable and I had a beautiful view of the Tokyo tower.i would most definitely stay at this location again.

Staying in the Prince park tower hotel is value for money, the hotel is excellent an amazing, hotel staff is very polite with smile. Restaurant food is good, view is beautiful, you can see the park and Tokyo Tower.

Stayed in Prince Park Tower over 3 nights for 3 people. Triple room was booked and we were very gratefully upgraded to a suite room at check in. As we had got an excellent rate on Jalan.net we felt like this was extremely good value. The room was perfect for our needs. One main bedroom with twin beds and ensuite bathroom and a connecting room with a single bed, living area and own bathroom and toilet. Very large space with great amenities, 2 huge televisions and a stunning bathroom equipped with spa bath. Not to mention a lovely view! Free Nespresso coffee was a nice touch. Amenities were the best I have seen so far in Japan. Hotel service was excellent, polite and efficient. All our needs were attended to and understood. Touring the hotel was fun and had a very nice feel. We loved the 1000yen per day no cleaning service. We used this money to buy breakfast at the bakery which was delicious. Can't think of a negative at this point. Thank you Prince Park Tower for a great stay. Can’t wait to be back.

We were lucky enough to receive an upgrade to a suite (thank you!!!) and the room was amazing. Two balconies with an incredible view over the city which was perfect for our final night in Tokyo. We did not eat in the hotel as it seemed a bit expensive but we did go for a drink at the rooftop lounge. View is incredible from there too! Would love to go back anytime. For the money, the hotel was fabulous.

We've stayed in the Prince Prince Park Hotel for 10 days,the staff was extremely polite,the room was huge,we could sleep very well,the bathroom was large,we had a wonderful view,the subway station was close and convenient .The hotel organised a one-day trip to the Fuji Mountain and also a one-day trip to Nikko,both were marvelous.We visited almost everything in Tokyo including Disneyland and wonderful Kabuki-za theatre.We highly recommend this hotel and Japan's worth as a once-in-a-lifetime trip!

I love to Travel and have stayed at a lot of Hotels over the years and this hands down was my favorite stay in any Hotel so far.Service: Outstanding! Before I even walked into the hotel I was kindly greeted and helped inside with my luggage. I arrived very early and my room was not ready but they proactively checked my bag and pointed me in the direction I wanted to go. When I came back they quickly got me checked in and escorted me up to my room. During my stay I had nothing but great interactions with all of the staff I came across. My poor ability at Japanese language was no problem as most workers spoke very good English.Room: I was upgraded to a corner view on the upper levels which was sensational. I had an amazing view of Rainbow Bridge and Zojo-ji plus inner Tokyo. I spent 5 wonderful days looking out at the sunrises and beautiful cityscape. The bathroom and room size were very large for Japan and the jacuzzi tub felt amazing after long days of walking and exploring Tokyo.Price: This was an incredible value for the view and service at the Hotel. I am not saying it was cheap but for Tokyo for this large of a room and that view it was a sensational value.Location: It is a 7-10 minute walk to Tokyo Tower and 5 minutes to Zojo-ji Temple. It is located in a lovely park as well. It is just a 5 minute walk to the Mita subway Line at Shibakoen station or 5 minute walk to the Oedo subway line at the Akabanebashi station. From these 2 stations it is very easy to get around Tokyo. The taxi ride from Tokyo Station to the hotel was not too long or expensive either.The only downside was there are not a lot of nearby places to dine apart from the Hotel (there are some places inside Tokyo tower to grab a bite). This was not a problem for me as the Hotel had a convenience store for breakfast and I ate out while exploring the city. Roppongi is just a few minutes away by train as are many other locations.I will stay at this hotel again every time I visit Tokyo from now on if possible. (This was my 5th time in Tokyo)

Stayed in the Prince Park Tower Hotel, room 2425, for a week over New Year. The room was very big and spacious with an enormous and very comfortable king size bed. The room was well equipped with free tea facilities replenished daily, mini bar, and a large flat screen TV. The marble bathroom had a jet spa bath and a separate shower and of course a remote controlled heated toilet! From the room's balcony you can see across to Mt Fuji in the distance. The immaculately clean and well located hotel is located in Shiba Park a very quiet location despite being in the middle of Tokyo. The hotel is right beside both the Tokyo Tower and the Zojo-ji Temple. Staff were friendly and polite. Contrary to other reviews the hotel is located equidistant between two subway stations - Akabanebashi (on the Odeo line which runs directly to Shinjuku in one direction and Ueno in the other) is diagonally across the road from the main entrance. The other station being Onarimon (on the Mita line).The hotel has a very handy shop and patisserie in the foyer that is open until late. I would definitely stay here again and having stayed in Shinjuku previously would say this was now my preferred option.

This hotel was very high end, wonderful room, spacious, nice amenities, staff however did not speak much English. I had a question and was handed off to 3 different staff members, none of which understood my question.Hotel is a distance from the main attractions. It's do-able, but car is better.

The property is impressive, the staff is excellent, the location superb (close to two subway stations) and the views from rooms on the higher stories spectacular. Because of the location in the park and views of the Tokyo tower from many of the rooms, the rooms are super quiet and a good nights sleep is guaranteed. Check in and check out, Concierge performance and room service speed and reliability exceptional. The bed is comfortable, the bathroom large and spotless and internet speed excellent. However, on the downside, the televisions are old and require immediate upgrade and replacement, the programming has 50 Japanese stations, one Korean channel, and the only English speaking channel (CNN) which has a live dub over in Japanese so you can’t understand it! Come on, this is an international city! Where’s channels with English, German, French and everything else in between! Also, although we did not have breakfast at the hotel, we did have sushi at their Japanese restaurant one night and it was overpriced and not very good. On top of that, they charge you $20 to use their average gym! The hotel falls short of being a world class destination, but with some focused improvements, has the potential to be a great property and we hope they will use their profits (hotel was fully booked) to make this a premier destination to be highly recommended.

The Prince Park Tower Tokyo hotel has two important assets: Tokyo Tower and the Zojoji Temple. Both are a few minutes walk from the hotel. Other than that the neighbourhood is very inconvenient.There's a subway station nearby (Shibakoen), but it isn't connected to very popular lines (only "Mita"). This means daily lengthy subway rides involving multiple train changes. The Price Park offers compensation: there's a regular free bus line to a bigger subway station ("Hamamatsucho") that does connect to the more popular lines.If you travel by car, the Park Tower is easy to reach (very close to the "Express way") and offers ample parking space.Even the nearest supermarket is farther away than usual in Tokyo. To compensate the hotel has it's own little supermarket, but product sizes are small while prices are high.The only restaurants nearby are located inside the hotel itself. Together these five (!) restaurants cannot serve a single vegetarian meal. I had to eat peanuts from the supermarket as "dinner". Shame on you Prince Park Tower Tokyo!The lobby looks very classy and there's lots of personnel available to help. I've used the concierge service more than once and every time he/she performed flawlessly. As it should be in a hotel in this price range.The room was a disappointment at first. It looks very dated, almost like a museum for rent. As it turns out older customers appreciate this and flocked to this hotel for public holidays. No matter what your taste is: the room is very spacious. Internet, both by cable or wifi, is free. During my one week stay the speed of the connection varied from reasonably quick to dead slow.The thing I appreciated most was the balcony. Most tall buildings don't have balconies and if they do the door / window is locked. The Prince Park Tower offers accessible balconies at high floors with an amazing view of the city. I couldn't stop myself from taking pictures out there almost every day!Another nice detail: there's a button near the frig (mini bar) to turn it off, so it doesn't make any noise during the night. Since the hotel is in a quiet neighbourhood anyway, expect long quiet nights.The hotel is remarkably conscious about the environment. One can refuse cleanup of the room every other day. This isn't just good for the environment but also for your wallet, because the hotel will give a 1,000 yen coupon. The hotel slippers are dry cleaned and thus reusable. When the air con is off when leaving the room, it remains off when re-entering the room later (most hotels turn it on by default). Very good!The Prince Park Tower is connected to the "airport limousine" (bus) service to the airport. Signing up was easy and the ride to Narita took 2 hours (it is a very inconveniently located airport, no matter where you are in Tokyo).

Stayed 2 nights on premier floor. New hotel, that means everything is shining here. spacious bathroom, wall to ceiling window with a tiny balcony(but it's rare in Tokyo), modern with elegance.Great view. No high rise building nearby. my room was facing toward rainbow bridge. Gorgeous view. If your room is on the opposite side, you also have a great Tokyo tower view which is right next to this hotel.Lobby, spacious room, central location, delicious breakfast (great quality of food, though $30 is a little expensive for breakfast).Stayed several nice hotels in Tokyo previously, but this is one of the few hotels that deserve 5 stars.
user_name:
TravelProNY
New York City, New York

review_body: The location of this hotel is great and Tokyo Tower view rooms are good size for Tokyo. Cost seems up and down by season as usual. One disappointment is amenity is poor. Despite paying about $250 a night, they charged for Coffee/tea in the room. I have hardly seen tea/coffee is charged in any brand hotel. Spa/Gym all cost additional $$. Zero kid activities. The corner room was extremely cold in the winter, had to ask for blanket and child nightwear. The restaurant and bar was nice and housekeeping and restaurant staffs provide high quality service. Around- Tokyo tower is just 2 min walking distance, lot of food options there. On 1F lobby there is also hotel store, that carries lot of supplies. Morning breakfast on the 33F is also awesome on a shiny day.

I cannot say enough about this great hotel.From check in to check out we had fabulous stay. Room facing Tokyo tower,jacuzzi in the bathroom, excellent breakfast, amazing japanese hospitality, great location for the decent price ensure you will have a great time in Tokyo.

Spent one week here in October/November 2013. Upgraded to a suite which suited our needs very well, 2 adults and 2 young adult children. Sofa beds were extremely comfortable and the rooms were huge! 2 bathrooms with a separate toilet, all very clean - they even give you pyjamas. Excellent view of the tower and the balcony was accessible. The hotel is great and the staff are very professional, but it is a little far from a subway station (10 min walk) and there is no JR line nearby, however a cab to the nearest JR wasn't expensive. The view from breakfast is stunning, and it is even better for drinks at night!

Really enjoyed my stay here, location is excellent and you can get everywhere from Akabanebashi station or Daimon/Onimaron all of which are short walks away.Staff all very friendly and every need was taken care of. Was shown to my room and given a quick tour of how everything works. View from 29th floor of Tokyo Tower and the city itself is amazing.All in all a great hotel, great location and great staff.

I spent one night here on 30/11 at a corner room. The room is bigger than I expected and the view is spectacular. I love tokyo tower, and its just right in front of my room. The bath room is very big and have a view of the Zojo Ji (a popular temple in Tokyo, also a nice spot). It is clean and the bathtub has massage function. For ladies, they also provided a whole set of cleansing foam to moisturizer and of course bath salt. Location wise, it is about 2mins walking distance to Zojo Ji and 10mins walking distance to Tokyo Tower. Around 15mins walking from Hamamatsucho JR station to hotel. I took a taxi from that station to hotel in midnight, after surcharge, its less than 1,000yen. Overall, its a very pleasant stay there.

We stayed on the Executive Level by joining Prince Club International. This is free to do and affords you access to the lounge (free breakfast and happy hour) and the onsite onsen. Breakfast can be had in the lounge or in one of two other restaurants. The choices were ample and the food was quite good. There was a combination of western and Japanese fare. The happy hour had a decent array of beverages but fell short on snacks - a few canapés, cheese, some crackers and nuts and some pickled veggies. The onset in the basement level is nice though dated. The guest rooms also are dated but in good repair. Definitely request a Tokyo Tower view - that won't disappoint. The biggest downside was one needed to walk about 5-10 minutes to get to a train station. Overall, I would still recommend the hotel based on the affordable rate we found and the club level amenities.

It is a very nice Hotel, very well located. Is a short metro ride to Ginza, Rippongi and other places in Tokyo. They give me a room with an spectacular view of the Tokyo Tower and the park, and only that is a must !! The service was excellent! The staff are super friendly and competent for all my requests. The room was a large room with all the amenities, and was a regular room. They do have special rooms in higher floors. The restaurant on the top offer incredible views, but I prefer the basement excellent Japanese restaurants.
user_name:
darwinsail
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I have been to Japan for more than 5 times and have stayed in more than 10 different hotels and The Prince Park Tower Tokyo surprised me.Generous size rooms with everything you need from tooth brush to facial moisturizer to a massage bath tub, friendly, professional and most importantly English speaking staff members, excellent view of the Tokyo Tower, Temple and park, a convenient store on ground level, easy access to the airport, Shinjuku and Roppongi... Probably the best choice I have made so far!Value is also excellent. At least not more expensive than most of the OK hotels (e.g. the B, metropolitan and sunshine city prince). I was there for holiday but i reckon it would be a great choice for business stay as well.Things that you may need to consider are, not necessarily bad!:No cafe/24 hours convenient store/malls...within say 300m from the hotel Can take sometime to go to places like ikebukuro, harajuku and ueno. Having said that it's not that hard anywayThe hotel is not very "Japanese" but very international. No "feel-like-home" feeling at all.

Everything at this hotel exceeded expectations, the room was very large, service was good, loved the late opening convenience store in the lobby. I didn't eat at any of the restaurants as they were so busy! but the food looked good, quite expensive though. there isn't too much in the immediate vicinity, you have to go for a little walk. i liked that akanebashi station was so close to the hotel, very convenient!! Would stay again :)

We stayed in this hotel OCTOBER 2011 (only just set up Trip Advisor account).Booked this hotel at the last minute due to its central location (was flying out in 2 days so wanted to be close to train to airport) and got a good deal on the most amazing corner suite! Amazing room, comfy bed, lovely bathroom - all looking out over the Tokyo Tower and the Zojo-ji Temple.Walking distance to main Hamamatsucho train station (and the multi-story Maruzen bookshop :D).

I spent 3 days here last week and was very pleased. I stayed on a superior floor and requested non-smoking, tower view, balcony, king sized bed. The hotel was able to honor all my requests. The room was spacious, view spectacular, bed gigantic (some kind of king plus.) Bathroom was large, clean, included nice amenities, with jetted tub and, as mentioned in a previous review, appeared to have toilet technology only available to advanced civilizations. The concierge was outstanding and really helped finding my way around. Transportation options were good, the Airport Limousine Bus was a very comfortable, easy to find and use option to and from Narita. Staff was very curteous. Internet was free, fast and available throughout most public spaces. The only restaurant I used was the breakfast buffet, it was excellent, a little overpriced but on the top floor the view alone made it worth it. I also thought the gym was a little expensive, separate and extra pricing to use gym and pool, extra charges if you needed swim gear (suit, goggles, cap,) and no Internet in the gym. Those are minor complaints, except for the gym the hotel exceeded all my expectations. I will definitely try and go back if I'm ever in Tokyo on vacation again, I'm an airline pilot and travel a lot, this is one of the best hotels I've ever stayed at.

We stayed here Nov 2-8. My sister had paid for the hotel. The staff knew sufficient English to converse with foreigners but (as the usual case in Japan), it was easier to understand them in Japanese. I was the only who can do this though, and it really does help that they can converse in English since I can't always be interpreting.I'm giving the hotel 4 stars because of two things: one, housekeeping forgot to replace our slippers for one night and we had to request for them; and the housekeeping staff can't really understand English that well (I had to make the request in this case). My second gripe is the fact that you have to pay $20 per person for usage of the gym and spa, which was usually free in a number of hotels we have stayed in. Well, at least there was a park right around the hotel, and in the absence of a gym, you can always just run around the perimeter and back.On the room: I loved the built-in jacuzzi and just to maximize what was paid for, I made use of it every night. ;) Very good after a long day of walking around Tokyo. The toilet was the most high-tech I've ever seen. It had a person detector (or whatever you call it) which was sort of cool, but sometimes creepy when the toilet cover and light suddenly closes. :P The beds were very comfortable and we always had a good night's sleep.WiFi is also provided in the rooms, and is pretty fast. I hate that you always have to input the username and password every single time.Our room had a terrace and it was overlooking Tokyo Tower, so we had excellent views of it in the morning and at night.The hotel also provides free shuttle buses to JR-Hamamatsucho Station. Alternatively you can walk a short way to Akabanebashi station on the Toei Oedo Subway Line. There's also a Family Mart near this subway station.

There are few places in Tokyo with an unobstructed view. This hotel is set in a park on a little rise near the Tokyo Tower . That means you gaze out on some greenness and are shielded from noise. It also means that the Bar at top has a splendid (overwhelming) view of the Tokyo wall of skyscrapers.It seems to have all the amenities. Although, I seldom avail of such stuff, it is nice to know that you could. The concierge was helpful which is a plus in a place like Tokyo. The neighborhood toward the main train line (4 blocks away) has a number of good restaurants both local and domestic. The temple adjacent to the hotel is quite nice. With all the goings on in the park you feel more integrated into Tokyo as a city.At least for my stay, the hotel offered good value for money vis-vis its peers.

It fits it's standard as 5star hotel. Services are superb. Upon arriving the hotel, I was greeted warmly and the bellboy helped me carried my bags all the way into room. No tips given. In Japan tipping is not a advisable I was told. The check in time was at 2pm.. So I requested for wifi access from the front desk. It was cool that with 1login you can use for few devices. Some hotels doesn't allow you to use multiple devices for 1wifi access. While waiting for them to ready my room. I took my lunch at the lobby lounge, foods were good and delicious. Price wise , slightly expensive but services was tip top. Upon checked into room, I was happy.. Room is up to my expectation. Spacious clean and comfortable. It has separate wardrobe, separate bath, toilet and everything is auto sensor. The lights, etc. I do not have anything to complaint about this hotel.

We have stayed at more than 8 hotels all over Japan, this hotel is by far the most expensive (for this trip) and the most pretentious hotel in Japan.The staff are just not genuine and can be rude at times. I'm sure other guests who have given their reviews had a pleasant stay, Unfortunately we didnt. If you're looking for value for money and experience Japan and their ways avoid this hotel..even for the location there are so many other hotels that's cheaper and the staff friendlier and with better location. I notice the lack of friendliness at this hotel after being in Japan for a couple of weeks. Every hotel we stayed at the staff were friendly not this one. What irked me so much was something that was small but the way it was done was a major put off.There's apparently a rule to not eat at hotel lobby while waiting for a shuttle bus which we PAID for and BREAD which we BOUGHT at the hotel bakery. We weren't eating soba or rice for goodness sakes. The person who told us was rude and treated us like we stayed there for free. As far as I'm concerned I can do without the spacious room (we're hardly at the hotel anyway) and the hoity toity atmosphere and choose some good ol fashion Japanese hospitality at a much cheaper and fun place. Will not book this hotel again and no recommendation from me.

We found all the staff absolutely delightful, friendly and willing to help even though we could speak no Japanese. The rooms were spacious, immaculately kept and very clean. We would love to have stayed longer.

Staff was very helpful and attentive. However, the majority of staff cannot speak english very well. Hotel is modern and clean. Room is spacious. There were 3 of us in a room and we really appreciate the fact that the toilet is separated from the bathroom.
user_name:
Haka_Nguyen
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: The hotel is good. However, I was being accused of spending in the club house on the 32F for which I never did. The receptionist insisted in the first place until I asked for evidence and was a mistake.

Spent two weeks here with my two children (in their own room) and can't fault the hotel at all. The rooms are decent sized by Tokyo standards, clean and very pleasant, and the location is superb. The staff could not have been more helpful.

Fantastic service, and all the staff make an effort to speak English, which will be reassuring for any foreigners visiting Japan for the first time! The rooms are nicely laid out, clean and spacious. The views are amazing. This was the second time we stayed here. The first time we had an executive room on the 19th floor with views of Shiba Park. This time we were on the 6th floor in a corner room and had a perfect view of Tokyo Tower - quite a sight at night time especially when it is lit up.The location is also great. You could walk to Roppongi in 30 mins or get a taxi for 710 yen. It's a 20 minute metro ride from Ginza and other shopping districts. If you're flying to Haneda you can't go wrong with this hotel. It's a short taxi ride (710 yen) away from Hamamatsucho station, from where you can catch the monorail to Haneda. There's also a shuttle bus that can take you to Hamamatsucho station, as well ad the usual Narita airport bus services. Breakfast is a little pricey at 3,000 yen per person. Unless you're coming on business you'd be better off going to the bakery on the ground floor for your breakfast.

We read a lot of reviews and overall seemed like people were happy so we booked and could not have been happier that we did. I travelled with my 12 year old son for our first visit to Japan. We loved the hotel. The Prince Park is in a a fantastic location in a park near a Temple. It is across the street from a subway station near many tourist locations. The staff was amazing from the moment we waked in the entrance. Staff were great and escorted us to a reception area and then following check in to concierge to discuss things to do. We will definitely stay here again.

With incentive, you save 1000 yen per day with no cleaning. Personally I would do it anyway as I love to travel but I hate that it is so bad for this earth I love to discover. But if it make more people choose it, then it's a big Bravo for the hotel.I travelled with four kids and we enjoy the stay, amazing view, breakfast included for the whole family, rooms fits two rollaway, free rollaway. Just be careful to mention non smoking, first we were on 22nd floor and one room was fine but the other one smell cigaret really bad, hopefully they changed us for 29th floor. Looks like non-smoking policy everywhere in Japan in not really strong.Easy to go around with to subway station close to the hotel, one going to edo museum or shinjuku, the other one going near Tokyo st on park ueno (one transfer).

This was my first visit for a short vacation in Tokyo. The hotel is well located in a quite park but centrally located close to two metro stations. The hotel has a great concierge service that was able to arrange all tours and restaurant reservations. The room were small but clean and comfortable with Wifi. We stayed at the premium floors and the extra expense was worth it. Their buffet breakfast was excellent with great views of Tokyo towers. I will definitely go again.

Not only is the position of this hotel outstanding, the views from our room - which was a Junior Suite on the 23rd floor, were amazing. Having the park around the base of the hotel gives it a huge advantage over almost anywhere else in Toyko.The staff are all proficient in English it seems - they answer your telephone automatically in English, newspapers in English are delivered without request, every care and need is anticipated.The food - whether room service or many of the wonderful restaurants there - created works of art of eat.Although the swimming pool and gym are a very long way from the elevators of the hotel, and cost approximately $20 each time to use, they were well worth the walk and the price. Superb set up - hot springs, as well as a steam room, walking pool and swimming pool, life guard on duty the entire time and googles and swim caps provided - very lovely and clean.

The location of the hotel gives you a nice view of the Tokyo Tower. Though my room was a little restricted from the full tower, the view at night was still great. It was a serene sight that made the stay very relaxing. Staff was attentive. There is service from the hotel to the train station, which was helpful.

The Prince Park Tower Tokyo is a nice simple hotel with good amenities, good value for money and good service. It is classified as 5 stars and we were greeted straight after arriving to the hotel and our luggage was taken to the room by the bell boys. Check in went smoothly but no information about anything, it would have been useful to know about the area and the facilities in the hotel. The guest service girl that escorted us to the room did not understand much English and had a ear snail in which we believe that she received replies to our questions - quite funny and not something that decreased our good impressions with the hotel. We had booked a superior room which is from the 18th floor and higher. The view was to the streets and could have been better, would have preferred a room with a view to the recreational areas and Tokyo Tower. Maybe next time. The room was nice and all the amenities for a 5 stars hotel, the bath was really nice and the bed is one of the best I have ever slept in. We both managed to sleep through the worst typhoon in 10 years! Without waking up. We tried the breakfast as well which cost an additional approx. 3000 yens. It was a good variety and very nice. It is situated on the top floor and has a very nice view of Japan. The egg station was a hit! Thank you for a nice stay, we would definitely consider staying with you again.

On my 4th trip to Tokyo, we stayed at the Prince Park Tower Tokyo, 4-8-1 Shiba-koen, Minato-ku, Tokyo 105-8563 for 2 nights. The bathroom has a separate shower, bathtub & sink, the toilet is in a separate room with a sink. The toilet cover opens, when you open the door. The toilet cover closes, when you close the door. It is very close to the Shiba-koen Station, the Tokyo Tower, the Zojoji Temple and the Roppongi’s nightlife. Our suite came with the daily “Wall Street Journal” in an elegant white bag outside our door handle. We had 2 breakfasts & 1 dinner at the addicting Shibazakura’s Japanese Restaurant, with privately curtained, tatami seating in-house. The meals demonstrated intricate skills, featuring premium seasonal ingredients. The blending of influences isn’t just seamless, it’s delectable. The sake was served to perfection.

Great price. Great hotel. Great location. We loved the proximity of this hotel to parks, Tokyo Tower, restaurants and subway. The bakery down the road was great too as an option for breakfast. There's a great running track around the hotel, approx. 3.6kms and used by many at all times of the day. Only downside was we couldn't enjoy pool or bar on top floor as we had our kids with us but we understand/ respect policy. Highly recommend. Lovely gardens to walk through. Staff delightful.

We're not complainers, nor are we usually hard to please so I'm surprised to read so many positive reviews of the service here. The room was great and we have no complaints at all, however, the service was awful and bordered on disrespectful. We were removed from the "superior" lifts (we booked a superior room) and check out was no more than a 'wham, bam' but without the 'thank you ma'm'. There is also no transfer from the airport despite what some websites will tell you. To be fair, I will mention that we were upgraded on check in as our room wasn't ready (after check in time). I left this feedback in a guest comment card but haven't had any correspondence from the hotel in the month since our departure. Clearly my experience is a one off, though it's odd that we felt it was so bad, not just 'the little things' when the other reviews here are so good!

Upon our arrival, hotel staff was extremely attentive and checked us in quickly without any waiting. We had booked a non-smoking room, but the room we were originally given didn't really smell like it. Whether it was a booking mistake or the previous guest breaking the rules, I'm not sure, but upon notifying the front desk, they were extremely apologetic and said they would arrange another room for us right away.They called back to inform us that they didn't have any other rooms with three beds, but if we would be able to wait about an hour they would rearrange some furniture and make one for us. We were fine with that, and frankly impressed with how seriously they were taking our request. As promised, a bit later, one of the front desk managers came and took us up to a significantly upgraded suite with a spectacular view.I'd absolutely recommend this hotel to anyone. Even if we had stayed in our original room, it would've been a great value. Though technically the hotel messed up, they took it as an opportunity to go above and beyond to make things right. Very impressed!

We stayed here for 4 nights during a business trip with some leisure time added on. The hotel exceeded my expectations for the price in this city. The staff and service was excellent throughout the hotel and our stay. The room (a corner double) was a good size with an outstanding bathroom and a large closet. Good working area too. When I say outstanding bathroom, I mean jacuzzi tub, excellent shower and huge window overlooking Tokyo and separate sink/toilet area. Location is good with subway stops not too far away. The shuttle to the airports is very convenient. Overall really excellent and would definitely stay here again and recommend it.

Great views if you get Rooms from 21st floor up facing the tower. Location was fine with us - quiet and the best connected station is just 5 min walk away (Midoiri). No dynamic atmosphere here either, mainly business and mod thirty age id say - which again was fine with us. The rooms are outdated (80's style) but the rooms come with a a very large bed and a balcony, the breath taking view which to us was way more important than decor.

The Prince Park Tower offers exactly what you can expect from a 4 star business hotel. Everything works smoothly. The rooms are nice and spatious, the service good and the breakfast plentyfull. No surprises there, good or bad. What maybe is lacking is a personal touch, but so it goes in a big hotel. On the pro side is the location. It is near the Shiba park, wall to wall with the Zojo-ji tempel, and in the shadow of Tokyo Tower. However, location must also be placed on the con side: the are two subway stations within walking distans but reaching some parts of Tokyo requires some planning. The hotel offers, however, a bus shuttle to Tamachi station giving access to the JR Yanamote ring line. Finding a good restaurant within walking distans can also be tricky. I chose to go to Roppongi or Yurakucho for dinner. The hotel has, however, some good restaurants, and if breakfast isn't included there is a shop with bread and such. Also on the pro side is the hot spring bath, which was really nice, worth the 2000 yen charge for a visit.So no suprises, and above all no complaints.

When visited Tokyo I stayed in this hotel for a week.It is a modern building and a luxurious hotel located in a park that dominates a whole block, including a temple and the Tokyo Tower in the opposite side. After the check-in at the reception, you must cross a bridge over water, within the building, to access the elevators. The area play with colours and materials, mainly metal and mirrors, blueish greenish as well as the water.The hotel is really a tower with three faces and 33 levels, having a lounge in its top floor. From that floor you can see the Tokyo tower so close that you have the impression that you can touch it. At night, the view of the Tower and the city is unforgettable. The hotel is also close to a metro station.Many facilities: 8 restaurants, among others, specialised in teppanyaki, or sushi, or tempura, or yakitori or modern Japanese fusion; a bakery, nice shops, and a health club. Pity I though is that to use the pool you must pay the equivalent to around US $ 20 (you can use the gym, sauna and hot spring), but if you want to use a pool every day during a week, that is quite an additional cost. Only people over 20 can use it. So one of my teenagers could not use it.The rooms are really good, including flat LCD TV, Jacuzzi bath tub and and touch with electronic curtains. Breakfast is of high quality and served in one of the top floor, so view is beautiful. Staff is friendly and effective.Definitely a place to come back. My hint is to keep a card with the hotel's name and address to show to taxi drivers. There is another hotel very close to this one, called "Tokyo Prince Hotel" and at the beginning of our stay, 2 times the taxi drivers mistaken the 2 hotels.

We got off to a good start. The lobby area and check in process were worthy of a luxury hotel. The room itself however was disappointing - dated décor, very 80's with orange wood everywhere and poor lighting. Meal at the Yakitori restaurant downstairs was also disappointing and felt like a classroom or hospital - zero atmosphere. The biggest disappointment was, as a hotel guest, you have to pay to use the gym, pay more to use the spa or pool, and then pay more to use... the bar (!!!). Insulting; I've never ever come across this before anywhere in the world. I'm convinced there are better places to stay in Tokyo than the Prince Park Tower for the price.

Hotel is beautiful Situated in a lovely park right beside the Tokyo Tower which we could see from our 31 st floor room Very well laid out room with everything you could wish for ( could loose the bathroom scales as they did me no favors holy moley am I that heavy !!!!!) Anyway it is a great hotel and I wouldd reccommend it highly staff are great and efficent and friendly.. and the location is good near a buzzing street with bars and restaurants

This hotel was arranged for me by my Tokyo office so I did not actually choose this hotel myself, however it was very well located for my needs. The hotel is right next to Tokyo Tower and has amazing views of the city from the breakfast room and bar. Unfortunately the view from my room was not great as I was on the wrong side for the city/tower. I had a corner room which was spaciouss but dated. The bathroom was very large and had a great shower. The hotel has WiFi but it was a bit of a hassle trying to connect as you had to follow some confusing instruction through the TV to get a code. I really don't know why they can't just give you a code at check in. Once connected the Wifi worked very well. We took the main buffet breakfast on the top floor and the buffet selection is ok, nothing exciting, however the views are amazing! The panoramic bar is also well worth a visit to enjoy Tokyo by night. All in all I would not regard this hotel as 'luxury'. I stayed at the Park Hotel Shiadome on my last visit which had smaller rooms but was an overall better experience. I did not personally choose this hotel but it was not so bad either.
We stay during our honeymoon.When you open the Curtain will see Tokyo Tower. Tokyo Tower is very beautiful at nightYou can also see it in the bathroom

What a hotel! Situated in the heart of downtown Tokyo beside the Tokyo tower. Rooms were large in size as was the washroom. There is a separate room for the toilet....where the lid opens automatically when you walk in!Great selection for the breakfast buffets and the view is amazing. The lounge on the 33rd floor also offered stunning views in the evening, if you were lucky enough to get inside. Many people were turned away and the hostess didn't speak English. While I realize we are in Tokyo, this is a classy hotel with many visitors from other parts of the world. The hotel would do itself and it's clients well to have a hostess on hand that understands English. Many walked away frustrated after trying to converse with the hostess.Would highly recommend this hotel as a choice while in Tokyo.

Our first stop after the 11 hour flight was a true delight. The Prince Park Tower gave us a corner room overlooking the spectacular illuminated tower reaching high above the lush garden parks below. The tower also displayed lighting celebrating their candidacy for the 2020 Olympics -which they won while we were there.Windows everywhere - you felt as though you were floating above the city. Breakfast offerings were delicious....choices between private dining and buffet...cuisines to satisfy everyone and all with those glorious windows to Tokyo's world. The Japanese people are so very accommodating and gracious and their country is so beautiful - we look forward to visiting again one day.

Stayed for 3 nights as part of our 9-day JTB Sunrise tour and this was by far the best hotel they organised for my wife and I to stay in.Situated in a park that's less than 10 minutes walk to Tokyo Tower. It has it's own convenient store next to the hotel lobby which is very handy for a quick breakfast or a midnight snack.The rooms are large! They have wifi and they have plenty of power points for you to plug your phone charger, camera charger, laptop, portable wifi rental, etc. Basically everything a tourist will be carrying with them.Unfortunately we didn't get a room with a view of Tokyo Tower so make sure you ask for a room with aTokyo Tower view when you book or check-in.The staff are very attentive and friendly. The concierge are quick to accomodate any requests. H.ae was excellent in both his English and willingness to deliver quality service.Not particularly close to a railway station, the hotel offers a free shuttle bus service to Hamamatsucho Train Station/Bus Terminal.Not too many hotels better than this one. Definitely enjoyed our stay.

This is truly a 5 star hotel in the middle of tokyo. The setting is tranquil and the grounds are relatively large. The location is decent, being close to a few train stations, so it is ideal for both those going for business and leisure. The rooms are large and do not smell of cigarette smoke. Our toilet was huge!There is definitely enough space for your luggage here, unlike some other hotels in tokyo. The internet speed is very good within the room and the staff are excellent, many of whom speak very good english. The down sides are of course the price and the relative lack of restaurants within the area (there are some, but they are generally very pricey). If you are not on corporate rates, you also have to pay for use of certain amenities like the gym. Overall, much much better than the average hotel in tokyo if you can afford it.

This hotel sits in a very nice oasis of greenery and tranquility---it's a great respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. Had a family room (with the extra single bed) on which all seem to be located on the ninth floor. Good basic offerings in the hotel quick mart and excellent fresh breads on offer every morning. Short walk to subway stations. Separate elevators to the premium floors, considering how nice our room was the premium floors must really be special and might be worth the upgrade costs.Of special note is the upstairs bar and restaurant. Had a 25 dollar roast beef sandwich and a 10 dollar beer clearly overpriced (but then it's Tokyo) but the view from the bar at night is not to be missed. The hotel sits at a lower elevation than the area the bar views at and it is an unusual perspective watching the land slope up to the horizon. Seats by the window have a 10 dollar seating charge but the bar seats are free. Nice staff=--helpful and very polite. Didn't use the bowling alley downstairs or the pool but they might be nice options for families although I'm pretty sure the pool prohibits tattoos--not uncommon in Japan.

This is a great hotel next to the Tokyo Tower. I always get a Corner Double room although I stay alone since it is large and typically has great views. I must have stayed her 10 times over the last few years.The airport limousine bus from NRT or HND stops at the hotel. There are two subway stations nearby; Akabanebashi on Oedo line (two stops to Roppongi) and Shibakoen on the Mita line. The bar at the top floor has a great view of the Tokyo Tower. Note that this is the old, orange-illuminated tower and not the very new SkyTree. You can actually walk to Roppongi.There are very nice restaurants at the hotel, though they are not cheap, which is typical at high end hotels in Japan. You can use a great fitness facility at the basement (you have to walk for 10 minutes to get to it) for a fee. You can even pay to get a personal trainer to stretch you after the exercise. A Starbucks is within 10 min walking distance due East, toward the Daimon Station, from which you can catch the Asakusa line. The Zojoji Temple is on the way to Starbucks; great Buddhist temple adjacent to a nice park; if you have seen the Wolverine movie, you have seen the temple.Service is great, which is also typical of Japanese hotels. I have traveled to Tokyo 25-30 times. This is one of my favorite hotels. Others: Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku, Dai Ichi adjacent to Ginza, Marunouchi Hotel across the Tokyo Station. All great choices, for different reasons.

Sits on a nice park with walking trails. Very convenient from Narita via airport bus. Hotel has option for you to bypass cleaning for a 1000 yen voucher that can then be used in restaurants or shop. Recommend the lobby lounge for a light meal overlooking Tokyo Tower and the rooftop bar for incredible views of Tokyo.Was cheaper than Sheraton.

Before the departure to Tokyo we needed a driving license translation in Japanese and the hotel arranged this for free.We arrived too early for check-in, about noon. The staff was sorry we had to wait two hours in the beautiful bar with garden fountain view and upgraded us for free in a marvellous 60 sq mt suite with Tokyo Tower panoramic view. The hotel and the service are really 5 stars.There are two subway stations very close to the hotel (Akabanebashi - 3 min walk, Shibakoen - 5 min walk) plus free shuttle to Hamamatsucho railway station, which make the transportation very easy. Don't miss Katsura Kobe Restaurant on the 1st basement. In two weeks in Japan we ate 5 times Kobe and Hida beef and this one was by far the best. The Kobe steak is very expensive, about 130 Euro for 150 gr, but after it the best filet mignon or prime rib will seem to you without taste.The next time we'll go to Tokyo we'll stay definitely in The Prince Park Tower.

This is a beautiful luxury hotel with convenient access from Narita. We took the airport bus, and this hotel is one of the programmed stops. The benefit is you don't have to lug your bags on the airport trains and through connecting stations. Really 5-star feel inside. Reception is a sit-down desk. They treat you like royalty from the moment you exit the bus and speed you through all the process to get you to your room. The views are spectacular. The amenities are overflowing. Fluffy beds you melt into.

A wonderful hotel in a good location. I had a nice, spacious, well appointed room with a view of the park. Service was very good and almost all staff members that I encountered could manage questions asked in English. Would definitely stay again if in Tokyo.

This large hotel is very well run. We stayed in a Premium floor room (Club floor) and it felt very exclusive and private. These rooms are on floors around 30. You need a key pass just to get into the lift area. The room is large and well appointed. Vast comfortable bed. Separate shower bath. Washlet toilet. Copious toiletries. We had a view over the park, city and the Tokyo "Eiffel tower". The club lounge is compact but comfortable. They serve a buffet breakfast with a chef preparing eggs several styles. Try the foie gras omelette. The hotel is outside of the central core and, as such, a bit less fraught. There are two subway stations within a couple of minutes and the hotel runs a free shuttle to the Japan rail station nearby every half hour. The fitness facility and spa are high quality - free access with Premium floor rooms, fee without. Highly recommend this property

The prince park tower hotel definitively deserves all the stars they got. It's placed right in front of the Tokyo tower, in the Shiba park, and it's right next the Zojo-ji temple. You can access within 5 minutes the E and I lines of the subway and get quickly to roppongi, ginza, and anywhere you need. The service is excellent - especially the staff working at conciergerie. We had a small issue with the toilet flushing and we were assisted within 15 minutes. Views are awesome. I suggest a corner room - not he cheapest but definitively worth the experience. The bathroom is great and amongst the best I have ever been. I don't review all places here but I have seen a few of these hotels and this bathroom is really great. It offers views on the tower and the temple. You can chill out taking a bath and staring at the view out there. As the hotel is in a park, you have nothing in front of you that disturbs the show.I'd suggest a quick drink at the top floor. The drinks are pricey to tell the truth but the view is among the best, if you can tolerate people smoking, it's worth to go. I suggest some of their non-alcoholic yogurt based drinks.Cleaning is good and packs you with amenities. We got all sorts of stuff, from hair brush to tooth brush, to bath salts, etc. If I come back to Tokyo for business or leisure I will totally go there again.

Great location for us and situated in a lovely park environment. Walking distance to subway and shuttle to JR station. Staff were very efficient and friendly. We opted for Premium Floor accommodation and found the room complete in every way and beautifully maintained. The view of Tokyo Tower and adjoining shrine were lovely. The Premium Lounge offered the same view but with complimentary breakfast, tea and cocktail hour. It was opened from 7 am until 10 pm. Staff were charming and eager to assistance. Refreshments were very nice. Breakfast buffet was ample and eggs were prepared perfectly. I would definitely recommend this property, especially the Premium Floor.

Was a little more than we wanted to spend but I've spent twice as much for much worse rooms. The room was clean, truly smoke free, and the views were epic. We had a corner double room which was easily American standard sized. Staff spoke prefect English, explained the room in detail and were all very helpful. Only regret was not staying long enough.

This hotel has nice (if small by western standards) rooms and is located in a convenient locale. Staff were attentive and we had no complaints. The proximity to the Shinjuku train station helps for navigation (always easy to find).It was a touch on the pricey side for what it was but worth it if you want clean and comfortable accommodation.

Excellent hotel. Top marks for service -- everyone we dealt with was very helpful and spoke English. Our room was lovely -- we opted for a premium room (higher in the building) in a corner, so we had a lot of room and an amazing view of Tokyo. The bed was very comfortable, the bedding of good quality, and the bathroom quite nice -- the toilet butt-jet is an awesome experience. The only negative we had is that we could not get the room as cool as we wanted, no matter what we did with the controls.Food: we ate at the breakfast buffet, which is extensive and covers Japanese, American, and European tastes. It's not cheap, but it's very, very good. We also got room service for dinner the night we arrived (from the US, terribly jet-lagged), which was also good. We otherwise did not eat in the hotel restaurants, but in the neighborhood. There are a number of places on the route to Daimon metro station and the side streets off the main drag -- take your choice and enjoy your meal for much less than the hotel!Location: It was a 5-10 minute walk to the nearest metro. The first part is through a park, and you have to walk up and down stairs in both directions -- if you are mobility impaired, this might not be a good choice for you. Once you get on the main drag, there are restaurants, coffee shops, pharmacy, 24-hour family mart -- all pretty convenient. The park is a pleasant respite from Tokyo (incredibly loud cicadas in the wooded part). We did not use the pool or exercise room because the surcharge was too steep.

We had three members of our family staying in the hotel. The room has enough space for an extra bed. The hotel has a good conservation policy of awarding the guest with 1,000 yen each day for purchases in the hotel if he does not require room cleaning (they will still clear the dust bins if you want). We used the coupons to buy delicious bread and drinks in the hotel bakery. A win-win policy for all.

The hotel and staff get 5 stars, had to deduct one star for location. The staff is incredible and most speak English, the rooms are spacious and comfortable, the views incredible. The restaurants are good, if a bit pricey, but that's to be expected in a hotel like this - a cocktail is $14.00 in the lobby lounge, but then again, there is no tipping in Japan, so it's probably the equivalent of a U.S. bar bill. The one star gets deducted because I am a westerner who likes my daily coffee. And there was no cafe on the premises and the closest one was a ten minute walk away. The hotel is located in a scenic park with walkways and a temple and somewhat hidden (both are worth visiting) cemetery if you have not seen a Japanese one. If coffee is not an issue for you and you don't need to be able to walk to shops (everything is a subway ride away), then by all means stay here. I just wouldn't recommend it to American first timers. Pros: besides the above, the full American/Japanese breakfast buffet was worth the $28. Buy it as part of your package ahead of time, it may be cheaper. The restaurant is on the 33 floor and has lovely views of city.Bowling alley in the concourse level, is super fun, they serve snacks and drinks/alcohol.Cons: besides location, the wi-fi was a bit weird, it's free and fast, but each time you turn on your laptop or phone, you have to log in again. No way to save the password. Minor inconvenience. Room tip: many rooms have narrow balconies, you can step outside but nothing more than that and friends with the balcony noted it was quite noisy when they opened the door. The corner rooms however have a comfortable layout for one or two people. I had a corner room ending with 23, (1523, 1623, etc). It had a view of the Tokyo Tower and I highly recommend it. The bathroom had huge windows with the same view, was very cool.Dining tip: the breakfast buffet is worth the money, but as others have mentioned here (and thank you everyone for the tip) there is a fantastic french bakery that serves full breakfast, lunch and dinner menu a ten minute walk through the park grounds attached to the hotel. It opens at 7:30am and last order is at 8pm. Try it at least once. www.lepainquotidien.jp Hotel gift shop: has its own bakery too and you can grab an good croissant in a rush and /or late night drinks, water and alcohol all very reasonably priced.Didn't get to try the spa or pool, but they offer in-room massages for a reasonable price.Shopping trip: Get the Pasmo subway pass and load up some $ for the week so you don't have to buy individual tickets. For nice upscale indoor shopping nearby, Tokyo Midtown, a complex that includes the Ritz Carlton is 2 subway stops away from hotel. Ask the concierge for directions.Airport: the airport bus to Narita or Haneda stops here and for 3000 yen you get comfortable ride and avoid the hassle of the subways.

The room is cozy, simple and beautiful. Toilette in a separate room with the bowl with all the controls you can imagine !!! Indulge yourself in that toilette !!! Than take a bath in a jacuzzi with a view to this great city. Breakfast US30 pp is pricy, but complete and with silver cutlery, linen cloth table and the best view to the Tokyo tower. Service is superb!!! Concierge youth helped so much us, every morning we were there to get information. Walk through the park and visit the Buddhist temple. Life is beautiful in this place !!! Onsen not that special, but this type of hot spring brown water is not my thing.

I stayed for one night but would have liked to have stayed longer. It's in a central location and easy to get around. They run a low-cost shuttle bus to the airport, which is well worth the price. I had a beautiful, clean, comfortable room with a great view. There is a lovely restaurant, which overlooks a fountain. There's a sundries store in the lobby which has snacks, souvenirs and baked goods. I would stay here again.

My husband has stayed at this hotel regularly due to the value for money, location and facilities. I recently stayed here for the first time and was also impressed. We were upgraded to a room on an the Executive Floor. The only negative that I can think of is that the styling of the King corner double room was a bit dated, however, for the price you pay and the excellent service you receive you couldn't do better in Tokyo. The bed was the most comfortable I have slept on (out of many) in Tokyo, the view was great with Tokyo tower right outside our window. The bathroom was huge with a spa bath.The staff are very friendly and helpful. Access to major hubs is easy either on the free shuttle bus or via the local subway (5 min walk). However, if the weather was cooler we would also have been happy to walk the 20 min via the park to Daimon or Hamamatsucho station.We weren't able to book at this hotel for our last night so we stayed at the new Tokyo Station Hotel. I was excited about moving to the central location, however, we much preferred our stay at The Prince Park Tower and it was half the price.

Many people talk about their great location, size and facilities, however, I didn't feel as impressive as much... I booked an upgraded double corner deluxe during my stay in Tokyo for 6 days.I have to say the view is fantastic, I stayed in the junior suite of Premium Floor (have to use a separate elevator) , great view of the Tokyo Tower and the gardens. Very nice and helpful staff. Easy transportation on subway and shuttle to the airport. Very clean and comfortable design. However, the room is kind of small and aging, not much to do in that area and too many unnecessary controls... Breakfast is overpriced... You have to pay to play bowling ...

Had the opportunity of staying at this incredible hotel. The location is absolutely stunning! Completely central to all of Tokyo. And the views from the Bar/Restaurant are just unbelievable. Totally recommend this hotel for anyone who wants to maximize their visit in Tokyo!

Been there 2 nights at the end of our trip to Japan. This hotel has a special sale and we booked 2 rooms, one twin and one-corner deluxe as we are couple with 2 kids. The corner room is simply great. The view of a temple and Tokyo tower was stunning at all day time or late eve. All facilities are great. Free wi-fi in rooms. Check-in breeze as well check-out. Service was great. The location fantastic. Free shuttle to JR station, which we used the most. Subway station just around the corner in 3 min walk. Amazing hotel. I will definitely stay again for the price we paid.

My wife, 12 month old and I stayed at this hotel for 4 nights at the tail end of our trip that covered Singapore and Bali. The hotel was built in 2008 and starting show signs of wear and tear. I would not consider it luxury property judging by the design, materials used to furnish the rooms, amenities, etc. Have you ever seen budget leatherette furniture of orange/brown shade and somewhat uncomfortable to sit in? Look no further, this hotel and your room will have plenty of it... There are too many unnecessary controls, nobs and switches on the walls, bathrooms, corridors, etc. - very traditional. The confort of the bedding was OK. We did get upgraded to a larger room with a direct view of the tower - I think we tried too hard as we got a room of monstrous proportions with emberracingly large bed (eventually we discovered that there were two queen beds pulled together). The staff provided with a nice crib and bedding for our 12 month old. As far as the gym facilities, which I managed to use only once, there is a charge of 2,000 Yen to use there pool / hot tubs (this was an issue in my mind as I am not accustomed to pay for hotel gym facilities a la carte). The biggest issue is that the gym is situated underground and is about 10-12 walk from your room! On the way to the gym you will pass wedding planning services and other related businesses... The location is central but there is little to do in the area. Instead of overpriced hotel breakfast on 30+ floor, you can do a nice breakfast at Le Pain Quotidien near by. There are NO kids play rooms and they are not allowed in the lounge (which is understandable).

What a great place! The entire staff are the most friendliest folks around! They can't do enough to make you feel welcome! The desk staff were always ready to assist you in whatever you needed. Our room was plush and very comfortable and we had a great view of the city. Subway stations are close by. The buffet breakfast had a huge selections of items. A wonderful stay, we hated to leave.

In May of 2013 I took my first international trip. I decided on Japan, obviously; and booked my trip through Sun Rise tours, a great company! This was my hotel in Japan and it was amazing! The entire staff was very kind and very helpful, giving me directions and telling me how to operate the train system (very easy). The hotel also has a shuttle bus that runs to the local bus station which is just a short walk from the train/subway system. Not to mention Tokyo Tower was about a five minute walk away and looked amazing at night. I also felt very safe here and that was a big thing for me since I was by myself. The rooms I stayed in were very nice and very clean. Overall a wonderful stay, I have nothing bad to say.

This is my 7th trip to Tokyo. My previous visit involved a stay at The Prince Park Tower Tokyo Hotel which I already reviewed and gave 5/5 to. Of course with a decent review as previously provided, I was keen to repeat my stay.The second time around I was not as impressed and mainly on the basis of our first room.I booked a couple of months in advance. Rates were quite high and the budget only afforded a twin room. This meant low floor, no balcony but still a very reasonably sized room to Japan. Having notched up 7 trips to Tokyo, and visiting many hotels throughout the country I can state that The Prince Park Tower Tokyo Hotel has extremely decent sized rooms. If you come from Australia or North America, your definition of size may not agree with this statement - but Tokyo is a dense city. Expectations cannot be based on what you expect back home.Note: we were to learn later on that rates available on the day from the hotel were actually cheaper than what we paid online 2 months prior. Check against the hotel website for today's rates and compare. In hindsight, we could have paid for the better room for the amount we spent on the cheaper twin.Having stayed a year and a half prior, seeing the small twin on the 10th floor was slightly disappointing. But you get what you pay for, and the rooms are as stated prior - large for Tokyo.We left, came back, got settled and noted one thing out of place. There was an ashtray and a sign saying - "don't smoke in the bed". The cigarette smell then became evident.Japan is certainly cleaner and safer than Australia and the US, but smoking rates are among the highest in the OECD which means that smoking floors that have all but been eliminated in the west, are still very common in Japan.We're non-smokers and couldn't stay in the room.It's at this point Japanese customer service (exemplified by The Prince Park Tower Tokyo) is illustrated. I spoke with the front desk and explained the problem. They admitted they had overlooked my non-smoking request, apologised and without fuss relocated us to a much higher, premium room with balcony and view of Tokyo Tower.Smoking floors aside, the location, staff and cleanliness of the rooms are all very good for the rates you'll pay.Rooms fittings and service are benchmarks which will be hard to find elsewhere for the same price.To assist travellers, those who travel using the extremely convenient Japan Rail Pass will find this hotel ideal. The main Shinkansen stations are Tokyo and Shinagawa; both have connections to the super efficient Yamanote JR line (59 minute, dual direction loop train around central Tokyo - it's free to Rail Pass holders and identified by green stripe on the side of the train).The best JR station on this line for the hotel is Hamamatsucho. It's the midpoint between Tokyo and Shinagawa (6 minutes in either direction, with a train every couple of minutes).Once at the Hamamatsucho station, head to the west side of the station and look for bus terminal 5. The hotel shuttle is at quarter past and quarter to the hour with Japanese precision; on the second.

This was my first time in Japan and I was happy with the Prince Park Tower. The hotel is nice and the staff were polite. This review will list my pros and cons and hopefully it will be useful in your hotel search.Pros: Location- it is a quiet area so you don't have to worry about restless nightsRoom- the size of the room (Twin deluxe) was comparable to the rooms in the US and it came with a veranda. The bathroom, which I tend to be particular about in hotels, was very nice and clean with a separate tub and shower and enough amenities to start a CVSWifi- the (free)wifi worked well throughout the hotel and in the roomsStore- there is a store at the hotel that stays open til 1am for those late night cravings or pick up a few necessitiesBowling Alley- there is a nice bowling alley at the hotel and the prices were surprisingly cheap, there is a bar in there tooBreakfast Buffet- there is an omelet station and a variety of meats, fruits, breads, etc to choose from. There is also a nice view of Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower in particularComplimentary Shuttle- there is a shuttle to Hamamatsucho StationCons: Location- if you want to be centrally located and near a station that has the main train lines, then this may not be for you. The Akabanebashi station is across the street but it is only serviced by the Oedo lineRoom- Even though I had a non-smoking room, it sometimes had a faint smoky odor Gym/Pool/Sauna- did not get to use the facilities because the price to use them was high, I believe 2000 yen for one or 4000 yen for all

I absolutely loved this hotel! The entire staff was so friendly and helpful. I found the hotel to be clean, with an upscale feel. My room was spacious, clean and had great bathroom amenities. I loved getting fresh baked breads from the hotel store each morning (there is a bakery within it). It made for an inexpensive, but delicious breakfast each day. The concierge was helpful in providing maps and general information, but the language barrier hindered some answers to specific questions I had. The hotel is extremely close to Akabanabashi Station (about a 3 minute walk), which was the starting point for nearly all my travels. A free hotel shuttle can take you to another station (on the JR line), if needed. As a female traveling solo, safety was very important to me. I felt very comfortable at this hotel, as well as walking to/from Akabanabashi Station, even at night. Actually, I felt completely safe all over Tokyo and would definitely recommend it as a great destination. I would absolutely stay at Prince Park Tower Tokyo again.

My family of 3 stayed here in early July, 2013. We had a fantastic view from a bank of windows overlooking the city and the Senso-Ji temple. Our room was very large and totally comfortable. The staff were welcoming, and their English is excellent. The hotel shop had everything we needed plus nice breads for breakfast.

We stayed here for 5 nights in March 2013. It was convenient to take the limousine (hotel shuttle bus that you pay for at Narita airport) to the hotel. The lobby is very open, smelled of fresh flowers (maybe orchids), with a nice water feature. The staff are dressed up. Men's uniform look like tuxedos. Bell-women wore hats too. In general, staff members speak Japanese only. They cater to mostly Japanese clients. They do have a few staff members who can speak English (one: really well, the rest: OK for basic communication). We had a few communication issues when we asked for adapter plugs for our computer and when we tried to ship our luggage to Kyoto. The building (inside and out) looks a bit sterile, lacking design. We were in a standard room with two single beds. The rooms are spacious with a large bathroom (combined room with toilet, shower, separate tub), but the furnishings look a bit cheap. It reminded me of particle board with brown veneer. It had all the Japanese necessities, including hot water boiler (which they fill with fresh water every day), slippers, shoe brush, shoe horn.We went to the 33rd floor for the western breakfast buffet everyday. Service was great. There were eggs, bacon, sausages, lots of fruits, drinks. The eggs were not the best texture. Some dishes were not well-labeled. There was a "daily meat" item, which looked like ground pork/veal/beef mini patties with mushroom sauce, which was there everyday. Not sure what it was but it was tasty. They also had chawanmushi (Japanese egg custom made with chicken broth) and soba noodles (with soy dipping sauce). These were good as well. There is a beautiful view of Tokyo Tower and the surrounding areas.We had the JR pass, so the closes station was Hamamatsucho on JR Yamanote line. This is roughly 20 minutes to walk, but there is an hourly shuttle bus which goes from the hotel (also serving two other Prince hotels) to the station and back. We took the shuttle bus a few times, but it was difficult to time your trips around the shuttle bus schedule (even though they were always on time). The surrounding neighbourhood is very quiet compared to other parts of Tokyo (e.g. our other hotel near Shinagawa had many more restaurants and shops nearby). The park is peaceful, but at 5:30 am, the shrine nearby starts their prayers with a few gongs. This woke me up every morning. Without many restaurants within easy walking distance (for elderly and younger family members), we ate two dinners at the hotel (basement). We had sushi one day and yakitori another day. The food was great but the prices were very high. It would be great if you were entertaining guests or clients, but overboard for family meals.

Each timeI stay in Tokyo, I stay at this hotel, everything is amazing, clean and made for you to have an amazing stay.Rooms can be noisy, it's best to ask for a room on the tower or Park side and on a high floor to have a nice view from the room. Avoid corner rooms which are from far the noisiest!

This huge tower hotel is located in the Minato district of Tokyo, next to the Tokyo Tower. The hotel is beautiful on the inside even though the outside looks a bit dated. Staff were very very nice. My room was large, excellent, and clean and had a balcony with a wonderful view of Tokyo. The only (minor) issue with this property is getting there. From the Tokyo central station, take the "lime green - loop" train south to Hammamatsu-cho station. Its a short ($7 US) cab ride or 15 mins walk from there. If you are arriving with a lot of bags, I highly suggest a cab trip. In the reverse direction, the hotel offers a free shuttle to the Hammamatsu station which is a nice bonus. You can walk to the Tokyo tower in about 5 mins.
user_name:
NikG76
New York City, New York

review_body: The Prince Park Tower is excellent. Showing its age a bit if you look closely around the edges, but exceptionally clean, great rooms and the most amazing service! Seriously, I cannot stress how great the service is at this hotel. The regular shuttle service to one of the mail train stations/monorail makes this hotel a great place to stay especially for a first time visit to Tokyo. Just note that the shuttle runs stop at 9:45pm, but there are 2 subway stations close. Plus, the Tokyo Tower is pretty cool to visit and makes for great photos.

I love the breakfast, natural hot spring spa, and shops in the hotel. The prices are very reasonable. My room is big and with nice view. The price is only 1/2 or 1/3 of Hyatt or Four Season's hotel. When I checked out, I left my Hemes scarf and other valuable items in my room. When I got on the limo bus to the airport, someone from the hotel returned my favorite Scarf with other valuable to me in a plastic bag.

Very comfortable stay in large standard Park Twin room. Great beds, wonderful bathroom with whirlpool bathtub and separate shower. I would suggest to refresh furniture, wallpaper and TV, but this had no impact on level of comfort. Free wi-fi works really well in the room. Close to Hamamatsucho / Daimon, 2 connected train stations, with direct train to Narita Airport for only 1280 yen and to Haneda airport for only 470 yen. Walk or use free hotel courtesy shuttle to Hamamatsucho station.You can get great room rates, but breakfast, fitness, and pool are extra, and quite expensive. The deluxe bakery in the large hotel shop was offers good alternatives for breakfast. One comment for Prince Hotel in general. Please keep the PCI member program up to date or just skip it. Last newsletter is from 2011 !!!! Currently the PCI dedicated website has old news, no good deals that could include breakfast or use of facilities. Given special rates are even more expensive than rates on the standard Prince Hotels website.
