Stayed here a couple of nights. Check-in process smooth and efficient. Room very nice and clean. I would stay here again. Each morning we walked to a nearby coffee shop for breakfast. Easy location to find since it is near the Tokyo tower. From most places in the city you can see the tower.

We were for a 10 days trip, for the very first time in Japan. The corner room at Prince Park Tower is a very good choice. I was extremely satisfied about the cleanliness of the entire place, about the friendliness of every employee and about the "green wiew" from the room window. The 33rd floor bar is a wonderfull place with one of the best Tokyo wiew.Large Rooms and techno toilets are also highlights of the hotel.

My overall impression of this hotel is that it is fantastic. I loved the location of the hotel. The fact that it is right next to the Tokyo Tower is a plus for me. There are two subway stations near it and it is near my preferred JR line. For me, the building exterior looked a bit ordinary compared to many five star hotels, but the interior is very lovely. I especially like the park next to it. There is a beautiful flower garden with different colorful flowers in the park. There is also a quaint wedding chapel in the garden. I enjoyed taking walks in the park.I stayed in the corner double room and it was worth it. The room is modern with lots of automatic features. The views from almost every corner of the room including the bathroom are breathtaking. I had fantastic views of the Tokyo Tower, the Zojoji temple and the park. I dined at the Torishiba restaurant and watched the chef prepare delicious yakitori. I was told that the Sky Lounge Stellar garden was a “must” so I made sure to go there for drinks. The night view of Tokyo from the lounge is beautiful.This hotel has fantastic customer service. From the moment you step off the taxi, you have staff waiting on you. They are very organized, your bags are picked up and you were led to seats while you check in. I liked that they provided seats for guests while we checked in and checked out. I reserved a corner room and when I requested a room with a good view, they upgraded me to a very high floor. They also made sure I got a corner room that faced the Tokyo tower. Most of the staff spoke fluent English, and the concierge was always very helpful in printing directions, and writing the names of places and restaurants in Japanese for me. I had a memorable stay here.
user_name:
FabGlobetrotter03
New York City, New York

review_body: I was very pleasantly surprised with the Prince Park Tower hotel. For the price and location (central Tokyo), it turned out to be a very good deal.The hotel is quit busy and modern. The rooms were bigger than I expected, with a separate bath and toilet area. The toilet was the coolest part, because as you open the door the light comes on and the toilet lid automatically goes up. It then shuts once you exit the loo!!The room was comfortable and we got one with a view of the Tokyo Tower, which was lovely.The hotel is in Central Tokyo and there are two metro stations within 5 mins walking distance. Therefore you are extremely well connected to the city. Places like Ginza and Roppongi are about 10-15 mins away by cab and the Haneda airport is about 25-30 mins away.The staff were very nice, but I must highlight the concierge desk in particular. They were extremely helpful, even going to the extent of printing out small maps for our very specific request on stores/restaurants. We didn't eat in the hotel, though they give you discount coupons for breakfast and if you stay longer than 2 nights, a discount coupon for taxis originating from the hotel also. For breakfast we went across to the Pain Quotidien near the temple - 5 mins round the block from the hotel.Overall an excellent choice for an expensive and cramped city like Tokyo.

Great location for people who know Tokyo, maybe not so great for first timers. Close to cultural sites, restaurants and transport. Nice big rooms, well appointed at a great price. But what i really liked about this place is their flexible attitude. I needed a 1 page document copied and asked front desk. Many places would point you to the business center, but they kindly copied for me. And I left a shirt behind and socks, they sent it back washed and pressed. When you stay at Prince Hotels, you experience the best of Japanese hospitality. Thank you, Prince hotels.

I stayed in a Corner Double with a King size bed and therefore the room size was more than adequate- if we hadn't upgraded the room might have felt a little crowded.The bathroom was fantastic- with a large shower and separate large bath (with wave features) and the best toilet EVER!!The hotel is a 15 minute walk away from Daimon and Hamamatsuchō Station which means that you can easily use as a base to explore Tokyo- and a 10 minute taxi ride from both Tokyo and Shinagawa stations if coming into Tokyo via Shinkansen or the Airport express train.Like a lot of hotels in Japan the rooms are a little dated but the level of service experienced was first class (but the prices paid are first class so this is expected). Overall a very nice hotel and I will certainly book here again on my next visit to Tokyo.

Not sure what to expect on my first visit to Tokyo. Quite an amazing experience I must say. Great room with nice bathroom and separate toilet in full Japanese style which I had heard about but still was an interesting experience. The different restaurants in the basement (sushi, traditional Japanese, tempura, etc.) are quite good. I went to the traditional Japanese restaurant; the staff was very friendly and the food good, although there were some unexpected flavours that were new to my tastebuds. Not sure if I liked it or not.The restaurant on the 33rd floor was incredible. I was tired and didn't want to go out. Turns out my only choice was between a seven- and a nine-course dinner. I chose the seven-course dinner ;-). The staff was very courteous, and the food (fusion Italian/French/Asian?) was incredibly. Seven courses flew by before I knew it. Exactly the right amount. The view from the restaurant windows is magical.

Very fashionable and modern crystal building full of lights and glasses . Gardens in roof and entrance show different views of Tokyo towers, Japanese temple and landscape. Breakfast offered at top floor provides breathtaking views and varIous fresh choice. The courtesy and hospitality of staff are also impressive.

Being right next to the Tokyo Tower, you'd think this hotel would have made some more updates, but it hasn't. It looks like a hotel from the early 90's. Having said that, the location is great (very close to the subway access), and it's clean and comfortable. Of course, the service is stellar as you'd expect from a Japanese hotel. And I'd add that the food was pretty stellar too. All in all, a nice place to stay, but it won't wow you.

I travelled with Brightwater Tours on a Temples and Gardens Tour of Japan and was booked to stay at the Prince Park Tower Hotel in Tokyo.My entire stay was very impressive. The room was far bigger than I expected and the view from my room of the temple and grassed area was superb. The spa bath that comes standard in every room really made me feel very special. The breakfasts are fantastic but if there is one thing I might criticise it would be the opening of the dining room at 7 am as there's usually a crowd waiting to get in for breakfast before setting off on business meeting etc. Something I liked very much was the hotel’s plan to save on laundry by giving guests vouchers to spend at the hotel restaurants and shops when tiding their own rooms and not request clean linen and towels. We are all trying to save the limited resources of our planet and I think other hotels should follow suit.All in all, a very pleasant stay.

Our room was much larger than we expected for Japan and the King Bed was enormous! A beautiful hotel with great views over the park and temple next door, as well as Tokyo Radio Tower. The whole experience here was fantastic and I will definitely return when I come back to Tokyo.

We stayed in this hotel as we were leaving Japan after spending one year on a working holiday in the country. The front desk agent upgraded us to a suite which had a fantastic view on one of the premier floors. It made for a truly memorable experience. Our every need was anticipated and we were made to feel welcome even though we booked through Expedia. Highly recommend.

This place is fantastic! Not too far from haneda airport we stayed here one night after a long haul flight. We were exhausted so this was such a lovely place to stay. This hotel has many benefits;1. Close to train station2. Many tours pick up from this hotel3. Great breakfast4. Clean rooms and good size for Tokyo5. Fabulous view of Tokyo tower6. Clean rooms7. Staff very friendly8. Rooms have fully automated bidets with fragrance function and all plus baths with spa jets9. Comfy bedsReally wished we had stayed another night at this hotel...really good experience!

(This is in addition to previous review of a month ago, stayed again for other business trip).This time tried to go early for breakfast before a long series of meetings. The main breakfast place, 33rd floor, opens only at 7am, at 10 to seven there were about 40 people waiting in the small lift lobby to get in. Being Japan, of course they open at 7 sharp, and then every single one has to be escorted at his/her table, the "paperwork" done (breakfast voucher, bill) and then comes the next. Inefficient, slow, and not caring about the customer. That is why I rate "poor service", even though the staff is very friendly (which is true of 99.9% of places you go to in Japan)

Stayed here for 6 nights on business. I got a pretty good rate and for what I paid I thought the hotel was great value.First impressions are not great. The building's architecture is kinda weird, with the structure looking like an out-of-sorts hexagon. The lobby looks a bit dated as well.However, rooms were big. Because of the weird building shape, the rooms are odd-shaped as well but still manage to be spacious. The bathroom is large and feels quite luxurious with black marble floors. However the feel and furnishing is still quite oldish, so those of us who prefer modern luxurious accommodation may not fancy this hotel.Location is not very good. The nearest subway stop is a good 5+ minute walk away. Although the station is 2 stops away from Roppongi, it is a one-line station, making it less convenient to travel to different parts of Tokyo. There is also nothing much to do eat around the hotel, although there is a convenience store in the hotel lobby that is open late.Tokyo Tower is just next door and is well worth a visit. Otherwise you can get a view of the Tower itself from the top-floor hotel lounge.Another nice touch for those of us who are environmentally conscious. The hotel offers a rebate (in the form of vouchers) if you decide not to have housekeeping service. I believe the amount is about JPY1500/night. Too many hotels ask customers to reuse towels in the name of the environment, when they just want to save the cost of laundry. Prince Park though puts its money where its mouth is!Service is great of course, as you'd expect from any Japanese hotel.An airport limousine bus from Haneda brings you straight to the hotel for JPY900 within 30 minutes (of JPY3000 from Narita, 90 minutes).

A classic business hotel, not really for tourists as the location is not too convenient for sightseeing. There are a few sites close by, but then the nearest subway is not that close. Hotel itself is nice and clean like everything in Japan, but what it lacks is character. Its very sterile, the rooms and surroundings have no personality. Again don't get me wrong, the hotel is perfectly clean, very very clean, with lots of technology just nothing special. Also another minor annoyance is that there are no 'combini' (convenience stores) nearby, weird considering there are some every 5 feet in Tokyo.

Stayed with our family of four and really enjoyed all the space offered by the room and the toilet being separate from the shower/bathtub. View and setting were beautiful, the kids really enjoyed the park and the nearby playground. Location was convenient although closest metro stop is on TOEI line which made it not the most convenient metro stop to get to. We didn't use the onsite restaurants or pool, but the kids loved the bowling alley (hotel guests get a discount) and staff were great with them.

I stayed here for business recently for 6 nights. The prices can be quite expensive; however you definitely get what you pay for! From the minute you arrive, through check-in, the bellboy, concierge and all other staff in the hotel you are greeted with friendly smiles and a can do attitude. Every request I had was dealt with efficiently and without fuss.The staffs on the premier floor are very helpful and knowledgeable, I had a few issues with joining conference calls from the meeting room and the staff went above and beyond to make sure everything worked well and all my needs were met. The room size for Tokyo is excellent and extremely good value for money if you compare other hotels in the region. The views are also excellent, my room had a perfect view of the Tokyo tower and a colleague had an amazing view to Mount Fuji. Shiba part below was looking quite barren but would look lovely in spring and summer.My complementary internet stopped working one day, however within 5 minutes of notifying reception someone brought a mini modem to my room and was back online working within 10 mins, I also needed an adapter as mine broke and I had someone to the room within 5 mins with a selection of 10 different types... can’t ask for more than that!Loved the views from the Premier Lounge and Skybar. The hotel shop has a decent selection of things you might need if you are late back from work or need breakfast in a hurry.The Airport Limo bus from Nartia is very easy, 2 hours and 3000yen and door to door service.Will definitely be back for the next business trip in May

I had very high expectations of this hotel after reading reviews on Tripadvisor. They were exceeded upon walking into the room.For those who are reading this, but haven't been to Japan yet, go with one expectation in mind. Japanese cities are highly populated and space is at a premium, and the Japanese certainly optimise their use of space. The laws dictating minimum doorway height, minimum roof heights and any other spacing requirements by law certainly don't compare with the sizes we have in Australia. On numerous occasions, I've had to duck just to get through someone's front door. I've hit my head on the ceiling of a Japanese bathroom here and there.I can easily draw comparisons with Italy. I've had barely 2m sq bathrooms in both countries.The Prince Park in this respect is NOT standard. The room I stayed in had a bathroom the size of some Japanese hotels I've stayed in, and even had a separate room for the toilet. Furthermore, while I am no longer surprised by the array of technology and buttons found in Japanese toilets, the Prince Park facilities even out did most of the others. It did everything but talk.Basically my point here is that the hotel rooms are way over the top - even for Japan.The view is spectacular. If you're on the tower side (like we were), you get probably the best view you can get of the tower. It fills the entire window, and you're elevated enough without obstructions to take excellent photos.The only catch for the Prince Park is it's locations.I always like to be on the Yamanote line for convenience. The closest station on the Yamanote line is Hamamatsuchō. But the distance from the station to the hotel is a 10 minute walk crossing many roads. If you have a lot of bags, this can be annoying.The hotel does offer a shuttle to the station. The shuttle leaves each hour at quarter past from Hamamatsuchō Bus Terminal Gate 5. In typical Japanese fashion, expect it on time. Try to at least time your train to arrive on the hour.If you arrive by Shinkansen or Narita Express, the closest station will be Shinagawa (2 stops on Yamanote line to Hamamatsuchō).Stayed January 2012

I booked this hotel through Hotels.com and got a great value at around $170 a night average including the weekend. I booked a double, but was upgraded to a Junior Suite that had a private elevator and was bigger than most apartments in Tokyo. All the typical amentities of a 4+ star hotel were present. The room was a little outdated compared to the mega modern hotels at the same price level, but definitely not run down. The rooftop bar had great views of the city and Tower next door. The lobby has a very convenient store that's not too overpriced so you don't have to wander around for a Lawsons at night if you want a bottle of wine in your room. The hotel sits back a little from most of the major neighborhoods for tourists, but there are 2 subways within a 5 min walk to get you anywhere you need in no time. The best experience though was the concierge booked us a reservation at a Steakhouse one night and when we arrived the server notified the first drink was courtesy of the hotel; anything we wanted. Overall, I would stay here in again in a heartbeat. The service was impeccable and it's central location, while not near the hustle and bustle of Shibuya or Ginza makes it a good spot to branch out to the whole city and return to the retreat of being in a city park.

Greatest hotels ever visited in my life.The warmth is felt right from reception till you exit the hotel.Greatest of convenience,staff & management.hanks for their cooperaton extended to us during our stay

We booked a double room for 4 nights at the Prince Park Tower based on the great reviews from Trip advisor, and also a very good price (170,000 per night). Finding the hotel was pretty easy (especially if you aim to take the short shuttle from Hamamatcho station), and the location was pretty good, although it was a bit of a walk through the garden to get anywhere. We ran into problems however, as the hotel restaurant (on the 33rd floor) does not let kids in, nor does the swimming pool (which my 4 year old was especially looking forward to). We also found the other restaurants in the hotel to be very expensive. In the end, we transferred to one of their other sister hotels (in Shinagawa) which had a pool that kids could use, however, found it to be too much like Disneyland. I hear that the Prince hotel in Shinjuku is best location, though small rooms.

I stayed at The Prince Park from Feb 6- 9, 2013. This is the hotel absolutely different from traditionally tiny -room hotel in Tokyo. Stunning Tokyo tower and park view with up to American-standard King-size bedroom (It is really huge). The bathroom is big with a massage bathtube and stand-up shower. I and my husband enjoyed the hotel very much. This is the hotel that you want to spend time with, but not immediately escape from the tiny room for fresh air. We stayed at the superior room with a balcony but my friend stayed at normal room with same size (The difference is no balcony only and nicer coffee machine!) . The bad thing that I would say for this hotel is the LOCATION. I am a Hongkongness. We like convenience very much. But you have to walk about 10 mins to Daimon subway and 15 mins to Hamamatsucho JR (Hotel also has free shuttle bus, but the walk is absolutely manageable). I think for shoppers or some people who really really want to stay at the heart of the city (something next to the subway). This is NOT your choice. But if you like good rest, quiet park view and enjoy walking in the sunny winter day, this is your choice.

We stayed here one night 2 pplWe arrived at the hotel and the customer service was really good and we were taken straight away to the reception desk to check in, we was then told we have been upgraded to a superior room on the 19th which was fantastic news. We got there really early too but no issues with check in. The reception and lobby was was clean and tidy and looked very upper class, when we got to the it was very clean, big, fab bathroom and it had an amazing view! Tokyo tower! Fell in love with the view. The rooms could do with a face lift though that's all I could say as a downside.We went to the bar at the top of the hotel which was amazing, trendy, hip, amazing cocktails, we had a mojitos! Just a bit of the expensive side though. Amazing views again at night. The swimming pool was chargeable which was rubbish to say you pay a lot to stay for one night! Wasn't impressed. There is a little cake shop downstairs In the lobby area which was really nice :) only issue was there was no seating to eat it which would have been nice.Location also good 5mins walk to tube station...we couldn't find any restaurants around hotel until we walked to rappongi or daimon which took 10-20 mins.Overall nice hotel! Good customer service! Nice room and amazing views! A bit expensive for what it was and to say we was upgraded no facilities were included. I would defo come back though but not In a hurry

Stayed 3 nights on business in a superior room. Very spacious, particularly the bathroom (shower, separate jacuzzi bath), 27th floor, great views. For Tokyo the price was good and the staff and service are first class. The room decor is a bit old-fashioned but still in good condition. All round, really enjoyed the stay. Level B1 has several restaurants offering all styles of Japanese food. Prices are not cheap but quality was good. Thoroughly recommended

very large rooms, while the decor is very 1980's it's spotless, clean and well maintained.I was on one of the executive floors that meant I had a balcony which I love. The view was over the water and the bridge to Henada and great morning sun coming through the large windows.Always easy to get a taxi and the staff are very friendly. The bathroom has a spa and a heated toilet seat.It also has plenty of draws so you can unpack. No irons in the room but a speed 3 hour turn around on pressing which was faultless.The only negatives were the wi-fi blocks VPN access and the only english TV service was BBC & CNN (BTW - you need to hit the bilingual button on the remote to do away with the dubbed japanese) it would be great if they could add Bloomberg.Mini bar prices are reasonable, there a convenience store down stairs.The bar on the top floor has a nice view,but the drinks are full of ice and not much else so I wouldn't bother.Overall a great hotel and I'm sure to stay here again.

This hotel is located near a park so lots of space to walk around or jog if you prefer. But within 10 min of walk you can find restaurants, ATMs, super markets, drug stores etc, so very convenient too. The Tokyo tower is right cross the street and you can see it from many of the rooms. The airport shuttle from NRT and HND stops at this property and the concierge desk can book the shuttle. Room is of normal size with two beds (I was told they don't have single bed rooms). Breakfast buffet at the top floor is bountiful with both Japanese and western selections, and the breakfast bento in the Japanese restaurant in the basement is adequate (but I felt more people would go for the buffet). What strikes me most is how environment friendly the hotel is. They offer voucher to use in the hotel for agreeing not to have the room service (max 2 nights at one time), which is a smart way to save energy and cost. The soap is in a big bottle rather than the small individually wrapped pieces (which you usually can't finish in 2 days anyways). I think maybe other toileterries (shampoo, conditioner and bathsoap) can be the same with the option to request individual packages. During my stay I did not have many problems or requests but they were all addressed in a quick manner. When I used my voucher to buy some souvenir at the gift store, the clerk alerted me that the food item I was buying was expiring in 2 weeks and asked if I wanted an exchange. I was travelling to other places and this reminder did change my mind. The customer oriented service should be commended.

Firstly i couldnt recommend the limousine bus more to get to this hotel, was just what we needed after a long flight. The check in process was fine no issues but the one thing we got when we first got into the room was a very pungent smell of seafood which we noticed was coming from the wardrobe, I remembered we talked about sorting it out in recpetion and maybe changing rooms straight away but we just couldnt be bothered. We kept the wardrobe closed the whole time and after the second day didnt notice the smell. We went down to the mainbar on the basement level right after having a shower on our first night, wasnt very inspiring so we left and went to the skylounge on the 33rd flr instead. Despite reading other peoples comments about the priceyness of the bar we actually came back to the bar every single night of our 6 night stay. To be honest i didnt find the drinks too expensive and with the great view and fantastic staff (Especially Kaz who we got to know quite well and who's english was pretty good) why wouldnt you want to come up here after a long day of travelling to unwind! But hey everyone has a budget so i understand why this may have seemed pricey for some. Another bonus about the hotel which I havnt seen other people mention yet is the bowling saloon which is on B2 Level- what is this you may be thinking?... well you can play ten-pin bowling,billiards or darts. Not cheap i think for an hour of billiards it was 1500 yen per person or something along those lines but it offers something i have never come accross in another hotel before. Some of the cons besides the smell in our room:1. No free wifi in our room, when we asked about it they said housekeeping could deliver a modem to the room, but what they failed to mention was the cost so when we saw a 10,000yen bill in our room for the use of it we returned it to them. 2. Unable to get a takeaway hot coffee anywhere in the hotel, seems such a simple thing but we just couldnt get one so the hotel shop was handy in that respect and we brought cold starbucks cafe lattes for about 200 yen each morning on our way out. Overall we were very happy with the size of the room and the bathroom was we thought abit of luxury, the staff were generally very good and helpful some spoke no english though which made small talk quite difficult. We would stay here again :)

Stayed in a Japanese Garden Suite late December 2012. It has a private room with a queen bed, 2 bathrooms (1 with no shower) and a dining room which can be converted to a bedroom wherein they laid 2 single bed cushions. We were 4 adults with 1 child which was perfect being together in 1 room and not having to book 2 rooms.The suite was very clean, well thought out amenities, plenty of towels and spacious. The hotel has several restaurants and food was good. One thing I dislike is having to wait in line to have breakfast. It becomes very busy and not enough dining tables after 8:30am. If you want to have a table with a good view of the tower then be early. Location is good... less than 15 minutes away by taxi to good locations like Ginza, Roppongi, etc...Receptionist at the front desk was very helpful and patient in answering my questions regarding tour activities. Most of the staff are proficient in English which made things much easier. They were all very polite and attentive. Overall it was a great stay and definitely will return to this hotel.

The location of this hotel is fantastic, just five minutes from the underground. The hotel is situated in a lovely little park with a view of Tokyo Tower. As amateur photographers the balcony gave great skyline views. The room was large (for anywhere, huge for Tokyo!) and the staff were all helpful, with plenty of English. The restaurants were all prohibitively expensive, but there was a shop in the lobby with a variety of foods available.

Tokyo is billed as the most expensive city in the world and during our five days stay here I could see why. But one place that wasn't expensive was our five star hotel, the Prince Park Tower. I was able to book it online during a flash Expedia sale and got it for just over $200 US a night. For this type of hotel, the price was ridiculously cheap. When we walked through the front door, I had to say WOW. The hotel is actually the flagship hotel of the Prince chain and it was designed by Japan's first superstar architect, a man by the name of Tange. We got upgraded to a two room suite the size of an apartment back home. Everything was so clean and tidy. The room has every amenities imagined and not imagined. A heated toilet which bathes your bum after use, anyone? We did not use any of the hotel restaurants but bought freshly made pastries from the gift shop each AM; there was free coffee and tea in the room. We were also offered free use of the nice hotel gym, but had no time to fit it in. I love the free super fast wifi service. I couldn't sleep one night and at 5 AM the room wifi malfunctioned and someone from the front desk came up and fixed it in no time flat. The hotel is five minutes walk to the tube and from there it is a two stop ride to trendy Roppongi where you will find all the best restaurants Tokyo has to offer. Try to visit the new swanky Tokyo MidTown or Roppongi Hills complex to see how the well to do Tokyolites live. Unfortunately the hotel is not in a part of Tokyo where you can walk around to see things. But the Tokyo Tower is next door ( quite dated and not recommended, go see the amazing new 634 m Sky Tree instead) and also a historic Buddhist Temple is a five minutes walk from the hotel and well worth a quick visit. Your shuttle bus from Narita will stop at the front door and the hotel can give you a free ride to the train station if you plan to travel by train after checkout. All in all this is an exceptional property. The service was flawless and all the staff was amazing and will look after you like family. For the price I paid I made out like bandits! Highly recommended. Why pay twice as much for something similar when there is no need.

A great hotel which we booked at short notice for a very reasonable price. Initially we were allocated a smoking room in error, with views to the Rainbow Bridge. Once we pointed out the oversight,we were offered a HUGE room with king bed overlooking the Tokyo Tower. It was clean, nicely decorated and was a surprise after all we had heard about room sizes in Tokyo. A bonus for us was the green offer the hotel operates. One can request that one's room is not serviced (except for rubbish bins) and receive vouchers (2 x 500 yen) to spend in the hotel instead. This service can only be requested two days in a row. Thus if one stays for 7 days, with no service on days 2,3,5 &6, one can receive vouchers to the value of 4000 yen. For budget-conscious travellers, "earning" 1000 yen in vouchers (one collects them on the day of no service) allows one to buy treats at the very reasonably priced hotel shop, or other hotel services. Loved our stay here!

This was a great find the first thing is that the airport limo bus stops outside which is great for first time visitors Stunning beautiful with all the Xmas decorations we were upgraded when we arrived to a suite may I say it was bigger than my first unit this would be perfect for families as it is a 1bed unit 2 bathrooms 2toilets lounge room where both lounges turn into beds a little kitchenette the staff where wonderfully helpful and polite it is a long walk from ginza but there are several train lines near overall I would highly recommend this hotel and I will stay there next time we are in tokyo

Just stayed here and had a wonderful time. We are from NYC and speak very little Japanese and the staff was extremely helpful and friendly. We had family in Japan that called the hotel numerous times and once again the staff was very patience and friendly while translating for us. The location is great! Tokyo is so big that I believe it’s hard to be centrally located however this was by subways, buses, etc. So getting around was easy. (Just as the front desk and they can help you with the subway routes.) Rooms were very comfortable. Restaurants at hotel were over priced but I guess that’s what you get for convenience. (Food was very good) The upstairs lounge that over looks the Tokyo Tower was nice however there is a fee to sit at a table. I would suggest checking out the Fish Market. We had a great lunch there that tasted just like our dinner at the hotel the night before at one third of the price. You do have to pay for gym which was about 20 bucks per person for a 24 hour period. So we were able to get to the gym two days in a row for the cost of one day. Just as a FYI, you are not allowed to use the pool/spa facilities with you have any visible tattoos. Husband and I both have some so we were not able to use those facilities which was a bummer, but we respect the culture so we couldn't complain. Overall it was a great hotel for our first visit to Japan. Not sure if we would stay there again next time because we would want to check out one of the other areas (since Tokyo is so big) but will definitely be looking for that chain to stay in. Hope you enjoy!
user_name:
M M
New York City, New York

review_body: Very spacious beautiful view of Tokyo tower and skyline. Restaurants and cafe very overpriced (20 pounds for a coffeee and orange juice) but hotel shop good prices and well stocked with pastries, sandwiches etc. AVOID chinese restaurant - huge lifeless vacuum looks like a converted entertainment room with worst service I experienced in Japan- plate of pot noodle type noodles with beef and a beer 30 quid. Had I not been alone I would have walked out after first 5 mins. Guess you could say I should not try an eat Chinese food in Japan ;-). Friendly Hotel Bus stops here for airport although as its first stop it takes 45 mins to collect from other hotels. Short walk to subway or free bus to station. Approx 10 pounds per night reduction voucher if you opt for GREEN service - ie no room clean

On business I have stayed at this hotel 3 times and each time it is just great. The outside of the building is not much to look at, but inside the rooms are excellent. The hotel has a nice shop where you can pick up gifts, food and a bottle of wine. The rooms are clean, not hugely spacious but enough room not to feel cramped. The toilets are always the interesting challenge in Japan. Just remember to close the door and then the loo seat top won't pop up everytime you walk by! Check in and check out are seamless and the ariport limosine picks up from the hotel frequently to get you back to Narita. All in all a very nice hotel.

This is a very nice hotel, in the heart of Tokyo. Part of a beautiful park, and next to the Tokyo tower ... an excellent place to walk around, day or night. The premium rooms are huge by Tokyo standards (or standards of any major city hotel), and very well appointed. The hotel's sushi restaurant is exceptional. The staff are extremely helpful. I've tried many hotels in Tokyo, and for a top hotel with great value, this is hard to beat. I will be back.

We have always wanted to check out this hotel & finally we got to stay for one night.Checking in a little late on a Saturday night we were unable to get a room with the Tokyo Tower view. So they put us into a half Japanese half western style room on the second floor. The room was very clean & spacious. No view but the room was very large.The location is a bit off the tourist trek but still very easy to get around.I will return but only if I can get a room high up with a Tokyo Tower view.good price also.

Had a fantastic time here. After a very long flight, this was the perfect antidote. Easy transfer service from airport, welcoming staff. Excellent quality of room, with outstanding view from balcony. Balcony is very narrow however, and may induce vertigo! Everything you would expect from a hotel of this caliber. A trip to the Sky Lounge on the top floor is a worthwhile experience, if a little expensive, for the views and the excellent drinks. Would return.

Stayed here for 3 nights at the end of 2 week holiday. Perfect. We got upgraded to a Junior Suite on the 19th floor with a stunning panoramic view. Room was elegant and spacious with large bathroom with power shower and jacuzzi bath and all the usual amenities for a 5 star hotel. Great service from all staff as you would expect and breakfast on the 33rd floor was a treat. Well stocked shop in the foyer open til late and free wifi in rooms. Peaceful location just by Tokyo Tower and few minutes walk to subway Akebanebashi! Shuttle bus to Narita started it's route from here and picked up at 3 or 4 other locations but arrived bang on time 90 mins later.

We stayed at the hotel in late August as part of an 11 day stay in Japan. While not in the heart of the action, I chose the hotel due to it's serene location at the edge of the park. We had a park view room, and the views of Tokyo Tower were spectacular. The metro was only about a block away, and fairly easy to navigate. The room was light and airy, and the bathroom was clean and modern. The lobby had very little seating, so relaxing and people watching were not really an option.  My major complaint was the restaurant open for breakfast. It opened each morning at 8 am, not early enough if you had an early tour. We arrived one morning at exactly 8 am, and there were at least 50 people on line. I learned my lesson, and every morning after that, I arrived at 7:45 am so we were the first ones on line as they opened. Located on the highest floor, the restaurant had a beautiful view. My other complaint was the price. While I knew that food in Japan would be very expensive, I was shocked that the not-too-impressive buffet was the equivalent of $40 US - and it was the only option. On the lobby level was another restaurant, but only had a Japanese-style menu, and I just can't eat salad and tofu in the morning. The great little convenience store in the lobby also had a bakery, but when we were there it opened at 10 am - also too late for touring. I would recommend the hotel as a true oasis in a bustling city. I found a deal on Expedia that gave us a 50% discount on our whole stay since we were arriving on a Monday, bringing our rate for a deluxe park view room to $166/night US.

Stayed for an extended business trip. Excellent service, close to several metro stations, and just next door to an interesting Buddhist temple complex. Tokyo Tower is just down the street, and provides a dramatic view from the breakfast buffet on the 33rd floor. Modern design, very spacious room and bath. Convenience store on the street level is quite large and well stocked. No hesitation to book here again for a future visit.

First of all, this hotel is beautiful, inside and out. It is set on park grounds, with tons on green space surrounding the hotel - including a 2 & 5km jogging trail This was a great discovery in the middle of Tokyo.My room was spacious & well laid out. Furniture was functional, with a surprisingly good desk chair. The wifi for the hotel is divided by room, so there is great performance.The hotel restaurants are located in the basement. They are not intuitive to find. You have to keep walking down the hall, taking several corners to get to the less expensive options.Location wise. I thout this Prince park tower was a good compromise. While it's a very ling walk from any attractions, it is a short train trip or cab to the imperial Gardens, ginza shopping district, tuna market and other tourist destinations.You need to pay. An additional fee to access the fitness facilities. This was a surprise and disappointment at such an expensive hotel

The hotel excellent service perfectly matches its great facilities. I stayed in a room with view of the tower (Definitely worth the extra charge). A short walking distance takes you to nice parks and the access to the metro lines can't be easier. The breakfast at the upper most level restaurant is a must. Can't wait to go back

excellent stay with as usual a very good service -but it has its price.I stayed for business and it was easy to move in the city and close enough to major tourist locations.there are three metro station nearby within 2-12 minutes walk

Make no mistake, this is an expensive hotel. However there are often deals on various websites for this hotel so be on the lookout.The service is very good at this hotel (we were even allowed to check in before the official check in time). The rooms are huge (especially given the standard size room in Tokyo is relatively small), equipped with free wifi and has a very modern and huge bathroom. We had room service a couple of times at the hotel and whilst it was pricey, the food was delicious.We paid an upcharge to use the gym at the hotel but it was worth the money. The gym has a mini onsen (hot spring spa) attached to it which was pure heaven (and free once you’ve paid your gym fee). There was a strict protocol that must be adhered to when frequenting the onsen, so if you are unfamiliar with onsens I would suggest doing some research before hand. There was also a bowling alley on site in case you wanted to laze around and enjoy the facilities at the hotel.The hotel is located near to several subways (about 10 -15 minutes by foot) or you can catch the hotel shuttle which ran every 30 minutes. Also make it a point to visit the Tokyo Tower and Zojoji Temple which are very close to the hotel.We would absolutely recommend this hotel and look forward to our next visit.
user_name:
Aneela D
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed five nights in the hotel on our Round the World trip with my wife. We found the service in the hotel to be excellent. The personnel was polite and friendly. The room was large end the bed huge (Superior King Comfort room). The bathroom was also good with a separate and roomy shower cubicle and a separate bathtub.The location of the hotel is good. There are two metro stations of two separate metro lines within a 200 meters walking distance. There is an Airport Limousine bus connection to Narita Airport, which makes the hotel easy to reach when coming to Tokyo with an airplane.One important thing to note is that the hotel rooms have a free of charge wireless internet connection that seemed to be of good quality and of high speed. This is not the case always in hotels.I can recommend this hotel!

For a 3 day visit we stayed in the Prince Park Tower hotel in Japan. Expensieve but every Yen worth. Very friendly and efficiënt personnel. Excellent food. Beautiful rooms. Situated very close to Tokyo Tower. Easy excess to all interested attractions and shopping malls. Train and metro stations easy to reach.I would recommend this hotel.

The hotel is in walking distance to Tokyo Tower and Zojoji Temple, both worth a visit. You can catch the subway just around the corner from Shibakoen or Daimon or you take the Yanamote / Keihin line at Hamamatsucho station, where you get with a shuttle bus from the hotel every 30 minutes or by foot in approx 15 minutes. The rooms are larger than the average. The breakfast buffet offers great variety, something I always appreciate, as I ususally stay in Tokyo for at least 2 weeks. Plus, the Western breakfast ( there is also a Japanese) is served at the 33rd floor with great views (see photo)To get to the hotel from Narita airport,you can take the Airport Limousine Bus. It brings you from door to door in approx 2 hours for 3000 Yen per person.

You know when you've chosen a good hotel, when you turn up and parked outside is a brand new Ferrari! We arrived an hour before the official check in time and despite many postings about the Japanese adhering to the times, we were checked in and shown to our room immediately.The room was fantastic, very large and spacious and a fantastic view over Tokyo. I couldn't have been more pleased. Nice slippers, robes, lots of towels, the most complex toilet controls you have ever seen and a lovely bathroom, with a separate large shower cubicle with plenty of toiletries! Just ideal.The location worried me for the first day or so, as there isn't much nearby, however I soon learnt that Tokyo is so big, that you need to use the tubes or buses to get around everywhere, so this wasn't an issue. Just don't expect lots of restaurants on your doorstep.My only other slight negative about the hotel, was that you have to pay to use the gym or pool. Which I felt was a bit cheeky. However I decided not to use these facilities and walk for miles around the city instead!Despite the above small niggles, I would have absolutely no hesitation in staying here again and I would certainly recommend it to other people.(n.b. watch out for good deals every so often on hotel websites for this hotel. It's normally quite expensive, however we got it for an absolute bargain but just watching and waiting)

This was a very special occasion for us. Our grandson was celebrating his 21st birthday, and his mother had promised him a visit to Japan as a 21st birthday gift, he has loved the country and the people since he was a young child. Sadly his mother our dear daughter, died three years ago, but her brother fulfilled her wish and paid for him to go. (I had the privilege of coming along) he had a list of all the places he wanted to drag his granddad.We had the most fantastic room; all the staff were very helpful. There was an young man at the reception who was from the UK who gave us all the help we needed to get around (and he saved us from missing our flight back) The hotel is right above the access to all the rail links, so no need to look for a taxi. Although not the best pace for breakfast, there are plenty of other options. The people who work there make the hotel a place worth staying. Thank you for helping fulfilling a young man’s dream.

I think what surprised me most about my stay here was the size of the room. I was on the 14th floor, and was quite surprised to discover a sizable king-size bed, a decent sized desk to work off of and a well equipped and large bathroom. The rooms are very modern and extremely comfortable.In terms of facilities, I did manage to fit in a gym visit which was great as it also serves as an external gym facility so it is well stocked with free-weights, machines, plenty of treadmills and a yoga/spinning studio (didn't do that but saw it was there). That was great.For location, I selected this hotel due to its proximity to our office. There are at least 2 subway stations easily within walking distance, but apart from Tokyo Tower and the associated shops around that, there isn't a huge amount of choice in the immediate vicinity. You pretty much have to taxi to any one of the many more bustling spots if you want to dine/drink/see outside of the hotel.The only other minor fault for me is that the Japanese restaurant closes somewhat early (9:30). They also don't do Japanese room service after that time - and so as a consequence, after my late international arrival, my only options were western (I was so looking forward to some great Japanese...).All in all, a great hotel, well staffed with helpful people, and overall a very good experience in Tokyo.

In the business district but walking distance to Tokyo Tower and walking distance to the safe easy to follow colour coded subway. Hotel has restaurants, spa facilities and a couple of shops and boutiques. Rooms larger than the average, separate toilet and bathroom. Get a corner room over the park.

This is a modern hotel, the rooms are great - quite large for Japan - good location near the Hammatsuko JR station with shuttle bus to the hotel.The best of all were the views to the Tokio Tower! It is also very close to a park and a cute temple (walking distance on the same direction to Hammamatsuko). Don't forget to have a drink at the bar at the ceiling: the sunset at Tokio with the sight of the Tokio Tower is a must!

We left the Westin Tokyo after several bad experiences, and decided on the Prince Park. WOW, what a difference. CHeckin was fast, bellmen has friendly and helped place out bags where we wanted. Free internet and WiFI, several onsite resturants, gift shops, etc. Shuttle service to the mono rail and the Pince Hotel. Prince tower outside your window, and great shopping/eating just 2 blocks away. Room service has been great, and the conierge was been OUTSTANDING helping us get around town and finding places to go see. I will take a longer commute to work to stay at the Prince Park than wasting my time (and being insulted) at the Westin. A+ for everything, but room service price. But, room service is expensive everywhere.

I stayed here on a business trip. The hotel has beautiful clean rooms -- very large by Japanese standards. Fairly modern facilities. Great service by the helpful staff. The location is a little far from shopping and sites, but the hotel is close to the subway, and the price is lower than other comparable hotels, so you get good value.

As tourists we would have chosen a different hotel had we known then what we know now! Rooms- Nothing fancy but a very clean room. The bathroom was clean and had a great toilet console with all the works!Food- It was interesting. The yakitori we had in the in-house restaurant was great but the atmosphere was quite uninspiring. The breakfast buffet was the standard fare in addiction to the local cuisine. The black tea was excellent. Staff- Good enough for us and spoke good english. Location- That was the deal breaker for us. It wasn't in the more popular half of Tokyo and a taxi ride from there was steep. It is close to the Tokyo tower but not much else by foot. If you are looking to walk around your hotel and find interesting spots then I would NOT recommend this.

While I am not an expert on Tokyo hotels, this was a lovely place with plenty of surrounding things to do and restaurants to visit etc.. The rooms are large, the staff helpful, and the adjacent park is a joy to venture through. The proximity to the Yamanote Line was very helpful to us. Tokyo is BIG. For me, even as a seasoned traveler, having an easy point of reference to a line that circles the entire city was very very HELPFUL. The Yamanote will get you to all the major neighborhoods. The hotel, aside from being nice and near the line, is not in a extraordinarily busy part of town. In Tokyo that is a pretty stunning achievement. It is not a sedate town. If you want a bit of tranquility, a park to run or walk in next to the hotel, and easy access to the more action packed places, then this will suit you quite well.

The rooms are immaculate, the service just the same - brilliant hosts.The view from our room was just breathtaking by night. Convenience store open till 1am was a god-send after a hellish flight and (very) late check-in.But...There are so many places to see in Tokyo and each area has it's own little town center, so your better off grabbing accommodation within walking distance of the town centre. In the case of Minato, Roppongi is a far more attractive city centre and this hotel is just too far away to enjoy it.

We spent the week as a family in the hotel and enjoyed every minute of it. The metro stations are super close and you have two to choose from. The only advice I would give is be VERY SPECIFIC of the bed types you would like before check in. If you tell them 3 people 2 adults (married) i child you will have 3 twin beds. It took a long wait and many pictures to try and clear this up. Ultimately we were put into a junior suite so we came out ahead.

Absolutely fabulousService, hospitality, room everything nice. . This hotel made me so proud of been Japanese. My husband (British) who travel all over the world absolutely amazed, still talking about this experience to everyone who are thinking to travel to Japan. Some people complained about eating place but 5-10 min walk towards to Hamamatsucho or Daimon, there are many Izakaya (dinning pub), noodle shops or restaurants. Just ask to concierge who will help you delightfully. There is a mini shop selling many nice things ex: drinks, snacks and very good breads and cakes in the hotel which is very convenient. However if you want to save money, there are a few convenient stores 5, 6 min walk away. Tube (subway) station is nearby and even Taxy is not too expensive if you are tired to change the train from JR or Roppongi. I give you advice, before complain anything, ask for help. They are so helpful and informative.
user_name:
yumimb
Bury St. Edmunds, United Kingdom

review_body: The rooms here are very large by Tokyo standards and the beds are very comfortable. Staff was kind and attentive. Close to subway lines. Restaurants in hotel were a bit expensive, but it is worth having a drink at the rooftop bar because the views are great. Convenience store in the lobby was great -- high quality snacks and some pretty gifts.

Excellent hotel very close to Tokyo Tower. We had a nice view of the tower from the premium lounge where we relaxed for a while in the afternoons. The location is a bit off but it´s only a short walk to the nearest subway station. The room was spacious and fresh, the staff very attentive. Great japanese breakfast and we preffered it to the continental. Very nice pool and hot bath, perfect to enjoy after a day in this intense and exciting city.

Enjoyed our stay at this hotel. Service was excellent. Staff proficient in English. Had the advantage of staying here in the off-peak period and received a room upgrade. The room was large, hi-tech and immaculate. Bathroom was very large. Beautiful views from all sides of the hotel from the upper floors. Several restaurant choices and they were very good. There was a market in the lobby offering drinks, pastries, sandwiches, cheese and crackers etc. Enjoyed the view of the Tokyo Tower from our room. Convenient to two metro stations. I would stay here again.

I stayed in the Prince Park Tower Tokyo for 5 nights during a 10-day holiday to Japan. Everything about this hotel is excellent, from the service to the location, grounds and room. It was a very welcome introduction to Tokyo and Japan. We were upgraded to a premium floor room on the 29th floor which was of generous size for Tokyo (or any city for that matter!). It included one of the largest beds I've ever seen in a hotel room (larger than a normal king size), desk, sitting area and substantial bathroom with separate shower and heavenly large tub with jacuzzi jets. Needless to say, the view from the 29th floor was impressive, overlooking the park (Shiba koen) and out to the Rainbow bridge. As with many Japanese hotels, there were a large variety of bathroom amenities, including a special travel pack to take away. One thing to note is that the design aesthetic in the room is very business-like. It is exceptionally clean and upmarket, but I wouldn't describe it as luxurious. This is not your usual 30-story business tower hotel. Despite it's large size, The Prince Park Tower felt remarkably tranquil. The tower is graced with an ultra-modern atrium that runs up the entire length of the hotel and you are whisked up to your room in sleek glass elevators. The hotel lobby has a very clean aesthetic with glass bridges, silent automatic glass doors, and gentle wood and stone accents. It is an excellent reflection of the modern Japanese aesthetic. The grounds too add to the sense of calm. The Prince Park Tower is unique in being located right in the centre of a large park which includes an old Shinto shrine. The grounds beautifully feature flowers, greenery and that blend of modern and traditional that Japan is famous for. The location is also perfect for it is just off the tourist track and away from the crowds, but close to key subway lines making it convenient to reach districts such as Roppongi, Shibuya and Ginza. The service was superb and what one would expect from a high end, Japanese hotel. Everything was always conscientious, efficient and friendly. The restaurant recommendations were excellent and I would especially recommend the ramen restaurant they prefer. It was the best ramen I've ever had!All in all, this is a top quality, modern Japanese hotel, well worth considering for any trip to Tokyo be it for business or pleasure.

Stayed for 3 nights. Rooms are very big for Tokyo, and have good views (if lucky) of the tower and the temple. Breakfast was good too. Location is pretty central, and well served by subway and taxis (which are expensive! They start at £7.10). A little dated now IMHO and feels a bit 70's in decor. Not a boutique romantic hotel, but very good for business.

I have stayed at this hotel several times over recent years for business. Rooms are nicely equipped and the ones towards the back of the hotel overlook Shiba Park and/or the and Japanese shrine. Convenient to the subway and other sites in Tokyo - about 10 minutes by taxi to the Imperial Palace, Tokyo Station and Ginza, depending on traffic. Roppongi area for eating and entertainment is a short taxi ride away, however not many eating options within walking distance of the hotel. Hotel restaurants are very expensive however there is a bakery/convenience store in the foyer which is reasonable and good for picking up snacks and drinks. Service is always excellent, staff are unfailingly polite and helpful. I especially love the restaurant on the top floor where you can enjoy sweeping views of Tokyo while having breakfast. Great hotel to stay for business but maybe better located hotels if you are going to Tokyo as a tourist.

We had stayed at this hotel in April 2012 and very much liked their deluxe twin room with a balcony overlooking Shiba Park, Tokyo Tower and the buddhist temple complex. So, for our recent trip in July, we booked another deluxe twin room through Kuoni. We arrived at the hotel at around 11:00 AM after a long flight from London. The lady at the front desk told us that we could not check in until 2 PM, which is the official check in time. She told us to go away and come back later and did not even offer us to use the toilet facilities or point out to us where to find the lounge for coffee and refreshments. When we told her that we had requested a room with park view, she looked rather surprised and spent the next 20 minutes or so trying to identify a suitable room for us. Eventually, she told us to leave our luggage with the concierge and come back at 1:00 PM. We thought this was rather unusual as most good hotels do offer to deliver the client's luggage straight to their room when it is ready. Eventually, we came back at the time agreed and a hotel staff helped us with our luggage to our room. Upon checking into our room, we noticed that it was rather smaller than the one we stayed in back in April and did not have a balcony as advertised. However, we were too tired so just tried to relax. The following morning, we looked at our bookings and the information on the hotel's website, which clearly indicated that we were given a standard room instead of a deluxe room, we then decided to go down to reception to ask them to put things right. After checking their records, the hotel staff apologized, handed out 2 free breakfast vouchers to us, and 'upgraded' us to the correct category of room. They then sent a staff up to our room to help us pack and move rooms. Had we not stayed in the hotel before and had not noticed the differences in the room categories, we would not have got what we had booked and paid for. This is rather unacceptable and we would ask the hotel management to address this issue promptly to prevent similar situations in the future. On the other hand, we would strongly recommend other travellers to always make the effort to check that they are allocated the correct room category, for example by checking the hotel website for room descriptions and features. Given what happened, we cannot recommend this hotel unless appropriate improvements are made to ensure good, satisfactory customer services.

Just make sure you know which hotel your stating at as there is the tokyo prince hotel with in the same area and are sister hotels I'm guessing. Id say this was the better of the two from what i saw of the other. We booked our hotel through expedia about 2 months prior and got a good deal .. which i would def advise of .. We arrived latish on a monday night dropped off by the airport limousine bus ( the only economical way to arrive) the there was a lovely man waiting with a big smile to take our bags.Something we didn't quite realise before we went to Japan was how hard the language barrier would be after traveling to allot of asian countries where english is readily understood its not quite the same in Japan so be sure to learn a little before arriving , i found that they either spoke very good english or none at all. Ok where i was going with that was that when we checked in , it was rather hard the girl unfortunately had limited english had found it quite hard to arrange an upgrade to find out what the price would be , non the less with allot of hand signals and miming we got there. We got up to our room which was lovely , not on a super high floor but had a great view of tokyo tower , which is magical at night. The room was on the corner and bit of an odd shape but very nice and just enough room for us to have all our bags out . The toilet is state of the art (you'll understand after you have visited japan lol) the bathroom was clean dn fresh with wonderful amenities . The bed was extremely comfortable and the rooms sound proof . The internet was free although trying to figure it out that there was no charge with the reception desk was hard , but we thought we would just sort it out at the end of our stay . They provide you a wifi modem when you check in so excellent service ! The breakfast ... mmm not that great but has the basics but for the price i did expect a little more... but the view of tokyo is amazing. The small shop in the foyer provides everything you need with a little bakery too , prices are prob 20% more than what you will pay on the street but its open late and takes credit card unlikely nearly everywhere else in Japan , cash is def king in Japan . The location , its so so you can get to everywhere you need to but you are in a park with not much action close by .. but if thats your thing then its perfect. I would have liked a little more action. There is a fantastic service the hotel provides a bus to the local train station ever 30 mins. Make sure you buy the japan rail pass before you get there if you are going to do any travel at all it will be well worth it! Would i stay there again - YesBest thing - view and bus to the train station and free internet Worst thing - prob the location i wanted a little more ini the thick of things ..but the location is still very central .

Clean, modern, great amenities at this hotel near the Tokyo Tower. We got a great deal on Hotels.com and were pleased with our choice as this is a great part of Tokyo to be in – very walkable to many locations and near the station and subway. Front desk staff was responsive pre-arrival and follow up on an issue while we were here was impressive. Concierge was very helpful. Rooms and bathrooms were good size with a little verandah. The views from the 33rd floor restaurant are amazing, especially at sunset.

My first hotel in Japan and I couldn't of asked for anything more. Great service, great location and even has a bowling alley right underneath! The hotel always is busy no matter what time of day and this shows me people love this hotel and for good reason. The rooms are big and comfortable. You have the Tokyo tower as your back drop and a nice park your within 5 mins to the nearest Subway or you have a free shuttle bus to take you to Hamamutcho Station it leaves the hotel at 8 past the hour and 38 past the hour. The concierge is always ready to assist with any inquire you have. For a nice stop and rest in Tokyo I would not go past this hotel.

Picked this hotel because it was about five minutes walking distance from our Tokyo office. Clean and comfortable rooms. Many restaurants within 15 minutes walking distance but not as much choice closer.I traveled with a business associate and he was booked into a corner room which as others noted have more space for the same price. We enjoyed the "American" breakfast daily although it took us two days to discover we had to ask for our omlette to be cooked "well done" to avoid runny eggs.Another tip, if you don't speak Japanese, ask the concierge for a business card with directions back to the hotel. You can give this card to any taxi driver and they can easily bring you to the hotel. Until we learned this trick we were surprised and appalled that many taxi drivers could not understand our English requests to take us to this hotel.We also made daily use of the spa - there is an up-charge for spa services but it is free to use the weights and treadmill and elliptical machines by showing your room key.

I very much enjoyed my 4 night stay at this hotel. I chose it because of its close location to our Tokyo office over other, more known chains, and was not disappointed. I was in Room 1126, a corner room (HIGHLY suggest booking one of these for space alone) with a decent SW view. The room was clean and very spacious. The king bed was comfortable, amenities adequate, closet very large, and the large windows offered great light and views (bathroom as well). The desk was not functional. It was small and pushed into a corner so do not plan on getting a great deal of work done in your room.The staff was fabulous, attentive and efficient (no surprise for a Japanese hotel). All spoke English which I found very helpful, and the small sundries shop was a great plus. They sold fresh baked goods, cold drinks, travel size products, etc. It was like having a very nice 7-11 in your hotel.The buffet was a little overpriced so be sure to eat your money's worth. But of course, the view of Tokyo Tower is unbeatable.Note, when looking at a map and taking taxis back to the hotel emphasis TOWER. The Prince chain has a second hotel on the same property which can cause confusion.I would stay here again, no doubt.

The pros of this place include the fantastic views of Tokyo & Tokyo tower, clean large rooms (with queen beds) a nice breakfast buffet with fantastic views, interesting architecture and glass enclosed elevators. I've stayed here 3 times with my wife and really enjoyed it (hence the repeat visit) The location is excellent and there is a shrine in the back! There are many places to eat within walking distance, two train stations equidistant from the hotel and very close to the fish market if you want to have an early morning adventure. There is also a small bake shop & sundries store in the lobby that has a wide array of things should you need a snack. There is also a fun bar on the top floor with great night views of the tower and a kind of weird piano bar that was totally empty.The only cons that I recall are all of the restaurants in the hotel are very expensive and not really that great . My favorites were the yakitori place followed by the tempura place.

We LOVED this hotel. Had a great Tower view room on the 20th floor, where we experienced a 5.2 (at sea) earthquake and felt very confident in the structure. As Californians, we took it in stride. Our room was incredibly spacious and well appointed. Our experience at 5 Japanese hotels was that all beds are firm, but I was comfortable. Everything is super clean and in excellent condition.Beautiful bathrooms. Wired internet worked wonderfully. Room was well appointed with Nespresso coffee maker, tea (maker), fridge and free bottled water. Staff was EXCELLENT, English speaking. Conceirge really helped me with figuring out train schedules/routes. Location is fine, easy access to subway and a shuttle to Hamamatsu-cho. Fresh bakery items through the lobby store make for yummy, cheap breakfast. Easy grab and go to begin your day.

I've got mixed feelings about this hotel. On the plus side the location is excellent. Many rooms have great views of the Tokyo skyline and the Tokyo Tower; the hotel is clean and very well maintained; the gym is large and well-equipped; staff are friendly and attentive; and the price is reasonable for Tokyo standards.There are various minor annoyances, though: room décor is bland and old-fashioned (I stayed on the Premium Floor); rooms are small; for regular rooms there are extra charges for the use of the gym and ironing board; there is no wireless internet; the gym is not open 24h (annoying for jet-lag victims); and the breakfasts were very disappointing.

We stayed here for a total of about eight nights on our most recent trip to Japan. We used to stay at the Shinagawa Prince, despite its shortcomings, because the location simply can't be beat, but when the Prince Park Tower opened, we switched and have never looked back. The hotel is much newer (2005) and more modern than the Shinagawa Prince, and the service is excellent. If we stopped by the concierge desk on our way out with anything in our hands, such as a shopping bag, someone immediately came over to see if we needed help. Housekeeping was similarly polite, stopping their vacuuming in the hallway and bowing as we passed by.It had been a few years since our last trip, and it seems that the rooms have already been renovated. There is now a sofa in one corner of the room, and we discovered that it is also a sleeper - handy if you need another bed. The toilet is now in its own tiny, separate room, which is really convenient if someone is tying up the bathroom bathing, shaving, etc and nature calls.The view of Tokyo Tower is spectacular if you're lucky enough to be on that side of the hotel. You can also see parts of Shiba Park as well as Zojoji next door.There are a few negatives, but so far they haven't been enough to make me choose another hotel. The in house restaurants are very expensive, and the food I've tried so far hasn't been as good as the prices would lead you to hope. $200 for a tenpura dinner for two, $123 for a steak of 100 grams (less than a quarter pound), etc. The location, while picturesque, is not as convenient as some, although they do have a hotel shuttle running from early morning to late at night. It goes by Hamamatsucho Station and the nearby Tokyo Prince. The Akabanebashi station on the Oedo subway line and the Shiba Koen station on the Mita subway line are a 5-10 minute walk, or you can have the doorman call one of the cabs that are always lined up in front.One last item - the beds are terrible! I don't know if it's because they're too firm, or too packed down or what, but I just did not get along with those beds at all. Your mileage may vary.Summary: nice building and recently renovated rooms, great service, great views if you're on the Tokyo Tower side, expensive restaurants, good but not great location, lousy beds.

The reception area is very upmarket and certainly raise expectations making the standard rooms even more disappointing. However the view from the bar or the breakfast room is breathtaking. Attentive service.

my wife and i stayed at the PPTT on a getaway vacation to tokyo and it was awesome. i made sure to get a room with a tokyo tower view and our jaws just dropped when we walked into our room. the view was spectacular--we just sat there for a few minutes staring out of our window. it was one of the best views from a hotel room i've ever seen. the room itself is standard high end tokyo--i.e. very clean, technologically advanced, modern, and comfortable. the bathroom had a jet tub and of course, a super cool washlet toilet seat. makes american hotels seem downright antiquated. the linens were outstanding and the bed was very comfortable. the customer service at the hotel was, as expected, better than anywhere else on the planet because they are japanese and they treat their customers like absolute royalty. this hotel is no different. everyone bows and is extremely helpful. the concierge there retrieved my sunglasses that i had forgotten in a cab that had driven off. if i had left my sunglasses in a cab anywhere else on the planet there'd be no chance of getting them back. LOL, not tokyo. my wife and i also got massages while there and they did a great job. breakfast buffet is pricey but outstanding. the hotel is also a convenient 5 minute walk to the subway which will take you anywhere you need to go in the city. this hotel is a great choice for tokyo. we would go back in a heartbeat.

The room was spacious and had big windows on two sides of the walls which was great to see the city, especially at night. I always like to stay on higher floors in hotel so this was exactly what I wanted. The view from the hotel lounge is great - because you can sit, relax, drink cocktail and look at the Tokyo Tower. The hotel has it's own bus service to Narita Airport, but I didn't use it because it's not very difficult to come to and from the airport by train and subway. Service is good and they speak English, which is not always the case with people in Tokyo. Overall, good hotel and I recomand it.

The hotel was nice, room was spacious with small balcony which was nice, bathroom was lovely spa and great shower. The hotel has nice view of Tokyo tower and it's close to the subway station which is very very easy to use. The restaurant upstairs for western breakfast isn't that great though and it's expensive but plenty of nice places to eat around if ur prepared to head out.

Funny but after what I had heard about hotels in Tokyo my expectations were very low. I loved this hotel, not luxurious and needs a refreshening but I love it. Big rooms with fancy toilets, expensive but convenient market in the lobby and great location surrounded by greenery and Tokyo tower as well as close to several subway stations. I highly recommend this hotel if you want to get good value for your money
user_name:
lornash
New York City, New York

review_body: We only spent only one night here, and I was not that impressed. We got a very good price for a last minute booking though, and with reviews so high on tripadvisor, we thought we'd try it. First off, the cab ride from Haneda was 6500 yen at 10:30pm, contrary to what the hotel website says it should be (4000 yen), so beware. Also, the man that checked us in did not smile, barely said a word, and processed our reservation quickly. I've never felt so unwelcome at a hotel (especially in Japan!). I had reserved a non-smoking room - but our whole floor and room still smelled like smoke, so I would stay clear of this hotel if smoke smells bother you at all. The woman who showed us to our room was very nice and helpful though. The snack shop in the lobby is a plus if you need something late at night. We had a corner room with a great view of the Tokyo tower. The bed was not very comfortable. The linens and furniture were rather old. The bathroom was very big compared to most other Japanese hotels I've stayed. The amenities were very basic. Check-out was easy. We took the limo bus back to the airport which is only 1100 per person and just as fast as the cab. I would probably avoid staying here again unless I had to.

Prince Park Tower, Tokyo====================It is an impressive hotel. We booked this for our return leg after touring other Japanese cities. We decided to splurge a bit so as to give ourselves a treat. I must say that it is one of the best accommodation decisions of our trip.Pros====- Very big room. Bed is supposed to be king size but a more accurate description is super king-sized.- Room has a superb view. Catching the sunrise/sunset with full view of Zojoji temple and Tokyo tower is an experience that we will not forget.- Nice bathroom, classy fixtures, excellent toiletries. - The surrounding Shiba park is nothing to scream about but give the nearby area a greener, less built-up feel, which is a luxury in itself in Tokyo.- Fantastic service staff. The best english speakers we met for the whole duration of 12 days in Japan were all staff of Prince Park Towers!- Very close to Akabanebashi of the Oedo line. Shiba-Koen station, which is the recommended subway stop by the hotel, is further away. - Limousine bus service direct to Narita Airport.- There is a daily 1000 yen rebate for going green (i.e no toiletries/towel change, making up of room etc.) We could use the vouchers in the hotel shop or restaurants. - Shuttle Bus service to Hamamatsuchō JR Station. Good eateries near the station. We went into this Izakaya restaurant, Akitaya, on a rainy night and had a most amazing dinner. Another Japanese fast food restaurant, Gindaco, is just a few shop-spaces away.Cons====- Nothing that I can think of. This might be a con to some lighter sleepers in that a gong in the Zojoji temple will go off upon sunrise, which was 5.15 am in April. However, we appreciate the different atmosphere that it lent to the hotel stay and showed us another side of Tokyo.Summary=======Not the cheapest but good value for the package and the experience.Tip===Visit the hotel website. They have a very informative page about shuttle bus timetable and map of the bus terminal. We had no problem at all following them.

Started my japan trip with a stay here and I was very happy. The wife and I were upgraded to a premium room (38sq metres - huge by Japanese hotel standards) on arrival which was a very pleasant suprise! The location might not be for some as it wasn't in a bustling area, but with Daimon St only 10mins walk away there were plenty of options for eating out.. as such we were surprised at some of the other reviews saying there wasn't much around.. sure, the hotel restaurant was expensive but with those other options so close by and with plenty of travel options available, the prince park tower was just right for us. Oh and the beds in the premium rooms are MASSIVE!

Myself and 2 friends were looking for a hotel at the last minute and found this one on www.hotels.com for a great (Tokyo) price - for 5 nights in a deluxe twin (2 doubles and a single). We paid a total of USD1,358.70 including taxes and fees.A comfortable (though rather dated) mid-floor large room, shower/bathroom, separate toilet, TV, plenty of storage space, balcony with view of the city plus tea making facilities. Unfortunately we were unable to get a view of Tokyo Tower, as requested, as the hotel was already quite full.Free wifi, polite and helpful staff (ice, iron/ironing board, extra soap brought to the room quite quickly).We didn't have the breakfast but bought yoghurts and juice etc from the nearby Akabanebashi Station which was 5 minutes away - this was the station we used most of the time for sight-seeing.Drinking water and coffee were not provided.We flew into Haneda and were able to get a Tokyo Monorail direct to Hammamatsho Station, costing JPY470 each, then a free hotel shuttle bus to the hotel (10mins). Only 20 mins travel time on the train!If flying into Narita there is a limousine bus costing around JPY3,000 (1.5hours).The lounge bar on the 33rd floor is really nice with an fantastic view. Though expect to pay JPY500 pp for a window view. Or just sit at the bar. Martinis were 2,000Yen each!! The train system ends about 12.30 and starts up at around 5am. We once walked from Roppongi back to the hotel at around 2am and it only took 30mins. A taxi was about JPY3,000.
