We went clubbing one night and got the first morning train back from Shibuya - about 40mins travel time, with train change, back to the hotel.The grounds are quite nice and Tokyo Tower is next door.I'd definitely stay here again!

We stayed here for one night at the end of our holiday in Japan. While we could not have afforded our whole stay there I feel the price was very reasonable for what they offer and was a great way to end our holiday. It is well located near to a subway station, key to any good trip to Tokyo.We had a corner room, very spacious and with a nice view of Tokyo Tower. The bathroom is big and has a powerful shower and jet bath. The separate toilet was the best I had sat on my whole trip! As well as the usual functions it had an automatic lid and flush, a drier and massage, I'm easily impressed. A paper was delivered to our room in the morning. The TV had some English speaking channels, but really Japanese TV is so much better and surprisingly easy to follow. Wired internet in the room, very handy.The staff were very friendly and helpful. Assisting us with luggage, free printing of our boarding passes, and booking us on the bus to the train station (very useful service).Breakfast buffet was amazing, just sad I couldn't make full use of it over a longer stay. Everything you could want for breakfast, plus two chefs cooking fresh pancakes and omelettes. All this on the 33rd floor with great views of the city.Sadly we didn't take in any of the hotel restaurants, little pricey by our standards but a great selection. They also had a handy shop for our snacking needs.I would stay here again if I could save a little extra for the trip.

The hotel is massive with lots of restaurants and activities, even in a bowling alley. The room rate was very reasonable for Tokyo, but the restaurants, bars and activities are ALL very pricey, probably average for Tokyo but expensive in American standards. We had a nice room with two twin beds and a balcony overlooking Tokyo tower. It was convenient to three different Tokyo train lines, but there isn't a lot within walking distance to eat or drink.
user_name:
striebee
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Prince Park Tower is a good standard four star hotel available at a reasonable price.The rooms are reasonable size, well fitted out and comfortable. The bathroom is functional, if a little cramped. The toilet was in a separate room and was fully automated in true Tokyo style.We did not eat at the hotel or use the gym or pools.The location is right next to a subway station, however we chose to walk about 10 minutes to the main rail line that opened up a lot more options, being the main circle route. From here it was only three stops to central Tokyo. There are some good noodle bars (hand nade Soba) on the way to the station. It is an easy walk to gardens at Hamarikyuteien which are a real gem. There is a shrine right next door, more a local place of worship than a tourist spot,Service is good, with plenty of English available.Sleep was a bit of a problem, with air conditioner being noisy. Too tired to bother about it on this trip.

Stayed here for a three day vacation in Tokyo with my partner. Hotel was clean, comfortable and had luxury touches, plus a great view from the top floor bar that rivals the park hyatt.It's right next to a metro stop (metro is the easiest to use of any city I've visited!) and a 10 min walk to a JR station, so it's handy if you have a Japan Rail pass. There aren't a lot of tourist restaurants or sites nearby, but we didn't find that to be a problem, there are plenty of places on the way to the JR station. It is a quick cab ride to the Tsjuki fish market, essential if you plan to get up at 3:30am to see the tuna auction. English newspaper delivered to our door every morning, English language stations on satellite TV.Hotel offers the chance to opt out of room clean for £10 a day in vouchers, which you can spend in bar, restaurant or gift shop. Free in room wifi. Tokyo is truly the city that never sleeps, so if cars driving at night keeps you awake, bring some ear plugs.Finally we saw Jackie Chan in the lift which is hard to beat! Would stay there again.

Easy access to subway and Yamonote line ,which loops around Tokyo . Very user friendly . T he hotel was 1 st class. Large rooms with comfortable beds and spotlessly clean. Restaurants were excellent . Expensive but worth it for a special dinner . Otherwise eating out is very reasonable. The standard of service was excellent by all staff . I would certainly go back . This is my second trip to this wonderful country .

i stayed there for one night on a business trip to tokyo. i had a view overlooking a garden and a temple. Accomodations were fine, staff spoke english, and were very courteous and helpful. The area nearby is very good for walking. with some nice restaurants.

14 days into a 30 day stay here and it is great. I have also stayed in the Tokyo Prince (ok) and the Ibis in Rappongi (yuk) and this hotel is the best by such a margin that I won't ever go back to those other 2 hotels. Great staff who speaks much better English than I do Japanese (thankfully). Expensive but yummy room service. Haven't tried the 33rd floor breakfast buffet yet but it is on the list. The lobby shop always has some decent bakery products which are nice.Akabanebashi subway station is across the street which is on the new Oedo line which is super convenient. Other nearby/convenient things?World Trade Center, Tokyo Tower, Hamamatsuchō Station.

I have been to Tokyo many times, normally staying at the Imperial, but new company with office near the Prince Park Tower led to my decison to stay there. It does not, nor would I expect it to, have the grandness of the Imperial but in almost every other respect it as least as good an experience. I stayed for 6 nights earlier this month (March 2012) on the 30th floor in a corner room with an awesome view of the Tokyo Tower. The room was comfortable reasonably large with a good working area, but it was the bathroom that was outstanding, with a hugh picture window overlooking Tokyo, one of the best showers ever and a great bath with a VERY powerful jacuzzi. Staff were welcoming & always friendly & helpful when needed.There are a few restaurants in the basement of the hotel, but the only meals I had were breakfast - at the buffet on the top floor. Great views of course, but I would say that the breakfast was average value for money at best. It was very busy on the Sunday morning (with non-guests?) and I had to wait for 20 mins to get a table.Overall, very happy with the hotel and the discounted room was particularly good value for near-central Tokyo.

I've stayed at the Prince Park Tower twice. The staff is incredibly courteous (which is, of course, culturally ingrained) and the concierge is prepared to go above and beyond. I contacted them a few weeks before my arrival and asked them to purchase tickets for the Shinkansen for me. They had no problem doing that and making a reservation for me at the Kayabukiya Tavern in Utsunomiya (the monkey waiter restaurant). The rooms are very comfortable and spacious and the bed (both times) was HUGE! I didn't partake in the breakfast buffet (American or Japanese) but I did order room service a few times and it was tasty. I just wish they had a slightly bigger variety on the menu but I can live without that. Take some time to watch Japanese TV...it is hilarious! The bathroom is enormous with a separate shower and bath and both times my room had a great, up close view of Tokyo Tower! And it's super easy to get a taxi in the morning as well as the shuttle to Hamamatsucho Station about every 30 minutes. Be sure to make a reservation because it's a small shuttle. Overall, great stay!

Stayed 1 night in Feb 2012. We got a great 50% off deal on a corner double room. The room was a fantastic size for Tokyo standards as was the bathroom (huge with separate shower & large bath). Toilet was separate to the bathroom as well. While not ultra modern all fittings etc were high quality & cleanliness of the room was perfect. 12noon check-out is a great bonus. Did not spend much time in the hotel however the staff were very helpful with the few requests we had & speak English.The hotel is in a nice quiet area however we did not see much in the immediate vicinity except Tokyo Tower is literally across the road & our room had a great view of it.The closest Metro station is Akabanebashi on the Oedo Line - take the exit marked for Tokyo Tower & to the right & across the road you will see the hotel as soon as you get out. Only need to cross 2 roads (1-2mins walk maximum). There were also heaps of taxis waiting to take hotel guests from the front door in the evening.If you can get a good deal & looking for good size, clean rooms with excellent staff I would highly recommend Prince Park Tower.

Service is pretty good, front desk and concierge were very responsive and courteous. The only issue was when I arrived at 10pm at the front door, there was no porter to help me with my two heavy bags. But once someone from inside saw me struggling, he came rushing to help.Room (incl bathroom) is of a good size, which is surprising for a Tokyo hotel. The design is "functional" at best, nothing luxury. But to have such a sizable room in Tokyo itself is already quite a luxury. And the view is quite spectacular, especially if you are in the mid-to-high floors, even if it was not a Tokyo Tower-facing room.Gym and onsen is okay. A long trek underground from the main hotel building, and it's not free. Actually if you go to the gym alone it is free for hotel guests, but access to the onsen and pool will require additional payment, which I thought was quite worth it.Perhaps the biggest complaint is the neighbourhood. There is NOTHING around! Took me almost 10 minutes to walk to the nearest convenient store, which was even less well stocked than the hotel shop. And there is no restaurant nearby. The only saving grace is the subway station 5 minutes walk away, which can take you to Roppongi and Shinjuku relatively quickly.
Very handy location and very friendly accommodating staff.Only negative was the 'non-smoking' section of the 1st floor bar, I don't think the bar actually accommodates non-smokers at all.

Great hotel near Tokyo Tower & Rail links. Close to tour boats of Tokyo area. Catch trains, boats to all Tokyo attractions easily and safely. English speaking staff and will translate your requests into Japanese for you to take on your journey. Lovely Shrines & Temples and walking distance to wander around the Emperor's Palace. Lots shops and eateries. Great noodle bars.

We stayed 3 nights in the Prince Park. Wonderful people, wonderful service. Very affordable for Tokyo and the location is EXCELLENT to explore the various parts of the city. We never ate at any of the restaurants in the Hotel but we did use the little market near the entry quite often for grabbing waters/yogurt/vitamin C gels etc. The rooms are very clean, free wifi, awesome bathrooms and the robo toilets are AMAZING! This is just the norm in Japan though but still very cool. Highly recommend this hotel. I did use the bathtub a few times and its very deep and is a jacuzzi style bath tub, very hot water and they offer bath salts etc. Super cool place! Oh yea one more thing. Its very quiet as well. We would go out partying all night and then come back and catch up on rest in the am and the room was extremely dark and quiet. Great views of the Tokyo Tower as well.

I booked this hotel online at the last minute while travelling in Japan and got a hugely discounted rate. The room, a corner deluxe, was very spacious by Japanese standards, with a massive bathroom. The service from start to finish was also first rate. The discounted price did not include breakfast which added another 3000 yen to the price, or about $40 each. And a coffee in the coffee shop was about 1000 yen or so I.e. $13. Overall this was an excellent visit especially if your expense account can handle the very large meal prices. Of course there are hundreds of other dining choices within easy walking distance as well.

Earlier good reviews are all valid. As a family of 3 [dad and 2 20yr olds from new zealand after a weeks skiing ] we stayed here to view over 2 nights, Tokyo. Firstly the hotel is in a park and only a 15min easy walk from Hamamatsucho Station(end point of monorail from Haneda airport) if you have little luggage [we left most of ours at airport hotel]. And the walk is straightforward, on polite streets past many nice restaurants (plus usual Starbucks etc). Secondly, perhaps because of the park, the hotel is quiet and our room [just a budget room with rollaway: but still fine and spotless] quiet. I'm sure all rooms have interesting view. breakfast tops, though $nz50. hotel like a retreat, so there is a 10 min walk + to 'tube' lines. But so easy from Haneda!

We stayed 5 nights in the Prince Park Tower Tokyo in May 2010. I checked prices during some time and read many reviews. I can recommend this hotel, right in front of the Tokyo Tower and not far from the underground

We got a great deal on hotels.com for a superior corner double room at about half price. We arrived and the room was on the 27th floor with picture windows spanning the corner and a beautiful view of Tokyo and overlooking the Tokyo Tower, which was right next door. The architecture of the room was excellent with indirect lighting. Separate bath and shower in the spacious bathroom. The location wasn't the best as it was about a two block walk to either of two Metro stations, but both were on the Toei line, which means a little more expensive when you have to transfer to the Tokyo Metro system. All in all, though, we highly recommend it, even if you can't get the excellent deal that we got.

I stayed at the Park Tower on a business trip. I was given a room on the superior floor with a fantastic view, a super king size bed and all the amenities (including free internet). I had a free access to the club and spa and free breakfast in the lounge or the restaurants. All were perfect. The staff was very nice with excellent English and a helpful attitude. Definitely a place to stay while in Tokyo. Pure pleasure.
We spent 2 nights in this hotel.The hotel is beautiful and the service of the staff was amazing.  The hotel is very well located, next to the Tokyo tower.

I was there for just over a week in late November and found the hotel brilliant. I had a Junior suite and it had a superb view of Tokyo tower. I doubt you could have gotten a better view from a room.The sky bar was superb and amongst all of the shops, cafes and restaurants on the lower level it even had a shop you could buy supplies at for a reasonable price. They even sell some reasonably priced wines.My last stay was at the Grand Hyatt and my preference for what you get for your money is The Prince Park Tower. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel.

We chose this hotel because it was in the right district and it turned out to be just great. Within walking distance to the Ginza area and both railway and metro very easy to reach.The hotel had a shuttle service hourly to the train station.The grounds are part of a beautiful temple and the Tokyo Tower is across the street. The hotel had a special on and even with the cost of breakfast at $nz50 per person we thought it was good value.We spent a week and could have stayed longer.The only negative was that the restuarants(not breakfast) did not have a non-smoking area. this meant we were unable to try the food offered of an evening.The staff were great and overall Japanese people could not have been nicer.The spa and pool were an add on but that maybe because we had a special rate.

Having stayed here several times over the past several years, it now feels like a home away from home. It is not decadent luxury. Rooms are very comfortable, well maintained and spotlessly clean. The jetted bathtub is wonderful at the end of the day. I always request a non-smoking floor, and I have never noticed cigarette smoke when I've been there. Staff is knowledgeable, friendly and helpful. The small shop in the lobby has useful collection of necessities and gift items. Lobby bar serves a nice variety of light meals (but it is hard to avoid the cigarette smoke there sometimes). Breakfast coupons can be used in a few different places, including the Japanese restaurant downstairs which serves delicious meals. There are a couple of subway stations nearby, but yes they do require a 5-10 minute walk, but it's a great area for wandering. Taxis stand ready at the hotel entrance. The nearby parks are great for some outdoor quiet time in the middle of the city. Zojoji Temple next door was once the Tokugawa Family temple and mausoleum for several early family members. The temple gate was constructed in the early 1600's.

I have stayed in this hotel twice for the past year while on business in Tokyo, and I really enjoy this hotel for its great rooms, service, and location.Last time I was upgraded to a big room with the great view of Tokyo tower in the Preferred wing of hotel, and it was great. Also don't miss stopping by the Sky Lounge, which is on the 33rd floor, for a drink and/or meal with a great panoramic view of Tokyo.

Japanese service is unparalled. From the moment I stepped into the hotel until check out, I had experienced nothing but excellent service. The room was well appointed, large and very comfortable with a great view of the tower. Located near the subway and JR lines, with shuttle service if you do not wish to walk. Loved the electronic toilet and bathtub even had jacuzzi.

Airport limousine bus stops right in front of the hotel. Check-in was a breeze. Breakfast vouchers explained with Thanks. Hotel room in-room wifi = front desk lending you a wifi router. Simply plug and use.Room and toilet are spacious for Japan standards and luxurious. Clean. Bed is comfortable. Bath towels thick and clean. Shower water pressure is one of the best, ever (for me).English language paper at your door every morning.Breakfast on the 33rd floor with a view to die for. Breakfast each morning was about 90% same items. Small changes here and there but you'd only notice if you eat the salads and fruits. Service is very attentive. By the way, if you overslept and wake up lunchtime. You can still use your breakfast voucher for lunch for up to 2,500Yen. If your lunch cost more, just top up with cash.You can/ must book your airport limousine bus trip back to Narita at the hotel lobby a day before departure to ensure a seat. Best to catch the bus 4-5hrs before your flight. < i am not kidding you.I will stay here again.

Stayed here with my family for a couple of nights before flying back to the UK. Had a beautiful room (Junior Suite 50 sq m) on the 21st floor which easily accommodated the four of us. Can't comment on the standard rooms but ours was large (6 windows) with a superb bathroom (jacuzzi bath / separate shower and loads of amenities), massive TV with some English channels and very comfortable beds.The location was superb - close to metro station and 3 mins walk from Tokyo Tower.Only gripe, if any, was the cost of room service and the restaurants but we ate out most of the time so this didn't really bother us.Overall - one of the nicest rooms and best hotels we have stayed in!

I stayed here over a long weekend when I was visiting Tokyo for the first time in October 2011. I travel by myself to cities for short trips quite a bit and look for high end hotels at which to base myself whle I wander around the city. The staff was very helpful and had a good command of English. They were able to guide me to the destinations I wished to see and were always smiling and cheerful. The room was small (but on par with New York city style rooms of the same level of hotel) with a comfortable king sized bed and a nice view of the park and the skyline. I exercise regularly when I travle and the spa was well equipped and clean. I did not use the pool but it looked very nice. The hotel was also close to at least two different metro stops. I did not eat at the restaurants and so I cannot comment on those. I booked through trip advisor and got a good price so I con't comment on the normal level of expense.One extra kudo. I was in my room one day when the maid came. She was an elderly woman was accompanied by a young man who actually made the bed because she appeared to be unable to do so. I think that a place that cares about its employees enough to help keep them employeed also cares about its guests and that was my experience.

I must echo some of the other recent comments about the high ranking this hotel has received here. I booked the hotel for one week and supposedly had a king bed in a "superior" room.Upon arrival I was given a "park" room on the 18th floor. The second the elevator opened we were overwhelmed with the unmistakable smell of embedded cigarette smoke. The room was even worse. Two beds instead of one and it looked and smelled like some cheap motel from Vegas in the late 70's.I immediately went down to the lobby to ask for a non-smoking room and king bed, queen, whatever. No dice. I was told that WAS a non-smoking room and that my reservation was "park" even though the printout I had said "superior." They brought up some gizmo to help clear the air but of course that's worthless. So while they were setting that up I hopped on the laptop and booked a room at three times the price at the Ritz in Roppongi, on a club level floor. Wow. Wow for the insanely decadent room on the 53rd floor with a forever view of Tokyo and all the amenities that come with that and wow for the credit card charge. Eek! But, you get what you pay for as someone else here recently commented.My wife and I spent 8 days in Seoul and 8 days in Tokyo, and besides all of the memories of activities on the itinerary, etc., the one thing that stood out most was the incredible hospitality of even matter of fact transactions at a cash register, etc. However, The Prince Park Tower was the exception to this, and the only one. The staff was flat out deceitful.When I simply grabbed my own luggage and came down and told them I needed a taxi to the Ritz, they immediately started searching for another room and wanted me to stay. What upset me so much is that I had even offered to pay more for a better room when I first came down to request a non-smoking room and they claimed previously that there were simply no rooms left. When they told me that all of a sudden they could accommodate me, that was sayonara. I don't even know at this point if I'm going to get my money back or not for the pre-paid seven nights.All that said, considering the ridiculously amazing stay we had at the Ritz, I'm actually glad it happened this way now. Buyer beware of this hotel.

If you are looking for a very smart hotel to stay in for your holiday, or like we did, a posh hotel for the last stay on our Japan trip you cant go past The Prince Park Tower, donn't confuse it with The Prince Hotel as ther are two different places very close together, check out the Sky Lounge it's magnificent, price is a bit above average but worth every penny, exceptional service you will feel like a celebrity.

This hotel would rather deserve a 3 1/2 rating but the option isn't there, so I've rounded down to 3 points. The location is actually quite good within Tokyo but you have to know that you'll have to take the Metro from either of the 2 stations close-by, which are located on 2 different lines and are within less than 5 minutes on foot. There 3 room categories in the hotel, with "Park room" being the most basic and "Superior" the mid-range. Only seen those two but the hotel website has pics of the other categories. The difference between 'Park' & 'Superior' is basically in the view, floor elevation, room layout (all Park rooms have twin beds) and minor differences in room size and fitout. Rooms are spacious and come with an accordingly sized bathroom, which includes a jacuzzi tub! The electronic safe is the largest I've ever seen in a hotel room and it can easily hold a large laptop case! During our 2-nights stay, the A/C wasn't coping well with the warm temperature outside (29°) and and couldn't bring the room temperature below 24°C at any time during the day, even at full power. However, the furniture style and colours in the rooms are reminiscent of the late 60s early 70s era and look extremely old-fashioned and don't do the hotel's positioning among the 'Leading Hotels of The World' any justice. The rooms are actually very functional with all the comfort that a business traveller or a couple on holiday could ask for, yet they lack any sense of appeal. So if you're only looking for a comfortable place to sleep at the end of a long day outside and you get a good room rate below USD 200, then this might be a good option. If you enjoy hotel luxury and are looking for a memorable stay while in Tokyo, then look elsewhere.We had booked online and requested a room with a double bed and a nice view, which was confirmed by the hotel. We arrived to the hotel around 9 pm to check in and were given a 'Park' room with twin beds and no view. When I protested and pointed out to the confirmation of my requests, I was told that they had no more rooms left with double beds and all they had to offer was a room with 2 adjacent beds on one of the 'Superior' floors. We eventually had to take that room and although the staff were very courteous, friendly and helpful at all times, it left us with a bit of disappointment. It seems that rooms are allocated on a first-come first-served basis, so since we checked in quite late, we had o take whatever was available. Special requests would only be honoured as long as corresponding rooms are still vacant. The hotel breakfast costs US 40$ per person but the hotel shop and bakery have a good selection of danish pastry, croissants and breads if you don't want to spend that much on breakfast. To rounds things up, this is a good and practical business hotel which also caters for package-tourists. Comparing it to a luxury hotel like the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo, which we stayed at previously, would be like comparing for example, a fully-loaded Lexus to a fully-loaded Hyundai: They may be similarly equipped for a high level of comfort and drive you safely from A to B, yet the former feels luxurious while the latter feels cheap and far less refined. No one would, at least currently, prefer a Hyundai over a Lexus for the same price and there is hardly anything exclusive about the Prince Park Tokyo Tower to justify the regular (high) room rates you may sometimes find online and which are rather at the level of Tokyo's established exclusive hotels.

In July 2011, we stayed for three nights in this hotel based on its high tripadvisor user reviews. The location is pretty good and within half hour walking distance of Rappongi, which is lively at night.However, there are three different types of rooms in this hotel. According to the signs in the hotel, you get "Park Floor" rooms in Floors 3-18, "Superior" rooms in Floors 2 and 10-28, and "Premium" rooms in Floors 29-31. We had a "Park Floor" type of a room, and I can tell you it wasn't nearly as good as one would expect after reading all the good reviews for this hotel. The room furnishings were so 1950s (vinyl, cheap wood, strange color carpeting, etc), even though I understand this is a fairly new hotel. Sadly, we found stains on more than one bed sheet, too.Unfortunately, I increasingly see this phenomenon that hotels have rooms with vastly different qualities (sometimes rooms in old wings vs. those in new wings), and I suspect the glowing reviews are for the better rooms in such hotels. We did not get to see the other types of rooms in this hotel, but I can say without any hesitation that the room type we had surely does not deserve 4.5 out of 5 rating. Maybe 3.One last word. We moved to this hotel after spending three nights at the Four Seasons Hotel in Tokyo, because Four Seasons was twice the money and its location is a bit far from interesting areas, BUT there is no comparison between the kind of room you get at Four Seasons and what you get at this hotel. I guess most of the time in life, you get what you pay for :-)

First tip- if you go to hotwire.com close to your travel date, you can score a room at this hotel for half the normal price, which brings you to about $175 per day, I believe.Definitely stay here if you have a chance. Located very closely to two different subway stations in a pretty park in the middle of Tokyo. The rooms are clean, pretty, and nice.I haven't been to the gym or onsen (you can't go if you have any tattoos that show), but I can imagine they are top-notch facilities.

I have always stayed at the classic, but old Tokyo Prince Hotel in the shadow of the Tokyo Tower but the Prince chain has built their newest hotel just ten minutes away on the other side of the Tower. It is the Park Tower and it is beautiful. Interesting that the oldest and the newest of their hotels are right next to each other.You should definitely try the Hawaiian themed lounge restaurant/bar on the ground floor as it is stunningly beautiful with cascading waterfalls and impeccable service. The French restaurant on the top floor has an almost 360 degree view of the Tokyo skyline and the food is excellent. I can't recommend this hotel more. It is just a 20 minute walk from the hip, yet often overcrowded with gaijin (foreigners) district of Roppongi and the subway line is about a ten minute walk away. Go there and enjoy!

From a personal point of view, this is now my favoured hotel in Tokyo - for work and socialising. It is convenient for me and even better if you fly into Haneda. Extremely courteous staff and great corner rooms with plenty of space.

Its was a great hotel, very huge..i was there for a conference..it seemed like a maze though..but was nice..they also have a departmental store at the lobby for buying basic necessities which was very convenient. Tokyo tower is right behinh.cafes, bars, restaurants are about 5-10mins walking from here near Daimon station..

We lived in Tokyo for many years and were returning for a family holiday with two young children. Centrally located, excellent service and best of all fantastic value at half the price of comparable hotels in the vicinity.
user_name:
James M
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Loved our 3 day stay. Arrived by airport limousine shuttle bus, 3000 yen. Charming, helpful staff. Lovely view from our window, spacious gardens. Location great, quiet and decent area of the city. Felt safe walking at night. Easy access to all Tokyo via 2 underground stations nearby. Also 7 Eleven within 5 minutes walk, useful for ATM for those with Visa or Mastercard. And for snacks. Hotel shop well stocked. Free wired or wireless internet in room - unusual in Japan. Drinks in hotel bar vastly overpriced 1200 yen for one coffee. Taxi to station 1700 yen early morning. Would head straight here if come back to Tokyo.

Booked through Agoda and got a very good room on the 24th floor with an amazing view on the bridge. The price is below 130E.The room is big, the bed enormous and the bath just perfect with a jakuzzi tub and a hi-tech toilet (apparently mandatory in Japan).There is a metro station at just 400 meters, three minutes walking from the lobby. A Family Mart shop is also at walking distance in case it was necessary to buy some food/drinks etc.highly recommended unless you have no budget constraints at all as I doubt that better solutions can be found in Tokyo for this price.
Very quiet location right next to the Tokyo Tower. Excellent French Restaurant.

My colleague and I stayed at the Prince Park Tower hotel in July 2011, and found it to be a very comfortable, business-oriented facility. It's a long bus ride from the Narita Airport, and in our case it was the very last stop on the bus route, so it took the better part of 90 minutes to get to the hotel. The staff was very welcoming and the lobby, while somewhat chopped up with pillars and bridges, was convenient and handsome. The rooms were small, as in all Japanese hotels, but clean, efficient, and well organized.Behind the check-in area there is a small shopping area and a very large restaurant for tea and snacks. It overlooks a handsome waterfall and made for a great spot to sit and plan our coming week's work. We ate in the hotel one night, and that was in a cluster of restaurants in the basement, below the lobby. The food was tasty and the service very cordial.The other nights we walked out of the hotel and turned left, going towards the city center. We found numerous restaurants and coffee shops, including a Starbucks, all just a short walk away.Behind the hotel is a public park (go out the front door of the hotel and climb the stairs on the left) which was pleasant and filled with people, puppies and plants.Also behind the hotel is the famous Tokyo Tower, a TV tower modeled after the Eiffel Tower of Paris. It's a bit of a walk but we strolled up there and enjoyed the view.One minor point -- this hotel has the best elevator service of any hotel in which I have ever stayed. You never waited more than seconds for the lift to arrive. It's almost like it sensed you were coming and pre-positioned the elevator on your floor. Amazing.All in all, an excellent hotel you will feel very comfotable chosing.

I stayed here in the spring of 2007. I'm not going to remember a lot of details, but I remember thinking at the time (and since) that I had never stayed in such a nice hotel. I was on a three week tour of China and Japan. The service was outstanding. The view was amazing. The restaurants were fantastic. I particularly liked the buffet breakfast on the top floor. I loved the view of Tokyo Tower from there. Then going over to Tokyo Tower, it was awesome to look across at our hotel. The park down the street was lovely. Idyllic. The only problem is that I'm far too cheap to ever stay here again.

this was my third time staying here and i enjoyed it very much. they have a nice gym and hot springs. bed was very comfortable and there are many places to see within walking distance. It was a 10 minute walk to roppongi. i stayed for $180 a night through expedia and it was worth it. highly recommend.

I booked this hotel for 3 nights thru their Japanese web site. The room type that I chose had a Tokyo Tower photo where some room type did not. And I checked their English page on facility, it states that gym use is free for members. I took the hotel shuttle from the JR station, I was sitting right at the station with my heads down and the driver simply drove over without stopping to ask. I had to run to shoot so the driver pulled back. I didn't mind that as he may have just missed me. At the checked in, I got a room on upper floor as advertised then I asked whether my room had the Tower view and she said "NO", so I said why not as my reservation showed the Tower photo. She said it's "just an image" so I said, that is false advertising because it didn't state in the site that it is just an image. Secondly, I asked about the gym usage, she said I can't use it and again, I said why not, and she said, it's for members only. So I showed her my Prince membership card and she said not this type of membership. She meant an actual gym membership. What the heck and I brought my gym gears? Again, false advertising, unless you work for Prince, you would not know what they really mean on their site. I was tired so I didn't want to argue. It was 4pm and I had a conference call at 5pm and I always use my calling card, so I showed the staff my toll free number and I asked whether I can use it and she looked at the number and said "I DON"T KNOW". I was like, go ask figure it out Ms Customer Service. Then she finally called somebody and told me it would cost me 3xx yen per call. So 3 minutes to the call, I dialed the number and it didn't work. So I called the front desk and they didn't really speak English well to understand my problem. Anyways, I got to an operator and told her this number does not work. So she dialed it and it worked but the touch tone couldn't work as I needed to punch in the password and passcode, etc.... As I was already late for the important call, I called their front desk again, and asked them to send someone to come up to help. In the meantime, I used my cell (expensive) and for 10 mins nobody came, so I called again to ask them send somebody up. I didn't want to bomb my mobile bill so I decided to use the hotel room to dial long distance to connect my confererence. They finally had somebody came up and I told her the problem and I asked her to go find out exactly how I can dial the toll free from my room and I reminded her to make sure try in another room first. She came back within 10 mins and told me I just have to ignore the first zero (actually I tried that already but also didn't work), so I said did you try it in another room? She said NO, I said then how do you know? She said my boss told me. I was so pissed off already, so I told her to get someone else. Then finally another lady came at 5:40pm and she said my number DOES NOT work in the room and suggest I use the PUBLIC PHONE, WTF? Listen to this, this is the BEGINNING, so I went down to the front desk after my call and asked me how much is the bill and they said 16,000 yen. I told them what happened because they gave me wrong info and I had an important call so I had to use their phone to call direct and I do not think I should pay for it. She went to get a manager and they didn't like my idea and the manager said, if my toll free didn't work, I should make a "collect call" instead, WTF? I had to go out so I parted from the conversation and came back at 11pm, this time the same manager and staff plus another manager (3 staff), I re-explained the whole situation why it was their fault and I should be paid for it and they kept saying the I should use "collect call" and in fact their operator did connect to the number but just I couldn't touch tone. I was like, that is the exact idea, your phone didn't function 100% and caused me inconvenience. So I asked, if your operator connected the line fine but if I can't hear from the room phone, should I still pay for it. They replied "YES", can you believe it? I spent another 90 mins till like 12:30am midnight with those three stuborn staff who completely lack of sense of customer service or I should say common sense. They said the best they can do is 30% off and I didn't accept, so they said they want to come to my room now and checked my phone, I said what will happen whether my phone works or not, the manager said they can only offer 30% off regardless of the result of checking the phone. I was like...then why you want to come up my room at 12:30AM if you can offering me the same 30% off, there was absolutely no value of coming to my room. I told them that if this happen to a real international branded hotel, the conversation would have ended in 5 mins and I wouldn't have to pay for it because they realize it is their fault. I was so mad and tired so I just went back to my room. I asked them to provide a contact from their head office and they said they can give me a customer service number but they never gave it to me. Next day, they slipped a letter and said they tried the number from another room and it worked and suggested me to come to front desk. I didn't go as I know they simply wouldn't get it. On the day of checkout, they still wanted to charged me the full 16,000 yen and I told them no way and they told me the samething about the other room works, so I told them "It does not matter whether it works in another room, what matters is your staff gave me wrong and different information about the phone and at the time I wanted to use it, it didn't work". I told them I was in a hurry so I just paid them the amount less 30% off. Japanese hotel simply do not understand customer service and they don't think from the customer's shoe. This is one reason Japanese hotels can never be popular internationally, only Japanese would stay in Japanese hotel outside Japan. This is by far, my worst stay at a hotel with "lack of customer service sense" staff.

Just back from a wonderful holiday in Tokyo where we stayed at this hotel. The rooms were spacious, the beds great, everything was spotless, and the staff were so polite and helpful. The hotel is located beside a lovely little park and in short walking distance from two subway stations, the Tokyo Tower, and a "Le Pain Quotidien" where we ate lovely breakfasts at a very reasonable price. We tried the hotel restaurant for breakfast once - it's on the top floor. There's a beautiful view of Tokyo from up there and a great breakfast, but it's a little expensive. We didn't see many Western tourists in Tokyo and there didn't seem to be any at the hotel, which is a shame. Everything is back to normal, it's safe, and the people we met made us feel very welcome.

I've booked the room with special discount and paid about $180 a room. I would not pay regular price to stay here but that was a big burgain for such a beautiful property. The bed was so comfortable and there was jacuzzi in the bathroom. The hall way, elevator and lobby was nice and comfortable. There is a bar over looking Tokyo tower and they make Japanese influenced cocktail. Loved every moment.

We've traveled alot and we've never had the combination of amenities and services that the Tokyo Prince Tower provided. Our room was large, well appointed and comfortable. From the Simmons mattresses to the complimentary night shirts we felt pampered. And after a long day of sightseeing it fit thebill perfectly. Breakfast whether you choose the Bakery downstairs or the buffet with the view is wonderful. And the former is quite affordable. The staff is helpful and friendly. We had no trouble verifying the tours we'd booked and getting instructions to various locales. The hotel is also nicely situated. Near a subway station and with bus service to the airport. All in all one of the nicest places we've stayed. And somewhere I'd happily go back again.
user_name:
ManattanTraveler
New York City, New York

review_body: This was only a month after the earthquake, so we were able to book 4 rooms for family that were visiting at 50% discount. The Prince Park Tower is a step above a typical Japanese business hotel, but not at the level of the big international chain hotels. The rooms and public spaces are all well-maintained as expected for Japan hospitality standards. Good access to a couple subway lines (Oedo, Mita, JR by shuttle bus) and the airport limousine bus stops here too. Shiba-koen is next to the hotel and has a nice shrine and many flowers and trees for a lovely morning walk.If you can book a room at discount, I'd highly recommend it.

We arrived in Japan to be transferred to the most outstanding hotel experience of which I will compare all others in the future.We stayed for 3 nights and were superbly attended to our entire stay.The wow factor was when the staff member escorted us to our upgraded room on the 33rd floor, pressed the button, the curtains drew back revealling the Prince Park Tower in all its glory.Breathtaking ! The staff were professional and friendly, the room was outstandingly appointed with more than one could need.We left a day before the earthquake ,we think of Japan often.We have much praise for The Prince Park Tower Hotel ,our stay was wonderful.

The outside of the hotel and the lobby area are quite understated, but the rooms are noticeably more luxurious than other hotels we stayed in.The staff are very, very helpful, courteous and efficient. They even allowed us to cancel a future 'non-refundable' booking!No doubt influenced by the weak Pound to Yen, the hotel restaurants were prohibitively expensive.The hotel is located in Minato, which is a bit quieter than other areas of Tokyo, which is good if you want to be away from the rush of Tokyo, but not good if you want to be in the middle of it.I sense that this hotel is pitched more at business travellers and weddings.It is a great, great hotel - but I don't think it is ideal for couples doing tourist things in Tokyo.One more thing - the gym was really expensive, which I found unusual.

Huge bed, two bathrooms, kitchenette, living room, in-room gym, two televisions.It was the absolute best hotel I have ever stayed in! The room was huge and beautiful. The bed was giant and extremely comfortable. The hotel was wonderful. Beautiful lobby and great staff. The room service was also speedy and delicious! Great location in the heart of the city. Super close to the Tokyo Tower and Roppongi, a quick train ride to Shinjuku and Shibuya. Definitely pricy, but well worth it.

This was the first hotel we stayed in during a trip where we stayed in 5 hotels in total. By comparison, this was not the best. Firstly - beware! Smoking is not banned in many places e.g. the top floor bar would have been very nice had it not been for the stink of cigarette smoke (and the high prices). The ground floor cafe/tea room was always extremely cold - wear a woolen or freeze. They have no gluten free options at all and they take make the black tea very very weak indeed. Most of the staff speak quite good English so communication is simple. We had a high floor room with a view of Tokyo Towers which looks nice when lit up at night. It claims to be higher than the Eiffel Tower but this can only be because of a huge mast on the top!! Tokyo Towers has little to offer the visitor and for better views I'd suggest the World Trade Centre Building a 40-story commercial skyscraper located in Hamamatsuchō. You can walk there in 15 - 20 minutes and pass the temple and many shops on route. The hotel is clearly focussed on weddings at the weekends and business conferences through the week and was very busy with both of these. If your idea of a leisure break is to get pushed out of the way at the lifts by Japanese business men or bowled over by wedding guests - stay here. The holiday maker and the individual business traveller (were a bit of each) are 2nd class. I can't blame this entirely on the hotel but they appeared to have the same attitude. Everything costs extra and it was overpriced so we did not use many facilities. The room was large and comfortable enough if a bit dull. The bathroom is the best part - high tech and included many more toiletries than the average western hotel. I couldn't see how the many shops and salons etc in the basement survive as I rarely saw anybody other than staff in them. The room was cold and despite asking for help nobody seemed able to turn down the a/c. I had to sit with a blanket round me. The worst part was that there appeared to be no lounge just for hotel guests. I have been surprised by some other feedback comments re a top floor lounge because even when I asked I was told there was none. Perhaps this was an 'extra' that also had to be paid for. Breakfast was very varied and well cooked on the 2 days I tried it but the restaurants were very expensive and we found they were either empty and soleless or totally full with noisy conference delegates. Would we stay here again? No. I disagree with the comments that said there is no nearby transport as we found two lines within easy walking distance but the hotewl is clearly not geared to addressing the needs of those staying for leisure.

The room was incredible! Huge beds. Huge windows and views. Huge bathroom! We received a free newspaper, a porter carried our bags to the room. Definately one of the flashest hotels I have stayed at before. A bus was able to take us straight from the Narita airport to the hotel. They had blackout curatins which was great after a long flight - we woke at 9am, thinking it was midnight!

Was staying at the hotel during the March 11 earthquake and was incredibly impressed by the staff and the service provided during this very stressful time. There were staff working more than 24 hours but you would never guess it as they remained calm and cheerful. They went out of their way to assist in any way they could. Thank you prince park tower for all your help, it was truly the hallmark of true Japanese culture.

It was a little far away from the city center, but there are 2 subways lines nearby that made up for it. But no regrets on its location, it is right next to a park where I took a walk every morning, gorgeous views of the Tokyo Tower right next to us too.The rooms are really huge by Japan standards. I love it.Most of all, the service quality of the staff is unmatchable. I was a little late getting back to the hotel for my shuttle ride to the airport and when I half-jogged in, a hotel staff was waiting by the shuttle bus with my luggage! I am so impressed!

The hotel gave me a free room upgrade so I was very satisfied with my room. The bed was the biggest king size bed I've ever seen (it could sleep 4 people). The bathroom was also very nice with a jet tub, shower and toilet/bidet. Balcony view was great.The restaurant on the 32nd floor was was very elegant but pricey. Room service and the breakfast buffet were OK.There is no shopping close to the hotel but there is a large mall a short taxi ride away. The park next to the hotel is quite pretty.I defintely recommend taking the airport shuttle bus to and from the hotel if you're not driving as it is a real cost saver. The hotel staff are extremely polite and accommodating

We stayed here only for one night (out of the five nights we were in Tokyo). This hotel was beautiful and extremely well kept. Lots of amenities, a conveniently located little store on the lobby level, fantastic spa services and onsen, etc. We were very pleased with the hotel itself; however, having spend four days touring around the different areas of Tokyo, we found ourselves not impressed by the area immediately surrounding this hotel. It was convenient to Tokyo Tower, and we took a taxi to Roppongi Hills to do a bit of shopping in the evening, which wasn't too far by taxi, but overall, we didn't find the area too charming (especially in comparison to some of the other areas we had visited in Tokyo). Also, to get to a convenient subway stop it was a bit of a walk (although maybe we were just spoiled being within a few minutes to subways everywhere else we stayed). All in all, a nice stay at a beautiful hotel, and we would recommend it for a variety of reasons ... but we will choose to stay in a different area of Tokyo for our next visit.

The hotel lobby is vast and futuristic and the staff are ludicrously helpful. But what really makes your entrance to this hotel memorable is the toilet. Open the door to this room and the light turns on automatically, the toilet lid rises to reveal a warm seat, and you can't help but giggle. Seriously, though, the rooms are actually quite spacious for a Japanese hotel. They're not terribly new, but they're very clean and the bathroom is quite large. There's no Wi-Fi, but the room service is prompt and delicious. The beds are also comfortable and my room had two walls of windows looking out of Tokyo. The location of the hotel would be good for those wanting a closer look at Tokyo Tower, but it's actually quite a distance from the rest of Tokyo. Those who want to hang out in the city will need to catch the train in.
Great view of Tokyo Tower. Nice breakfast. Close to subway.

I booked this hotel to give myself a treat for the first night in my backpacker trip in Japan. And it exceeded all my expectations! The staff was non-intrusive but ALWAYS there for you. They seemed to be constantly thinking of better ways to serve me and that attitude is something you can't find in many places. I couldn't imagine the rooms being any better for the price. It's amazing how a high-end hotel can keep its value so high. The breakfast the icing on the cake. Funnily enough, I had my best salad ever in the breakfast buffet. The salad ingredients were super fresh, and clearly everything was made from the best ingredients.Although, I can't afford these kind of hotels for the whole trip, I can totally see the extra value of the higher rate in every way.

We just came back from 3 days at the Prince Park Tower hotel, and it was 5 star all the way. A few highlights - never waited for any service and they were all incredibly helpful...maps, resrevations, I left some folders in the airport limo and they hunted it down and returned to me with a smile. We have a 5 and 7 year old, and they absolutely loved the spectacular lobby, glass elevators, and especially the very cool bowling facility (with 10+ lanes and equally outstanding service). The hotel is very close to a train stop that gets you anywhere you want to go in Tokyo (the fish market...very cool at 7am...3 stops away, great restaurants in rappongi..2 stops, Ginza and all its excitement...4 stops, and with a few changes, to Disneyland for a day..40 min away). The big room had an incredible view of the Tokyo Tower, and at night from the small balcony, it was brilliant. We have never been to Tokyo, and I'm sure there are many many outstanding hotels with great service, but this was one of the best hotels that I have ever visited. Thank you Prince Park Tower Tokyo.

I have stayed at this hotel several times. The last time I was there, they upgraded me to a suite on the 30th floor. The views of this amazing city were fantastic and the room and bathroom were huge and very clean. This hotel is comfortable,modern, and offers good service. In my opinion, it's far better than many top-rated hotels in the Western world. The location is excellent too: close to several subway stations and overground JR lines. It's also within easy walking distance of various places of interest. I had breakfast up on the top floor a couple of times. It was good, but a little expensive. The European-style bakery on the ground floor, on the other hand, is brilliant and inexpensive. All in all, I highly recommend this hotel.

Stayed with family of 5 in Jan 11. You see what you get here. Some good deals about but not really worth the money. Two standard rooms with great view of Tokyo Tower, but fairly dated. Still clean and good size. Check in was far more arduous and took a long time, particularly as we had pre-paid. Nothing really wrong just think you can do better. Location in Minato was ok and close to a few subways, it just was not the right place for us. The Hyatt Regency was much better for us.

Beautiful and luxurious! Room was spacious and had gorgeous view of the Tower. Bathrooms were spotless and had a large tub to soak and relax in. The breakfast buffet was the best I have ever had. Massage rates downstairs were affordable and pampering. Bar at top charges for a seat for the view- I bought wine downstairs in their shop and enjoyed the view in my room. I can't wait to return! Many travelers mentioned that the location was not convenient to sightseeing spots, but it's easy to get a taxi and the hotel offers a shuttle bus to the subway. I liked the location-it was quiet and not overcrowded with people.

I can't believe this hotel is only rated 4.5 stars. It is far better than most 5 star hotels I have stayed in Western countries, such as Australia. The service from the staff is exceptional, started from the time they spotted us dragging luggages outside the hotel. We were greeted by number of staff along the way and shown the way into reception desk and seats were offered to us to sit down to check in. Of course the luggages were delivered to the rooms.We were given a huge room (with a huge and large king size bed) right in front of Tokyo Tower with magnificent Tokyo city view. It's modern and everything is spotlessly clean. The bathroom (with large shower box and jacuzzi bath tub) is also a decent size. There is a restaurant on 36th floor with a magnificent city view. This restaurant serves Western breakfast in the morning (which is also good). We love the Japanese breakfast at the restaurant at basement. It's delicious, elegant and beautifully presented.The hotel is located diagonally opposite to a subway station. It's only 5 min walk. Tokyo tower is also 5 min walk.The hotel also offers shuttle buses to the airports and pick up service from a station (which we couldn't find the bus stop. We ended up catching the subway)By the way, we also used the laundry service which is reasonably price and also excellent.We have such a wonderful stay. It's one of the best hotels I have ever stayed and I highly recommended.

We stayed here on the strength of the reviews - all good. We got a good rate the night before after deciding to spend an extra day in Tokyo tomescape the cold of the mountains. We had 2 rooms on the 20th floor. The corner room had a sensational view including a picture perfect view of a snow topped mt Fuji in the morning. The other room was a twin room and was v spacious. The bathrooms were great; the view lovely; choice of 3 different train lines; v easy to get to narita - jr to nippori then sky liner; the boulangerie was fabulous for snacks and breakfast, and while the bar at the top was frightfully expensive 7000¥ for 2 lemonades, a glass of wine and a sake - it was a great experience and the Tokyo tower was sparkling. Felt sophisticated.We found fabulous restaurants in the couple of blocks to the JR station down the side streets. All in all a good choice.

We stayed at the park prince for a week after reading the reviews here. I must say this has been one of the best hotels I have visited! We booked a superior comfort king room. The room is pretty big with a huge bed in it (3-4 persons?) which sleeps very comfortable!! We were lucky to get a room on the 21st floor overlooking Tokyo and the tower! Amazing views, we spent every evening just looking out over the city! You also have a small balcony, free (wired) internet which I made wireless with the Apple Airport Express (very handy if you have an Ipad or Iphone). The bathroom was spacious and with a nice japanese toilet (spraying and warmed). Bathtub nice and nice big shower!Staff was very helpful, also worth a mention is the free shuttle bus going to the Subway station and back every half hour. Very handy indeed... Also worth knowing is that the limousine bus service from Narita Airport makes a stop at the hotel.Downstairs you have a small shop for drinks and food, always good! Pretty nice restaurants too... Well everything was just right for a great price!We left our luggage in the hotel when we went to Kyoto for 5 days which was no problem, after that trip we spend another 4 days at the hotel, same floor, same type room, again excellent!I can highly recommend this great hotel! Thanks everyone at the hotel for a great Tokyo experience!

Stayed here for 3 nights and it was simply the best hotel I have ever stayed at in my life. The service was absolutely remarkable and the location was great. Was walking distance to the Tokyo Tower and everyone that worked here was amazing. I would definitely come back and stay at the Prince Park Tower again!!!!!

Located right next to Tokyo Tower so you get amazing views of the tower at night. It is also next to a park- I have seen many guests of the hotel jogging in the park every AM. There's also a quiet little temple next to the hotel. The hotel restaurant is really pricey but since the hotel is by the business district, there are lots of cheaper restaurants about 3 blocks away. The Tokyo Metro is really close but the nearest JR station is a good 15 minute walk away. Hotel wifi is almost nonexistent but they provide free high speed internet through LAN. Like most hotels in Tokyo, one has to pay extra to use the gym and the swimming pool. I advise first-time visitors to get there by cab. We got there by JR Yamanote and had a really hard time looking for the hotel entrance. We ended up using the south entrance which was very confusing as we had to go down to the lower level, navigate through a maze of corridors, and go up again to the first floor to the main lobby. The rooms are quite spacious for a Tokyo hotel and the beds were really comfy.

We chose this hotel for our last days in Japan. We found a special offer on their site and paid for a Superior Comfort Double with king bed the same price a ryokan in Asakusa requested for a room with a public bath. I wasn't sure whether it was a good idea to stay in this kind of place, and it turned out it was!The whole experience was great: the reception desk, the elevators, their rooftop breakfast... and of course the view! We spent a lot of time looking at Tokyo skyline. If you wonder if it's worth paying a little bit more to have a stunning view from one of the top floors, believe me, it is! I felt sick one of the evenings and could stay in bed watching sunset and then all the Tokyo lights, it was simply amazing.The king size bed is pretty big, maybe too big for a couple of honeymooners, believe me, you feel a little alone in the middle of that huge thing! About the bathroom, it was fantastic. There is both a shower and a bathtub (with jacuzzi!), you get bath salts, and high quality shampoo and body gel, bathrobes are comfy, though yukatas are surprisingly small and ugly.Housekeeping service turned out to be useful. You can get free ice, a new towel or any other thing almost immediately. There are free shuttles to the closest JR station (great when going to the airport). Also breakfast is amazing (though expensive). Lasagna might sound strange for breakfast but it was a real treat (and we hadn't had a real western meal for a while). Restaurants are incredibly expensive, definitely not worth it (1000 yens for a Coca Cola, really?), but the one in the 33rd floor has stunning views. And finally, the elevator ride. Stupid, but still fun, kind right straight from a sci-fi movie!I certainly recommend this hotel. It's expensive but totally worth the price.

My Husband and I stayed here for 9 nights in Nov / Dec 2010. After a long flight and troublesome train ride to the hotel we had to wait until 2pm for check in....which was expected, so went to the restaurant on the Ground floor to get some food. This was quite expensive, but the food and service were flawless.Once we were able to get in our room - we were very pleasantly surprised at how spacious it was...we had a corner double room. The bed was a good size and the bathroom was very spacious with a spa bath that was to die for!!!Some other great features of the hotel were the free internet in the room (we brought our own laptop), the option to skip housekeeping and get a 1,000 yen voucher for the hotel shop (we did this on a few occasions), the hotel shop was a god send as no 7 elevens that close to the hotel ( the prices were standard as well). This shop has a lovely bakery in the back - much cheaper option the paying for the breakfast. Overall we had a very enjoyable stay here - there is a subway station just a short walk away, so don't let this put you off....the trains run every few minutes.

We prebooked and got a heavily discounted room making this a really good value stay for two nights at the start of our trip around Japan. The hotel service was excellent, staff were so helpful, and we had a corner room (recommended) with a great view of the Tokyo tower. The roof top bar is expensive but well worth a visit for drinks & snacks in the evening as the Tokyo views are stunning from some comfy settees. The western style breakfasts, also on the top floor, were first class and very popular. Although the local area wasn't great for restaurants, or at least we only found a few, it is right on top of the metro (Shiba-koen or Akabanebashi) so getting to other areas couldn't be simpler.

This hotel would be one of the best hotels in Tokyo, if the price-value performance was good. Meaning for that price everything should be perfect. The lobby is very modern and the grounds of the hotel have some beautiful Japanese gardens near the hotel. The rooms are huge for Japan and there are 3-4 nice restaurants on the top floor. There are fitness studio onsite, onsen bath and swimming pool. It is located near several tourist attractions in Tokyo like the Zojoji Temple temple and the Tokyo tower. This hotel is extremely popular for Western Style weddings.Here is the hitch. The restaurants are insanely expensive even for Tokyo. You have to pay a daily fee to use the fitness studio and onsen. At the price you pay for the room it should be included in the price. OK the hotel is centrally located, but it not located for easy access to subway and train. Only one subway station is nearby. I was lucky to find a great deal online. My recommendation, only if you have money burning a hole in your pocket or if you find a good deal would I recommend staying here. Somehow I think you can get the same value for 2/3 of the price at other hotels.

I split my time in Tokyo between the Prince Park Tower and the famed Park Hyatt (see review). Honestly, I preferred the Prince Park. The hotel is in a lovely location--a bit away from the Shinjuku hustle, next to Tokyo Tower. The large room ( over 325 feet is large, particularly in Tokyo) has wonderful amenities, including the jaccuzzi style tub and a host of thoughtful little extras---bath salts, tooth brushes and tooth paste, to name a few. I had a lovely view of the Rainbow Bridge from my room.Getting to the Prince Park from Narita is a breeze. Simply purchase a ticket from the Friendly Limonsine Service (it's a nice bus) for approximately 3,000 yen. You will be driven directly to the hotel (with additional hotel stops prior to your arrival at the Prince Park). The Prince Park is massive, sleek, lovely and very safe. I paid $150 per night for my room. The price was unbeatable given the hospitality and amenities provided at the Prince Park.

My husband and I absolutely loved the Prince Park Tower. When we staggered off the airport limousine bus after arriving in Tokyo, exhausted and jet-lagged, the hotel staff blew us away with their welcome and wonderful service. Our room, a superior double, was fabulous - spacious, comfortable, well-lit, and with great views and a fantastic bathroom. We enjoyed the coupons they gave us, 2,000 yen per night we stayed, and used them for a free breakfast and a free dinner. We also took advantage of "green cleaning" - ie skipping cleaning - for an extra 1,000 yen per night. For Tokyo, I thought the 21,400 yen we paid per night was quite reasonable. If I ever return to Tokyo, I'll definitely stay here again.The only slight drawback is the location. For JR pass holders, it's about a 15 minute walk from the train station, though there is a shuttle every 30 minutes. The subway is closer. There aren't a lot of great food options within walking distance. There are a lot of cheap noodle shops, but not much that's nicer. However, it's not a big deal to take the subway or train for a wider array of food options.

The rooms were very beautiful, spacious, and extremely comfortable. Across the street from Akebanebashi subway station, which make getting around the city easy, fast, convenient, and affordable.The view from my room was also incredible overlooking the park.

I stayed in executive room of them for 5 days. Price/Earning ratio for me is very good. One of the best rooms i have every stayed. A week before i was in 4 seasons Istanbul, and for me Prince Park is a little bit better with an half price.I easy can advise this hotel to my friends and do not worry to stay there if this is your first visit in Tokyo as mine was.

We stayed at the beginning and end of a 2 weeks trip to Japan. The tower is divided in the first levels with standard rooms - if you book on hotels.com or websites this is most likely what you will get - and superior bedrooms/suites on the top levels. We stayed first in a standard double corner (the best), the room size and bedding was very good although it was a smoking room so smelled a little, but the view was amazing! the bathroom has bathtub and shower, all the little things you need (from shampoo to hairbrush). Second stay we were in a non smoking standard twin bed: not the best view but same cleanliness, qualitty of bedding, bathroom a bit smaller. This hotels is one of the "Leading hotels of the World" so you can expect great service.Overall it is a really good deal if you book online through an agent as local prices are very expensive. The hotels offers a lot of services including newspaper to your door every morning, bakery and shops, spa in lower floors, a couple of restaurants and ...bar on top with amazing view over the Tokyo Tower. The staff was very polite and helpful. Finally please note (very handy if you have a JR pass and want to use the Yamanote line in Tokyo) that they offer a free minibus ride to the nearest yamanote station. Two tube stations are also walking distance.other things to note: there is free internet via cable so forget it if you use an ipad and the gym is extra (very expensive).

We just returned from our first trip to Tokyo last night. It was a very enjoyable vacation, which was added to given the quality of stay we had at The Prince Park Tower. First of all, the service was just great from the moment we stepped off the airport bus. Everyone greeted us with a smile, spoke very good English (which we heard was hard to find at many places in Tokyo), and was very accommodating even though we were the only ones there with a small child. They upgraded us for free to higher level and larger room to give us more room for our son, which we really appreciated.The location was great. You are very close to several metro stations and within walking distance of some great attractions in Tokyo. We did not eat in any of the restaurants, but were appreciative with a small child that a McDonalds was only a 5 minute walk away. We also utilized the Hotel Shop for pasteries, yogurt, and juice every morning which fed the three of us for around 1,300 yen (300 yen if you include the 1,000 yen voucher they give you for waiving cleaning service to your room).The room was very spacious and had free internet that we really appreciate to help planning on days in Tokyo. Will say that they do advertise that the rooms have a fridge, but it is actually a stocked mini-bar, but we were still able to fit our colas, waters, and juices for our son thatt we purchased at stores nearby or in the lobby.Highly recommend for any type of traveler.Would highly recommend for anyone making a visit to The Prince Park Tower

Stayed for a week in one of the higher level floors which included a balcony that afforded excellent views. The room and bed were exceptionally large by any standard and we too were amused by the bathroom features.Limo. bus from Narita drops off and picks up at the main entrance and two metro stations less than 5 mins. away make criticisms of quiet immediate surroundings seem a bit shallow.Used the 'forego room servicing - collect voucher' system to have complimentary breakfast on the top floor.We made the reservation on the basis of reviews here and also got a good deal from Expedia. Very happy with our decision.

Hotel is located at the heart of the city, very well connected with trains, metro and limousine services.Most of the city attractions like Roppongi (for Night life), Shibuya, Ginza, Daiba etc are minutes away from Hotel. The famous Tokyo Tower is within 2 min walk from hotel, a must see place, and good for clicking few photos!Hotel has excellent facility for Jacuzzi (so after spending time in city you can relax in it!), Swimming pool, Fitness center, etc.Food is excellent!No need to mention that the staff is very nice.I must say that I had a great time staying in this hotel.

I've stayed at the Prince Park Tower a few times on business and can say that - for a hotel rated as 5 star - it is functional but far from exciting. The rooms are good size for Tokyo but smell of smoke (even the non-smoking rooms) and are rather dated, but are clean and have great Japanese whiz-bang toilets that can sing and dance...Lobby is impressive, lots of very Japanese restaurants (even the non-Japanese restaurants), which is a good thing in general. However, they close early, so don't expect any food after 10 pm if you are arriving late except for room service. The area around the hotel is a park and the Tokyo Tower. Good to look at/nice to walk around but deathly dull. Need to hop into a cab to get anything more interesting in a city with some really great, lively areas. Even the stunning view of the Tokyo Tower at the top floor bar (which is nice) is offset by the really, really tame atmosphereAll in all - good for a business hotel if office in area, but much better option in the city...

Paid extra to get a room on the executive floor. Money were well spent once we have enterd the room. Tokyo's breathtaking panorama filled with neon lights seemed to be invading our room through floor-to-ceiling-windows. Fantastic!

First trip to Tokyo...or to Asia for that matter, and was very happy with our choice for a nine night stay. Stayed on the Premium floor which I think was worth the price. The premium lounge made it easy to grab a snack when you didn't want to deal with going out, and having breakfast in the lounge was a relaxed experience as opposed to the other breakfast areas which were a lot busier and hectic.After making the reservation, I did have a bit of anxiety about the hotel location; as mentioned in other reviews, it's not in the middle of everything. This worked out to be a blessing of sorts. The hotel is located in/near Shiba park, which contains a very nice temple complex which I read contains the oldest wooden structure in Tokyo. The setting is very peaceful, which we appreciated since we were running around town so much, in what ended up being the hottest September on record. The relatively new Oedo subway line, accessed at the Akabanebashi stop, got us almost everywhere we wanted to go. It's a line that takes you quickly and directly to the fish market, Roppongi and Shinjuku. You are also near the Shibakoen stop of another line that takes you near the Imperial Gardens/Tokyo station directly. Really, getting around could not have been easier on Tokyo's excellent spotless subway system. I recommend getting a Pasmo card at the subway station (a proximity type card, cash only) which will automatically take off the price of the subway ride. Also notable is that most ATMs don't take American ATM cards, so you will need to either go to a 7-11 or post office, both of which are very near the hotel. The concierge will help with that.One thing I found odd was the decor of the room. It had everything you could really need, and it was kept near spotless, but it looked like it was decorated by a Japanese grandma, which is so different than the public spaces of this hotel, which are very modern with glass, chrome and white marble. I guess this is geared more towards Japanese middle-aged tastes, as opposed to the decor you would fine the the Four Seasons near Tokyo Station or the Ritz in the new Midtown tower, which is more international. In some ways it added to the authenticity of the experience, instead of feeling like you are in a luxury hotel room in any large city. I will also add that I would not consider the room to be large, but we were able to storage our luggage reasonably out of the way, and the bathroom actually was quite big.Putting the decor of the room aside, everything else about the room was great. The bed was extremely comfortable and the bed linens were very good. Towels were good and the water pressure and hot water availability was excellent. Washlet toilet was a unique but recommended experience. Once we settled in, we appreciated the comfort of the room more and more. Keeping the room cool with the heat outside was a little spotty at times, but this really was not a big issue, particularly since we like our rooms really cool. The room view was EXCELLENT and a very good selling point.We got a very attractive rate by using the rate search function on Tripadvisor...it's worth checking out since we got something like 40 percent off the usual prohibitive price.The fitness complex/Japanese bath is pretty remote, but very nice. It's part of an extended conference complex attached via underground to the hotel which was used for a national election while we were visiting. We felt like we were part of history!Service was very helpful. Arranging for the bus back to Narita could not have been easier with the bellhop's help. Also, the hotel will hold your luggage up to 10 days, which we used for a 3 day getaway to Kyoto/Osaka. I have heard from others that the level of service in Asia is hard to beat, and I could not agree more. Get ready for a LOT of bowing, though!We loved the trip, and despite a wicked long flight and jet lag from which we are still recovering, we plan on returning. Would be open to other hotel options with our return, but if the Prince Park Tower ended up being a good deal, we would not hesitate in booking.

smelly damp rooms smelling of carpet. i cant believe its a "luxury hotels of the world" member. even the spa is mediocre. and "people with tattos are banned from the spa" how quaint is that. even though my room was on the 17th floor and I could get sunlight, I cant figure out why there was a smell of carpet and damp

I staid only for three nights with my wife and 2 kids (4 and 13) in our first visit to Japan. Disregarding a mistake assigning us a Smoking Room when I explicitly requested -while booking- a non-smoking one (that was solve very quickly) and not taking into consideration how expensive are the restaurants inside the Hotel (more than the average for Tokyo that is already very expensive in comparison with US standards), I have to recognize that this was the Top of the three hotels we staid in our trip that took us to Beijing, Shanghai and Tokyo.I found and excellent deal in Orbitz and taking in consideration the high prices for taxis in Tokyo I choose -correctly- this Hotel that was relatively close to all the places I planned to visit (Yoyogi Park, Shibuya Crossing, East Garden and Imperial Palace, Ueno Park and his Museum of Nature and Science, Asakusa-Taito and Tsukiji Fish Market), this was the best option and I don't regret at all.You have to take advantage of the great hydromassage tube and will hallucinate with the high tech WC (this is for the first time visitors) that you will have in your room and the endless bath amenities they offer.Our room view was just great, in front of the Tokyo Tower in the 9th floor. I reserved an additional bed and it was just find for our crew. A little bit small for US standards but good enough for us.The breakfast buffet was expensive for our budget (around US$ 34 each) so we choose different options you have when you take the way to METRO DAIMON STATION.If you are planning to take 4 or more metro rides I suggest you to buy the Day Ticket that will save you money, time and convenience.The hotel was just excellent room service, Internet access and everything. They also have a convenience store in the Hotel Lobby, is a bit expensive that the regular ones but is an option.We didn't use the complementary bowling and swimming pool but they look great. I couldn't connect my electric devices to their outlets and I just call Guest Services and they provided my one in a very expedite way.You have three metro stations very close to the hotel: Daimon, Shibakoen and Akabenabashi.I strongly recomend this hotel.
