I stayed here last weekend for two nights covering business and leisure, and was struck by the politeness and efficiency of the staff (perhaps I ought not have been that surprised, it is Japan after all), the cleanliness of the hotel, the modern and contemporary style of it, and the modest but well appointed rooms. The bathroom was quite something to behold - marble walls, slate floor, huge mirrors, a roomy and powerful shower, jacuzzi bathtub and, not that I would normally comment on it but, a toilet that would turn Jimmy Saville green with envy; all gadgets, functions, features and powered everthing. Almost laugh-out-loud funny. Laundry and room service was polite and efficient to the point that it made me feel ashamed of what our own country has to offer, and should probably give American hotel services pause for thought. The bar, restaurant and breakfast costs would probably make an oil sheik cough his mints out, but the location means that you're only 5 minutes walk from Minato district which is food and drink heaven. Some great attractions also within walking distance - Tokyo Tower (5 minutes); a large, operational (is that the correct phrase?) Buddhist Temple (next door); a beautiful park (adjacent and next to the World Trade Centre); World Trade Centre (10 minutes); harbourside (12 minutes); Roppongi Hills district (1/2hr, or £5 taxi). One of addtional great features of this already great hotel is that it operates a low price coach service to and from Narita airport from in front of the hotel - about £30 each way - that is a thoroughly recommended alternative to the punishingly expensive taxi service (which comes in at an eye-watering £215 each way. You have been warned =D). All in all an excellent and throughly recommended hotel.

The Tokyo Prince in Minato has surprisingly big rooms, compared to other hotels in Tokyo. My nightly rate was 11,000 Yen/night. Though the hotel was kinda old--as in 70's old--it was clean. Plus they've got Zojoji Temple nearby.

Great place to stay! We stayed in a corner club room. Excellent restaurants, bar and coffeshop! Excellent spa! And near almost everything! (Within 15-20 mins of most places!) The hotel lobby shop is also excellent and at non-hotel prices! Overall a great experience!

I am a veteran traveler who goes to Japan 10 times a year, and stays at numerous hotels. I grew up in Japan and North America so I understand both culture. I stayed here for the first time a few weeks ago, and you should be aware that I do NOT agree with most reviewers for the following reasons:1) Location - it's only great from the perspective that you are close to Tokyo Tower, but you are AWAY from everything else like shopping. Since Tokyo Tower can be accessed by train from anywhere in metro Tokyo, why stay close to Tokyo tower where there is nothing (not even great restaurants around there). Within walking distance, other than the Tokyo tower and a nice park, there is nothing else to see.2) Cleaniness - I was shocked to find some "human hair" (not head hair) around the basin area and generally, the room is outdated (early 2000 style) except for the semi-decent TV. The decor is awful, there are so many other hotels with better interior for the same price.3) Service - OK at best. When I complained about the hair problem and general cleaniness of the room, I got a different room but they never apologized. When I try to ship a luggage from the hotel to Narita airport (which is usually a 3 min task at places like Hilton), it took more than 45 minutes! 4) Noise - The place is congested because there are so many group tours. Not a quiet or pleasant place to be. 5) Cost - I paid about $220 which is ridiculous considering that for another $50 I could have stayed at Imperial hotel or Conrad Hilton (top hotels). This is not good value.Trust me, there are many other better hotels in more convenient locations such as Shinjuku Hilton or Shiodome Royal Park Hotel or Dai-ichi hotel in Ginza. I do NOT recommend this hotel unless you are find a super deal or you are in love with Tokyo Tower and want to stay within walking distance.

Enjoyed this hotel very much due to large room, great views, fine service and reasonable rates. Joining hotel club online was worthwhile for specials including promotional rates and included buffet breakfasts. I believe rooms above 20th floor are premium and worth the upgrade. Buffet breakast on top floor was very good. Top floor bar nice for a drink but rather expensive. The hotel shuttle to city's great subway was convenient and ran often. Getting used to the subway is essential to a Tokyo visit and there are quite a few english speaking citizens to help lost tourists.

We stayed at the Prince Park Tower Tokyo for 3 nights. We had a superior comfort king room which had an amazing view of the Tokyo Tower and a buddhist temple. The king size bed was larger than a regular king size bed. The bathroom was a nice size as well. The staff were very polite and helpful. Our rate did not include breakfast, but the hotel has a small store in their hotel that sells soda, water, yogurt & a small variety of pastries. We had dinner at the chinese restaurant in the hotel. The portions were small which is typical for Japan and the prices were high which are also typical for Japan. It was a 10-15 minute walk to the nearest subway. Once you get the hang of it, the subway is incredibly easy to use to get around Tokyo. We would definitely stay here again!

This hotel has several nice features including gorgeous views, worthwhile premium level rooms and lounge that include full useage of the spa and fitness facility. The fitness and spa facility are a long walk from the rooms but the real hot-spring water in the onsen bath and fitness facility with true dance studio and heavy weights are adequate for even the professionals. There is a nice bowling/billiards and dart salon which was busy and fun. The view from the bar is absolutely stunning and the second hand smoke situation in the bar is much better than at the Park Hyatt Tokyo. The concierge staff at this hotel was better than most. Housekeeping and room service were quick to respond. Although I didn't use it, there is a woman only floor where it is impossible to be seen by the general public. Security at this hotel was visible.

A calming oasis in a famously hectic city, this hotel was a great place to return to at the end of a long day. The Tokyo tower facing rooms also overlook the nearby Buddhist temple which is worth a visit. The fastest way to get there and least expensive is to take the sky access train from narita to Daimon station and then walk or switch trains and go one stop further to Akabanabashj atop. Roppongi and the Tsujiki fish market are just a few subway stops away. Strongly recommend this hotel!

I spent three weeks in this excellent hotel and would recommend to anyone. As other reviews have mentioned the outside of the hotel is rather disappointing, but this soon disappears once you step inside the hotel. I stayed in the cheapest room - the park twin - but was still excellent. The room was clean and fairly spacious with a jacuzzi bath and separate execellent power shower. The green clean scheme is worth taking advantage of - where you are given YEN1,000 credit to spend in the hotel shop if you forgo the cleaning in your room (room has to be cleaned every third day at a minimum though).Free internet also a bonus.I had breakfast included in my room rate, although being vegetarian the choice was a bit limited, there was enough in terms of potatoes, vegetables, toast, cereal, pastries vand fruit to fill me up. Meat eaters have a huge choice.The gym and spa facilities are excellent for hotel facilitiesThe hotel is conveniently located near a couple of subway stations - both within a few minutes walking distance to get you anywhere in Tokyo - even as far as Disneyland. For bars and restaurants, Roppongi is just a couple of stops away (from Akabanebashi station). The Tokyo tower is also just a few minutes walk away.Overall, an excellent hotel in a convenient location with excellent service.

The Prince Park Tower is a lovely, 4 star hotel. We had a triple room - not so easy to come by in Tokyo -- that was spacious and graceful. The bathroom was excellent with fine toiletries, separate shower, jacuzzi tub and, naturally, a separate, wonderfully equipped toilet. Yes, the lounge is on the expensive side, but lovely and tranquil -- and if you need a quick pick me up, yogurt for breakfast, a drink, a snack, or some fine pastries the store in the lobby has everything you need for 100-200 yen. There are several combini in the area and 3 nearby train stations, so that you can go in any direction at any time. The concierge staff is adorable and they give you maps galore and point you in the direction of everything you need to know.

From our premium type room on the 29th flloor we enjoyed a great view of the Tokyo tower. The location of our hotel is ideal, Hamamatsucho station on the JR loop line is only 10 minutes by (complementary) hotel shuttle twice an hour. Hamamatsucho station is just a few stations to Shinagawa or to Tokyo central station. Furthermore, two TOEI subway stations are near, one just across the street and the other around the corner, on the Hibiya dori.Staying in a premium room, we had (complementary) access to the lounge on the 32nd floor and to the swimming pool. There is only one problem, the traffic noise because the windows in the bedrooms are single panes. Surprisingly, the windows in the lounge are double panes, the lounge being therefore more quiet than the bedrooms.We benefited from a special offer: when we skipped the daily cleaning of the room, a voucher was offered for that day which we used in the hotel shop.One suggestion for dinner: the Benoit restaurant (with its menu from A. Ducasse) on Aoyama (east of Shibuya JR station) offers excellent French food witthout being overpriced.

For $200 a night for a triple room, the deal we got on the Prince Park Tower Hotel Tokyo can't be beat. The hotel is located near Tokyo Tower, Akabaneshi station (subway), and Shibakoen station (subway), and is very convenient in terms of transportation.Otherwise, the hotel pretty much has everything that a luxury hotel has: large rooms, good views (though not of Tokyo Tower unless you're willing to pay $20 extra), and friendly (English-speaking) service. Unique touches included automated window shades and separate bath and toilet rooms. And $200? Some business hotels in which we stayed neared that price for 3 people.The only disappointment is the high prices for the spa/pool downstairs. If you're in Tokyo, however, you're probably better off not lounging in the hotel.

We spent three nights at this great Hotel, the rooms were lovely, my wife and I had a corner double and my son had a twin room which was next door but not adjoining. Everything was taken care of very efficiently the service was top notch. The rooms were kept impeccably clean. I loved the robes and slippers.One tip I can give is to sign up for the Prince Hotels reward card with this card we were given a decent rate that included a buffet breakfast (quite good) and access to the pool health club and some free bowling. I only wish that I had the time to use all those benefits

Friendly Staff, very attentive, helped greatly with planning trip.rooms had a ridiculously awesome view. clean.the outside of the hotel is in need of a revamp, and when i arrived i was a little wprried that the inside might match the outside. that wasnt the case. this hotel is worth the money, great location, great staff.dont eat at the hotel, a little expensive for what you get have to pay extra for the pool (-)

We stayed here 2 nights. The room had very modern interior and the service was very good as well. We requested a room with the Tokyo Tower view, when we booked online. They charged us 3500yen, but it worthed. Our kids loved the close view of the Tower at day time as well as at night with lights. We had a big double-bed, a cot and a single-bed for our 4-y-old son. All these beds made a room a bit smaller, however our kids had enough space to play in the room.Besides the view from the room, we enjoyed also the view from the breakfast reastaurant.

With the beautiful view of the elegant Tokyo Tower, especially the illumination light up during evening, and the tranquil Zojoji temple just beside, this hotel is worth staying. Staff are helpful and friendly. Breakfast Buffet occasionally gets busy especially on weekends for they have extra guests attending weddings, so if you hate the crowd, better to have breakfast outside. Like other Prince hotel groups, it's spacious, having conference rooms, party rooms, and shops. I was very moved that the shop sells fine cosmetic products. Restaurants are wonderful. If you ask in advance, they'll prepare personalised lunch or dinner, with very very good food.

I thought the Prince Park Tower was nice but not overwhelmingly fantastic. The rooms could stand to be a little more modern/sleek but were comfortable enough (except for the bed). I know it is Tokyo and things are expensive there, but I was mildly put off that you are required to pay about $20 USD per visit to the pool/gym and that I paid about $9 for a 12 oz. ginger ale in the lounge. Great views of the Tokyo Tower, great service from the staff, and close enough to the subway...but if I were to go back to Tokyo I'd try out another hotel.
Big Room for 3 persons, clean environment, just next to Tokyo Tower. Shuttle Bus service straight to airport and easy access to shopping area.

Service was great, excellent views, handy free shuttle bus to metro station, easy 5 - 10 minute walk to some good little restaurants. Nice spacious room with balcony.Had excellent meal at their steak restaurant downstairs, we ate late and were the only customers had personal chef cook in front of you and two great waitstaff looking after us.

I am not really used to luxury hotels but I wanted to indulge myself a small pleasure and was not disappointed by this one. The lobby, rooms, spa and services are quite wonderful. A huge jacuzzi was available in my bathroom and the toilets contained one of these amazing high tech bidets :) If you have money for, I will definitly recommend this hotel.

I found this hotel in central Tokyo on-line at an incredible price of 199 dollars a day - with stellar reviews and a 4 star rating in Fodor's guide to Japan. It was an amazing find. Was priced at $400 to 1000 dollars a day in the guide books - not sure why we were so lucky to get 4 days at that lower rate. Worth far more. Delightful, helpful concierge - made restaurant, event (tea ceremony, etc), and even next-city-destination hotel reservations for us, printed out maps, gave us excellent advice. Rooms exquisitely clean and beautiful - with even more beautful views. Great baths and amenities. Deep soaking tub with fragrant bath salts, awesome shower. Cool bidet toilet with heating and cleaning and massage options! Little gift of origami paper and paper crane on our arrival. Location excellent - a neat temple across the way walking distance from rail station (though they had free shuttle service!) and from sushi bars and restaurants and even a Starbucks! Close to the ever-lit Tokyo Tower - so a beacon was always there to guide us back to our hotel when on foot. What more could you ask?

My husband and I visited this hotel with our 3 teenage children and my sister. From the outside it isn't much but, the inside-wow! I am a bit of a hotel snob but this hotel met my expectations and more. It was clean, quiet and had a terrific bathtub that would be my absolute dream to own!. I got an incredible deal on this through hotels.com at $162. USD per night for a double-double on the 14th floor. We were on the 14th floor and had quite a nice view of the city. Tokyo Tower views were not available. As with any hotel in Japan, restaurants are quite expensive. Since this was the topper of our 11 day Japan trip, we splurged and had dinner at a beautiful Japanese restaurant in the hotel. The menu was authentic and we had many exotic dishes. Upon check-in they gave us discount vouchers for a tasting menu that was priced at $40 USD. If you are an adventurous eater, I would highly recommend using them (only 2 of us did). Everything else was a la carte and very pricey. With drinks and 6 people- 3 of them teens, our bill was $400. Then we went into a karaoke bar that had private rooms right across the hall and had quite a bit of sake and was great fun for the whole family. I must say that the teens had a terrific time and it was a real hoot, but there went another $400 USD. We were looking on these splurges as a 'once in a lifetime' indulgence and I'm glad we did it...once. We are not kin to Bill Gates but for 1 night, we lived and felt like we were.Room service again very expensive and there are not a lot of restaurants close by if unless you are up for walking a few blocks (I have mobility issues), except in Tokyo Tower which does have a food court but it geared to tourists, even hosting a McDonald's. The Tokyo Tower experience was nice but it IS NOT equipped to handle patrons with mobility issues as it has stairs. I would recommend one of the bus tours that can be arranged by the concierge- who was extremely helpful. You can see the sights and then you get dropped off in neighborhoods if you wish and you can kick around on your own. My only drawbacks were the expensive restaurants and the lack of things for teens to do. Luckily it was near a train station and Tokyo is a very safe city so my teens came and went even in the evenings. If traveling without kids, I would recommend without hesitation for a few days. There is a fitness center and indoor pool but you have to be 20 years of age to use it. There is Tokyo Tower and a beautiful shrine and gardens right next door. Avoid Tokyo Tower during the day unless you go on Sunday due to the large school groups. You are probably not going to see Mt. Fuji anyway unless you are in Japan on a cool, clear day and those are quite rare. I would go at night but DO NOT go if you can't do stairs. I'm glad I stayed at this luxury hotel as a treat but I would not stay there again as I have 'been there, done that'. PS: There is no tipping in Japan!!

Excellent location within Shiba Park,walking distance of Tokyo Tower, Underground link from hotel rear exit, Limouisine bus from airport takes you directly to door of hotel. No need to book. Buy ticket from desk at airport.Look out on hotel website for special packages. We booked 2 night package which included breakfast and spa. Breakfast can be expensive otherwise ! We had a corner double room with wonderful views over the city and to the mountains beyond. Views from the top floor bar are amazing at night. A seat at the bar is free but £5 cover to sit on a settee with a table by the window---well worth it !Hotel is stunningly beautiful with excellent facilities---lovely pool area---costs to enter.Internet usage is free---a bonus as not the norm in Japan.

We caught the Airport Limousine Bus from Tokyo Airport to the hotel.When we arrived I must admit to being a little underwhelmed with its outside appearance. However once inside that all changed. The place was very modern, service was excellent, and the room was above expectations.The beds were among the most comfortable we have ever slept in.We found the location to be fine. There are two subway stations within five minutes walk. Although these are not on the main Toyko line the hotel does provide a free shuttle service to another station that is. The shuttle runs about every 15 minutes or so.We were staying here for a couple of days before going on a cruise departing from just outside Yokohama. I approached the concierge and told him that I would like to get to the cruise terminal by train and asked him the best way. He immediately took us in to his office and 5 minutes later we had directions printed in English and Japanese telling us which trains to catch, which line they were on, and even how much each train would cost.Extremely helpful. As were all of the staff here. We had dinner one night at the Chinese restaurant in the hotel. I have to say I didn't enjoy it. This is in no way a reflection of the hotel or restaurant, just that it did not appeal to my taste. Now the boulangerie , that was a different matter. Delicious !!!!All in all I would recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Right next to Tokyo Tower and Roppongi in central Tokyo. A great central location to base a business trip. Good choice of restaurants in hotel, with excellent top floor bar overlooking Tokyo at night.

This was definitely one of those hotels where the lobby promises but the rooms disappoint.The problems started pre arrival, when we found it quite hard to contact the hotel by email and get a response. That's not a good sign in service-obsessed Tokyo, but since the hotel had been booked as part of a package it wasn't possible to change it, unfortunately.The lobby was encouraging - very new-looking, glass, chrome and marble. Check-in was a pain - although it was conducted sitting down at a desk, it took ages when really it should just have been a matter of copying our passports and collecting the hotel voucher etc. The rooms were a good size and it was nice to have a little balcony looking out onto the Shiba park & Tokyo Tower, but the furnishings were very dated and my wife was a bit put off by a rather prominent & suspicious-looking white stain on the purple sofa. There seemed little point in mentioning it to the hotel though as it would most likely have meant moving all four of us to new rooms which would have been a waste of time. The bed was very comfortable. The hotel had a 'green' scheme whereby you could offer to not have your room cleaned and receive a credit of so many yen per day - but they wanted us to waive all cleaning (ie no fresh towels, no clean bins etc) which is too much. Bizarrely like many hotels now they ask if you want fresh towels that you put them in the bath, so we religiously hung ours back up when we didn't feel we needed new ones - and they changed them anyway!!The following morning we made the mistake of not reading the little breakfast vouchers we'd been given, so we went to the basement Chinese restaurant for breakfast; it was not good - the floor of the restaurant was sticky, presumably following a party the night before or something, and the food was not great. We complained but we're not sure they really understood why we weren't happy. The next day we found out we should have gone to the top-floor international buffet, which was quite a bit better, although sometimes we had to queue for a table.We didn't eat any other meals in the hotel.The other major disappointment was the following. One of the reasons we'd selected this hotel from the choices offered by the agent was that it had a pool and our kids like to swim after a day of sight-seeing. But when we tried to use it, we were told it was only open to people over 25 years old! We complained and they were apologetic but very firm that it was not possible for us to use the pool.The location is not tremendously convenient if you are out and about a lot as it's not very near any subway (there are a couple of stations but they're all 5+ minutes walk) so as a regular traveller to Tokyo on business I would not choose this hotel.Although the rooms are larger than is typical in a Tokyo I'm going to go back to the other place I stay next time I'm there as I thought this place was a disappointment.

My wife and I stayed here for 4 nights in late April. We booked our room with hotels.com. We were upgraded upon check in, and were placed in a corner room on the 20th floor. Fantastic views...and free visits to the hotel gym (with large pool)!Positives:- Outstanding staff, large rooms, great hotel store (we often got breakfast here, pastries, water, etc. Open late too), nice gym with fantastic pool (inside a huge pool hall), bathrooms were open and spacious, the hotel was placed on extensive grounds (meaning that hotel sat on a plot of land surrounded by gardens, vs. other hotels that stood next to other buildings), safe and secureThings to keep in mind:- You will probably need to walk for 10-15 mins to find restaurants and bars (the hotel restaurants are typically expensive). But the surrounding area is very safe and easy to walk, so we didnt mind.- We used the Akabanebashi subway stop. You will definitely need a subway map. The Tokyo subway lines are extensive, convenient, and cost effective ($1.50 USD per ride?). However, they can be confusing at first, so make sure to have a map.- We never used taxis. A taxi to the airport would've been about 20,000 yen, or about $200 usd. The airport shuttle is the best way to get to Narita airport, at about 3,000yen (about $30) per person). Takes 1.5 to 2 hrs, but it's a nice ride.Overall, a great hotel, and we were very please with the service. Enjoy your trip!

We (a family of four) stayed three nights here in early May 2010. We were unable to get a room to fit 4 people so we opted for 2 rooms of twin beds. This was affordable because we got an excellent rate by searching those discount room websites. BTW, some can be cancellable, not all of them require full non-refundable payment, watch for that. The hotel is high quality. We did hear motorcycles at night sometimes but I suspect it to be better than the traffic noise you'd hear at other Tokyo downtown hotels. This one is in a quiet park! Other reviewers noted that there are no restaurants nearby, which is true. Also, we always took a taxi to/from the JR station, because you have to book the hotel's shuttle otherwise it's full. The taxi allowed us to go at our own times without pre-booking and was only about $8. Easy access from the JR station to other areas of the city by train. The pastry shop in the hotel's gift shop is great, opens at 8 am but closes fairly early. I would stay here again.

This is a nice hotel, with a nice bathroom and fairly large room (also has a safe in the room). The customer service was great, but the English-language abilities of the staff at this hotel, while manageable and fun, were not as good as the other two Tokyo hotels we visited. You can get decent deals (<$200/night for two persons), but the location was average for first-time Tokyo visitors. We wanted the best deal possible, so we also had to use two twin beds.Regarding the location, it's near the Tokyo Tower but I found that the only benefit to being in the southern part of Tokyo. If you're using the JR Rail Pass, it's definitely possible to avoid using other (non-JR) subways in Tokyo, but it's a 15-20 minute walk to this hotel from the JR line. Coming from the airport (if this is your starting location) is not too difficult (only one transfer at Tokyo Station), but the food choices in the area are somewhat limited. Some of the areas of town are a little more fun for first-time, younger, visitors (e.g., Shinjuku, Ikebukuro, Tokyo Station).

We were provided this hotel as a homebase in Tokyo by Friendly Planet tours. WOW! My husband & I absolutely loved our 5th floor view of Tokyo Tower. The beds were comfortable, and the soaking tub was delightful. The Daimon line is walking distance, and the hotel has free shuttle service to the Subway. Beautiful grounds to walk after a delicious buffet breakfast! One thing to keep in mind is the Japanese still smoke heavily, so request a non-smoking room.

Great hotel, about 10 mins taxi from Tokyo Station. Spotless rooms have v. good beds, views over park or Tokyo. Located next to a park and near the Tokyo tower. Wide variety of food - breakfast on 33rd floor is brilliant, also range of restaurants downstairs - western and Asian. Staff could not be more helpful. Pricey, but good value by Tokyo standards.

We stayed here for 6 nights in April with our family of 4 (2 kids aged 9 and 10). We had booked a triple room for 3 adults, so we ended up with 2 king singles and a single bed. The room was quite spacious, but on the first night, we could just barely hear some talking from the adjoining room. With our 2 relatively small kids, we actually slept 1 adult + 1 child in each of the single beds. The wardrobe was very spacious so we kept one of our large suitcases in there.The room had the best toilet we had in our Japan trip - the lid automatically opened when you entered the toilet cubicle, and it automatically flushed too! Bath was much enjoyed by the kids after days of walking around. There was also free wired internet in the room to help plan your next day. Also loved how the corridor lights only turned on when you walked in that direction. Smart :)The service was very good here - too polite. When checking in, they had someone at the front of the first queue to direct you to a free desk/station. But they were all busy so this person invited me to take a seat nearby. But for only 30 seconds! The concierges were helpful with directions and instructions (eg. wanted to buy tickets to the Ghibli museum and they even printed out instructions from the web for us!). There is a hotel lobby shop with a bakery where we bought our cheap pastries for breakfast and drinks and snacks for the day and evening. We didn't eat at the hotel restaurants.In terms of location, the hotel is near 2 different lines and the stations are very short walks away. We used these subway stations for most for our trips around Tokyo. Wasn't a problem walking back with the 2 kids at night (especially getting a nice view of the Tokyo Tower each time).You can also book to go on the free shuttle bus which brings you to the nearest JR station (Hamamatsucho). We actually took this shuttle bus to the hotel from the JR station when we arrived - just make sure you get to the right JR station exit. Besides this, it's a bit of a walk to the JR station and other external restaurants in that area (if you have young kids). There is a Lawson's a few blocks away (if you need to get Ghibli museum tickets). We booked the Airport Shuttle to get back to the airport, and it stopped at this hotel. This hotel has a green program where you can opt to not get your bed made/towels changed for a 1000 yen voucher. We did this a few times and it paid for some breakfast and gifts from the hotel shop.Great value for money (the price we got made this hotel nearly AUD$200 cheaper per night than our Kyoto hotel and a ryokan we stayed at). Might have been more convenient to be located in a major shopping/restaurant area, but with subways so closeby and the price, I can't complain.

I should have known it was too good to be true to be paying $200 a night for what seemed like 5 star accommodations in Tokyo. What you need to keep in mind is that the first 17 or so floors are probably 3-4 star and the floors above are 5 star. That said, our room was very clean and spacious, just not as pretty and modern as some of the advertised pictures suggest. The customer service, like every place in Japan (even 7-11's) is amazing. My husband was disappointed that NO tattoos are allowed at the fitness center (there are large beautiful gardens surrounding for a morning run). They offered a "green option" where you get 1000 Yen certificate ( ~ $10 at the time of our trip to be used in the hotel) for every day you do not need maid service (up to three days in a row). We used ours at the beautiful 33rd floor lounge (1000 Yen cover charge). You need to call them before 8 a.m. for this. Our rooms had the twin sized beds and my husband and I were disappointed you couldn't move them together (bolted to the walls). The convenience store had snacks and drinks including alcohol for okay prices. The snacks and drinks within the room were very expensive. The tap water is potable and we would refill our water bottles before heading out. The restaurants were all very expensive (i.e. 1700 Yen for a ham and cheese sandwich). Shuttle to major subway station and walking distance to other stations. Airport shuttle service (Airport Limousine - orange signs) to and from the hotel was 3000 Yen each way (you can get one easily from the airport and reserve one at the Hotel a few days in advance). This hotel is right near the fabulous Tokyo Tower - try to get a view of it from your hotel if you can. Otherwise, enjoy it from the 33rd floor lounge. I would still recommend this hotel as long as you know what you are getting into. No free wi-fi - free internet only if connected via wire to laptop. Business center is 250 Yen/15 minutes.

This hotel lived up to our expectations, being a Leading Hotel of The World. My husband & I booked through Continental Airlines and got a good rate. We had a corner room on the 26th floor for 8 nights. The room had a fantastic view of the city, we could even see Mount Fuji on a clear day (alas not many whilst we were in Tokyo). The bathroom was really big, shower was excellent and, as others have reported, the toilet had aheated seat and other gadgetry. We were never disturbed by hotel noise, just general traffic out on the roads but that wasn't a problem. The bed was classed as a double but I am sure it was a king size. The pillows, bedding etc were excellent and we slept well. We had breakfast in our room a few times and the service was excellent. No wireless internet, surprising but the wired service was fast and worked well. The hotel has numerous restaurants, we loved the steakhouse, Kobe beef best we have ever tasted, service very good, everything cooked in front of you. Chinese restaurant was not so good, too bright, no atmosphere, food lukewarm and service not brilliant, bit of a surprise really as that was the only bad thing we had to say about our stay at the hotel. The coffee/cake lounge very relaxing, good service, buffet breakfast excellent, fantastic views, some queues in the morning but the line moved fast while we were there. The charge is 3000Yen, expensive maybe, but this is a top hotel and theres plenty to eat and remember NO TIPPING, it all adds up. The tasting corner very good idea, my husband sampled some sakes one evening before dinner. The American breakfast restaurant did not have a great menu but if theres a line at the buffet its another option. This hotel has a shop that sells snacks, cakes, pastries, savouries, gifts, magazines, toiletries etc, another shop selling various attire, a full spa offering a great range of treatments. Full wedding service, florist , chapel etc which looked very impressive. Pool, gym, we didn't use either but I believe there was a charge for the gym. 2000Yen I think. Oh and theres a bowling alley, its a good size too, impressive, unsure how busy it gets and whether you have to book, there was also an electronic dart board in there too. Lastly the conceirge was excellent. Yoko organised all our tours, followed up with further suggestions and we were very pleased with the effort and detail she put into arranging things for us. I would recommend the private taxi with English speaking driver. Its money well spent. We took the full day Greyline city tour one day and quite frankly it was awful, although Micki our tour guide was very good, she spoke good English, but it wasn't organised very well. It ran from 8am pick up and due to delays we didn't get back to the hotel until 7pm, far too long hanging around waiting for other buses to swop over with us etc. only 10 minutes in Imperial gardens and a horrible boat tour, packed in like sardines, no safety info, hard to see anything on a tour like that. Not worth the money. Do not recommend this tour. Next day we spent 5.5hrs with Takumi our private driver in a very smart comfortable car going where we wanted and getting lots of interesting information, he even went back to the car for umbrellas for us when it looked like rain. We booked for 4hrs but he was happy for us to extend it. We also did the bullet train to Kyoto, with Sunrise tours, it was excellent, everything went well. So use the concierge at this hotel, they are very knowledgable and have a lot of folders/maps under the desk with a wealth of information for you. We felt the hotel was a good location. It s right on top of Tokyo Tower and a little park. It was about 10minute walk to Daimon tube station. This was a nice walk, safe etc and past a park and temple. There is also a free shuttle from the hotel to main bus terminal and another station much closer to the hotel, unsure of the name. Few minutes walk to plenty of restaurants, and Starbucks also only about 7 minutes on the way to the tube station. (If you want a change from green tea. We went all over the city on the tube, the ticket machines have an english button to translate everything for you. The hotel staff in the lobby will explain all this for you if you ask them and give you a good map. Its a good hotel, you get what you pay for, its not cheap but look for deals and you'll get good value for the quality of service and comfort. and don't forget theres no tipping in Japan, think how much you save on that.

We stayed 2 nights last weekend and enjoyed the experience. Here are the details:Location: Close to the Tokyo Tower and next to Shiba park and the Zojoji temple. 5 min walk to the nearest subway station (Akabanebashi) from where we took the subway for all our sightseeing in Tokyo. Found it easier to take the airport limousine bus from Narita to reach the hotel. This is one of the last hotels on the airport bus route - so it can take close to 2 hours to reach the hotel. Preferred to take a taxi to Tokyo station when we left the hotel to catch the shinkansen to Osaka.Room: We stayed in a corner room with a double bed. Room was very clean and nice but a bit smaller than I expected. Not the smallest room I have stayed in while in Japan but smaller than most rooms elsewhere in the world. We decided not to ask for a baby cot for our 1 year old daughter because there was no space to put in an extra cot. Bath was very nice with a separate shower stall and bathtub and the toilet was very high-tech! Internet was free which was a great relief after having paid extra for internet access in other hotels in Japan. Smaller sized LCD TV and a couple of English channels (CNN & BBC) apart from the Japanese channels.Service: Very helpful concierge and reception staff who spoke good English. Was disappointed though with their policy of not allowing us to check-in a couple of hours earlier than 2pm despite seeing that we were travelling with a 1 year old and had just reached Tokyo after a long-haul flight. There were rooms available, so that was not the issue - they insisted though that they would charge us extra for the earlier check-in. Food: we did not eat at the hotel except for the breakfast buffet which was included in our package. 3 different options for the breakfast buffet - 1 western style buffet in the Sky Bar, 1 Japanese buffet and a mixed buffet (western, japanese and chinese) in the restaurants. We tried two of the options but the quality of the western buffet was not upto our expectations. Can't comment about the Japanese or Chinese options. There are a couple of nice eating places within a 15min walk from the hotel but the options are limited compared to other locations in Tokyo.We would recommend the hotel for leisure and business travel especially if you are keen to stay at a quieter location in Tokyo.

The hotel was fantastic and the best hotel we stayed in on our trip. The only downside for us was that it was fruther away from the main attractions but it was close to the subway. The staff were exceptional and it was a nice way to finish our trip.The Sky Bar has spectacular views of the city but is very expensive

this was the first hotel we stayed at in Japan and was the best. The staff were very friendly and helpful, we had a corner room which was large and clean. The bathroom had an amazing spa bath in it and my other half was very impressed by the techno toilet! Its about 15min walk from the nearest train station but they do have a shuttle bus.Its in a really nice park, with great views from the sky bar but be warned they have a table charge (1,000Y) and a glass of wine was 1,300 Yen.

I stayed at this hotel in February 2009, and loved it, as my previous review will attest. So as the conference I was attending for the second time was being held at the hotel again, I was very keen to stay once more. As many have noted, the Airport Limousine bus from Narita does stop at the hotel, and it's great if you have a lot of luggage and don't want to be transferring on trains. However, since this time I was coming in by myself, I decided to take the NEX train, because if you take the bus, the Prince Hotel Park Tower is the last stop so the bus trip actually does take almost 2 hours. I bought a ticket to Hamamatsucho Station at the Narita Terminal 2 along with the premium one must pay to ride the NEX train - cost me Y3,110. I got off the Nex at Tokyo Station, and transfered to the Yamanote Line (Keihin Tohoku works too) and arrived at Hamamatsucho 2 or 3 stops later. I could have tried to figure out the times for the bus to pick me up from the station, but when I got to Hamamatsucho I just decided to walk because it was a really nice night, and arrived at the hotel less than 20 minutes later (heading west from the station towards the Zozoji Temple).The hotel was terrific, again. I got a smaller room this time, but it was still very nice, on the 10th floor. The bed was very comfortable, the Internet was free and the bathroom was nice and large. It had a bathtub where one could flip one switch, and runs a bath at the perfect temperature, and shuts off automatically. The pastries at the Boulangerie Tokyo were as good as I remembered, and having the store there made it irrelevant that the nearest convenience store was about a 10 minute walk. I went one day to the area just a little past Akabanebashi station, in Azabu-Juban, and thought that was very nice and atmospheric. Another night, I walked with a friend to an excellent tonkatsu restaurant not far from Daimon station with specialty pork from Tochigi prefecture (www.musashiya.net), the proprietor doesn't speak much English but is incredibly nice and helpful. This time, knowing the area a little better, I really appreciated everything it had to offer. I highly recommend the hotel and certainly plan on staying there again.

I was invited to go to Tokyo with my then friend (now fiance). He couldn't have picked a better hotel. The service, location, and rooms were impeccable! We had the buffet brunch a majority of the time. It's a bit pricey but well worth it. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone planning on visiting Tokyo.

A white Bentley parked outside always sets the right tone. Back to Tokyo again for a two night stay for Tokyo Girls Collection 2010, at which my daughter is a guest star. The hotel looks slightly retro from the outside, but once into the lobby, it is pure 21st Century. A stunning atrium rises twenty floors or more, glass lifts smoothly lifting guests to their allotted room. Check in is rapid and efficient . A very elegant female porter escorts us to our room and drops off the suitcases. No tipping, as is the way in Japan, just a member of staff which the rest of the world could learn from. The standard of the room, overlooking the freeway, is immaculate. Two comfortable beds, plenty of space, and the expected amenities and standards of cleanliness. The loo is separate from the bathroom, and is like something from Buck Rogers. It opens the lid as soon as you step in the room, and intuitively knows when to flush. Spooky. The bathroom sports an excellent shower and an air spa bath, along with top line toiletries. Unfortunately, due to the place being booked out, we can only stay the one night here, but we will be back. The complex goes on for what seems miles, and the spa looks excellent. As with all top end hotels, the prices for food and drink are, in my opinion, unnecessarily extortionate. Why is it that nobody in this industry will cotton on to the fact that if they were more competitive in their costs then more people wouldn't leave the building and eat out - which we always do. Overall, highly recommended. Seek out the best deal you can, and you will not be disappointed.

I was invited to Japan courtesy of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The hotel was absolutely first rate. I had a corner room on the 27th floor overlooking the city. Everything was thought of and I felt very very fortunate. I had heard that hotels were small and cramped, but this one was entirely the opposite. Breakfast on the 31st floor with lovely views as well.

I stayed at The Prince Park Tower Tokyo for 9 nights in February. I stayed in a Deluxe Twin Room - the room was massive - way bigger the your typical Tokyo room. The room had everything - big TV, big bathroom with separate shower and spa bath, separate room for toilet, wardrobe that you can actually walk into, couch, chair with coffee table, desk with free wired high speed internet, comfy beds, balcony. The view from my room was of Tokyo Tower which looks awesome at night time with all the different coloured lights.Check-in was easy and efficient. All the staff at the hotel were very friendly and helpful when required. The hotel shop is quite good and the bakery has some very delicious items that I would highly recommend. Location wise - the hotel is is a quieter are of Tokyo - so if you want to be right in the middle of the hustle and bustle - then I would stay in Shinjuku or Shibuya. It is about a 10-15 minute walk to the nearest JR station on the Yamanote line - Hamamatsucho - but there are subway stations that are closer also. There is a free shuttle every 30 minutes that runs to the JR station.Overall I was very happy with my stay here. I would recommend others to stay here but it would definitely depend on what room rate you can get - I managed to get a rate less than 30% of the rack rate - which was great.

Overall, we were pretty happy with the hotel. The location was quite good given that it was only a few minutes from the subway station. It is on the Oedo line which takes you to Shinjuku and Roppongi without changing lines. We were also upgraded to very nice room with a great panoramic view of Tokyo. For japan standards, the room was huge and had good amenities like Nepresso machines with free pods etc. Communication with the hotel prior to arrival was quite challenging. There was no email address on the hotel site - only a web form. However, no one seems to receive the emails from the web form as our 3 email attempts were ignored. Upon our arrival, the local staff were very apologetic. The biggest issue we had with the hotel is the concierge service. We had only a limited number of nights in Tokyo and wanted to make the most out of it by going to some Michelin starred restaurants for dinner. The concierge booked us into the wrong restaurant (I mean, shouldn't they know which ones are Michelin starred?) and so we ended up dressed up, paying for a taxi, arriving at the restaurant only to find that they didn't have our reservation. Ended up eating at some roadside sushi place which was still good... but we were pretty pissed off about it. The staff were very apologetic and tried to make the best out of the situation but I would not recommend this hotel if you are planning to ask the concierge to make lots of bookings for you!Also... what is the deal with hotels not offering WiFi? We had in room wired internet ...but this is the 21st century.... we had to hack some sort of peer to peer computer network to try to surf the net from the bed...

We picked this hotel because of reviews and were not disappointed. Great location - near parklike area and shrine. Good for morning walks. Great location for subway. Able to take subway all over Tokyo from our hotel. Beautiful walk to Tokyo Tower.Nice sized room. Nice Restaurants. Wonderful breakfast buffet with view from top floors.They charged a fee to use the work out facility and the pool is for those over 25 years old ....and without tattoos. Glad I never got a tattoo!

This was our first trip to Tokyo and we stayed in a corner room. The view was fantastic and the size large by European/US standards, so important after a long journey! The service, efficiency and politeness was excellent as it was in the rest of Tokyo.Superb food, lots to do and see. I hope to go back soon! We stayed on Sunday and Monday nights on our way to NZ and fortunately there was a 50% discount for these nights (only) which made the rates competitive.Short walk to two tube lines and the limo bus goes direct from the airport.In short, no negatives!
Room was huge with a spa bath and the largest bed you've ever seen. Amazing view of Tokyo from balcony. Not the best location but we didn't have any issues getting to or back from visiting places.

The Prince Park Tower Tokyo is a perfect place for a stay in Tokyo. Surrounded by a garden/park this free-standing bulding has views on all sides.Some reviewers claim the location being uncentral. But gigantic Tokyo doesn't have one centre like many other cities, and the Prince Park Tower is actually convieniantly located between Tokyo's most important central areas like Ginza in the East, Odaiba in the South and Shibuya in the West. The Airport Limousine Bus brings you directly to the doorstep and there are several subway stations nearby.Make sure you book a room with a balcony, they are large by Japanese and even European standards.And make to get a room as high up as possible, the view is breathtaking.Tip: Join the Prince Club International before booking. Besides good rates you will get breakfast included in your room rate - and breakfast isn't cheap in the Prince Park Tower. The membership also gives access to a private lounge with breathtaking views and free snacks and drinks.

My husband and I stayed here for ten days during our vacation to Tokyo. We stayed in a standard twin room on the 11th floor overlooking the temple and park. The room was perfectly adequate, with plenty of room, comfortable beds and a very spacious bathroom with large separate tub and shower. The electric toilet seat with it's various bidet settings and heated seat was fun too.The hotel is located in a non touristy area of Tokyo which we preferred but is still extremely easy to get to all the major areas. There are two subway stations within a five minute walk, really very close and one in Hammatsucho which is under fifteen minutes and is also a main JR station. The area of Hammatsucho has plenty of reasonably priced restaurant options if you don't want to travel back to the busier areas. We liked staying in this location as it felt more authentic and consequently prices were aimed at Tokyoites rather than tourists. The service in the hotel was excellent but this was the case everywhere we went in Tokyo as people really seem to take pride in their work. We also took advantage of the Green Cleaning program, if you go without housekeeping for two consecutive nights you are given credit to use at the hotel. By the end of our stay we had about $60 worth of coupons which we used in the gift shop/bakery. We didn't try any of the restaurants at the hotel as they were so expensive and there are plenty of options nearby if you don't mind exploring a bit. For example if you walk like you are going to the Akabanebashi station but turn left under the bridge before you get to the station and walk down the major road for about fifteen minutes or so on your left you will come to a street full of restaurants and this brings you into the Mita area. I also liked that the housekeeping staff came to our room one day at 4pm to clean as we had accidentally left our do not disturb sign on and they couldn't access it earlier. I would imagine in other places in the world they would have said we were too late that day. We found a great Chinese restaurant in Ginza called X'ian I would highly recommend, fresh ingredients, busy and a great price. My favorite places to visit in Tokyo were Asakusa and Ueno, both great for wandering around and seeing a more traditional Tokyo, with great street food and lots of alleys and streets to explore. Also Ginza and Shinjuku., especially Yakatori Alley in Shinjuku for an authentic japanese after work drinking culture experience. Roppongi was a little seedy and the restaurants in the new shopping complexes like Roppongi Hills are overpriced. Tokyo is such a safe, clean, efficient city and nowhere near as complicated to navigate as people might say. The subway is well marked in English with signs at every exit and there are large maps posted in major areas when you exit the subway. People are incredibly polite and helpful and will even approach you to offer help.

My partner and I had two lovely stays at the Prince Park Tower. The location in Shiba Park was beautiful and very convenient (once we discovered the "southeast exit"), the rooms very well designed, and the staff extremely professional. Our first stay was in a "superior" room on the higher "VIP" floors; the second in a lower-priced "deluxe" room, which was every bit as nice.
One of the best hotels I have ever stayed in (and I've stayed in a few). Stayed here for 5 nights - wish we had stayed for more.

The hotel is next to Shiba Park and in a less hectic area of Tokyo than Shinjuku or some of the other business/commercial districts. Booked a large Superior twin room on the 23rd floor. Great view on Tokyo Tower and the city. The room was spacious (33sqm) with 2 large and very comfortable beds. Marble bathroom with separate shower and bathtub. The room decoration looks dated but all the furniture and fittings were in perfect condition and very clean. It shows that the hotel has excellent staff. Check-in and check-out took less than 2 minutes. Great to have convenience store on the ground floor and freshly baked cakes from the boulangerie for breakfast. From Narita airport to the hotel, it was easier to take the Airport Limousine Bus (JPY 3000, 70 minutes) and be dropped at the hotel entrance than to walk through train stations with suitcases.

It is hard to believe and picture till you really spend a few days in this hotel. Everything is awesome -- the staffs were friendly and can speak very good English, the room was very clean and had a nice view of the Shiba park, a fully automated toilet bowl and the bathroom was just superb, completed with Pola products!For travelers who mentioned that the restaurants are too costly, you can actually:1) Buy food from the department store in the hotel, they are inexpensive, fresh, and most importantly, delicious.2) Walk 5 minutes to the nearest 7-11 stores and find food there.3) Walk 7 minutes to Tokyo tower and a hosts of inexpensive restaurants await you.4) Walk 4 minutes to Akabanebashi station on the Oedo line and head to Roppongi hills for nice food, or head the other direction to Tsukijishijo for authentic local food.5) Take the free shutter service that departs every 30 minutes to JR Yamanote Line's Hamamatsucho station, where you can get lots of other shops over there.I don't understand why some say the hotel location is not good, we had no trouble traveling around Tokyo, as Oedo Line literally connects to all other major subway/JR lines in Tokyo!

We thoroughly enjoyed our 2 night stay at the Prince Park Tower and wish we had stayed longer. The service was perfect from the time we stepped off the complimentary shuttle bus. Our check in and check out was seamless and the staff could not have been more polite and friendly. We loved our room, Park Suite, and would recommend it to everyone. We would happily return.

I stayed here for two night, and wish I could have stayed longer. This is a great hotel. The lobby is elegant, and the service upon check-in (and throughout my stay) was impeccable. My room was big by any standard. (Note: I stayed in a "Superior Comfort King" room since I found a good deal online. Superior rooms are on higher floors with restricted access.) The room was well-apportioned, and had a very comfortable bed! There was free (wired) Internet in the room.There are some negatives. The restaurants in the hotel are expensive, and you have to walk a bit (5-10 minutes) to find something else. I found the location the biggest problem in general. The hotel is not really near anything you will want to see, although it is just a 2-minute walk to two different subway lines (Akabanebashi on the Oeno line, and Shibakoen on the Mita line).

We booked the hotel by taking advantage of a special deal we found on hotels.com for 4 nights or more. This made the Prince Park Tower way less expensive than any other 5-star hotel within the main areas of inner Tokyo for the dates of our stay, excellent value for money. However, while the hotel mostly deserves its 5* rating and has many very good features, it does have some drawbacks. The greatest drawback, and probably the reason the hotel frequently has good deals available, is that its location, realistically, is far from ideal – certainly, for the needs of most tourists. It is about a 20 minutes walk from the nearest JR train station, Hamamatsucho. There are a couple of subway stations that are closer, but these lines do not connect directly to many of the destinations most tourists wish when sightseeing in Tokyo. (We were fully aware of this issue, having been to Tokyo before so knew where it was located, and had borne this in mind when we made our booking.) The distance from the JR train station is mitigated slight by a complimentary shuttle bus service, but this is shared by the other nearby Prince hotel - so there is a risk that the bus may already be full when it arrives to take guests to the station, and the journey to the hotel has to go via the other hotel, when you work out where the pick-up is.Further, the hotel is not in an area of good or interesting restaurants. The best and biggest selection in walking distance are on the walk from the banqueting entrance of the hotel to Hamamatsucho JR train station, but you do need to use public transport to find better options and a wider choice. You either need to take the JR Yamanote Line one stop to Shimbashi and head towards Ginza or the Toei line subway to Roppongi for an greater, more Westerner and tourist friendly choice of restaurants, bars and other evening entertainment.The good features worth mentioning include: The hotel staff – everybody is very well trained, very courteous and polite, efficient and helpful. They also all speak good English, except seemingly the drivers of the shuttle bus service to the JR train station.The setting – it’s effectively within Shiba park so it is surrounded by a lot of greenery with pleasant areas for a stroll, and it is right beside Zojo-ji temple, where some of the most popular New Year celebrations take place, which is worth a little exploration.The bedroom - it was a very good size for a standard room, the largest we encountered in any hotel in a major city. The décor was fairly neutral, clean and fresh. We were able to fully unpack all our luggage and find somewhere appropriate to store all our clothes, toiletries and other paraphernalia – no mean feat this is Japan! The beds were huge, very firm and comfy and had the best quality cotton linens we have encountered in a hotel for a long time. The windows were huge and the doors onto the narrow, balcony actually opened – unusual when you’re on the 18th floor! The black out drapes really did work – we needed to set the alarm, even on very sunny mornings. The flat screen TV was huge and received several satellite channels including the usual suspects, eg. CNN and BBC News24. Almost unheard of for a 5 star hotel, the in-room wireless internet was free of charge, and they even provided a LAN cable, too.The bathroom – this too was very spacious. There was a separate shower cubicle and bathtub. The shower enclosure was a very good size and the shower good and powerful and there was even space inside to rest personal products. The tub was the longest and deepest encountered in Japan and had Jacuzzi jets built in. Sensibly, and a nice touch – they provided lovely smelling bath salts that do not foam to enhance a soak after a day foot slogging your way around the stores and major sights of Tokyo.The vanitory unit was wide with room for some personal care items, but they also provided a wheeled cart to hold more. The mirror behind this was heated so never steams up, however long you stand in the shower! The toilet was in a separate small room. The light came on automatically as you opened the door and the seat lifted, and it flushed automatically after use. The control panel to operate the toilet and all its wondrous features would not have looked out of place on a starship!As you would expect of any 5* hotel in Tokyo, the prices in the restaurants and bars are high. However, you do get what you pay for. If you wish one splurge in the hotel, treat yourself to a cocktail in the Sky Lounge on the 33rd floor when it’s not raining. You get great night-time views directly onto the Tokyo Tower and the Rainbow Bridge in the distance. (You can, if you take advantage of the hotel’s green eco programme and don’t have your room cleaned in return for vouchers, trade these against the drinks bill!)The patisserie off the main lobby, which also took the vouchers, sold breakfast goods at a fair price, if you wished to avoid the hotel breakfast charges or only wanted a lighter bite. The atmosphere perhaps of the restaurants was very ‘hotellish’ rather than tasteful or cozy, and some of the public spaces looked rather old fashioned, but were clean, bright and spacious.Obviously, it is a very large hotel. It is used by large groups, so there are times when the lobby is quite crowded and noisy, but the efficient staff handled them very effectively so this wasn’t an issue. Overall, it was a great place the stay, and we’d go back.

Didn't mind spending the big bucks as we only had 3 nights in Tokyo, so why stay in a dump if you can afford luxury? Having said that... I'm not super rich either and this is what you need if you want to enjoy your stay here.After you spend $700 US on a room per night, you would expect not to have to pay to use your computer, breakfast or go for a swim and a workout.. but this is what is expected. Those little hidden extras are mean.If I was to stay in Tokyo again, which i would love to as it really is a fab city, I'd stay in Shinjuku, as it offers better restaurants, shops and nightlife and generally a better style of person. As for that hideous monstrsity that is the Tokyo Tower, that the Park Tower looks over, I'd go elsewhere.

Also I am not even sure if Hotel is a correct way to describe this place. I felt like I was a Princess living in my Palace. The only negative if anything is just that it is hard to move around from the hotel to other attractioins. We have to get a bus from the hotel convenient but doesnt leave as often as we would have liked and we never figured out how to get the bus from the station back to the hotel so we had to get a taxi back. So the location was a tad inconvenient in getting to the station (it is a long walk trust me) and getting to attractions, however the neighboring area is pretty and the park downstairs next to the temple is very awesome. The tour buses to get to tour things do stop there it is a major hotel so that is very convenient.The restaurants are great, the food is great (the Chinese restaurant is just awesome (expensive but the food is still in my mind after all these months. We still talk about it.)). The spa was amazing and considerably cheap! I just love this place so much.

We stayed here for a week and used it as our base for exploring Tokyo. It is a little way out of the centre, but this as as much an advantage as a disadvantage. Within the hotel there wasn't anything we could fault. I recommend paying the extra for the Superior rooms on the top floors. The rooms are excellent, roomy and well equipped and the extras are fantastic -including free champagne in the room, free afternoon tea and drinks in the special lounge on the 32nd floor with brilliant views of the Tokyo Tower and across Tokyo, free and good internet access and free use of the spa and the 10 pin bowling in the basement. All the staff were very helpful and courteous. Despite the size the hotel feels welcoming and is well maintained, giving the impression of newness. I wish that all the hotels I stayed in were like this.

Premise: I work for an airline and travel quite a bit. I have stayed in all classes of hotels. I stayed at this hotel because I got an industry travel package This hotel is located in Minato-ku but not in the center. The entrance is nice and the staff is very courteous There is a language barrier even with those that do speak English. The breakfast was not great but the view was wonderful and again the service is great. We only tried the American one. The coffee is really good.The room is 3.5* and the hotel is dated but nice enough. The bathroom is fine, toiletries are very generic--no lotion so make sure to bring. Bed is comfortable enough.I got a massage in the room and it was awful. I got another in Le Temps on the lower level and it was wonderful. We did not check out the spa, but you have to pay to use it. Yes, I have had massages all over Asia and am familiar with the difference styles.There is no wifi available, not even in the lobby. But there is a business center right behind the concierge desk--250 yen for 15 minutes.My issues with the hotel were the location and the difficulties presented by the language barrier-- it was hard to find restaurants and our way around. For example, the 1st night we arrived we asked the concierge where we should go to eat, drink, etc. Mind you, it was raining outside. They sent us to Daimon crossing, on foot, which I later realized is the Minato central area. This is all outside and all the signs are in Japanese. We wandered around for quite awhile, jetlagged, at night, in the rain trying to find a restaurant. I personally love a good adventure and this was ok at the time--not ideal but when in Rome (or Tokyo)... But another day, we went to Roppongi which is just 2 stops over on the train and there is a mall there, indoors, with a lot of trendy restaurants and bars with English translations more available...(if you're not familiar with Asia... it is normal for the good restaurants to be located on the upper floor of malls and the lower floors) why didn't they send us there?? I think it's because they were probably too limited by the language and so did not attempt to tell us to take the train to Roppongi. That would have definitely changed the entire experience for us... because after that 1st night my friend was very intimidated by the restaurant situation and it made things difficult.They never even told us where the metro station is. We discovered it on our own. They sent us to a JR Line train station which is further from the hotel (not by much but still after walking around all day...) and has less accessibility to the metro lines. So, if you're staying here. When you exit the hotel turn right and go to the intersection. The Akabanashi metro stop is diagonally to your left underneath the overpass. From there you can go to Roppongi, 2 stops or Diamon, 2 stops or connect to other places.There are no restaurants in the immediate vicinity of the hotel, you have to travel. If you're trying to decide where to stay. I would say that Roppongi is a very nice area and the Hilton looks fabulous. Or in Ginza, there is a Peninsula, the Imperial, and a few others I forget the names of. Ginza is like 5th avenue and very nice--and right next to the imperial gardens. Enjoy!

Like other reviewers I was upgraded when I checked in after arriving late from the airport. I was given a room on the 27th floor on one of the superior floors which I could access through a separate lift. I was so stunned when I saw the room that I was left speechless. There was a huge window from one end of the room to the other that had a spectacular view across Tokyo city. After the view, then I noticed the room - the bed was big enough to comfortably sleep 6 people. There was a living area, kitchenette with kettle and Nespresso machine, separate toilet (with all the usual buttons, and a warm seat), and jacuzzi bath in a large bathroom with a full set of toiletries. Wow.The hotel is in a non touristy location, which I liked, but within 5 mins of two tube stations - Akanabashi and Shiba-Koen, both on Toie subway lines. A previous reviewer said that the nearest station was a 10 minute walk away, but he was referring to Daimon/Hamamatsucho, which are not the closest stations. Also, the hotel is supremely easy to get to from Haneeda airport. The monorail goes straight from this airport to Hamamatsucho, and its a short, cheap (Y710 min fare at night) taxi ride away if you have too much luggage for the 10min walk.My big disappointment was the breakfast. The buffet breakfast just wasn't that impressive in terms of choice or quality, for the price (Y3000). After a couple of days I tried the Japanese breakfast in the basement instead for the same price, but it was all too new and too different for me to be able to stomach at that time in the morning. The staff at this hotel are wonderful, and in particular the concierge desk. Every person I asked for help went far out of their way to help me. One staff member even wrote and then printed a map and directions in Japanese that I could give to a taxi driver to find my work location the next day.The gym was not impressive - it seemed a little old, with few machines and poor air-con. Also very expensive at Y2000 a session. Use of swimming pool, another Y2000 on top! Surely a hotel of this standard should offer complimentary gym and pool?Overall though, I highly rate this hotel, and if I could get the same deal on price that I did this time - 50% discount through Expedia, then I would be delighted to return and stay here again.

We booked through Hotels.com and apparentely got it at a 50% off rate for a last minute booking, so it was great value at about £120 per night, which is very good for Tokyo and for the lovely room we had. Fabulously done up, very luxurious decor and impressive communal areas. We went in through the wrong entrance and realised how massive this hotel is - there's even a bowling alley! Staff very helpful and sweet. Shame the pool was so much extra. Our room was a "comfort king" and was enourmous - the biggest bed I have ever seen. Bathroom was lovely with a jacuzzi bath. Handy bakery and reasonably priced shop at the entrance - we used that instead of taking the v pricey breakfast, although I'm sure it would have been great, if your company is paying! Room had a fab view of the Tokyo tower. A little out of the way as it is a 10 min walk to the nearest station (free line with the JR pass), but there is a bus every hour run by the hotel if you time it right. It was easy to use the trains, and didn't take long from Tokyo station having used the Narita airpot express trains. The C&C japanese fast food curry place on the main road to the station from the hotel was surprisingly good with a friendly English speaking waiter!Would definitely recomend this hotel if you don't mind being a little away from the central hub of everything, but it was nice and peaceful so we quite liked that. Free internet if you take your own laptop. Usual English business tv channels.

It is a very large hotel. So clean and the staff went out of their way to help us, Taxis always available short walk to station. Parks nearby. Food at hotel very nice.Walking distance to Tokyo Tower a must to see at night the views of Tokyo are stunning. Bakery at hotel very good especially for breakfast. Not to far in taxi to Ginza or Roppongi for shopping and restaurants. Saw some beautiful weddings being held at the hotel.

After having flown 10.5 hours from Vancouver, then taken a bus to the Prince Park Tower Tokyo, I knew I was in heaven when the bellman RAN to the bus to pick up my luggage. I was pretty tired so wasn't relishing the thought of lugging anything anywhere at that point.I was whisked into the lobby and seated while a gentleman quickly sorted out my one night reservation only to be told that I was being upgraded to a special room in an exclusive area of the hotel, accessible only by a special card that you used to enter. A lady took me to my room on the 26th floor and even as tired as I was, I was blown away by the city skyline view when you showed me how the curtains opened automatically with just a push of a button. The lights of Tokyo shimmered for miles beyond my balcony, which she also demonstrated, was actually usable.The lights knew when you were in a room by turning on automatically and I was treated, for the first time in my life, to a toilet seat that was actually heated. The toilet could do all sorts of other things but I left it at that.The room was very spacious, had a built in work desk, mini bar, a small seating area and an expresso machine. The bed was luxuriously comfortable with a thread count beyond anything I have ever experienced. Frankly, I never wanted to leave....Last but not least, I managed to get this hotel at an excellent price on the internet (about $170 Canadian including taxes). It was highly recommended by my daughter and her boyfriend who stayed there for one night upon their arrival in Japan and I am thrilled that I took their recommendation. I also read the reviews on Trip Advisor and was happy to have discovered the bakery just off the reception for breakfast the next morning. I'm afraid I can't comment on the convenience of the location because I was (most unfortunately) in and out, but it was about a $20 cab ride to the train station which is where I headed after checking out.If you ever go to Tokyo, want first class luxury in a most accommodating hotel, then the Park Prince Tower Hotel should be your first choice.

We were totally happy with the Prince Park Tower (Tokyo) ... Our guest room at the Prince was completely comfortable. We stayed at the Prince following our arrival in Japan from California. As you probably know, the westerly flight from L.A. to Tokyo is somewhat brutal. The Prince is an ideal location to try to shake the travel-related stupor that usually follows lengthly flights. The room was quiet, the bed comfortable, and the bathroom luxurious. The location is excellent - though not in the middle of a touristy neighborhood. Easy walking distance to a handful of subway stations and lines. I recommend attempting to figure out the lay of the land during the daytime (and not immediately after getting off the plane). If you take the JR Line to Hamamatsucho with your suitcases, it could be a little challenging finding the hotel in the dark. Instead, take the Narita Express to Tokyo Station and take a taxi to the hotel (1500 yen approximately).

We're currently enjoying our last night at the PP Tower Hotel, and we've loved every moment. We spent our first night in The Hilton Osaka, and although that hotel is nice too, I think this hotel is much better. -Stayed in Superior Double Room, it has a spectacular view over the city, but not of the tower if that is what you are wanting-The bedroom is extremely spacious, comfy bed, the best & cleanest linen, comfortable pillows. Has everything, wired internet for your computer, (free), just ask at reception for a adaptor to run power. -The bathroom is the best I've seen in a hotel, 5 star bathroom! Luxury toiletries, jet spa, fluffiest best towels ever! -Easy to catch a taxi everywhere local, cost 890yen, from Shin Osaka to hotel, 980yen from hotel to Roppongi, Caught the Shinkansen Nozomi from Osaka to Tokyo Station, approx 2hrs, 13420yen one way, stops at Kyoto, so am assuming its a cheaper fare to get there?-Tried room service, probably cheaper at the restaurant itself, restauant is expensive as mentioned already but you might want to try it at least once.-Nearest station to the hotel is Shibakoen Station if tha route is available to you on your return journey to the hotel at any time-Supermarket in Roppongi is cheaper to buy your alcohol from, the hotel shop (by reception) is cheaper than the exact same drinks in the minibar-Food is good & cheap at train stations, or on your venture out of the hotel, however the bakery next to the reception hasgreat sandwiches & other items if you need something straight away-Weather is quite hot during the day at themoment, aircon in room is excellent. However the night we arrived, we were meant to land in Tokyo but there was a typhoon & we were diverted to Osaka overnight. Next day it was bright & sunny liked nothing happened.Excellent stay especially if you get a good deal on a good travel website. We booked through Expedia and have paid more per night for hotels far below these standards.Totally recommend this hotel!

Got an excellent rate (GBP 163) for a Premium Twin room for 4 nights including breakfast, use of the gym and swimming pool and free internet. The premium room also came with use of the executive lounge, which was fantastic for breakfast and afternoon tea if around at that time. This was a big bonus as the normal breakfast room was a lot busier - and the executive room was peaceful and luxurious - with the same great views over Tokyo Tower and the city. The bedroom again was great. Big for Japan standards, extremely modern and clean, wall to ceiling windows and a balcony with fantastic views from the 31st floor over Tokyo. Great bathroom with large jacuzzi bath, separate shower cabin and the obligatory hi tech toilet. Incredibly quiet room, didn't hear other guets once in 4 days.At this price and some more I would thoroughly recommend and can't see what double or triple so expensive hotels like the Park Hyatt or Mandarin could offer better.

Myself and my brother and sister stayed in Tokyo for 4 days, and enjoyed a lovely time at the hotel. The beds were comfortable - although they use duck feather pillows and duvets in the hotel - not something that i am used to. Upon check-in we were automatically upgraded to the 18th floor. We had a view of the south east side of Tokyo where we could see the Rainbow bridge and the Ferris wheel in the distance. The room was nice and we had a connected room, and two bathrooms between the three of us. Mine and my sisters bathroom was very big! And the rooms were also very spacious. Service was brilliant as was eveywhere we travelled to in Japan - culturally they maintain an excellently high standard - although the english of the hotel staff was a little limited but with lots of hand gestures and the assistance of a phrase book, we managed! Location was good - being a 5 minute walk to two different subway stops. And the hotel also provided a free shuttle bus to the nearest JR station. Although the hotel was located near the Tokyo Tower - we didn't bother going as i was told by many people that it wasn't that great. Better view points were the Tokyo Metropolitan Building or the World Trade Centre Building.The rooms - bathroom especially - were very clean - as again is down to the excellent Japanese standard. And breakfast was good with again excellent service.Overall - our stay in Tokyo was enjoyed thoroughly more due to to our stay at the hotel. Highly recommended.

Stayed at Prince Park Tower for 4 nights.
