It was one of the best hotels we stayed in our 12 day trip to Japan.We were able to get a good price for the Premium double with balcony from Expedia.The premium rooms included access to spa and fitness center and half a bottle of Champagne every night and breakfast for two. It also gave us access to the premium lounge which offered complimentary soft drinks, expresso and cocktails. It is a small room, nothing fancy, but has great views of the adjacent temple and Tokyo skyline. Also they only serve alcohol after 5pm.The breakfast buffet was great, they have two options of either the Japanese one in the basement or continental breakfast room on the 33rd floor with amazing views.The restaurants in hotel are very expensive, you can find quite a few cheap places to eat arround the hotel. Room service food seemed to be a much cheaper option than the restaurants there.The hotel has a free shuttle every 30 mins to the Hamamatsucho train station which is pretty close, a 10 min walk. Its on the JR line so the JR pass can you used.On the whole we enjoyed our stay at the PPTT, service was excellent and the hotel was close to the train line.

This was my first trip to Tokyo, and it couldn't have started off better. This hotel has it all. Restaurants, cafes, shops, it even has a bowling alley in the lower section of the hotel. We got a great special on expedia, which offered us "premium membership". This meant free snacks and drinks nightly with the super friendly staff on the 32nd floor. It also meant free breakfast in any of the hotel restaurants, or in the premium lounge itself. The rooms were spacious and the amenities were perfect. Free high speed internet meant we could skype at our leisure. The subway line was a five minute walk, and the JR line was an eight minute walk. Lots of restaurants in the area, and a karaoke machine that will never be the same after our visit :)The staff were incredible. They recommended and booked restaurants, and helped organize a special sumo training session visit.This is somewhere i would love to return to when I next visit Tokyo.

Anyone who has arrived in Tokyo on an early morning flight from the UK only to find that their hotel will not allow them to check in until late afternoon, will welcome a hotel that does! a great plus!!hotel staff were pleasant and profesional, hotel is clean, rooms are large (again quite rare in Tokyo unless you drop big bucks per night) , location is central (next to the Tokyo Tower) - only fault i could find is pricey room service and minibar, other than that - Spot on!

The Prince Park Tower was a fabulous find. We had 2 rooms in the corner with breathtaking views of the Tokyo Tower. In fact, I was able to soak in the large tub while drinking the complementary champagne and gazing at the beautifully lit up Tower...what a great way to end our days in Tokyo! The rooms were clean and well-appointed with excellent amenities. The breakfast buffet was a wonderful fusion of american and japanese cuisine combined with the incredible Tower views. The hotel is within easy walking distance to public transportation (even with 3 young kids) and the neighborhood was clean and safe. We didn't get a chance to enjoy much of the "club" and when we were there, they didn't have much to offer but everything else was fabulous. We highly recommend this hotel!
This probably was one of the best hotels I've ever been to.It's located right beside Tokyo Tower and the view is amazing.Interior design is so elegant and stylish.I'd love to go there again.

Absolute perfection. We could get an upgrade to a fantastic room. We've watched the city from our 23th storey bathroom yacuzi.... it's lovely. The curtains opened and closed by pressing a button. Beds were perfect. Staff's perfect.. Restaurants and bars are expensive but good. The have an indoor hotel shop where you can buy food (breakfast) and drinks, so you don't have to rely on your minibar or expensive breakfast service.Close to subway lines and a beautiful quiet haven in a crowded city!
This hotel was wonderful, beautiful, amazing! I can go on and on and on. The staff, the food, rooms, the views... everything. Stay here, it is as close to perfection as a hotel can be.

This is our second stay at the Prince. Location: In a quite part of town, and there are limited choices of restaurants and shopping nearby. The hotel is served by two nearby subway stops making it a great location. (5 minute walk) Near the Tokyo Tower and on a beautiful park and Temple.Hotel: Very nice hotel, we had a room on the executive floor with access to the lounge which was very nice. Lounge included light breakfast, evening snacks and drinks. Service: Very good, staff in the lounge also helpful with restaurants, suggestions, etc.Breakfast: You can have it on the 33rd floor with a great view of the Tokyo Tower. It is buffet and it was included in our room rate otherwise it is about $30 Canadian (to expensive) but worth it once for the view.Shuttle Bus: Pick up/drop off for airport (about $30 Canadian) and one subway station (free)Onsen: Our room rate included access to the onsen (great), pool and a nice small gym, otherwise access is very expensive.Overall: Still a great hotel although the service and breakfast quality seem to have been cut back little. Wired internet free - no wifi If possible get a room rate with breakfast and access to the executive floor and lounge.

Previous reviewers have lamented the lack of nearby retaurants in this otherwise ideal hotel. All one needs to do is venture across the road and there are at least ten fine small local restaurants with a diversity of foods withinn 500m in the side streets across from the Akatanebashi Subway station next to the hotel. My wife's favourite place to eat in Tokyo is the nuun restaurant which is closest to the hotel 50m down the side street across the street from the ENEOS gas station next to the hotel. It's a very inventive organic vegetarian Japanese where dinner for two with a bottle of white wine will only set you back $50-60.

The hotel and its grounds were beautiful and immaculately kept. The room was spacious by Tokyo standards and while very reasonably priced was located on premium floor. Asked for a Tower view and was accommodated accordingly. Mini-bar expensive (not-surprisingly) but delicious tea was available for free in the room. Bathroom had jet tub and separate shower -- best showers of my life. You don't need to bring any toiletries: toothbrushes, mouthwash, combs, brushes, hairbands, razors, and luxurious l'Occitane shampoos, conditioners, shower gels, and body lotions were provided. Also: best hair dryer I've ever used (and I've used some); it was quiet and it didn't seem powerful but my hair dried really fast and remained frizz-free in the high September humidity.For your computers, if your plug is 3-pronged, just call down for an adapted and they'll bring one up to you (for free -- unless you lose it) in a flash. A cord for the high-speed connection was already provided in the room (the girl who showed me my room brought it out of the desk drawer immediately).Service was unlike anything else I've ever seen. Very polite, warm and friendly... eager to please. I approached the hotel with 2 shopping bags in each hand from a day in Ginza, and a bell hop hurried toward me to take my bags and bring them up to my room for me. One day I asked the concierge how I could go about sending a bottle of wine (a thank-you gift) to a colleague in Tokyo, and before I knew it she was filling out a courrier form and wrapping the bottle in bubble-wrap for me, etc. Unbelievable!Food in the hotel was quite good (except food that tried to imitate American food... just stick to the Japanese food) but overpriced -- go elsewhere for main meals.... but the bakery/gift shop on the first floor was extremely useful. Every morning I started my day there for a fruit smoothie and a small bite to eat before heading out for my day. It's also open till 1 a.m. so it makes for a great late-night snack if you're jet-lagged and watching Japanese variety shows on your enormous flat screen tv.The hotel was also very well located. Don't believe anyone who says the subways are far; that must be an extremely lazy person! There are two subways nearby: Shibakoen which is right on the other side of the park, and Daimon (which I used the most) which was less than a 5 minute walk away in a very clean and very safe neighbourhood (mostly salarymen around). If you have any doubts, the concierge will be only too happy to whip out an area map and a subway map to draw you the very short route, and even tell you what's the easiest way to get to your destination.I fully intend to visit Tokyo again, and when I do, I fully intend to stay at the Prince Park Tokyo Tower. It was a great deal (after all, I'm a graduate student and am not rolling in dough...yet, hehe), and I couldn't have asked for better service and luxury even if I'd paid twice as much. You'll also appreciate that it's surrounded by a park; I'd considered staying at the Cerulean Tower hotel, but when I walked by it in Shibuya, I was happy I wasn't staying in such a busy (and somewhat smelly) area. I had somewhere peaceful but still central to unwind and relax.
I would definitely stay there again. it's got my 5 star level satisfaction , but the price was very reasonable. LOVED it.

We came directly to this hotel after a few weeks in China (which was disgusting!) and I am so relieved and happy to find this amazing hotel! We got very lucky and booked this hotel at a very low rate, which usually means they throw you into some un-renovated room with a view of a concrete wall - but not here! They actually upgraded us to a beautiful room on the 15th floor with a view of the park, shrine and Tokyo tower. We have a large room (even by US standards), its spotless (even by Japan's standards) and it has a fabulous super-toilet, balcony, comfy beds, big TV, couch...Even the free toilet products are great (a nice razor and mini-can of shaving cream were much appreciated!). There is a great bakery/cafe/gift shop in the lobby where we bought a bunch of treats at normal prices. Room service prices are laughable ($58 US for a pitcher of beer)!but hey...It's Tokyo. This hotel is not in the main-on-main area, but I think that is a plus - I like to hear the sound of the trees in the park below. It's only 5 minutes to the nearest station and you are 10 minutes from Ginza shopping by train or a brisk 25 minute walk to Roppongi Hills.

Prince Park TowerI spent 8 days here with my sister on a summmer trip.The hotel was excellent in every way - service, rooms, cleanliness, view….We did not stay in the upper (executive) floors (which start at floor 19) but we asked to be as high up as possible so they put us on the highest non-executive floor (18). The bar on top is great - we didn’t try the restaurant. The spa is fantastic - overall it's a great hotel, highly recommended for friends/couples travelling. Breathtaking views of the city, the Ginza and the Rainbow Bridge.I am going for the same hotel next time I'm in Tokyo.

Stayed at The Prince Park Tower for the first leg of my honeymoon. Got a wonderful room with a fantastic view of the Tokyo Tower! Check in was very swift and efficient, and we were then whisked away to our suite. I really liked how the lights in the hallway turned on as you approached, and turned off behind you - felt like something out of Star Trek!We were in an Executive Room which was extremely spacious! The bed was huge, and there was a separate couch and seating area. The balcony overlooked the Tokyo skyline and Tower - very cool! Included with our room were some breakfast vouchers.The first day we had a traditional Japanese breakfast which was - interesting. Nothing like having grilled fish at 9am in the morning! Glad to say that I tried it but not really my cup of tea. Had breakfast in the Verte area the rest of the stay. There was obviously a conference in town, as it was very busy with business men from all over Europe. It meant a bit of a wait for a seat, but not too bad at all. The food was very good and service was even better!The location of the hotel was very close to the subway, which is an amazing way to get around. As a foreigner, I found it extremely easy to navigate, as each subway line is assigned a letter, and each stop a number. The language barrier is non existent in that case, as it was simple as getting to "I-9" and seeing that we changed to the A line.We had dinner at the Yakitori restaurant one night, and it was extremely entertaining and satisfying. We were so full at one point, we saw the Chef cooking up some fish, and both my wife and I were saying to ourselves "Don't be for us, don't be for us!!". Thankfully it wasn't so I didn't have to undo another belt buckle!All in all, a very satisfying experience at The Prince, and if I ever find myself back in Tokyo, I wouldn't hesitate to book there again!

We're a family of 2 adults and 2 kids aged 9 and 10. We stayed in a superior comfort double room on the 21st floor. Spacious room with the biggest bed I've ever seen. Big enough to fit all 4 of us if we wanted to. Very comfortable bed as well. Fabulous view of Tokyo Tower and its surroundings. All the pros mentioned in previous reviews are true. The only con was the hotel restaurants are very expensive. We arrived late at night and were very tired after 12 hours flight. Went to its Japanese restaurant and paid about usd $100 per person for dinner and still felt hungry afterwards. So, definitely go out for dinner. A lot of good restaurants about 15 minutes walk or 5 minutes Oedo subway line from Akabaneshi to Azabujuban. Overall, great hotel which I would recommend to anybody.

Located in a great spot, close to two subway lines and a bus from the airport gets you right to the hotel. The rooms are spacious and clean, slept really well each night. The fitness center has the best pool I've seen in a hotel to date. The changing rooms also have an lovely onsen available, and I could waste days in there. There are several restaurants to choose from, if you feel like staying in the hotel, though the can be a bit pricey. One of the best hotels I've visited.
Excellent hotel both for business travelers and tourists.

The Prince Park Tower was an excellent base for exploring the city, and a welcome retreat at the end of each day. We found a promotion on Expedia for 3+ night stays that brought the daily rate under $200 per day - not cheap, but great value by Tokyo standards in our opinion. (Our rate included access to the fitness center, pool and onsen which normally runs 4000 yen per day for all three - worth looking for. High speed internet access was also included.) Pros:- Excellent access to transit (Akabanebashi stop on the Oedo line - 5 min walk, Shibakoen stop on the Mita line - 5 min walk, Hamamatsucho JR station - 20 min walk, hotel provides free shuttle every 30 minutes during certain hours)- Large, well-appointed rooms with separate jetted tub and shower (great after walking around all day)- Phenomenal pool area with the best indoor pool I've found at any hotel (proper 25-meter pool with two lanes for lap swimming plus a separate play pool area), sauna, jacuzzi, and - best of all - onsens (Japanese hot bath) in each locker room. Swim caps (required), goggles and kickboards provided. - Good gym with decent cardio and excellent strength training machines. Gym clothes are available to borrow in the locker room for anyone who left theirs behind.- Bakery and store in lobby provided decent alternatives to restaurants and room service for breakfast, snacks and drinksCons:- Hotel restaurants extremely expensive (expected)- Nearest non-hotel restaurants 10-minute walk away (towards Hamamatsucho JR station)I will definitely consider this hotel first for all future visits to Tokyo.

This is a good 4 star hotel with excellent service, but do not expect it to be a luxury hotel. I booked the hotel because of the high reviews from Trip Advisor, and I felt that some of the reviews probably overrated the hotel. I stayed in the premium room for 7 nights, and felt a little disappointed at the lack of awe factors that I will expect from other luxury hotels.For starters, the room design was a bit outdated, I was expecting more of a modern luxurious feeling from a premium level room; it felt more like an early-2000s-designed superior room on a higher floor level. Sure; there was a daily free bottle of champagne, Ella Baché toiletries, Nepresso coffee, a Jacuzzi tub, exclusive floor access and such, but these are things one will normally get from staying on a premium floor. There was nothing really spectacular from the premium level room. I had a corner room with a view of Tokyo Tower from the bathroom, but sadly the tub was placed in such a way that you can’t enjoy it while facing the tower. Breakfast was included free for the premium level rooms, and there was a choice of three restaurants. A buffet style as well as a continental breakfast set style on the 33rd floor, as well as a Japanese set style breakfast on the basement level. Breakfast was fresh but disappointing when you consider the actual price of the breakfast. For the same price (if you had to pay), a much larger and better spread of choices for breakfast are easily available anywhere else in Tokyo. The portions were very small in the continental and Japanese set breakfast (even for an Asian like me). There is a variety of dishes in the buffet, but after the 4th day at the buffet, the dishes become rather unappealing.What was very disappointing was the premium lounge; it is the worse lounge I have ever seen. No food was served there at all except for a couple of crackers and some fruits in the night. What was surprising was that despite the obvious lack of facilities at the premium lounge, there were still other guests hanging around there during cocktail hour. The attendant at the lounge makes good cocktails though and it was nice to have a drink or two in the evening, unfortunately the lounge closes at 10pm at night.Premium level rooms also have free access to the hot springs below the hotel, a nice place to go after a tiring day in Tokyo. Japanese hot spring etiquette applies here, and a good time to be at the hot springs will be either late in the evening or early morning where there are much lesser people.Overall, the hotel tries hard to be a level above other hotels, but it still fall shorts of being a luxury hotel. Unless there is a promotion going on, you may want to consider other international luxury hotels.

Great hotel, wonderful quiet location with good metro access to wherever you need to go. Get a package with breakfast included—nice buffet, with windows overlooking Tokyo Tower. Free internet. Tip: For a great evening, go to the Tokyo station area of town and have dinner at Resonance, a French bistro. Then listen to jazz at the Cotton Club next door.

I travelled to Tokyo in May with my parents. The hotel was beautiful and the staff all spoke English and were very helpful. The hotel is about 20 min walk from the nearest JR station and the hotel runs a free bus service to the station-we didnt find out about it till the second day though. The hotel doesnt have a lobby to sit and wait in if you need to kill some time. There are no food places near the hotel though.The closest stuff was the JR station.

My daughter and I enjoyed a very pleasant stay at this hotel. We booked the Special package which included breakfast and complimentary lounge privilege. Exceptional value. The room was spacious, clean and comfortable. We had the buffet breakfast and appreciated the variety of the vegetable and fruit sections very much. It appeared many locals came here for the buffet on weekend mornings. We found that our breakfast lasted us til suppertime (we were full but not "stuffed"). We took the hotel shuttle to Hamamatsu station and walked back from the station to the hotel every night - about 12-15 minutes. Although we were out walking all day, the jacuzzi bath and vigorous shower would refresh us every night. The towels were of one of the best I have seen in hotels. The beds and linens were very comfortable. We went to the lounge only once. It was just a small room with a few small tables and no people except for a hotel host/server. He could hear every word we whispered - no privacy at all.Overall, we loved this hotel!

The room is spacious and clean, but the TV is quite small. State of the art electronic toilet as you would expect in any top hotels in Tokyo. Friendly and helpful staff. There is also an indoor pool and Hot spring in the basement, which is perfect for travellers to relax after a day of work/travelling. All facilities are spotless. What I enjoy the most is breakfast on the top floor of the hotel. On a clear day, you can see Mt. Fuji at the distance. The breakfast could be quite pricy, (about 3,500 yen), but it's all worthwhile. The rooms are not cheap. So if you have money to burn, and would like to enjoy a nice stay in Tokyo, this is a very good option.

One of the most satisfying stays I have ever had. This Hotel was absolutelly flawless and by far surpassed my expectations.We arrived at NRT and took the "Frindly airpot shuttle", who were trully friendly, over to the hotel. The ride was 3,000 yen per person, but its quite far and i guess the most convenient alternative since they drop you off right at the door.We were greeted by friendly staff who promtly checked us in and escorted us and the bags up to our room. They put us up at the 31st floor -- WHAT A VIEW!! Keep in mind this hotel has only 33 floors, 32nd floor is for royal suites and 33 floor is for restaurants.Even the ride up with the all-glass elevator was cool. Also, they got separrate elevators for Premium/Superior room guests - a very nice touch! Kind of like First class on a plane.The room, while not huge, had everyting and anything you could possibly want. All ammentities from bath robe to slippers etc. etc. These were changed every day and the toiletries replenished. If you stay here, you will not need any personal hygene stuff, they got it all.It was the cleanest room/bathroom I have ever stayed in.The breakfast buffet was absolutelly awesome. They had it all...and more. Exteremly well organized, excellent service and everything was fresh and constantly replenished. Best breakfast buffet I have ever seen, by a large margin. Please note, the breakfast is 3000 yen, so make sure you get that included in your stay. Our breakfast was included in the stay, we received breakfast coupons upon check-in.The location was ok, with subway station close by. However, the hotel wasn't in any busy district such as Ginza or Shunjuku, some might see that as a drawback. We did walk back from Ginza once, and actually it wasnt that far. Not to mention it was quite good for sightseeing. The Hotel is located in a small park, great for evening walks. Otherwise its walking distance from Roppongi hills district.The staff was amazing. Extremelly friendly and promt to respond to any requests. Overall - highly recomended.

I just stayed for a few days of a month long vacation in Tokyo but I really loved this hotel, the staff were very friendly and helpful, which was great for me as I speak very little Japanese.I would agree that it isnt the most convienient location as far as the subway goes, but only a 10 min walk so this didnt bother me at all. Anyway, once you figure out how to use the underground system you'll be hopping from line to line like a local to find the shortest route to your destination. I absolutley loved the restaurant, it was one of the best meals I had in Tokyo and the views from the bar and restaurant overlooking tokyo tower and the rest of the city were amazing. I only stayed a couple of days and would defo go back again.

My wife and I spend a 10 days holiday in Tokyo and stayed at the Prince Park Tower Tokyo. Originally we’re looking for hotels in the Shinjuku area with a budget of <=$250 per night, we narrowed it down to Keio Plaza Hotel and Century Southern Tower but after reading Tripadvisor comments we’re a bit discourage with them. We then found Prince Park Tower, the price was within our budget and read many positive reviews, we were a bit hesitant with the location since we wanted to be in a convenient location but we decided to go for it. We booked a Superior Comfort King room from Hotels.com, the price was about $230 per night. We took the Airport Bus Limo service to the hotel (little bit over an hour away) for 3000 yen per person. The hotel check-in was quick and pleasant. The Superior room has its own dedicated and private elevators, which requires room key access. We’re at the 20th floor and the room has a great view of the Tokyo Tower, Zojoji temple, hotel landscape, and Tokyo skyline. The king size bed was huge and comfortable, room also comes with free-wired Internet access, and mini refrigerator with drinks and snack. The bathroom has a great separate shower stall, Jacuzzi tub, and a terrific Toto toilet with features that many bums will enjoy ☺ The only item that was missing was an iron and ironing board however housekeeping will deliver them upon request. We used laundry service twice and got 20% discount each time. The location and nearby Shiba park creates a pleasant peaceful environment especially after spending all day walking through congested streets and subway stations. There are 2 subway stations nearby; Mita and Oedo Line, both are less than 3 minutes walk and they are not congested stations compare to Shinjuku and other main stations. Sample routes - Odeo line to Shinjuku is about 6 stops and Mita line to Ginza is about 3 stops. If you have an iPhone download the Tokyo Underground app ($.99), you just enter to/from subway info and it will tell you what subway lines to take and change to. The Tokyo City Atlas book was also helpful while exploring Tokyo. There isn’t much restaurant nearby the hotel, however the Tokyo Tower (less than 8 minutes walk from the hotel) has shops, convenient store, and fast food restaurant (Japanese and McDonalds). Another option is to take the Oedo line and head over to Roppongi, it’s only 2 stops away (170 yen each way). If you want to try Japanese food but cannot read or speak Japanese, Roppongi Hill (http://www.roppongihills.com/en/) has many restaurants’ menu that includes Japanese and English. The hotel also has several restaurants we tried the Café Novel and Lobby Lounge for late lunch and afternoon tea and the Brise Verte for breakfast. The breakfast was a bit expensive (3000 yen per person) considering we don’t eat much, for the rest of the trip we picked up drinks, bread, and pastry for breakfast from the hotel shop/bakery, they were cheap and delicious. The hotel normal checkout time is 12PM and we’re looking to check out at 2PM for a 6PM flight, we notified the front desk a day prior to our departure and they basically said “No problem”. To our surprise they did not charge us extra even though the hotel policy states ~30% for late check out. The hotel shop has an ATM machine however it only allow withdraw from Japanese bank and Citibank. Unfortunately it did not work with my Wells Fargo debit/Visa card, in fact we’re not able to withdraw money from several Japanese bank ATM machines. Eventually we discovered Shinsei bank and Citibank ATM machines works fine with Wells Fargo and Washington Mutual (Chase). Shinsei bank has some ATM in subway station, we were stopping and changing subway line at Hibiya quite a bit and it has a Shinsei bank ATM machine. Roppongi Hill ATM machine also works fine. Overall we enjoyed our stay at the Prince Park Tower, we didn’t use much of the hotel services and facilities like concierge, business center, and gym/swimming pool. We used the subway all the time and did not rely on taxi, we got familiar with the subway system within the first full day. If you prefer to be near a convenient location with main subway lines, train station, shopping, and restaurants this might not be an ideal hotel for you.

Frankly, I am surprised with all the raving reviews for this hotel.We were there for the easter holidays, stayed for one week to visit only Tokyo (last time we had visited Kyoto).Location : The only subway station nearest is the Akabanebashi Station and it serves only one line, the Oedo line. The hotel is nearer to Roppongi hills but not by foot. It is two stations away.In short, it is not situated in a major junction like Shibuya, Shinjuku or Roppongi.When, you go outside the hotel, the view is quite depressing because it is not the same bustling atmosphere like Shibuya or Shinjuku.If you want to grab a quick food outside the hotel, well, you have to take the subway or the taxi. The same goes for mundane shopping. I located only one late-night small supermarket on a walkable distance.Yes, there is a park… slightly larger than the ones you find in front of any council building.There is also the Zozoji temple almost at the foot of the hotel.The rooms were very spacious which was a plus point. But the biggest minus point being that it was impossible to make the AC go down below 20°C.The hotel staff came up with three engineers and stayed almost an entire evening to fix it only to say that it should be working automatically…..but the room remained hot.Did not try any of the hotel restaurants for we were mostly visiting. Called for room service which albeit fast and efficient, a bit pricey which of course is not a surprise. The highspeed Internet service was very good in the room. To finish, Tokyo Tower. Well, it is right next to the hotel. That’s it .One of the guide books we tried was Louis Vuitton’s. Very disappointing. For hitech goods, the guide suggests Laox store (like any other guide). To me, Laox store is outdated. I prefer Yodobashi(I am giving the name from memory so my spelling may be not exact), in Shinjuku area or the one situated in Akhibara.For those who crave for Indian food, we tried the south Indian dosais at Dhaba India…one of the best dosais we have ever had and the interior of the restaurant is sober.We also tried the bowling in the basement of the hotel which was quite fun. But, remember, everything (pool, gym) is extra and you have to pay for it.The hotel certainly merits more than the one star I give. But, the one star is because I’ll certainly not come back to this hotel. I still think that Keio,which despite the fact may look outdated and constructed by Kremlin architects, is one of the best price vs. quality hotels in Tokyo.

The Prince Park Tower is an attractive hotel near Tokyo Tower. Despite its central location, it is near no restaurants. As a result, if one is tired after a full day, one is tempted to eat in the hotel rather than take a costly cab ride or walk 20 minutes to a neighborhood where there are some eating places. All the restaurants in the hotel are extremely expensive, although a modest dinner for 2 can be had in the hotel's Chinese restaurant for $70 USD. We had a comfortable, fairly decent-size room with a GREAT bathroom with a jacuzzi tub and a terrific shower. But everything in this hotel is a hassle, at least for non-Japanese. This was the only hotel in Japan (out of 4) where we felt this way.The reception clerk gave us a problem about honoring my membership in their "club" for foreigners, the benefits of which include breakfast and access to their Premium Lounge. Incidently, their Premium Lounge is the least "premium" of any club lounge that I have ever experienced anywhere in the world. Stale nuts, stale crackers, a plate of fruit and a few cubes of foil-wrapped processed cheese are hardly worth a return visit. To boot, the hostess could not understand any language but Japanese, making the ordering of a drink difficult. Unlike club lounges in other hotels, the Prince Park Tower doesn't trust their guests to pour their own drinks, not even non-alcoholic drinks.The concierge answered questions but never made a suggestion, like they did in other Japanese hotels we stayed at -- as a result, I had a lot more research to do than I should have. The air conditioning was broken and was never fixed. Getting turn-down service at night was a hassle. Using the business center computer was a hassle.Unless you get a real deal, with breakfast included, go elsewhere.

I stayed in a 'standard twin' room at the The Prince Park Tower for 5 nights from 12th April. In consensus with many of the other reviewers it is a 'very good' hotel. However, I don't think I can go as far to say it is 'great'!The staff were very helpful and courteous (as you come to expect in Japan). The room it self I felt was fairly generic - similar in quality and size to many hotels I've stayed in across Asia.The location is not a strong point. Apart from the Tokyo Tower there is not much nearby, and I didn't come across many restaurants etc. close to the hotel. However, for me, this wasn't a big deal as there were two subway stations within a 5-10 minute walk.The one thing that I felt let the hotel down is the lobby area. I thought it poor compared to other hotels I've stayed in of a comparable class. It's fairly small and there aren't enough chairs etc.

My wife and I like to travel all over the world. The hotel was our base in Japan for ten days. We fully agree with all positive reviews about the hotel. We will highly recommend this hotel and if in the future we will go to Tokyo we will definitely stay in this hotel. This is exceptional hotel.

We really enjoyed our stay at the Prince Park Tower Tokyo. The staff was so friendly and accommodating. We used the concierge quite a bit to find things around Tokyo, and they were always very helpful.The rooms were nice. They weren't overly roomy, but big enough, especially by Tokyo standards. The bathroom was definitely the highlight of the room. It was very modern with a huge jacuzzi tub. We got a great deal at the hotel by signing up for their loyalty club. It was free to sign up, and included free breakfast and a lounge with cocktails, tea, etc. The breakfast options were great, too. We only ate at the breakfast buffet during our stay, but there were also two more formal options included in the club membership.The location of the Prince Park Tower is good, although it isn't close to many restaurants or bars. It's within (long) walking distance from the JR train station, but there is also a shuttle that will take you there. A short taxi ride can get you to Roppongi, if you want to go out for dinner or check out some Japanese nightlife. There are several restaurants and bars in the hotel, too. They are all a little more upscale.Overall, I would definitely recommend The Prince Park Tower to those visiting Tokyo.

We stayed 5 nights and didn’t want to leave. We chose the Executive King (now known as the Superior Comfort King). The room is extremely large and very comfortable. The bed is the biggest bed that I’ve ever seen, so soft and with lovely pillows. The bathroom glorious and we loved having a spa every night. The view from our room of Tokyo Tower is exactly as we wanted. We were a little concerned about the distance to the JR station but there is a free shuttle to and from the hotel that runs generally every half hour and if you miss the shuttle it is a very easy flat 20 minute walk. Walking, you get to check out all the great food places for dinner. We didn’t eat at any of the restaurants as they were a little out of our price range. We did use our free drink voucher in the bar in the lobby on our last night. There was no way we could afford a second drink.Always make sure to book the hotel shuttle when you want to leave the hotel, as long as you don't mind walking if it is full.

Stay at this hotel for 3 nights, this hotel is right next to the Tokyo Tower. The staff are super friendly, and the restroom is pretty big compare to the other Japan hotels. If you want to stay at this hotel, make sure you find a deal that includes breakfast, cause the breakfast cost around $20 to $30 usd per person/per day. Overall experience, excellent !!!

This is a terrific hotel. The rooms have large windows, which in addition to great views, also give the rooms a lot of light and ambience. The bed is really comfortable, and I loved the bathtub with jets. You will also get used to the heated toilet seat.The location is also great, being walking distance to two subway stations on two separate lines that make transportation very convenient.But the best thing about this hotel is the staff. They were incredibly helpful with everything we needed, from help in the pharmacy, to making restaurant reservations. They are a fantastic resource for guests and an asset to the property.

Stayed here for 6 nights. I had stayed in Tokyo but not here, this was up with the best. I liked the quiet location and yet many things are easily accessible via train or metro. Tokyo Tower adjacent.Warmly and personally welcomed and taken to room.Train via the hotel bus and Yamanote line is good but remember the timetable the bus does have published times that have the odd non standard gap. Metro offers 2 stations easily walkable. Comfortable room quietly located with free internet access.I ate breakfast at the hotel and thought it was excellent.

My wife and I just spent 2 weeks at the PPT and can only confirm what others have said - possibly the best service we have ever had. Lovely people, attentive without being intrusive, polite, professional and friendly. All the facilities and the room were excellent as well.Location was great as it was close to central Tokyo, handy for trains but very quiet and relaxed as it is located on the edge of a large park and temple. Right next to Tokyo Tower so almost impossible to get lost. Easy walking to many restaurants and a quick taxi ride to areas like Roppongi.

We have just come home from a 3 night stay at Prince Park Tokyo. What a pleasure it was! We got the airport limousine from Narita to the Hotel. We had to wait an hour for the bus at the airport and the trip to the hotel was just short of 2 hours. It cost 3000 Yen each way and 4 hours after landing we eventually got to this great hotel!The service at this hotel is absolutely incredible .... the best we've ever had and we travel a lot. Only down point was that we arrived to a room that smelt of smoke and had 2 single beds even though we'd requested a king bed as it was our honeymoon. Within seconds we were moved to the 27th floor to a nice smelling room with a king bed.The room was huge (the biggest in our 6 weeks round the world travels) and spotless. The views out of Tokyo tower were also quite impressive. As previously mentioned there is every ammenity under the sun (hair brushes, hair bands, combs, razors, toothbrushes etc etc etc). The bath is great (big and deep) and the water automatically stops running when it is full. It also functions as a spa bath with jets. We didn't have breakfast included and had to pay 3000Y each which I thought was a bit steep (50AUD per person!) but Tokyo is not a cheap place. The food was pretty good and buffet choice adequate. There are not many places around the hotel to go for breakfast so I'd suggest getting this included if you can get a good rate. The breakfast lounge is on the 33rd floor so you do get great views.We didn't have a problem with the hotel's location contrary to other reviews. We only had 3 days in tokyo but managed to get around and see everything we wanted to. The closest station is Akabanebashi on the Oedo line. I timed our walk there from the hotel lobby and it was 5 minutes exactly (1 minute of which was spent waiting at the big intersection for the lights to turn green). It took us 20 minutes to walk to Roppongi Hills from the hotel ... easy walk just turn right outside hotel and keep walking until you get to Roppongi! IThere are over 50 different places to eat at Roppongi althought it was very quiet the evening we went up there. If it's raining the hotel will lend you umbrellas.The other plus was free wifi which we really appreciated after having to pay 75US centre per minute previously!I'd highly recommend this hotel based on its big rooms, excellent service and what we thought was a pretty neat location away from the hustle and bustle.

First class all the way for a city hotel. quality, service, atmosphere. We only stayed one night but it was great. My only caution is ... the hotel restaurants are expensive, shockingly expensive. That said the Sushi Restaurant... the best we've ever had. I guess you really do get what you pay for.If you can afford it, go to the 33rd floor lounge for an evening drink and gaze at the Tokyo Tower across the street. Be prepared for an overwhelming level of attentiveness here... I believe I counted seven people from the lounge exit to the elevator thanking us for coming up.As for recommending to a friend...only a rich one.

Superb hotel - has all that you need and it is huge!Stayed here with a friend in January and its a great place. Very close to the public transport, well appointed and the staff are super helpful. For the price you get a great room (albeit a touch small but it is Tokyo after all) and superb service. Rooms are clean, have all that you need and have those crazy Japanese toilets - I could not work out how to turn down the toilet seat heater from scorching. The view from the bar at the top is breathtaking and well worth going for a look - if only to see the beautiful people who have arrived in their Ferraris. There are loads of restaurants which were great as well and you could eat in a different place almost every night of the week.The only issue I had with this place was that a small glass of beer in the bar was 10 UK pounds (when you converted from Yen) and a can was 4 in the hotel shop. I appreciate that Japan is expensive but that was a bit hard to swallow - or not as the case was.

This property gleams with modernity and the latest technology. The hotel systems and infrastructure are the latest and greatest, without a doubt. Service in Tokyo is always gracious, but here it was also fast and effective - and I was surprised at the high level of English even though the Prince chain is Japanese-owned. The rooms - mine had a spectacular view of the Tokyo Tower - are an ample size, larger than usual for a Japanese hotel and I found the price - similar to the ANA, which offers a better location but is a much less attractive hotel - very competitive. About the only thing I didn't like is the small-ish LCD TV in the room...an OK size but not as large as increasingly usual these days. Overall, I would definitely say 'two thumbs up' concerning this hotel.

We booked this hotel for our final 3 nights in tokyo and wow we loved it.The hotel isn't that great to look at from the outside.But from the inside its beautifull. We got an amazing rate on Expedia. We had an executive room on the top floors with a breathtaking view of tokyo tower. Room category included free champagne every day from the minibar. The bathrom was big with jacuzzi. It also included free executive lounge , lounge a little disapointing. Breakfast was good.Only niggle the computers use was not free. The hotel was huge and had a shop too with reasonable prices.A great hotel if your looking to pamper yourself.The service was excellent !

My husband and I took a belated honeymoon to Japan and we stayed at the Prince Park Tower for two separate stays (7 nights total) in Tokyo based on the great reviews from TA. The reviews are correct...Prince Park Tower is fantastic! We took a short trip to Kyoto in the middle of our trip and stayed at the Hyatt Regency.The hotel worked out to be a great base for us with amazing services. We booked the Premium package (first leg through American Express travel and second leg through Expedia.com) and I would highly recommend the package. You get one of the Executive rooms with its own elevator bank that you access through your room key card. It comes with complimentary champagne every day, 2 bottles of water, daily breakfast (we LOVED the Japanese breakfast and had it almost every morning!), access to the Spa/Gym and the Premium Lounge.The hotel is modern and beautiful with amazing amenities. As others have mentioned, the bathroom is fully stocked with everything you might need including Ella Bache toiletries with a cute pouch with facial cleanser, toner and moisturizer plus a separate kit for men. The rooms are kept spotless and housekeeping kindly provided many extra coffee capsules for the Nepresso machine at my daily request.During our first stay, we were able to get the Tokyo Tower view which is awesome. There was also a nice note with a box of cookies from the property for the occasion which was sweet. Also, we went bowling a few times (the "salon" is by the spa/gym) and because we were on our honeymoon, we got two games plus shoes comped. I think the policy is that if you don't use the spa/gym, you can trade in that pass for one game. The bowling alley is really well-kept! I also used the hot springs and it's so soothing after all the walking we were doing. Concierge was great. The location was about a 10-minute walk to various subway lines and JR station. I do wish it had more convenient local restaurants around the property but I guess it's a trade-off because it was very peaceful and quiet by Shiba Park. We ate at the Japanese restaurants a couple of times plus had the room service bento dinners. Yes, the food was pricey but hey, we were on vacation. Overall, it was a fantastic time at Prince Park Tower Tokyo! Don't hesitate to book your stay there!

We (2 ladies) stayed in the Prince Park Tower for only a weekend in November but I wished it was longer! Everything was just wonderful!!!! When we arrived at the hotel a staff dressed in a kimono came up to us immediately and took our luggage, then guided us to the check-In area where we could sit down comforatbly in leather chairs while checking In- that was the best Check In I ever had! We were upgraded to the ladies floor (with extra toiletries, foot massage equipment, bath salts, ...) which was on the 30th (??) floor with an amazing view of Tokyo city and Tokyo tower! The room provided all the amenities one can ask for and we especially loved the NESPRESSO machine and the remote controlled curtains (Lost in translation!!). The staff is extremely friendly and always helpful.I have been to my share of 5 star hotels (Sheraton, Steigenberger, Sofitel, Hilton,..) and have to say that the PPT hotel was my best experience so far! Can´t wait to go back!

We spent my birthday weekend at the Prince Park Tower, and I was more than delighted. The hotel was lovely, and we were treated beautifully by the staff. Our room was gorgeous; we upgraded to one of the executive floors, which was well worth it. Our view of Tokyo was fabulous. Our bed was huge and comfortable; linens were gorgeous; the bathroom was great - jacuzzi-type tub, separate shower, lots of lovely amenities. We had a view to the river, and also, below, of the Buddhist shrine complex. The hotel offers a shuttle to the JR station; there is also a bus to Narita, although we had JR passes, so took the JR line back to Narita. There are two subway stations within a short walk, different lines. Via subway, the hotel is close to Roppongi, with many restaurants and exciting nightlife. We found it convenient to go anywhere we needed to, and also, wonderful that it is surrounded by a park, so that there was not alot of traffic noise. The spa and baths were very nice. I won't need to look around for hotels next trip to Tokyo; we'll go back to the Prince Park.

We recently stayed at the Prince Park Tower. On previous trips we had stayed nearby at the older Prince hotel and decided to stay at the Park Tower Prince because they have an executive lounge and I use it alot during the day.The location is very similar to the older Prince so there isn't much outside the doors of the hotel. The location is good for my husband business meetings. And its close to Tokyo Tower. You can walk into Roponggi (sp?) for dinner and its about a 15 min walk. Lots of restaurants.The hotel is very new and looks it. They do have a fitness center and pool but there is an additional charge to use them.There are many restaurants to choose from in the hotel. And they have a few stores; some upscale and the convience store with take away food and drugstore items. Hotel staff was very attentive and helpful as always.Internet was free as far as I can remember.The room had the usual amenities; robe, safe, coffee maker etc.

I just returned from a few days at the Price Park Tower, and was I amazed by the high standard of service this hotel offers. I have stayed at other high-end business hotels in Tokyo, and this one is at the very top of the list. If you can, get a premium room for free breakfast in your choice of three restaurants, free access to their simply amazing spa, and little things like free champagne and great toiletries. I requested a Tokyo Tower view and it was stunning. The rooms themselves are not huge, but fine by Tokyo standards, and overall, they lack a little personality. But the bathrooms are stunning. The service by staff is simply beyond what one would expect. There really isn't anything that they won't try to do for you. And by far the best English by staff I have come across in Tokyo. The location is not perfect, but there is a subway very close by, and that will take you to most place with just one transfer. And Tokyo Tower is a five minute walk away, and Daimon Dori is a great place for local restaurants. Overall, one of my best hotel experiences, and the hot spring spa alone is worth the stay. Simply amazing.

We stayed 4 nights and this hotel and really enjoyed it. We had a executive king room with a brilliant view of the Tokyo Tower. The costs was £159/night. We didn't opt for the breakfast but that is no problem as there are many places within walking distance. The hotel is located in a quiet area but is only 10-15 minutes by foot to major subway and JR stations. This was the first place we stayed after the long flight from London and were very happy. You can't go wrong with this place.

Avoid the Prince Hotel, the old one without the tower. Tourist trap for package tour hordes. Depressing to even walk past.The Tower is another story. The location is perfect, near a monastery and the "Eiffel" tower. Make sure you get a room in the tower, preferably high floor. Very cool.Imagine, a whirlpool, your own balcony (that opens!) over nighttime Tokyo. Impeccable front desk, but why would it be any other way?Liked it so much that stayed there on both parts of a two part trip to Tokyo. No frequent traveler points and no nonsense.

Outstanding Hotel. Location is exceptional. Fantastic views. Rooms are large and immaculate clean all the time. My first experience with a Toto Toilet left me angry at the American difficulties to get this in USA. Heated toilet seats are not rare in Japan but the Toto technology is Patent obstructed in USA. The hotel restaurants are expensive but in our case was included in the Tour hence, no problem with the price. The same applicable to room prices which are quite high (over U$250 a night for standard level) .The hotel computer access is outrageously expensive so, use an Internet café nearby as with the meals due to overpriced restaurants in the building.Service of the staff is outstanding and very cooperative for directions to the subway or the nearby areas of Shinjuku or Roppongi, the Imperial Palace or via metro-line to Asakusa, the soul of Tokyo and Senso-Ji Temple, the heart of Asakusa.

We enjoyed a three night stay at the Prince Park Tower in the middle of October. The service from staff is fantastic, and the location is convenient for sightseeing. The hotel is a ~10min walk from JR Hamamatsucho Station, which is nice for those who have bought a JR Pass. There is also a hotel shuttle to and from the station which runs every half hour. The neighborhood is quiet and safe to walk around in.The hotel restaurants are very expensive and we did not try them. There are lots of good, reasonably priced restaurants near Hamamatsucho including working-man gyu-don places where you can an entire meal for $4.50USD.The room itself was a good size, we had a 9th floor Standard Twin. Very clean and the beds were comfortable. It was fully stocked with toiletries, robe and slippers. Notably missing is an iron (not found at other Japanese hotels either), although one is available upon request. Our room faced the front of the hotel which opens up to a big street and a highway. There was some road noise but it was not bad.The service at the hotel is incredible, especially for someone used to U.S. standards. They were friendly and genuine in their desire to make our stay pleasant. Their English was quite good and we never had any communication issues. Our one complaint was with the air conditioning. It didn't seem to have the capacity to cool the room properly and the room was always a bit warm, perhaps 77F. It was under 70F outside which makes this a bit disappointing.

I booked a Premium Room via Expedia and got a great rate by booking and paying a month or so in advance. The room and Hotel has just about everything and every gadget you can think of - so perhaps what it doesn't have is easier: doesn't have one of those little retractable cords/lines in the bathroom for when you rinse out your smalls. (I suppose they want you to use the laundry service). And they don't provide milk for making tea/coffee in your room. And well - that's all I can think of that's missing. Oh - and an english language channel on the large plasma screen TV - missing one of those - all TV is japanese.so - Free Internet, ella bache toiletries - and a very wide variety, twinings tea, our package gave us free breakfast - great buffet! Free shuttle to the nearest JR station, rooms are FULL with A/C, lights everywhere, electric curtains, leather chairs, we had access to the free Premium Lounge and free access to the fantastic gym/spa complex. 2 free bottles of water and a free 1/2 bottle of champagne everyday. There is even a trouser press, netspresso machine and air purifyer. HUGE marble bathroom with fantastic views over Tokyo (the hotel is in the middle of a park so no other blds around and has clear views). Jacuzzi bath with bath salts. Great fluffy soft towels.The hotel seems very new and very plush. Great little boulangerie/store - although the restaurants are outrageously priced - too expensive for us. This place is WAY comfortable, great service (one day I hit the "please make up my room" light and 3 dudes with their trolley and equipment turned up in less than 3 minutes and got stuck in - amazing). room service would turn up in about 5 minutes.We really enjoyed staying here - made us feel special

Very nice hotel because of its location, outstanding service, well appointed large comfortable rooms with all the amenities you can possibly think of, tremendous views from the restaurants and bars on the top floor (also for breakfast!!!), free internet, regular free shuttle bus to and from closest JR station Hamamatsucho (or 12min walk), which allows you to go anywhere in Tokyo with the JR Yamanote Line (included in JR PASS!!!), great breakfast buffet. I got the best deal directly from the hotel.

Great hotel for a great price!Service is impeccable and the rooms are top notch, 5 stars with all the amenities of a luxury hotel.I booked it in Expedia and upgraded to the one after the standard room, it was worthwhile.The hotel in general very clean, highly organized and no issues at all, just plan relaxation and great service.I had stayed at the Hilton Shinjuku before but this hotel is much, much better - from a 3.5 stars to 5 stars.When I read the reviews I was a bit skeptical about the Prince Park Tower hotel since it's not a known chain in the west but I'm so glad to stayed here. The location is perfect! The subway station is very close and will get you anywhere quick, we didn't take any taxis and we had a 2.5 year boy with us.Don't think about it so much and reserve this hotel, you wont' regret it...
I enjoyed my stay in this hotel very much. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The room was very nice with a plasma screen tv and the view was awesome.

The moment I approached this hotel, staff rushed towards me, took my case and directed me towards a desk. I had booked one of their most basic rooms for 8 nights, but without saying a thing, they upgraded me to an executive room on the 27th floor!The room was the nicest I have ever stayed in - very large (especially for a Tokyo hotel) with a TRIPLE bed, leather chairs, balcony looking toward Tokyo Bay, 32" lcd tv and a very nice bathroom. Also, bottled water was provided free of charge.The staff were very pleasant, and I would recommend this hotel to anyone staying in Tokyo.The only downside to this hotel is the price of their restaurants (quite expensive), and that it is not close to many other restaurants - the nearest ones are alongside Daimon station, which is a 7-10 min walk away. Apart from that, the hotel is reasonably located - when travelling by subway, you don't usually need to change lines more than once.
good price. reasonable sized room. great gym, pool and Japanese bath (but for extra money) and spectacularly cool toilet/bidets

I really enjoyed my stay at the Prince Park Tower. Be sure to request a corner room if you can. Imagine 2 walls of windows, the view was fantastic. My room was great. Great bed, nice size plasma tv, huge bathroom with separate shower and jucuzzi tub which was perfect after walking all day. You are given mint and lavender bath salts as one of the many toiletries. The toilet has a little room of its own- When you open the door the lights come on and the toilet seat automatically raises up. Hotel was very peaceful, I got a good night's rest every night. Breakfast buffet on the top floor was great, very filling, many choices. Although juice is served in some very small glasses, so I found myself making a few trips back and forth to the juice machine.The staff was very helpful and polite, some of them do not speak English, but they will get someone who does. I did not go to the pool or workout room, but I did discover that you must pay an additional charge to use them. Not sure how much.There is a bakery, convenience store, gift shop, bowling alley, nail salon, massage parlor, Cartier store, and bridal shop all in this hotel. The area is safe even for walking at night. The subway station is about a 4 min walk from the hotel. The hotel is on a good subway line, so you can go to most places in 1 or 2 transfers. There is a mini bar and tea maker in each room. Room service is available, but I found the prices to be way too high. Example: 2 scrambled eggs and bacon was almost $30.00, and I am not exaggerating. Just read the menu prices carefully.I highly recommend this hotel, you will enjy your stay

A luxury and relatively recent (built in 2005) hotel on a convenient location with an excellent service. There is twice an hour shuttle to Hamamatsucho JR station (two stations from Shinagawa JR station). Our large and comfortable room (with a full size bed, sitting area and desk) was on the 25th floor, All possible bathroom amenities were provided. We enjoyed our buffet breakfast on the 33rd floor with views of the Tokyo Tower or the Zooji temple.My suggestion for dinner: the "gourmet" dinner buffet in the "Viking" in "the Imperial" on the 17th floor (easy to reach with the Toei subway line)

Rated as a 4 star, quite simply in most of the world it would be a deserved 5 star+. Top of the range facilities and excellent friendly amiable staff. Beautiful Spa/Gym and they lend you a full set of top of the range kit to wear if you didnt bring your own. Lots of different restaurants throughout the hotel, huge beds in the rooms, superb room service. Direct coach link to Narita airport. Great location a few hundred metres fromTokyo Tower between Rappongi and Ginza and 3 underground/overground stations close by for getting around the city. Fabulous value for money. Good for tourists and business people alike.

My son and I recently visited tokyo for my eldest son's wedding. I booked through the hotel website . We stayed at this hotel for 7 nights & we were not disappointed ! First of all customer service is IMPECCABLE ! Even though not all staff spoke english , everyone had a basic understanding of the language . We took the airport bus (3,000 yen each) and dropped us off right in front of the hotel . we arrived late at night however staff was there to take luggage and showed us to our room. The glass elevator took us to our executive room which was on the 19th floor , we had a balcony and a beautiful view of Tokyo Tower ! My other son who lives in japan came to visit us . we asked if he could stay the night and this was no trouble , room was spacious enough to fit an extra bed, not only did they bring in a rollaway bed but all the toiletries as well ! Room was extremely clean, bathroom was fantastic, shower had four different nozzle adjustments including massage ! Jacuzzi tub was relaxing to soak in after a day of shopping . Toilet even had a warm seat ! Location wise - close to two subway lines (about 2 minutes walking distance) and hotel also provides free shuttle to Hamamatsucho station which connects to the JR line. We always carried our subway map and although looks daunting at first, was quite easy to work out & very efficient . Tokyo transport system leaves sydney for dead ! There is a television , however, only CNN & BBC in english . There was also free fast wireless internet in our room which was very handy as we did not have our mobile phones.. Sadly , there are no restaurants in close proximity however we enjoyed our meal at cafe novel (basement level) . There is also a spa & fitness centre but my son could not use this facility as it is only for people over 25 years of age (which was disappointing). The hotel shop has a bakery and sells yummy pastries & bread. We went to asakusa for souvenirs & shopping. We went to Ginza where we saw hundreds of people queuing to enter the new HM building - quite amazing !!! On our last night we had cocktails at the Sky Lounge on the 33rd floor - outstanding view ! Having my PCI card meant we were able to check out later in afternoon. We had buffet breakfast on the last morning - great assortment of food ! We were sad to leave our hotel at the end our stay - an unforgettable experience !!

I don't think this hotel deserves the high rating it received; on our first night, we were given a tiny, horrible smelling smoking room (after I had indicated specifically on our reservation for a non-smoking room) resembling nothing that was shown on the hotel website. It was positively hideous, small windows and dark. When I complained, the young woman said there was simply nothing else available. As it was late, I decided to take the matter up the next day.The next day, at my insistence I was offered a better room, but should this have ever happened?The indoor swimming pool is not included in the rate and was never disclosed on our reservation.I would not recommend this hotel.

I really can't say enough good things about this hotel.The airport bus drops you off right in front, although it is one of the last stops. The hotel is really nice and cool. I was there in the heat of July and it was always so nice to come back to the hotel and have it be so cool.There's a little store just as you enter the hotel that has pastries and snacks and sodas and beer. Rather than eat the hotel breakfast, I would just grab a pastry or yogurt from here.Free wireless Internet.The gym is really good. I would echo other comments here...wear your own clothes down to the gym with street shoes...but bring your running shoes with you. Then you can change into their gym outfits once you're in the locker room. I actually ended up bringing my own gym shorts, but using their t-shirts. (Which are quite nice--the kind that wick moisture away.) You do have to pay for the gym. I was very impressed with all the amenities in the locker room and was sad I did make more of an event of using the facilities...pool, sauna, etc.My room was fantastic. It was an executive room. The bath was a whirlpool bath and really deep. I normally am a bit skeeved out by hotel baths, but this was one of the cleanest I have ever seen, so I did use it after a long day. It was great.You're close to two metro stations, which is really convenient. Perhaps my only complaint is that there weren't any restaurants right on the hotel's doorstep. You had to walk a bit to get to any.All in all, this is a super high class hotel. I stayed at the Park Hyatt on my last night--how could I not, right?--but I would say that the rooms at the Prince Park were much better, newer, and more modern.

After reading such great reviews, I was determined to book this hotel and eventually found a fabulous rate for the premium executive rooms on expedia. We stayed here for 6 nights after staying at the Hyatt Regency in Shinjuku. Although I feel that staff are slightly more friendly at the Hyatt, the room and facilities at the Prince Park Tower were certainly better. As we had a premium room, we had special executive elevators to get to the floor, which included the previously mentioned glass elevators. This is quite an experience as you shoot up the 31-floor atrium in a glass lift! The room was very well equipped with flat screen TV, free internet and far more exciting, remote control curtains! Well it's the little things that count!The bathroom was great with a separate large shower and jacuzzi bath, and the bed was the most comfortable I have slept in in Japan.For the extra money we paid for the premium room, we really reaped the rewards. We had free breakfast each morning in the Sky Buffet on the 33rd floor (otherwise charged at around £12.50 per person) and free entry to the beautiful and well equipped leisure club, pool, jacuzzi and hot spring baths. Again, this would otherwise have cost around £15 per person, so well worth it, especially in the middle of August! We had entry into the small but pleasant premium lounge, where we could order cocktails free of charge every evening between 5 and 10pm, and even better, our mini-bar was re-stocked every day with a complimentary half bottle of champagne. Sitting in the jacuzzi tub overlooking the lights of the city whilst sipping my free champagne was a highlight of this holiday. I should also mention that the restaurants on the lower ground floor of the hotel seemed very good, and price-wise appeared much more reasonable than at other hotels. And whilst its tempting to head off to Ginza or Roppongi every night, the area around the hotel is also pleasant for an informal evening. If you head out of the back of the hotel (follow the signs for leisure club, or banqueting entrance), you emerge by the Zozoji shrine. Follow the main street down towards Hamamatsucho station, and along this street are a number of pleasant pubs, bars and Japanese Yakitori places and Izaka-ya. We found a great Japanese place on the 5th floor above a British style pub. A couple of beers each and a meal of sashimi, yakitori, roast meats etc would set us back around £20 in total! Combine that with the free drinks in the premium lounge & you have a very cheap night out. Whoever said Tokyo is expensive has clearly never spent any time in London!!

Booked this hotel after reading good reviews on Trip Advisor. When we pulled up to the hotel, I thought it was nothing special (it's very tall, but looks a little dated from the outside)...but once we got inside, wow, wow, wow. The lobby is great, the glass elevator that faces the interior of the hotel is great and the rooms were fabulous. We got an Executive Room and it had an amazing view of Tokyo Tower. Distance to the closest subway station was about 2 minutes walking(station is Akabenabashi). Very close to Roppongi Hills which has great restaurants and shops. I would definitely stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo. We traveled all over Japan on our 2 week trip and this was by far my favorite hotel!Oh and the staff was outstanding, great restaurant recommendations and accurate directions!

We have just returned from Tokyo where we spent 10 days at the Prince Park Tower Hotel. Everything was excellent but most importantly the service. All the staff had excellent training and the service was consistently impeccable in every aspect you can think. The room was on the 24th floor, large and immaculate with a balcony and great city views. I can't praise this hotel enough. The hotel bar on the top floor for cocktails and great views of the city will give you the impression of being in Lost in Translation! A view of Tokyo Tower is a must day and night. We will never forget our stay there and were very sad when it was time to go.

Ok .. here's the deal .. The hotel is in a decent location, safe and near a park (though you will have 30.00 cab fares to anywhere worth seeing as its in an isolated part of town and the subway stops at 12am), the price for size and cleanliness is fair .. The staff are more than helpful... Would I, if I could have, stayed at the Hyatt Roppongi? Yes I would have ( its a better location and more pleasant rooms, and you can walk to most sites and its a cheaper cab ride) However all the public areas of the PP Tower hotel were impressive; The rooms were outdated with an odd mixture of colors... Mauve, bright green, yellow beige. Cabs had a hard time knowing where it was unless you mentioned Shiba Park ... ASK FOR A CARD WITH ADDRESS AND LEARN THE NAME OF THE NEAREST SUBWAY STOP, sometimes just having one or the other wasn't enough... all of that said .. The staff were amazing, the toilet (outrageous), with all its different operations, was a japanese novelty... the only other place I've seen them is at Morimoto restaurant in NYC ... I know crazy .. For the price you cant beat it .. but for a little more money stay some where better ... You'll save on cab fares to make up the difference...

I stayed in the Prince Park Tower for one night in May 2008; it served as the perfect base for a short stopover and allowed me to see the highlights of Tokyo in a very short amount of time. The room was large and immaculate - a real suprise as I was expecting a very small room in this city. I really wished I could have stayed for longer; I can't praise this hotel enough. The staff were very helpful in planning my day's itenerary. Check out the hotel bar on the top floor for cocktails and great views of the city too!

We arrived at the Prince Park Tower at around 10am and we all did a double take, we couldn’t believe how awesome this hotel is. We actually felt that we had walked into the wrong place but thankfully we hadn't.Unfortunately, but not unexpected, our rooms were not quite ready but we were able to check our luggage at the front desk and organise a time for our check in.The hotel is massive, especially as it is only surrounded by Shiba Park and Zojoji Temple, both of which are welcome relief from the hustle and bustle of the city.Once checked in we were escorted up to our rooms (watch out for the glass elevators if your afraid of heights oh and if your above floor 10 your ears will pop as you whizz up) on the 17th floor. We had two deluxe twin rooms with 3 guys in one and me and my boyfriend in another. Both rooms were huge and all 5 of us could happily hang out in one room after a crazy day.Each group was shown their room and given a demo of how all the gadgets work from the 32” LCD TV, separate power shower, jacuzzi bath, balcony doors etc. Yep that’s right 17th floor and we had a balcony, with a view out toward Roppongi and the Shinto Expressway. Thank God for double glazing as the expressway was never quiet.The hotel is outstanding, everything is provided for you including traditional nightwear and slippers. We didn’t eat in any of the restaurants as they are very expensive; however, there are plenty of places to eat on the main strip up from Hammatsucho station (closest, Yamanote JR line for those of you using the JR passes) everything from Chinese, Japanese, Italian to your McDonalds and Wendy’s. There is a food court (mini restaurants) in the basement of the World Trade Building that’s quite reasonableThe hotel is easy to access via train and is also a stop for the airport limo bus. We will defiantly stay here again though I think we’ll pay a bit more and have an executive room with the access to the free lounge.Oh btw beware the toilet!! Its an interesting experiance if you can't read japanese... hehee

Although I typically stay at the Tokyo Prince, I stayed this time at the sister hotel, the Prince Park Tower. What a difference! I have an executive room with a beautiful view overlooking Tokyo Ginza. The food choices are superb. Executive floors have a dedicated set of elevators accessed by key card. The staff is friendly and attentive. The fitness facility is outstanding, albeit quite a walk. Be cautioned: Unlike American hotels, people typically dress in street clothes to the fitness center and change there. They look a bit askance if you wear your workout clothes in. They do have new clean clothes for you to wear while working out. They also have a full length lap pool (indoor and immaculate) and a wonderful natural hot spring. Internet connection is via LAN and no charge. The cable is in the room, thus avoiding those annying trips to the front desk (why some hotels do this is beyond comprehenshion). There are a number of wonderful sites within 15 minutes walk, including lovely shrines in Roppongi Hills and the Zojoji temple.The Dutch Embassy is very nearby. Tokyo Station is a 10 minute (1500 Yen) taxi ride. The bus from Narita takes appx 1.25 hours and costs 3000 Yen. Akihabara (electonics) district and Roppongi (party) district are both within 15 minutes public transit. Nearby shopping is high end, so with the state of the dollar, be forewarned.This will be my hotel of choice for all future business trips to Japan.

Having stayed in Tokyo before - in a truly amazing hotel (the Grand Hyatt) and a truly dreadful one (the Keio Plaza), I had a fairly polarised experience of hotels in the city.This one is definitely at the top end of the scale.Location-wise, this is well-placed. If you are staying here, do ask for a view overlooking the Temple or Tower...the best views are to be had from the North or North-West aspects; the hotel overlooks Shibuya Park, which is simply wonderful and (if you like Tokyo Tower) offers a spectacular view both of it and other landmark buildings such as the Mori Tower at Roppongi Hills (which you simply must visit).From a public transport point-of-view, you are very well-placed for Akabanebashi (Odeo Line) and Daimon (Odeo and Asakusa Lines). However, as fun as the Metro is, you can be in Shinjuku in 20 mins in a cab or Tokyo Station district in about 20-30 depending on the time of day. Cabs aren't that expensive (caveat here being that I live in London, so I'm used to very pricey cabs); a fare from the Prince to Roppongi was always on or about 1000 Yen, which is five pounds sterling or 10 USD at time of writing. So, for the sake of getting an air-conditioned taxi, save yourself the hassle of getting on a Metro train if you need to arrive at your destination dressed well. Don't even bother with the Metro at peak time. Just don't. Unless you really like being VERY intimate with your fellow man. As for the hotel itself, the room was spotless, truly. The service at the front desk was very good and housekeeping responsive if you need to ask for an iron/power adaptor etc. I would say, however, that the vast majority of hotels in Tokyo have the same level of service regardless of class. If it's one thing Japanese hotels do well, it's hospitality. If you are a vegetarian, you will need to eat elsewhere other than the hotel in the evening, which - if, like me, you've just got off a 12 hour flight from London and a one-hour drive from the airport, is a little tedious. However, I don't actually see that, even if I weren't a veggie, that I would eat in the hotel. The food menu looked very good, but very pricey indeed. As mentioned above, I would be inclined to take the five min cab-ride to Roppongi Hill instead, which has many restaurants and bars to suit all tastes in one of the most progressive and modern parts of the city. However, the bar at the top of the hotel is well worth a visit at night, since the view and service is exceptional.Breakfast in the Hotel is a good variety of Western and Japanese cuisine. You will not leave feeling like you have paid over the odds for a poor choice of breakfast, as has been a common experience for me. Breakfast cereals, breads, lots of fruit and juices, pancakes...the choice is very good. Hotel breakfasts are never "value for money", since the mark-up is huge, but the choice and variety is very good indeed.This has been mentioned elsewhere, but a word of warning about the gym and spa. You will not be allowed to use this if you are under 25 years of age. This is a problem for some with families and seems a little harsh to me. I would rather see the hotel having its facilities open to all between certain times and 18+ years from, say, 1900. This, for me, emphasised the "business hotel" positioning that the hotel is gunning for.In summary - I would not hesitate in recommending the hotel to anyone staying in Tokyo. It is well-placed, with a good team of staff who will look after you almost to the point of it being a little embarrassing.Do learn a little Japanese before you go. "Please" and "thank you" will elicit a warm response from the locals and is a basic courtesy!Finally...and I know this sounds daft....but for a hotel that has over 500 rooms, I never felt like I was staying in a "large" hotel. The layout is designed very well as such you will not feel like you bumping into people every five mins.One downside - two of the internal lifts made of glass that run from the ground to the 33rd floor overlooking the atrium. Very cool if you like that sort of thing. Not so nice if you have vertigo, like the poor Spanish lady I met on my first day!

From the minute I walked in the door I was amazed, truly the greatest experiance I have had at any motel.The staff were very welcoming and helpful, they got me checked in and into my room extreamly fast.I stayed in a Superior Double and it lived up to it in every sence of the word. The room was extreamly moden and roomy, king size bed, coffee machine, casual sitting table, mini-bar, automatic blinds, sensor lights... the list could go on.The bathroom was the highlight of the room. It had all your standard fancy japanese features, heated toilet seat, bidet, shower with adjustable head, bath with automatic fill, bath jets.The motel is a little less central then other places but they make up for this with the number of bars and restaurants located thoughout the motel. Everything is only 10 minutes away via the train anyway.I'd truly recommend this motel to anyone wanting to have a great experiance in Tokyo, knowing that you have a fantastic motel room to return to when you are tired from sight seeing is a true luxury that is a must for any holiday.

I go to Tokyo for business regularly, but have only recently started to stay at Prince Park Tower. It's location is near to my business location, but everything about it is first class.
