It is not a Western Hotel, and feels much more like an upscale Japanese Hotel. The rooms are spacious, with separate bathrooms, and shower / tub combinations. Internet is free, and it has a nice desk area for business work. The Hotel has several very good restaurants; I tried the Sky Garden for breakfast buffet (great!), and the Japanese Steakhouse, which was also very good (but very expensive). In addition, it has a bowling alley, fitness area, and many shops - all expensive with the Yen to $ ration of about 100:1 now. I mentioned the Cherry Blossoms as they were out fully when I was there Mar 26-30, and many families and couples were having parties and dinners in the park alongside the hotel

The hotel was as good as I was led to believe. Clean. Spacious. Modern. Attentive staff. Good location. Deluxe bathroom. Nice views from the floor to ceiling window and balcony. A great find AND value.
user_name:
Aviron
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel was the cheapest available with our air/hotel package on Expedia. We were more concerned with price than star ratings, so anything would have been fine. The being said, this hotel was way above-average, especially for the price. As soon as you pull up to the hotel you really get a feel for Japanese hospitality. Everyone is bowing and saying "Welcome to the Prince Park Tower," and they even pull your chair out for you while you await check-in. We had an extra person in a deluxe twin room, and after getting to the room the doorbell rings and 3 or 4 super-polite staff enter and begin making the third bed. They even brought an extra set of toiletries, towels, and china for the tea. The room was fairly spacious especially compared to the other hotels we stayed in on our trip. The balcony was great, and the room was impeccably stocked. There is even a jetted tub and washlet (Japanese electro-bidet, haha). You can also have a staffmember come up to your room and give you a "pillow consultation," where you select your favorite pillow. In the evening, there is turndown service as well. During the day they have kimono-clad women stationed outside the elevator and they bow and push the call button. Because we were sort of backpacking, we kind of felt underdressed at times, but we weren't treated any different than the business-suit clad types.Yes, the fitness center/pool are for those 25+, but we didn't really come to Tokyo to do any of that anyway, so it wasn't a big deal. Besides, Japan has onsen! which are better than a big chlorinated pool any day in my book. I've checked recently and this hotel is still one of the cheapest available on hotels.com and expedia, which is still a huge surprise.

I just stayed a week at the "The Prince Park Tower Tokyo" hotel and I rate the hotel as excellent, especially at that room rate (paid in Euro). In comparison: Last year I stayed at the ANA Hotel which was more expensive, but did not offer the same quality.The staff is very friendly and very helpful.The room is well equipped and very clean (I had a basic room with twin beds on the 5th floor) and everything looked new. Free LAN, bathtub with bubbles, additional shower, large windows with view into a park and at the Tokyo Tower nearby. Important for me: the curtains close perfectly and the hotel is extremely quite (no noise of any cars for example).The breakfast room is on the 33rd floor and the view on Tokyo is amazing.It is a perfect hotel for a business traveler and I hope to stay there again.The only downsize: The location is not perfect, if you have a very busy schedule. It is a little bit off the centers (there are several centers in Tokyo), but in walking distance to two subway lines. I presume you can't have everything or you would have to pay much more...

In Tokyo for a week-long conference at the adjacent Zojoji Temple. The lobby of the Prince Park Tower is elegant and understated architecturally. The staff was welcoming and helpful at every level. As a business traveler, I found the concierge particularly helpful, coordinating dinners and even ordering ahead for me. The on-site restaurants were good, albeit a bit pricey for the quality. The rooms were well-appointed and comfortable with large windows. Shibakoen, the adjoining park, is a beautiful sanctuary in which to walk and find cats (in rather unexpected places at time)...if you like cats. Tokyo Tower, one of the more recognizable features of the Tokyo skyline, is a short walk from the hotel lobby and subway stop is right across the street. I would definitely return for business or for fun.

This is a fantastic hotel. It really exceeded my expectations. The staff was wonderful and went out of their way to make us feel welcome. I didn't expect such service since I booked with Expedia. I highly recommend paying extra for a Premium room because the Sky Buffet Breakfast is outstanding and you get a complimentary bottle of Champagne every night. I love this hotel and I can't wait to go back. I have stayed in many hotels in this is my all-time favorite. The location is also very convenient.

The U.S. has a lot to learn when it comes to flawless customer service. The staff at Park Prince showed us just that. They pay attention to every little detail and everyone always has a smile on their face. They even have someone dressed in a japanese kimono to press the elevator button and bows until the door is closed. Wow. The room was spacious and very clean. Nice bathroom and tub and separate toilet. One bad thing about the toilet is that you kind of get attached to it. How I wish we have heated toilet seats here with built-in bidet. The hotel is easily accessible by Limousine Bus from Narita Airport. The cost was 3000 yen and they drop you off at the hotel. The Oedo subway line is a 2 minute walk.What a great find!

• Cool location near the iconic Tokyo Tower• Hotel is huge and the reception is welcoming• In - house boulangerie and convenience store, bowling, pool and restaurants galore ranging from sushi to tempura to steak and chinese• Staff very friendly• Near the Toei subway lines, 4 mins walk to nearest subway

It's a beautiful hotel with a beautiful view...but ,if you're under 25 you can't use the gym, the hot spring, or even the pool. Sadly, they don't advertise this on their website. The sole reason I picked this hotel over the others offered was all the extras it had to offer. Unfortunately, my son that was traveling with me is only 20 and couldn't use any of them. It was very disappointing to say the least.The rooms were beautiful and clean. The tub was heaven, especially after a long day of sightseeing...(although the hot springs probably would have been nicer.)The staff was very stuffy and we had several problems finding someone that understood English well. I think they cater mostly to businessmen and conferences and really don't care about regular tourists.The other hotel I had stayed at in Tokyo in March was much more tourist friendly.

I stayed at this hotel in Nov 2007 on business. i was suspicious at first b/c it was so inexpensive (approx $200 night) compared to the other hotels i considered (Park Hyatt, Grand Hyatt at $1000 a night!!!). surprise, surprise. the hotel was spacious, elegant , modern and well equipped. not luxurious but really just fine. i am from NYC and have stayed at some pimped up places around the world and really, this is just fine. the internet worked without a problem (key for me) and the bathroom has almost as much square footage as the bedroom. marble bathroom with separate shower and tub. separate WC. spacious vanities and decent amentities (no name brand toiletries but fine). the hotel is huge and has multiple banquet /conference areas. it is centrally located so a 7 minute cab ride to roppongi hills. farther to Shinjuku (maybe 20 min?). the breakfast buffet at the top floor is decently priced (3600 yen approx) but the food was very good, fresh and had a great variety of things for the western and japanese palatte. the gym was decent. on the smaller side but the equipment was new and the locker room was very nice. i had to pay extra (i think 2000 yen a day) but whatever. didnt use the pool but i hear its nice. i think this hotel is not considered "hip" and "cool" which accounts for the lower price. the restaurants are not that great but you dont need to eat there. roppongi hills is close by. they have a well stocked convenience store that is open late and has an amazing bakery that is great for a snack or breakfast on the go (delicious breads).i would definitely stay again. overall, a fantastic value.and PS, i took a private cab from Narita to the hotel which cost me 25000 yen approx. i hear its better to take a limosine bus to any of the close hotels in roppongi (it doesnt need to have an exact stop at this hotel) and then take a cab.

We stayed in an executive suite which was on floor 21 and rated as 5 stars. It certainly met all our expectations.The staff were courteous and helpful and all were fluent in English - which is always a bonus.The hotel has a range of restaurants with a wide variety of food styles. It sits next to Shiba Park and close to Tokyo Tower with views either over the park to the Bay or to the tower.Large widows and good layout meant the room was clean, light and airy and extremly comfortable. Room service, restaurant and mini bar costs were low for a hotel of this standard.A courtesy bus to Hamamatscho JR station is available although we generally walked the 10 minutes to get there. Metro stations are less than a 5 minute walk away.Far enough away from the hustle and bustle of the shopping areas, but close enough to reach them easily I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking for a high quality hotel in Tokyo.

Overall experience was great. Convenient location: walking distance to Roppongi, a few minutes walk to Oedo Subway line. Short walk to Hamamatsucho Station on JR Yamanote line, but we mostly used free hotel shuttle, which operates every half hour. Beautiful views from the rooms. Specious bathrooms and nice toiletries including bath salts, toothbrushes, and lots of other stuff. Didn’t try any of the restaurants, but the upstairs bar is worth checking out. Although the drinks are expensive ($17-$20+$10 table charge), they are really good, and the night view of the city and Tokyo tower is impressive. Definitely stay in this hotel if you are on the budget. It is one of the best for the price. However, don’t expect a free room upgrade or a free breakfast if you booked at discount rate.
stayed on upper floor, wonderful viewbreakfast on 33rd floor free if you join prince cludtwo subway stops nearclose to roppongi and ginzaquite beautiful area for walking

Because I got such an excellent rate at hotels.com, I was not sure of the quality of the hotel. Was I in for a pleasant surprise. Great, unobstrusive service, incredible beds and bathrooms and, in my case, a balcony. It was easy to get to Roppongi Hills, there was a shuttle to Narita, the desk personnel were incredibly helpful. Get a room high up to enjoy the amazing view, it is well worth it. I can not wait to return.

My wife and I attended an OR conference at the Graduate School of International Policy Studies and they initially booked us at the Tokyo Prince Hotel, which seemed ok since it was close enough to Roppongi which was where the school was located. But I checked Trip Advisor two days before we left and found poor reviews for Tokyo Prince - 187th out of 256, I think - so I became desperate and quickly looked for alternatives in the same area. Turned out there was a Prince Park Tower Tokyo, also owned by the Prince chain, and just across the street from Tokyo Prince. It was new - built in 2005 - which is probably why the school wasn't too familiar with it. It was rated a high 11th in Trip Advisor. The rates were almost similar. So we immediately asked the school to rebook us, and luckily, they were able to. It's one of the last stops on the Airport Limo Bus service but that was a bit of blessing since it allowed us to see a number of hotels in the area, esp Tokyo Prince which looked quite old from the outside. The limo bus had to park 150 meters from the front door which was a minor inconvenience but the bell people were very quick to meet the bus and unload our luggage. Every one who got in was met individually by a front desk person and led to a separate stall with guest chairs. What a nice touch, rather than having you line up and stand while checking in. Maybe it was just us but they didn't take our credit card - "we'll just need that at the end", they said. We were booked on the executive floors - from 18th to 26th, I think - since they were the only ones available with just 20 hours before check-in. For that, we paid a bit more than standard - appr $250 per weekend night and $225 for weekday night. But for that, we got a very high floor - 24th - with a fantastic Tokyo skyline view (floor to ceiling glass window), including a very peaceful vantage of the Zojoji Temple adjoining the property and the Tokyo Tower nearby. The view alone was worth the price. And the hotel room had a balcony which was great for occasionally going out at night to just check in the city lights and cool air. Part of the package was the autumn meal plan, which was a bit beyond the usual free breakfast. What it did was allow us to take breakfast at any of five outlets, or alternatively, take lunch in the coffee shop, or use the coupons for gym - very new equipment and free trainers, or for bowling - yes, they had a great 8-lane alley in basement 2! So if you felt you had already overeaten or had a lunch outside, you could use it to bowl or work out. That system was so flexible. The hotel itself is so impressive. the bank of elevators dedicated to the executive rooms - 4 of them - were so classy - lighted glass, dark wood, steel, chrome, with glass-and-wood doors. And the whole elevator foyer was similarly stunning. They had their own bakery cum convenience store cum gift shop. They also had a Hallmark type store plus drug store. My wife was looking for vitamin C tablets and I needed some back pain relief and we both found what we were looking for. The hotel also had several specialty designer (foreign brands) shops in a sort of short "high street". The coffee shop in the basement was well-designed, with a skylight that showered natural light on a basement location. The sky lounge on the 33rd was similarly impressive because of the wall-to-ceiling glass that provided unobstructed views. But what was unique - although this didn't apply to our situation - was that the hotel seemed to be geared for weddings and honeymoons. Half of a basement floor was dedicated to wedding banquet halls. They had shops for bridal gowns, wedding-honeymoon photos, wedding planners, pre-wedding grooming, flowers, a Wako Dept Store wedding gifts section, etc. There was even an outdoor chapel just above the wedding halls and an escalator from there to the wedding basement. Unbelievable!On our floor itself, the carpets, lighting, and room doors were all very tastefully done and designed. The rooms were decently sized - I believe about 40 sq meters or just a bit less. The bathrooms were large, with jacuzzi (my wife loved it!) and stalled shower. The toilet seat was usual "smart" Japanese - with heating, deodorizer, flush volume control, etc. They were way over the top with amenities, including giving my wife an obviously-expensive Shisheido pack (of course, they only did that once for the entire stay. As you would expect, there were a lot of lighting controls bedside. There was white reading light on the end of a flexible neck that you would only find in the business class of a plane. Curtains were by push button. But the aircon controls didn't seem to respond too well, when we wanted to lower the temperature from the auto 24-25 degrees to something cooler. We weren't sure if that was the design or there was a flaw. The pillows were too thick and a bit on the hard side. But you could ask for a replacement - my wife changed hers for one of those molded ortho ones, free of charge. I had a problem with the two lounge chairs in the room - they were obviously leather and expensive but they weren't too ergonomic. We also had a minor issue with the room safe. Unlike other safes, you had to key in the number every time you locked. So there was a danger that you weren't paying too great an attention when you closed up again and you might have punched in a wrong number. Which was what happened to us on the 4th day. But housekeeping was very quick to respond and reset the safe - they were in the room a minute after we called. Wired internet access was free - nice. But no wireless. But - they were thoughtful enough to provide an ethernet cable! What thoughtfulness. And the best touch - a flat panel Sony LCD TV! It looked like a 42 incher. But - the satellite channels only gave you CNN Japan, BBC, and Fox - and half of its programs were in Japanese. There was also a sports program which had the occasional MLB and Euro football if it wasn't doing the Japanese baseball. You could also do HD TV but they were all Japanese programs.The concierge were very helpful - and spoke good English - but the Hata tours and the Grey line tours were often fully booked. My sense was they had very limited capacity - so make sure you book your tours way in advance. The hotel itself is in the Shiba Park, which is probably green in spring and summer but it was turning brown in late September. Still, the park is a nice place to spend a hour or so since they have many park benches and they have short hill climbs. The Shojoji temple is just nearby and very conveniently gives you a feel for the Buddhist architecture and influence. You don't really have to go to the far-off Asakusa Sendoji temple which is in the itinerary of all the tours. In the same block as the hotel is the the Shiba-koen subway station. I's one of the few stations that gives away an English version of the subway system map - make sure you get one. The downside is that it doesn't overlap with any other line so chances are, unless you're going to the Imperial Palace, you'll need to make transfers. When you're booking a hotel, make sure your hotel is on the list of the airport bus and the tour buses for pick-up and drop-off - fortunately, Prince Park Tower is on those lists. For those who are scared of learning the subway system, the hotel is sort of close enough that you can walk - long though, on average 30-40 minutes brisk walk - to the pier area (for a river cruise or to see the Hama Detached Garden), to the Imperial Palace area, to Roppongi, and to Ginza. All in all, I was very impressed with the Prince Park Tower - especially at the price point - and will certainly have no second thoughts about booking there again if I needed to be in that general South Central Tokyo area.

I stayed here the first few days of a vacation to Asia - wanted a place that was very comfortable and a peaceful retreat in case of jet-lag. I was very impressed by this property and would wholeheartedly recommend it.The location has pluses and minuses - the hotel is in the middle of a very pretty park, so it is not particularly close to anything, but it is a healthy (15-20 minute) walk to Ginza or Roppongi, and a $10-12 cab ride. It is on the airport "limousine" bus route but is the next-to-last stop, so the ride takes approx. 1 hour. It is very close to the Oedo and Asakusa subway lines, so if you can navigate the subways, it is incredibly convenient. Because it is the highest building in the immediate area, the views are incredible, and it feels very quiet and restful.I got a fabulous rate online with one of the expedia/travelocity type sites but still joined the Prince Club - didn't get breakfast included in the rate, but they did give me a nicer room than I had reserved - ended up north-facing, on the 14th floor with a small balcony and a spectacular view of Tokyo Tower and the Zozoji temple.The hotel and the room were quite impressive - the hotel is still fairly new and is in pristine shape. The room was much larger than I had expected it to be - a very good-sized room by NY standards - and well furnished, with a comfortable bed and nice linens. The bathroom was done in grey marble and had a separate shower enclosure and whirlpool tub. The toiletries even included bathsalts for the tub!The bar upstairs had a spectacular view - the drink wasn't very good and was ridiculously overpriced (~$25, with table charge) - but was still worth it for the view. The sushi restaurant downstairs was not cheap, but it was quite good. The main gift shop downstairs had very reasonably priced pastries and small bites, and made for a wonderful snack/breakfast stop.The service at the hotel was truly superb - the check-in and out was quick and easy, and the money exchange desk staff were very good. The concierge was superb - she came up with excellent recommendations for trendy yakitori in Roppongi and wonderful Kaiseki in Ginza, and printed out maps of each restaurant to give to cab drivers or to navigate myself. The bell staff was extremely good at giving maps and directions to cab drivers.Bottom line - I would have been very satisfied if I had paid $350/night to stay here. At less than $200 a night (or even $250 a night), it is an extraordinary bargain, and I couldn't have been any happier.

Just returned from a thoroughly enjoyable stay at the Tokyo Prince Hotel Park Tower. We had a great room on the 15th floor with fabulous views of the Tokyo Tower and the surrounding city. Our room was well appointed, immaculately maintained, and extremely comfortable. As members of the Prince Club, we enjoyed the tasty complimentary breakfasts served at the Brise Verte Restaurant and at the bountiful buffet restaurant. Both of these restaurants are located on the 33rd floor and offer spectacular views. We relaxed and enjoyed the evening skylight views and the complimentary evening cocktails and appetizers served at the Club Lounge on the 27th floor.  The customer service offered by all levels of the the hotel staff was excellent. They were extremely attentive and went out of their way to assist us. The Tokyo Tower and the Zooiji Temple are within a few minutes walk from the hotel.. A complimentary shuttle to and from the Hamamatsucho Station is available for all guests..  We would definitely stay at this hotel again when we return to Tokyo and heartily recommend it to others who are planning a visit .

Fantastic hotel with value price for 5 star property. Joined the Prince Club International to get special discount rate and free buffet breakfast for two. Wife and her family members thought the hotel was fantastic as well. Had the Superior Twin room (365 sq feet) with huge marble bathtub. Quite large room. Very tranquil surrounding as located within park (Tokyo Tower is located in the park) but very close to Roppongi. Taking a cab to Roppongi was very easy and also 5 minute walk to subway station. Hotel is basically brand new and loved the design. Room was about US$250 per night with breakfast buffet for two. And you can eat the buffet on top floor of building with nice views of Tokyo. Will stay at this hotel again.

Where too start....The hotel covers that big an area that i managed too get lost several times looking for my room.The staff are freindly but at times seem unwilling to speak English, not a must for them, but i had been assured that they would all be trained in English.The hotel has plenty to do in house. The aquarium is great value for money, the cinema shows English films, the bowling was fun.Everything about the hotel is great. I heard that the breakfast was expensive, but i did not have this myself, so cant comment on this.Railway line just outside the hotel is very handy.

This modern new hotel is situated in a park. It's away from the frenetic bustle of the city. It's neighbor is the Tokyo Tower, 10 min. walk. There is a large temple 2 min. thru the park. The roomand bath are very large with high def. TV. About 5 min. from the nearest subway system, which by the way is the most efficient and CLEAN. The hotel provides a shuttle to the JR train station on the hour. The hotel was built in '05. There are about 5 resturants in the hotel,, but pricey like NYC. No shops or eating places nearby only disadvantage.

I visit Tokyo often, and have variously used The Palace, The Renaissance (terrible), New Otani, The Tokyu Capital etc. This is my first visit to the Tokyo Prince Park Tower. Wow, it is superb - better than all the above.Nice 'sit down' check-in, higher security than I've seen in most hotels eg, my swipe card limits me to my floor alone, plus public floors. It takes me through three separate electronically controlled doors between the lobby and my bed!The room is lovely. Good size for Tokyo, with nice touches such as plasma tv, electric curtains, robe I can almost walk into (plenty of space to store my big suitcase inside). The black marble bathroom includes a separate big shower (I really don't like shower over baths) as well as bath. Huge array of Ella Bache lotions etc.Like most Japanese hotel chains, Prince Hotels offer 'club lounges' to guests. Always free, it is just necessary to sign up, just once for each chain. Access is available irrespective of room rate etc, unlike the American chains that provide club lounges if you pay a premium rate, on the 'executive floor'. Minutes ago I finished breakfast at a very nice lounge. Fabulous view from the 27th floor, with juice / cereal / toasts / bakery / fruits etc provided. No hot food as is the norm in these lounges. And only 3 other guests.... I had earlier walked past the queue of guests waiting for a table at a main restaurant, where it costs big bucks for breakfast - and I'm a light eater. The Prince also include free evening cocktails. And in the case of this visit, the Prince upgraded me to what is one of the nicest king sized rooms I've ever had anywhere. It is on a special meeting conference rate, but is still amazing value for 23,000 yen per night, tax and internet included, when the free club lounge then provides the evening drinks and breakfast too.

This hotel is one of the most impressive I've ever stayed in. The hotel lobby and indeed the very fancy bathrooms are solid marble.The "open to the roof " lobby with its glass elevator is spectacular, as is the view to the floor below with its pond and all the restaurants(14 of them). The rooms are large even by American standards, and some even look out at the Tokyo Tower. The bar at the top of the hotel is classy and elegant. As far as the bathrooms go, the toilet has its own little room opposite the bathroom, which has a separate shower and tub. Included amenities are lovely. Every up to date electrical trick is in this hotel, lights that automatically brighten at the approach of a guest, lighting controls for the room next to the bed, etc. Beds are fairly hard, but the down pillows and duvets are great. A word of caution: Book a package that includes the $35 breakfast, which is excellent.Do not confuse this hotel with the Prince Park Hotel. It's shabby next to this brand new hotel.

This was my best hotel experience so far, and I've stayed at the K Palace in Paris. From the reception area to the room itself, the place was immaculate, beautiful and very well run. I was upgraded on arrival to an Executive room (2103) for about $268(USD)/nite, which has a panoramic view of the Tokyo Tower and the large park spreading below that is breathtaking, day or night. Bed was excellent, bathroom large with whirlpool tub. Mirror was heated on one side so no matter how steamy you could use it. The only faults I found were that the bathroom should have an exhaust fan and speaker for the TV/radio. This hotel is fortunate in having wide open space around it that many (prestigious) hotels do not. Service was impeccable and there is a plethora of dining choices, even a small Mini-mart off the Lobby that has a bakery, selling wine, beer, munchies, sundries and gifts. Buy your cold coffee in cans there, because few places in Japan serve a decent cup. Quite handy. But see if you can get a deal that includes breakfast, because at $37(USD), its a bit steep if you're one of the granola & fruit herd.Given what I saw of other hotels arguably closer to the action, the tradeoff is to the Tower's advantage. Walk to the Tokyo Tower, go by the Temples in your next door park or hop the subway/grab a cab. This will be my Tokyo Headquarters.

From the outside this hotel looks like a 70's building although it only opened in April 2005. However, inside is a different story. You are met with a view up the inside of the hollow tower from the bottom to the top (30 floors I think), which is amazing. I definitely recommend going to the sky bar at the top for a drink at night as it overlooks the TV tower which is lit up at night. We were staying in an executive room on the 26th floor which had the most amazing views over Tokyo, especially at night. The room itself was large with the usual amenities you would expect. The bathroom was the real treat - with a heated toilet seat, marble sink and jacuzzi bath. The only down side is that the immediate vicinity of the hotel is not very central. However, there are two metro stations within a few minutes walks and these will take you anywhere in the city. I would definitely stay at this hotel again.
